webTitle: English footballers should move abroad to complete their education

fields.headline: English footballers should move abroad to complete their education
fields.trailText: The major problem that afflicts English football is not that we import too much but that we barely export anything at all.
fields.body:
A couple of seasons ago a Dublin-born Republic of Ireland international was asked for his thoughts on how his Premiership club should go about strengthening their squad during the close season. "Well, for starters" he replied, without apparent irony, "we don't want any foreign bastards."

It is possible, of course, that the player was unaware of partition or that he wanted his club to buy exclusively from the League of Ireland. It is more likely that he was using the word "foreigner" in its accepted English football sense, that is to say "somebody who doesn't come from the British Isles".

This semantic quirk may explain why the Uefa chief executive Gerhard Aigner's remarks on the need for urgent action to limit the influx of foreign players has been seized on in some quarters with a kind of unrestrained glee normally encountered in football only when a player has to change his shorts on the pitch.

Doubtless buoyed by having organised a new transfer system that calls to mind Lord Palmerston's words on the Schleswig-Holstein Question, "Only three men ever understood it fully and one of them has since gone mad", an excited Aigner told the Observer: "If we have three English teams in the Uefa Cup, they should be three English teams rather than an international select team."

I am not sure this is quite the good news for our game some people appear to think it is. Uefa's interpretation of what foreign means is different from that of most British people. As far as Uefa is concerned, Great Britain does not exist; it is four separate football nations. When Aigner says English, I'm sure he means English.

We have seen the effect this interpretation has on our clubs before. When, in the 1990s, the rules of European competitions limited the number of foreign players a side could field, nobody in English football seemed too pleased about it.

Indeed, many of the same people who are now quick to support the Uefa chief executive's comments moaned then that it was unfair to English teams because Ryan Giggs, Mark Hughes, Brian McClair, Denis Irwin and Roy Keane were foreign only technically speaking.

The fact is that the most successful English club sides have rarely been exclusively or even predominantly staffed by Englishmen. When Liverpool beat Roma in the 1984 European Cup final, for example, seven of the starting line-up and both the substitutes they used played football for countries other than England. Did Liverpool fans think that this was, in Aigner's words, "against the spirit in sport"? I doubt it.

Likewise, while in England nowadays the complaint is that the number of foreign players in the Premiership is weakening the national team, I do not recall anyone in the 1970s muttering that Leeds United's great midfield of Billy Bremner, John Giles, Peter Lorimer and Eddie Gray was causing selection headaches for Sir Alf Ramsey. To Uefa it may seem plain that three Scots and an Irishman were keeping a quartet of plucky English lads from learning their trade as surely as two Frenchmen, a Dane and a Swede, but sometimes tradition overrides logic.

The major problem that afflicts English football is not that we import too much but that we barely export anything at all. No other country that aspires to anything like top-class status has so few of its nationals plying their trade abroad as we do.

A check through the estimable European Football Yearbook shows that last season in the top divisions across the continent, England was represented by three players in Belgium, three in Finland, a couple in the Netherlands, a trio in Malta, one each in Sweden and Israel and the enterprising duo of Chris Knight and Joseph Paris in the Faroe Islands. And then, of course, there was Steve McManaman.

Compared to us even those other traditional stop-at-homes, the Spanish, look like an Australian with an Inter-rail card. If our national balance of payments deficit mirrored that of football, Gordon Brown would have locked himself in his office with a revolver long ago.

Instead of hoping that Gerhard Aigner will stop overseas players coming in to England, we should be petitioning him to get English players to move abroad. Zinedine Zidane, who should know about such things, has said that Serie A is the best schooling a player can have. Surely it is time more of our footballers benefited from such an education?

webTitle: Attack on referee may be final straw for Hagi

fields.headline: Attack on referee may be final straw for Hagi
fields.trailText: The Romanian midfielder faces a seven-month ban after spitting and stamping on an official.
fields.body:
Gheorghe Hagi may have ended his career after attacking the referee during Galatasaray's 2-1 win over Genclerbirligi in the Turkish league at the weekend.

After seeing Erol Ersoy disallow a goal by Hasan Sas, the 35-year-old Romanian midfielder spat at the official and stamped on his feet before being dragged away by teammates.

Hagi then added insult to injury, saying: "The ref's a thief. He came to steal three points from us but couldn't. He does this all the time. The federation want Fenerbahce to win the league." Galatasaray, the Uefa Cup holders and Turkish champions, are eight points behind their Istanbul rivals.

The offences, which could lead to a seven-month ban, were scarcely mitigated by Hagi's apology. "I apologise, I lost myself," he said. "But this referee provokes us. He's always a problem for us. He's trying to send Hagi off to prove he's a big referee. If you ask me, he's no referee, just a guy who wears black."

The FA yesterday backed Fifa's call for full-time referees as they announced plans to find shirt sponsors for officials.

Professionalism has previously been rejected as too expensive but a spokesman said: "We believe that the sponsorship market in England is big enough to support sponsoring referees. This would be an obvious way of paying for the cost of having referees on salaries."

The Spanish FA has already sealed a £3m sponsorship package and the rest of Europe is likely to follow suit.

Sheffield United are considering legal action against Andy Johnson after the Nottingham Forest player's challenge on Saturday left Georges Santos with a fractured eye-socket. "Another quarter-of-an-inch and he's blinded," said their manager Neil Warnock. "That's why this can't be allowed to happen." Johnson denied blame and said: "If anything, their boy was late on me."

Wimbledon are to sign the Stockport County winger Kevin Cooper for £800,000 as a replacement for Marcus Gayle, now at Rangers.

webTitle: North London semi-final to be staged at Old Trafford

fields.headline: North London semi-final to be staged at Old Trafford
fields.trailText: An early-morning 200-mile trip awaits fans of Arsenal and Spurs.
fields.body:
Up to 60,000 Arsenal and Tottenham fans must endure an early-morning 200-mile trip to watch their teams' FA Cup semi-final after the Football Association yesterday decided that the venue for this north London encounter will be Old Trafford in Manchester.

Both clubs and their supporters have reluctantly accepted this as the best option to ensure as many fans as possible can see the match, which will kick-off at 1.30 on Sunday April 8. Each club is expected to receive between 25-30,000 tickets.

The other semi-final between Liverpool and Wycombe will take place at Villa Park at 4pm on the same day. Fears in Liverpool that they would be forced to play at Hillsborough were unfounded. The FA never entertained the idea.

The FA decided on Old Trafford, capacity 68,936, for the other tie because with Wembley due for demolition and Twickenham ruled out because of local opposition no other London ground was big enough to satisfy the demand for tickets.

There will be obvious fears about confrontations between rival fans at motorway services en route. But the prospect would have been greater in the confines of London's road and Tube system. There was also the chance of congestion in the capital as so many fans headed along similiar routes to the game.

Chief inspector Tony Deacon, responsible for the Metropolitan police's public order section, said: "We have had extensive talks with the FA. There were very limited options, and we are more than happy with the outcome."

According to the FA's executive director David Davies: "Even by recent standards, deciding on the venues for these matches was extremely difficult. Preliminary discussions took place even before the quarter-finals.

"Ultimately, with the backing of police forces in several parts of the country, supporters' groups and the clubs, we have reached a conclusion that will give as many fans as possible a chance to see these games."

Both clubs accepted the decision. Arsenal described it as "the best compromise under the circumstances" while Tottenham's vice-chairman David Buchler said: "We recognise the inconvenience for travelling supporters, but the choice ensures as many fans as possible see what should be a terrific game."

Barry Baker, secretary of the Arsenal Supporters' Club, said: "We feel the bigger the stadium, the better, so we have no problem."

Bernie Kingsley of the Tottenham Independent Supporters' Association added: "It's not ideal and we will probably have to set out about six in the morning to get there but they had to go for the biggest ground."

Meanwhile, the FA have decided that in future the semi-final draw will be made only when all four sixth-round ties have been played.

The Spurs manager George Graham had criticised the decision to make Sunday's draw before his team's tie with West Ham had finished. "It was awful, wasn't it? It takes away the dignity of the competition," he said.

webTitle: England play host at court of St James'

fields.headline: England play host at court of St James'
fields.trailText: England's coach Sven-Goran Eriksson was so impressed by the atmosphere at Newcastle's 52,000-seat stadium that the club will host their first England international in 63 years when Albania visit on September 5.
fields.body:
The task of giving England's World Cup qualifying campaign a lift will be entrusted to the fanatical fans of the north-east on the September 5, when the match against Albania will be played at St James' Park.

Apparently England's coach Sven-Goran Eriksson was so impressed by the atmosphere at Newcastle's 52,000-seat stadium that the club will now host their fifth ever England game, but the first since a 4-0 win over Norway 63 years ago.

The Albania game comes only five days after the fixture with Germany in Munich, and England's qualification hopes may well be in the balance. Newcastle's chairman Freddy Shepherd said: "If we're fighting for points in the last games they'll certainly get the Newcastle folk behind them, I'll tell you that. The Geordies aren't slow coming forward and they'll get right behind the England team."

It was this which registered with Eriksson. "He's been here a couple of times and I think he was just amazed by the stadium and by the strength of the support and noise that's generated," said the Football Association's director of marketing Paul Barber

It was also the ground's capacity which attracted the FA. Newcastle have spent around £70m to develop the stadium into the second biggest in the Premiership, after Old Trafford. Around 5,000 tickets will be specifically reserved for local schoolchildren and priced at £11 - half the lowest adult admission price.

Adam Crozier is keen to revive the Scotland-England fixture and discussed the idea with his Scottish FA counterpart David Taylor at last weekend's meeting of Fifa's International Board in Edinburgh.

Crozier, a Scot and also the Football Association's chief executive, admits that the chances of resurrecting a tournament involving the four home countries are slim but remains optimistic about the chances of reviving the world's oldest international fixture, with the teams facing each other every two years.

"Both sides are looking at it positively, but the congested fixture calendar is a problem," Crozier said. "There is a will to revive the fixture but it's a question of logistics."

Scotland and England first met in 1872, a 0-0 draw in Glasgow, and the match became an annual event until 1989 when persistent crowd trouble led to the respective FAs deciding to call time on it.

The Wales manager Mark Hughes has named Cardiff's Andy Legg, 34, who last played for his country three years ago, and Nottingham Forest's Christian Edwards, who has one cap but has not figured since moving from Swansea two years ago, in his squad for this month's World Cup qualifiers with Armenia and Ukraine four days later.

Huddersfield's full-back Steve Jenkins joins them along with Robbie Savage. Although the Leicester midfielder is banned for the match in Yerevan on March 24 he can play when Ukraine visit Cardiff four days later.

Wales squad: Jones (Soton), Freestone (Swansea), Crossley (N Forest), Ward (N County), Delaney (A Villa), Jenkins (Huddersfield), Barnard (Barnsley), Roberts (Tranmere), Edwards (N Forest), Legg (Cardiff), Melville, Symons (both Fulham), Page (Watford), Robinson (Charlton), Johnson (N Forest), Jones, Savage (both Leicester), Pembridge (Everton), Robinson (Wolves), Speed (Newcastle), Saunders (Bradford), Roberts (Norwich), Bellamy, Hartson (both Coventry), Blake (Blackburn), Giggs (Man Utd).

webTitle: Four-match ban for Cup hero Brown

fields.headline: Four-match ban for Cup hero Brown
fields.trailText: The Wycombe midfielder will take his punishment "on the chin" and look forward to the prospect of the club's historic semi-final against Liverpool.
fields.body:
Despite a huge wave of sympathy, Wycombe's Steve Brown will take his punishment "on the chin" after yesterday receiving a four-match ban for being sent off in Saturday's famous FA Cup win over Leicester.

He was shown a second yellow card for unveiling a vest bearing the name of his sick 15-month-old son when Second Division Wycombe scored a late winner. He left the pitch in tears. The good news for him, though, is that he will be available for the club's historic semi-final against Liverpool.

The FA have applied the letter of the law in dealing with the midfielder. Saturday's red card brought an automatic one-match ban, but as he had already been sent off this season that was extended to two. Brown's first yellow card at Leicester also took him up to 10 cautions, which means a further two-match ban.

"I don't want this to overshadow what we achieved in the match," Brown said yesterday. "The referee made a decison and he's got to live by it. It's there in the referees' handbook that it's a mandatory yellow card so I'll just take it on the chin, serve my suspension and look forward to the semi-final."

The FA are awaiting the referee's report before deciding what action to take against the Wycombe manager Lawrie Sanchez who was sent from the dug-out for protesting after he felt his side should have been awarded a penalty.

Leicester's goalscorer on Saturday, Muzzy Izzet, will be out for at least a month with a torn calf muscle, but a scan on Robbie Savage's knee, damaged in the same game, has revealed only bruising. Preston have completed the signing of the Leicester striker Richard Cresswell on a month's loan.

Only the formality of agreement by the Football League stands between Hull City and financial security after Adam Pearson resigned from his job as commercial director of Leeds United to reveal himself as the club's saviour.

Under a deal agreed yesterday with the club's administrators Pearson will become the sole owner of the club, which came within hours of a winding-up order in February.

"I am committed to turning this club around and making it a success," Pearson said. "I want to give the people of Hull something to be proud of. The immediate task is to stop the club haemorrhaging money, but there will be limited funds made available to the manager for new players."

Pearson has promised that the players, who have not received their wages for two months, will be paid in full.

fields.headline: The long and winding road
fields.standfirst: Sam spends much of his first full week in Africa in transit, and has plenty to say on the subject of border crossings, customs inspections, donkey-cart taxi services and sharing a sleeper compartment with a man in need of relationship counselling
fields.trailText: Week 14, Johannesburg to Victoria Falls Sam spends much of his first full week in Africa in transit, and has plenty to say on the subject of border crossings, customs inspections, donkey-cart taxi services and sharing a sleeper compartment with a man in need of relationship counselling
fields.body:
Pulling into the Zimbabwe border-crossing at Beitbridge, I realised that I was in for a long wait. It was chaos. In a wasteland of rubble and half-built buildings, there were people everywhere. Cars and trucks lined the side of the road, loaded down with goods of every description. It was more like a municipal rubbish tip than a border control.

This was the first leg of my African adventure. My plan is to travel up through Zimbabwe, briefly transit Mozambique and then cross into Malawi, where I'll spend four weeks with my girlfriend (hooray!). Then I have two choices - either continue with my original plan and go up through Tanzania, Kenya and fly home from Nairobi, or come back to Victoria Falls and pick up an overland tour through Botswana, Namibia and down to Cape Town. I'm leaning more and more towards this southern route, but I'll wait until I get to Malawi before I decide.

The journey up from Johannesburg to the border was relatively comfortable. I was on an air conditioned bus and they played videos (actually they only played one video - twice, and at full volume).

My fellow passengers were all Zimbabweans returning from work or visiting relatives in South Africa. Having got through immigration, we had to haul all our bags off the bus for inspection by customs. The officials are pretty keen to catch locals trying to smuggle in South African goods without paying the duty. I couldn't see any likely looking smugglers amongst our little group but there was a palpable air of nervousness as we waited with our belongings. This was catching and even I began to feel worried. We did seem to have a lot of gear between us. Numerous huge, woven plastic laundry bags full of blankets and second hand clothes sat on the ground.

After about an hour, an official swaggered over, made the most cursory of checks (he completely ignored my bag) and waved us through. We all got back on the bus with big smiles and sighs of relief. I almost felt like clapping as we crossed the border.

14 hours after we'd started out I arrived in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second largest city. I spent a few days there and liked it a lot. I wandered down the big wide streets and stopped for lunch in noisy, greasy-spoon cafes. I visited the local arts and crafts centre and watched the students carving new pieces. There was also a small gallery of established work in an old colonial building which was very interesting. I stayed just south of the centre at a lovely place called the Travellers' Guesthouse. It was empty except for me. In fact, I've seen very few tourists - the current poltical uncertainties seem to be keeping them away. While this is quite refreshing for me, it's a disaster for the local economy.

Leaving Bulawayo, I caught the overnight train to Victoria Falls. I had booked a sleeper compartment which I shared with a pleasant young Zimbabwean called Muny. Muny was very chatty, telling me about his job (he repaired electronic scales), his girlfriend problems (he had two), and his deep longing to buy a motorcycle. Finally, with the night slipping by and a thunderstorm building on the horizon, we clambered up into our narrow bunks and went to sleep.

I remember waking in the early hours to sound of cowbells and children calling to each other. I peeked out the window and in the moonlight I saw we had stopped at a station on the edge of the jungle. Dark shapes were moving along the horizon. The local boys were runinng a taxi service to the nearby town using donkey-carts to whisk their passengers away. I went back to sleep as the train continued its excruciatingly slow progress.

webTitle: New probe into links between flying and deep-vein thrombosis

fields.headline: New probe into links between flying and deep-vein thrombosis
fields.trailText: A further study of the effects of flying on passengers' health was announced today by the government. The results of the study, which will include a look at the deep vein thrombosis (DVT) phenomenon which can afflict passengers stuck in cramped seats for long periods, are expected this summer.
fields.body:
A further study of the effects of flying on passengers' health was announced today by the government. The results of the study, which will include a look at the deep vein thrombosis (DVT) phenomenon which can afflict passengers stuck in cramped seats for long periods, are expected this summer.

The risk of air-travel related DVT and the quality of air on board aircraft have been identified as the key areas to be examined, but consideration will also be given to the transmission of infection, cosmic radiation and the effects of jetlag and work patterns. "Although a good deal of research has already been done, the purpose of this study will be to evaluate what we already know about DVT, air quality and other issues, and to help us decide what in-depth research to support later this year," said Bob Ainsworth, minister for aviation. "It is essential that we have all the information in front of us before making crucial decisions on large scale, government-sponsored research programmes. We must ensure that research concentrates on the right areas and does not duplicate existing work."

This latest study will be co-funded by the transport and health departments, with support from the Civil Aviation Authority and the health and safety executive. It follows on from a first-stage study, which identified the main aviation health issues and the main stakeholders with an interest in aviation health.

The new study will identify where specific research on the risk of DVT posed by air travel would be best targeted, and suggest appropriate methods for carrying this out.

fields.headline: Fulham set to sign Goma
fields.trailText: Fulham have agreed a club record £4million transfer fee for Newcastle's French international central defender Alain Goma.
fields.body:
Fulham have agreed a club record £4million transfer fee for Newcastle's French international central defender Alain Goma.

Goma, 28, will moved to Craven Cottage subject to agreeing personal terms and passing a medical. His signing surpasses the £3million Fulham paid Sunderland for midfielder Lee Clark.

The move could be manager Jean Tigana's first step in a rebuilding programme as he prepares his his side for the Premiership next season.

Managing director Michael Fiddy said in a club statement: "The club is looking forward to welcoming Alain to Fulham, once he has completed a medical.

"His record has been proven at both domestic and international levels and we are sure he will become a great asset to the team for the rest of the season and for years to come.

"Alain's signing is indicative of the ambition of the football club to achieve the chairman's vision of both Premiership and European honours in the future."

Goma joined Newcastle for £4.7million in July 1999 after spending 10 years with French outfit Auxerre.

webTitle: Hugo Young: Labour is intensely neurotic

fields.headline: Time for Downing Street to use power instead of paranoia
fields.standfirst:
Labour has an impregnable majority, yet it is intensely neurotic

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is going to win the election, whenever the foot and mouth lets him hold it. When he's done that, we have to hope he runs a different kind of administration from the one we've lived under so far.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is going to win the election, whenever the foot and mouth lets him hold it. When he's done that, we have to hope he runs a different kind of administration from the one we've lived under so far. The Hammond inquiry is only the most recent piece of evidence that he needs to. What his government lacks is specific gravity. It's the most disturbing of its weaknesses. In the least vulnerable government for 20 years, it is a perverse omission. The second term should start by recognising that the commodity Mr Blair most needs is ballast that measures up to his power.

The evidence of the coming victory isn't only in the opinion polls. We see it more tellingly in the ease with which scandal, or the rumour of scandal, is reduced to hoo-hah. Sir Anthony Hammond may have decided that every minister touched by the Hinduja imbroglio deserved the benefit of the doubt. But the British people got there before him. That's the way it almost always is with intimations of impropriety. A government needs to be already rotten, or palpably at the end of its natural life, for such stories to disturb popular acquiescence in the belief that most politicians are pretty dodgy anyway. It is doubtful whether Profumo could have unhinged Macmillan, or Aitken helped destroy John Major, had the revelations occurred when these leaders were in their prime.

Labour is fortunate to be so untouchable. Hammond's forensics, although benign, still reveal a shocking mess. In a different national mood, they would have produced a conviction not an acquittal. Especially fortunate is Jack Straw, who not only mis-assessed the available evidence before he called one of his colleagues a liar, but urged his own officials to work "helpfully" on the passport request from Prakash Hinduja, and then deployed a fake grammarian's casuistry to pretend that this didn't mean his officials were meant to be helpful. Peter Mandelson's own lack of transparency would also have counted against him rather than, conveniently, in his favour.

But not a blow was struck. We shrug our shoulders. Not even the Tory press can gain much traction when their own man is plainly on the floor. Only when there's a chance of drawing blood does the pack seriously show its teeth. There have been several mini-scandals and mendacities involving Labour politicians, often aggravated by the brazen willingness of the Commons Labour-run standards committee to override the ethical adjudications of the parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, with their own partisanship: or, as has now happened with Keith Vaz, to allow an MP's persistent obstruction of her inquiry to justify a verdict of innocence, however unconvincing.

Such episodes count for nothing. The time is not ripe. Tory attempts to keep new scandal going until election day, putting Robin Cook or Wafic Said in the dock, seem desperate measures. When a huge majority is expected to remain impregnable for an other five years, some of the life goes out of the normal rules of accountability.

This systemic frailty, however, is paralleled by a worse one. While sheltering behind its unchallengeable strength, the government acts at other times from weakness. It is intensely neurotic. It has not used the institutions at its disposal in ways that befit its power. Instead it has marginalised them, as if in terror of anything that does not emanate from the tiny power-centre, 10 Downing Street, where all must be decided. It lacks, in short, ballast.

The most obviously sidelined body is the House of Commons. A deep paradox is at work there. The size of the majority turns out to be in inverse ratio to the scale of creative relevance which is permitted to it. The parliamentary majority matters less than the media minority.

The majority is seldom consulted. Instead of deploying it to overwhelm the transient passions of the press, Blairism has all too often allowed the media to dictate the final shaping of its legislative programme. There have been times when no difference was discernible between the dithering uncertainty of this government with a majority of 179, and its predecessor whose leader often had to spend the day calculating whether he would survive the vote at 10 o'clock that night.

A similar distrust for the old pillars is to be found in New Labour's attitude to the civil service, and to Whitehall's more valuable mores. The Mandelson/Hinduja affair offers a good example. A month ago, I wrote disparagingly about the role in this of Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary. I owe him an apology. I knew he had been present at the impromptu court that decided Mandelson should go, but not that his own advice, as we learn from Hammond, said there wasn't "a shred of evidence that anything improper took place". Sir Richard wasn't a spineless accomplice, as I implied.

On the other hand, he was impotent. He was cited to me as sealing, with Lord Irvine, Mandelson's fate, when in fact, apart from asking the prime minister whether he still had confidence in the minister, he didn't. If anything, he went the other way, urging Mr Blair to deflect the issue from himself. But Downing Street couldn't let that happen. The weight of the cabinet secretary's word isn't what it used to be. Blair had no time for the rules of natural justice, nor for the patience that some were counselling. He took a decision that was the acme of what's most oddly wrong with this mighty administration: panic-stricken, overwrought, hysterical about the next election.

There are other symptoms of the kind of weakness New Labour is prone to. This could be called corruption. But it is not personal corruption. There's been quite a catalogue of charges of impropriety, shading the edges of old-fashioned standards but not descending into personal venality. These men aren't on the take for themselves, though they may be for their party. More to the point is this Labour government's capacity for institutional seduction by rich men, its mesmerisation with the wealth and power of people whom all Mr Blair's predecessors as party leader, with the partial exception of Harold Wilson, regarded in essence as their enemies.

The corruption is institutional. It's a corruption of outlook more than conduct, and was born of insecurity. Apart from the attraction of the rich as party donors, there was the guarantee they could offer that Labour is no longer just a party of the poor and underprivileged but one with credibility at all levels of society. Even for a prime minister, it seems, sitting down with the Hindujas shored up his status as the friend of every mover and shaker in the land.

In the second term, there will be no dome, one assurance of better times ahead. No more supplication at the trough where public folly fed off private wealth. But Labour needs a new equilibrium. After a second victory it must no longer fawn or truckle. Its arrogance will need constant watching. But let's hope it also stops, at last, behaving as if its nervous-system will implode at any moment.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: hue and cry in the name of hunting

fields.headline: An unheard of hue and cry in the name of hunting
fields.standfirst:
Special report: parliament
Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Lord Carter, the government whip, made a tragic plea in the House of Lords for peers to keep their speeches short. There were 69 listed to speak on fox hunting. He said, pleading, that if they stuck to seven minutes each, "we might even finish on the day we started."
fields.body:
Lord Carter, the government whip, made a tragic plea in the House of Lords for peers to keep their speeches short. There were 69 listed to speak on fox hunting. He said, pleading, that if they stuck to seven minutes each, "we might even finish on the day we started."

Fat chance. After the first four speeches they were already 38 minutes late. But, as Lord McNally said, the Lords have always been terrifically excited by "badgers and buggery". He meant "badgers" to stand for animals in general, so he could have offered "stags and sodomy", or "foxes and fellatio". A treat for another day, perhaps.

Lord Bassam introduced the bill sombrely, though when he alleged "the government is neutral", the Tories erupted in a low, grumbling, thunder, rather like the pounding of 200 hooves.

In their view the bill is just a preliminary to locking up all morris dancers in concentration camps. (Not a bad idea, when you think about it.)

Lord Cope was about to speak for the Tories, but he couldn't, because Lord Longford thought it was his turn. "I have an amendment tabled," he said, angrily. Lady Jay told him to wait. He was number 58 on the list.

"Now, now!" he shouted. "I was going to move an amendment in favour of drag hunting, which everyone agrees with. I can't wait up until 2am!" Lord Ferrers uncoiled to his full height, which takes a while, and averred, "I have a horrible feeling that Lord Longford is right." So they ignored him.

Finally, the Tory front-bencher rose. His name is Lord Cope of Berkeley, and the Berkeley hunt rides near his seat. (The word "berk" is derived from this, making Lord Cope a rare example of human rhyming slang.)

Things have changed in the House of Lords. People were never so rude as now. Lord Falconer nipped off for two minutes, no doubt for a pee, and was greeted on his return by loud and ironic cheers. Lord McNally got quite furious with Lord Lawson - you may recall him as Margaret Thatcher's chancellor, though to most people he is now the father of the more famous Nigella.

The male Nige tried to interrupt. "I will not give way!" yelled McNally. "Why haven't you put your name down? If you're still here at midnight, we will be very surprised! I'm not going to play your game!"

It's not supposed to be like this in the Lords. Barking at each other is the equivalent of Mrs Bennett hurling her tea in the vicar's face. One longed for Alastair Sim to murmur, "girls, girls!" but they just don't have the language to cope with this kind of outbreak. Moments later, there was even an angry stir when McNally drank water.

Lord Burns, who wrote the Burns report on hunting, ruefully reflected on the way that his opinion - being killed by dogs "seriously prejudices the welfare of the fox" - would "pursue me for some time." He undertook to explain what he meant by this curious circumlocution, and failed. (It had something to do with the fox feeling pain as it kicked the bucket.)

Lord Longford suddenly popped up again. "I tabled an amendment!" he shouted, several times, then fell into what seemed a deep, dreamy and blameless sleep.

Baroness Castle described her own success as a countrywoman: camping and growing roses. It was a stroll down memory lane, except that memory lane has been closed due to foot and mouth.

She loathes hunting. "I couldn't do it! It makes me sick! Just to see it!" she shouted. It seemed that everyone was shouting.

Some older Labour peers could not resist a frisson at this extraordinary spectacle: Barbara Castle, of all people, denouncing the practice of blood sports.

webTitle: Brown hits at EC aid delay

fields.headline: Brown hits at EC aid delay
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday launched his second attack upon the Brussels bureaucracy in as many months accusing the European commission of dragging its feet over a crucial aid package to the regions worth £1bn.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday launched his second attack upon the Brussels bureaucracy in as many months accusing the European commission of dragging its feet over a crucial aid package to the regions worth £1bn.

Mr Brown condemned the commission for "unjustified" delays in approving his so-called venture capital funds for Britain's regions.

His comments came after meeting the commissioner in charge of the approval process, Mario Monti, to voice his concerns. "I have left him in no doubt that the delays being experienced for getting permission for the new venture capital funds are unjustified and it is very important that we get a decision on this very quickly."

But the commission yesterday rejected his accusations. "It has to be a transparent procedure," a commission spokesperson said. "We need to respect procedures, translate it into 11 languages and wait for people to comment. In this case we have done all of this extremely rapidly."

webTitle: Vaz criticised for blocking Commons watchdog

fields.headline: Vaz criticised for blocking Commons watchdog
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz yesterday became the second minister in months to be criticised by Parliament's most powerful watchdog committee for frustrating a "sleaze" inquiry into his affairs and being less than candid in answering questions.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz yesterday became the second minister in months to be criticised by Parliament's most powerful watchdog committee for frustrating a "sleaze" inquiry into his affairs and being less than candid in answering questions.

The criticism of the behaviour of the Foreign Office minister follows a damning attack from the watchdog committee on John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, who was found to have put pressure on a witness giving evidence to Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner.

Mr Vaz was largely cleared by the Commons standards and privileges committee of breaching the MPs' code of conduct or Parliament's registration procedures but the report reveals intimidation and threats by Labour party activists.

It said: "This inquiry has taken far too long. If Mr Vaz and other witnesses whom the commissioner asked for information had answered her questions fully and promptly, the commissioner would have been able to complete her report in a much shorter time."

It singles out Colin Hall, chairman of Mr Vaz's Leicester East Labour party, for particular criticism. It says his threat to put legal and disciplinary pressure on one of the witnesses, Mustapha Kamal, is "a serious contempt". Two other officers of the local party, Piara Singh Clair and John Thomas, are condemned for a "consistently unhelpful attitude ... intended to frustrate the commissioner's investigation."

Mr Vaz ended up refusing to answer any of Ms Filkin's questions and is chastised by the committee for breaking the code of conduct in not cooperating with her.

On the one charge which is upheld - the recommending of an honour for Sarosh Zaiwalla, a City lawyer, without disclosing that he was a Labour donor - Ms Filkin is particularly scathing. She accuses him of initially denying he had accepted two small donations until she had documentary proof - and then refusing to disclose the finances of his family firm, Mapesbury Communications.

Ms Filkin was also unable to complete her inquiries into eight allegations because Mr Vaz, his family and Labour party officials declined to co-operate.

On his family company, she says: "Mr Vaz could and should have been more forthcoming in answering my questions about Mapesbury Communications ... given the role of Mr Vaz's wife as director and sole shareholder, it appears beyond doubt that Mr Vaz had direct access to the relevant information."

Mr Vaz yesterday condemned the 13-month inquiry: "Whilst I fully support the need to ensure that MPs maintain the highest possible standards of probity, the present procedures give too much latitude to the purveyors of lies and malice," he said.

His lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, said: "I don't think it is right to say he did not cooperate. In some cases, he did not answer questions fully because he wasn't told clearly what the allegations were."

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, called on Mr Vaz to resign: "The minister for Europe has become Mr Stonewall. Frankly, he is quite unfit to represent Britain. A Foreign Office minister, of all people, must have total integrity or his word would not be trusted."

Downing Street and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, backed Mr Vaz. Mr Cook said: "I am very pleased for him. I hope he can now be allowed to get back to doing the job that he does very well."

webTitle: Call for relaxation of rollover prize rules

fields.headline: Call for relaxation of rollover prize rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The ban on rollover prizes in bingo should be lifted to help the National Lottery's rivals fight back against declining income and popularity, a committee of MPs said yesterday.
fields.body:
The ban on rollover prizes in bingo should be lifted to help the National Lottery's rivals fight back against declining income and popularity, a committee of MPs said yesterday.

In a sharply worded report, the MPs recognised the "positive aspects of bingo clubs" as social centres and called for a relaxation of rules governing private lotteries, football pools - where 5,000 jobs have been lost - and other forms of gambling hit by the £5bn a year success of the National Lottery.

They also condemned all sides in the battle over the lottery franchise and urged the government to break the lottery up among different organisations to prevent it becoming "a perpetual private monopoly". Nor should the BBC be allowed to broadcast all lottery draws in future, it said. However, the committeee praised Lord Burns, the former permanent secretary at the Treasury, who was brought in to run the beleaguered lottery commission last year after Dame Helena Shovelton resigned amid a welter of criticism. "We do not consider the commission to have had the relevant skills or expertise prior to the appointment of Lord Burns. The government was fortunate that someone of his quality was available," said the committee, chaired by Labour's Gerald Kaufman.

The MPs also noted the change of tone adopted by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, between August 2000 when he praised the exclusion of Camelot, the current franchise holders, and December when, after legal action, they were restored to the bidding alongside the People's Lottery consortium, led by Sir Richard Branson.

The committee urged ministers to consider "the financial and cost implications of a not-for-profit operator" like the People's Lottery so that clear guidance can be in place next time the franchise is open to bids, in 2008.

webTitle: Cut back Campbell's powers, urge MPs

fields.headline: Cut back Campbell's powers, urge MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, should be stripped of his unprecedented power to issue orders to civil servants, a committee of MPs will recommend today.
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, should be stripped of his unprecedented power to issue orders to civil servants, a committee of MPs will recommend today.

In a hard hitting report into the role of ministerial special advisers, the cross-party public administration committee will say that handing over such powers to Mr Campbell has upset relations within government.

The report will be published after the former premier, John Major, who is standing down at the next election, launched a stinging attack on the government for fostering a "miserable political climate of spin". In his farewell speech to MPs last night, he said: "I hope we will be able to end the miserable political climate of spin and counter-spin that has grown up here in recent years."

His remarks showed what a highly controversial figure Mr Campbell has become since Tony Blair passed a special order after the last election which allowed his press secretary to issue orders to civil servants. Similar powers were handed to Jonathan Powell, the prime minister's chief of staff.

Special advisers, who technically become civil servants, are subject to strict rules, and until the prime minister's special order in 1997, were never allowed to issue orders to career civil servants.

The public administration committee today says that Mr Campbell and Mr Powell should no longer exercise their powers after the election.

Tony Wright, Labour chairman of the Commons committee, raised fears that Mr Campbell and Mr Powell were influencing the promotion of civil servants.

Downing Street will dismiss the committee's findings because the prime minister is determined to use Mr Campbell and Mr Powell to tighten his grip across the whole of Whitehall. However, the report will provide powerful ammunition for the Tories who complain that Labour has vastly in creased the number of special advisers as it attempts to politicise the civil service.

The report points out that Mr Blair has appointed 27 special advisers to work in Downing Street out of a total staff of 149, a massive increase on the six who served Mr Major. The MPs conclude that seven special advisers, who work in Downing Street's press office and its strategic communications department, should be appointed through open competition.

Mr Major demonstrated the unease felt among MPs across the House at the role played by Labour's special advisers when he lambasted the behaviour of spinners.

"We need to separate fact from fiction, substance from soundbite, information from innuendo; the public, the electorate, the people who sent us here deserve more than to be spoon fed a cocktail of headline grabbing feelgood stories," he said. "They deserve the truth; every member of this House, whether backbencher or minister, has the obligation, the duty, to provide it."

webTitle: Tory peers rage at hunt bill move

fields.headline: Tory peers rage at hunt bill move
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was accused yesterday of breaking parliamentary convention after the government reneged on a commitment to allow peers to vote on the hunting bill in the same way as MPs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was accused yesterday of breaking parliamentary convention after the government reneged on a commitment to allow peers to vote on the hunting bill in the same way as MPs.

Tories reacted furiously after ministers announced that peers will be asked later this month to vote on whether to impose an outright ban before being given the chance to vote on other options to regulate the sport.

The government's move, which appeared to be a mere technicality, angered Tory peers, who detected a ministerial plot to force them into a premature confrontation with the Commons.

MPs voted overwhelmingly in favour of a ban on fox hunting last month after rejecting the two other options in the "multiple choice" bill - self- regulation and a licensing system. The government had indicated that peers would vote on the three options in the hunting bill in the same way as MPs, with the ban vote coming last. But when peers vote on the bill on March 26, they will be asked to vote first on whether to impose a ban, an option they will reject.

Tory sources in the Lords said they suspected the government wanted to provoke the Lords into a confrontation with MPs so that Labour could go into the election claiming that "toffs in the Lords" had refused to accept the will of the elected chamber.

Lord Strathclyde, Tory leader in the Lords, said: "The government is trying to strong-arm parliament for Labour's private political purposes. The government is attempting to bounce the Lords into a vote with the minimum possible notice."

Lady Jay, Labour leader in the Lords, dismissed the Tory claims as "nonsense".

The row came as peers debated the hunting bill for the first time last night.

webTitle: Doubts over Maff's handling of Foot and Mouth epidemic

fields.headline: Doubts over Maff's handling of epidemic
fields.standfirst:
Nick Brown defends policy of closing down the countryside to prevent the spread of disease

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Nick Brown defends policy of closing down the countryside to prevent the spread of disease.
fields.body:
The government was last night under growing pressure on two fronts to reassess its strategy for dealing with the foot and mouth epidemic as the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, insisted that the disease was under at least a degree of control.

With backbench MPs voicing concern about the ability of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food to cope with the crisis, a former government vet who helped to deal with the last outbreak in 1967 called for a radical reappraisal of tactics.

Ken Tyrell said that the stockpile of 41,000 carcasses awaiting incineration could be spreading airborne infection and called for ministers urgently to consider burial as a better alternative - although the National Farmers' Union said the revised policy of sending animals to a rendering plant at Widnes was a far safer option.

At the same time, a former chief economist at the National Farmers' Union argued that the government might soon have to consider reopening tracts of the countryside to prevent a collapse of the rural economy. Sean Ricard, now a university lecturer, said ministers were in danger of overplaying an outbreak which in reality was directly affecting only a tiny sector of the British economy.

But while the prime minister met the chief vet, Jim Scudamore, to assess the crisis as the number of cases approached 200 and with little sign of the epidemic peaking, Mr Brown insisted: "We have got it curtailed. Our problem is that we can't predict where the disease, which is already incubating, is going to emerge, nor do we know how much of it that there is."

He defended the policy of effectively closing down the countryside, to prevent the spread of the disease, on the grounds that it was halting the movement of animals "that carry the infectivity and are most vulnerable to it".

But Mr Tyrell, 35 years with Maff, led a growing chorus of experts and MPs questioning ministry tactics, arguing that dead animals left outside for days were still covered with the foot and mouth virus, despite being disinfected. "Why aren't we burying?" he asked. "It is the fastest, quickest, most expedient and cheapest way of getting rid of them - put them underground where they can't do any more damage."

Asked on BBC radio whether the government should opt for a different approach, such as mass vaccination of animals, he added: "I would certainly hope the ministry has ... dusted down its vaccination plans. But that is a major undertaking because there aren't the staff to do it."

Some backbench MPs, including those supportive of Mr Brown, believe the crisis has been mishandled because of staff shortages at Maff. There has been a sharp cut in the number of ministry vets over the past 10 years, forcing the government to import over 200 vets from as far away as New Zealand.

Peter Atkinson, MP for Hexham, whose constituency includes Heddon on the Wall, where the outbreak almost certainly began, said last night that an element of panic was now afflicting Maff, with a monitoring system weighed down by bureaucracy.

Maff has not been helped in the run-up to the outbreak by scores of sheep being transported around the country without proper records. This has made tracing some animals almost impossible.

Ben Gill, president of the NFU, said: "We do know that the movement restrictions have curtailed any potential contagion around the country, but we still do not know at this stage where exactly the sheep that were moved from the infected markets went."

While the NFU is careful not to criticise Maff - Mr Gill meets the agriculture secretary most days - its former chief economist argued that the outbreak, while painful for farmers whose livestock was being destroyed, was far from a national emergency. Mr Ricard recalled that in 1967 up to 80 cases a day, involving high value cattle, were being reported. Now a majority of the infected animals were sheep.

"The highest number of daily cases so far this time was 25 on Sunday and we really ought to keep this in perspective and realise we really are talking about a very small fraction of our economy," he said.

fields.headline: A disappointment
fields.standfirst:
Mr Vaz is (mostly) innocent

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: For the second time in four days, Keith Vaz was treated to a warm bath of relief yesterday.
fields.body:
For the second time in four days, Keith Vaz was treated to a warm bath of relief yesterday. On Friday he was acquitted by Sir Anthony Hammond of having an "improper" connection with the Hinduja brothers. Yesterday the House of Commons committee on standards and privileges gave him a second reprieve, clearing him of nine separate allegations, ranging from hustling for cash to that old favourite: failure to declare financial links with businessmen.

He was found guilty on only one count, omitting to mention that a lawyer he had nominated for the honours' list had earlier given £450 towards his constituency activities. On this, the committee's punishment was clear: nothing. It suggested taking no action. That left eight more claims of wrongdoing. On these the committee withheld its judgment: it could not rule because Mr Vaz had refused to give them the information they needed.

What does this episode, and the current rash of allegations of deceit and general dodginess against Labour, tell us? First, it confirms a way of doing business that, if not illegal or even "improper," feels not quite right. The Commons committee did not feel sufficiently troubled by Mr Vaz's help in seeking an honour for a gen erous contact to do anything about it. But our guess is that most Britons will feel disappointed by it. They will have seen confirmed, albeit in a minor way, what they always suspected: that money talks - even to a Labour government.

Of course, much richer evidence of that truth came in the Hammond report. Officially it exonerated everyone: no one acted improperly, everything was above board. But reading it in full is an education in the way of the world. The Hindujas' application for passports was put on a fast track - nudged along by the Cabinet's most senior ministers and the civil service's top ranking bureaucrats.

Sir Anthony pretends that that was totally normal practice - when the rest of us can see the real reason as plain as day. The Hindujas got special treatment because they are rich. Forget the lip service about the universal right for equal treatment under the law. What this affair has proved beyond doubt is that some are more equal than others. It suggests another thought, too. If the many inquiries and investigations conducted by civil servants and parliament always find this pattern - and always declare it perfectly proper - then perhaps our definition of "proper" needs to change.

On this, the committee's punishment was clear: nothing. It suggested taking no action. That left eight more claims of wrongdoing. On these the committee withheld its judgment: it could not rule because Mr Vaz had refused to give them the information they needed. What does this episode, and the current rash of allegations of deceit and general dodginess against Labour, tell us? First, it confirms a way of doing business that, if not illegal or even "improper," feels not quite right. The Commons committee did not feel sufficiently troubled by Mr Vaz's help in seeking an honour for a gen erous contact to do anything about it. But our guess is that most Britons will feel disappointed by it. They will have seen confirmed, albeit in a minor way, what they always suspected: that money talks - even to a Labour government. Of course, much richer evidence of that truth came in the Hammond report. Officially it exonerated everyone: no one acted improperly, everything was above board. But reading it in full is an education in the way of the world. The Hindujas' application for passports was put on a fast track - nudged along by the Cabinet's most senior ministers and the civil service's top ranking bureaucrats. Sir Anthony pretends that that was totally normal practice - when the rest of us can see the real reason as plain as day. The Hindujas got special treatment because they are rich. Forget the lip service about the universal right for equal treatment under the law. What this affair has proved beyond doubt is that some are more equal than others. It suggests another thought, too. If the many inquiries and investigations conducted by civil servants and parliament always find this pattern - and always declare it perfectly proper - then perhaps our definition of "proper" needs to change. webTitle: Leader: the Act of Settlement sucks

fields.headline: Bowing to the inevitable
fields.standfirst:
It's official: the Act of Settlement sucks

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Our announcement last December that we would mount a legal challenge to the Act of Settlement of 1701 caused near paroxysm in some circles.
fields.body:
Our announcement last December that we would mount a legal challenge to the Act of Settlement of 1701 caused near paroxysm in some circles. Long-faced columnists queued up in the more monarchically-inclined papers to defend the rather outdated law which bars from the royal succession all those who are not the legitimately conceived Protestant heirs of Queen Sophia of Hanover. "What we read in the Guardian yesterday," intoned one, "we may one day read in the very last Queen's Speech."

But away from the quaint pages of the Daily Telegraph there was a more reasonable acceptance that this was an issue deserving of serious attention. In Scotland, for instance, it is a subject which unites rightwing Tories and fervent nationalists. The Scottish assembly voted unanimously (but fruitlessly) to ask for the act to be rescinded. Courtiers quietly admit that Buckingham Palace does not seek to defend the act. Prince Charles is happier to talk of defending faiths than defending one particular faith.

Now another significant voice has been added to those who wish to see the Act of Settlement abolished - that of the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn. In an interview - by pleasing irony, in the Telegraph itself - Lord Williams conceded that the act was discriminatory and argued that it should be amended. As a member of the Church in Wales, which was disestablished in the 1920s, he is not at all alarmed by the prospect that the repeal of the Act of Settlement could lead to the uncoupling from the state of the Church of England.

Lord Williams's calm acceptance of the inevitable is welcome. Now all he has to do is repeal the equally objectionable Treason Felony Act of 1848, another archaic law which makes it a crime to call for the abolition of the monarchy, even by peaceful means. If the monarchy is to survive it must do so without a barrage of silly laws propping it up.

webTitle: Leader: the farm crisis is not out of control

fields.headline: From bad to worse
fields.standfirst:
But the farm crisis is not out of control - yet

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Suddenly things are only getting worse - considerably worse for farmers. This time last week the foot and mouth outbreak was still being reported as less serious than the 1967 epidemic; this week it looks worse.
fields.body:
Suddenly things are only getting worse - considerably worse for farmers.

This time last week the foot and mouth outbreak was still being reported as less serious than the 1967 epidemic; this week it looks worse. Last week all sides were agreed that it was still under control; this week farmers are disputing the ministry's assertions. In the first three weeks of the outbreak, 155,000 animals have already been earmarked for slaughter; in the eight months of the 1967 outbreak, only 433,000 were slaughtered. And yesterday the possibility of slaughtering 500,000 sheep currently being kept in lowland winter quarters was raised, rather than risk spreading the disease by taking them back to their hill farms.

Things are getting worse for ministers, too. Last week they were still earning high marks for the way they were handling the disease; this week the headlines have turned. First came complaints from the non farming rural community, like the hotel and tourist industry which is suffering even bigger losses than farmers without any compensation so far. Then came yesterday's splash headline in the Telegraph - Foot and mouth 'is spinning out of control' - with equally negative stories in other papers following accusations by an Irish minister that Britain had mishandled the outbreak. What happens if food shortages return? What happens if schools have to be closed because of the outbreak? Then there is the spectre of 1,000 schools being disrupted by the current dispute over teacher shortages. Suddenly, May 3 does not look like quite such a certain date.

Downing Street's response yesterday was to give an even clearer unofficial steer that May 3 was the selected election date. They do not want to be budged, particularly if things look as though they can only get worse. They will have been encouraged by an ICM poll for the BBC showing 63% of those questioned believed the election should go ahead on that day no matter what the status of the foot and mouth outbreak - with even 58% of Tory supporters agreeing.

The calmest voice in the political maelstrom belongs to Jim Scudamore, the government's chief vet. He knows it is serious. He acknowledges it has spread further and faster than first envisaged. There was far more movement and mixing of animals than officials had estimated at the start of the outbreak. But what they are doing now is right. Quarantine restrictions have been extremely strict but necessary. Ministers have not been totally inflexible: they were right to relax the rules to allow farmers to gather sheep that were ready to lamb.

Slaughter has been right too - as farmers, slaughter houses and the opposition concede - but the delays in disposing of the carcasses has been unfortunate. What the public has failed to understand is that although there were more cases in 1967, the outbreaks this time have involved far more animals as farms have got bigger. Some flocks have numbered over 1,000 animals. These delays are now being tackled. The fleet of trucks now taking carcasses for rendering have been extensively tested and found safe. The opposition has called for the army to be called in. Surely it is better to use experienced contractors, of which there are many thanks to BSE, rather than inexperienced personnel?

It is too early to say the ministry has lost control. All currently identified cases can still be traced back to the first outbreak. Once the outbreak is over, there are several modern farming issues to be resolved. But the chief vet - and ministers - are right to remain cool and continue with their present strategy.

fields.headline: Softly, softly
fields.standfirst:
Britain should stop hounding Mugabe and look for an African solution that lets him leave gracefully

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Britain should stop hounding Mugabe and look for an African solution that lets him leave gracefully.
fields.body:
The shadow foreign secretary's weekend description of Zimbabwe's ruler, Robert Mugabe, as a "thug and a murderer" might not be inaccurate but it is certainly unhelpful.

Francis Maude, who called for Zimbabwe to be expelled from the Commonwealth, was merely following the increasingly combative British line that began with Peter Hain's appointment as foreign office minister responsible for Africa. While Mr Hain must be congratulating himself for being among the first to highlight the extent of Mugabe's misrule, he must also be wondering whether his approach was the best one.

For Zimbabwe's decline has dramatically escalated: the economy is in freefall; the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) is in tatters; white farmers are still being dispossessed; the judiciary and the press are under attack and Mugabe continues his pillage of the Democratic Republic of Congo, enriching his immediate circle at vast expense to the country as a whole. Like Saddam Hussein, that other tyrant with whom the west got tough, Mugabe appears as entrenched as ever.

The departure of Hain from the Foreign Office might be a good opportunity for Britain to reconsider its policy towards Zimbabwe. It clearly has not worked, and looking at it from an African perspective might explain why.

These British politicians fail to take into account how deeply patriarchal Zimbabwe is. Male pride and status is all and public criticism from a former colonial master is profoundly humiliating for Mugabe. His automatic response is to salvage his wounded pride with macho defiance. Thabo Mbeki of South Africa understands this, which is why he confined his efforts to behind-the-scenes persuasion.

Yet that has not been effective either, perhaps because of another very African trait: respect for age, particularly among the aged. Mbeki is much younger than Mugabe and less experienced, so the latter might consider advice from him impertinent.

But it is, nevertheless, an African solution which might now have the best chance of success. African elder statesmen of Mugabe's generation, like Presidents Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria and Sam Nujoma of Namibia and ex-president Quett Masire of Botswana, could be pressed into service to persuade Mugabe to stand down before the presidential elections, due within the next 14 months.

To prepare a graceful exit for him, a very public focus on his past, as opposed to his present, would be necessary: his role in the liberation of Zimbabwe and his early, more successful, days in the presidency recalled and honoured. Perhaps a financial retirement package could be proffered. Mugabe must be coaxed out because he clearly cannot be hounded out.

His successor ought to be another candidate from Zanu-PF, rather than the rival MDC's Morgan Tsvangarai. There are younger, reform-minded people within Zanu's ranks who could erase Mugabe's legacy and at the same time build on Zanu's experience.

The MDC - a young and fragile coalition of very disparate interests including white farmers trade unions and urban intellectuals - might rule in favour of the farmers and multinationals, neglecting the majority peasant population. Their western support is tinged with commercial interests.

One ardent backer is the Zimbabwe Democracy Trust, whose patrons include Maude's predecessors, Malcolm Rifkind, Geoffrey Howe and Douglas Hurd. Another is John Collins, chairman of National Power, Britain's largest energy company, which won a contract in 1998 to build a power station in Zimbabwe. South Africa is urged to pull the plug on Zimbabwe's electricity - it is its biggest supplier - but fears that if it does, other players will step into the breach. Chester Crocker, another ZDT sponsor, is a director of Ashanti Goldfields, which owns Zimbabwe's biggest gold mine.

Mugabe benefits from British hypocrisy, given that the Hawks he uses in his rape of the DRC fly with new British parts. But Britain is crucial to a satisfactory outcome: it must start a dialogue with Zimbabwe. It could also stump up some serious cash to buy off the white farmers. Mugabe exploited dissatisfaction over land in a cynical and corrupt way but its redistribution is necessary for the stability of Zimbabwe. Still essentially an agrarian society, land monopolised by whites needs to be more evenly distributed among land-hungry subsistence farmers. Land reclaimed must be paid for and its new owners given the seeds and tools to farm it productively.

If Zimbabwe went down the tubes, it would be deeply upsetting for Britain, with its emotional and historical ties, and some pockets would be hit. But for South Africa, it would be a disaster. Penniless black refugees would flood in from the north; the whites would probably end up in Cape Town, swelling the ranks of disaffected whites. Above all, foreign investors who, in a rather racist way, lump African countries together - who would write off France if Germany imploded? - would desert South Africa as well.

For everyone's sake, we must get this right.

fields.headline: Minister 'delighted' by Commons verdict
fields.standfirst:
Standards committee and watchdog reject most complaints but point out that lack of cooperation hampered their investigations

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office minister, Keith Vaz, was yesterday criticised by the Commons standards committee for failing to cooperate fully with an inquiry which largely cleared him of not disclosing his business dealings to parliament.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office minister, Keith Vaz, was yesterday criticised by the Commons standards committee for failing to cooperate fully with an inquiry which largely cleared him of not disclosing his business dealings to parliament.

The Leicester East MP was found to have broken the MPs' code of conduct by not declaring a small financial interest with a City lawyer when he recommended him for a political honour. No action will be taken against him for this breach of rules.

Mr Vaz also broke Commons rules by failing to disclose a Leicester property in the MPs' register. But the committee decided to allow Mr Vaz to register it without incurring any penalty or criticism.

Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards and the Commons standards and privileges committee, rejected nine complaints that Mr Vaz failed to disclose cash donations of thousands of pounds to his office and charities which he supported. Eight other complaints could not be properly investigated by Ms Filkin after witnesses and Mr Vaz refused to cooperate or answer any other questions by the commissioner about them.

The standards committee ignored advice from Ms Filkin to demand the production of more documentary evidence or insist witnesses appear and give evidence to MPs on oath. Instead the committee decided that it could not uphold the complaints.

The committee found that Mr Vaz broke the MPs' code of conduct by not revealing his dealings with Sarosh Zaiwalla when he recommended the lawyer for an honour in 1997. The lawyer had made a £250 donation to the minister's constituency office and paid £250 for an advert on a calendar "associated with Mr Vaz", the committee report said. It added that Mr Vaz did not want to disclose the recommendation for an honour because it broke the confidentiality rules surrounding the honours system.

The MPs and the commissioner threw out a string of complaints about other donations, including an allegedly undeclared £10,000 donation from the Sikh community to his 1997 election campaign; £3,000 in donations from Mr Zaiwalla to his office; and making misleading entries in the MPs' register of interests.

Other inquiries that could not be completed reveal a picture of claim and counter-claim inside Leicester East Labour party. Colin Hall, the constituency chairman, apologised after threatening one of the witnesses with disciplinary and legal action for talking to Ms Filkin.

Another allegation that was never fully investigated said Mr Vaz solicited and received payments from a Leicester businessman, Jaffer Kapasi, in return for help in obtaining building sites and planning permission to construct religious buildings and a mosque.

Mr Kapasi, a deputy lieutenant of Leicestershire, told journalists that Mr Vaz had received payments from him. But in evidence on oath before the committee later, he retracted the allegations, claiming he had been put under pressure by journalists. The committee found his retraction "unconvincing", saying: "We find it difficult to believe that a man in Mr Kapasi's position would make a series of detailed statements alleging highly discreditable behaviour on the part of a member of parliament, knowing them to be completely fictitious, in the hope that journalists would then leave him alone."

The committee did not uphold a complaint that Mr Vaz had used a company of which his wife and his mother were directors to fund his parliamentary office, without disclosing the source of income.

But it also found that officers of the Labour party in Mr Vaz's Leicester East constituency had shown a "consistently unhelpful attitude" towards Ms Filkin in a bid to "frustrate the commissioner's investigation".

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: hue and cry in the name of hunting

fields.headline: An unheard of hue and cry in the name of hunting
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: March 13: Simon Hoggart on the hunting debate in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Lord Carter, the government whip, made a tragic plea in the House of Lords for peers to keep their speeches short. There were 69 listed to speak on fox hunting. He said, pleading, that if they stuck to seven minutes each, "we might even finish on the day we started."

Fat chance. After the first four speeches they were already 38 minutes late. But, as Lord McNally said, the Lords have always been terrifically excited by "badgers and buggery". He meant "badgers" to stand for animals in general, so he could have offered "stags and sodomy", or "foxes and fellatio". A treat for another day, perhaps.

Lord Bassam introduced the bill sombrely, though when he alleged "the government is neutral", the Tories erupted in a low, grumbling, thunder, rather like the pounding of 200 hooves.

In their view the bill is just a preliminary to locking up all morris dancers in concentration camps. (Not a bad idea, when you think about it.)

Lord Cope was about to speak for the Tories, but he couldn't, because Lord Longford thought it was his turn. "I have an amendment tabled," he said, angrily. Lady Jay told him to wait. He was number 58 on the list.

"Now, now!" he shouted. "I was going to move an amendment in favour of drag hunting, which everyone agrees with. I can't wait up until 2am!" Lord Ferrers uncoiled to his full height, which takes a while, and averred, "I have a horrible feeling that Lord Longford is right." So they ignored him.

Finally, the Tory front-bencher rose. His name is Lord Cope of Berkeley, and the Berkeley hunt rides near his seat. (The word "berk" is derived from this, making Lord Cope a rare example of human rhyming slang.)

Things have changed in the House of Lords. People were never so rude as now. Lord Falconer nipped off for two minutes, no doubt for a pee, and was greeted on his return by loud and ironic cheers. Lord McNally got quite furious with Lord Lawson - you may recall him as Margaret Thatcher's chancellor, though to most people he is now the father of the more famous Nigella.

The male Nige tried to interrupt. "I will not give way!" yelled McNally. "Why haven't you put your name down? If you're still here at midnight, we will be very surprised! I'm not going to play your game!"

It's not supposed to be like this in the Lords. Barking at each other is the equivalent of Mrs Bennett hurling her tea in the vicar's face. One longed for Alastair Sim to murmur, "girls, girls!" but they just don't have the language to cope with this kind of outbreak. Moments later, there was even an angry stir when McNally drank water.

Lord Burns, who wrote the Burns report on hunting, ruefully reflected on the way that his opinion - being killed by dogs "seriously prejudices the welfare of the fox" - would "pursue me for some time." He undertook to explain what he meant by this curious circumlocution, and failed. (It had something to do with the fox feeling pain as it kicked the bucket.)

Lord Longford suddenly popped up again. "I tabled an amendment!" he shouted, several times, then fell into what seemed a deep, dreamy and blameless sleep.

She loathes hunting. "I couldn't do it! It makes me sick! Just to see it!" she shouted. It seemed that everyone was shouting.

Some older Labour peers could not resist a frisson at this extraordinary spectacle: Barbara Castle, of all people, denouncing the practice of blood sports.

webTitle: Straw plan to give up extradition role

fields.headline: Straw plan to give up extradition role
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Home secretaries will no longer be involved in deciding whether fugitives should be sent back to other European countries after Jack Straw's bruising role in the Pinochet extradition case, the Home Office announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Home secretaries will no longer be involved in deciding whether fugitives should be sent back to other European countries after Jack Straw's bruising role in the Pinochet extradition case, the Home Office announced yesterday.

Mr Straw's proposals to reform Britain's 19th century extradition laws also include the introduction of a fast track system to other European Union states based on "Eurowarrants", without a British court issuing a separate warrant for the return of a criminal fugitive to face charges in Britain. Police would have new powers of detention of a fugitive on the basis of a notification through Schengen information system, the common EU police database.

The pressure to reform the extradition laws followed the outcry of the complexity and length of time it took to resolve the request from Spain for the extradition of General Augusto Pinochet to face torture charges. The endless appeals to the high court and to the House of Lords meant the process took nearly two years.

Reform would require a new extradition law approved by parliament. Most of the extradition requests Britain makes abroad involve the return of serious criminals on the run, such as the road rage killer Kenneth Noye, and many involve Spain. The new extradition procedures would also apply in Irish-British cases which in the past have been fraught with difficulties.

"No one should be able to escape justice simply by crossing a national border. The Extradition Act is now over 10 years old with some of its provisions dating back to previous centuries. We are still using 19th century mechanisms to fight 21st century crime. The proposals announced today seek to remove, where possible, delays in our present system," said Mr Straw.

The extradition proposals, which Britain intends to adopt unilaterally, would see the home secretary withdrawing from any role in deciding cases involving other EU countries. Mr Straw faced accusations of political bias from all sides when he was supposed to set aside his Labour politician's hat and act only in a neutral "quasi-judicial role" in the Pinochet case.

Requests from other EU countries are also to be streamlined so that they are decided by a single hearing before a circuit judge with only one appeal allowed to the high court rather than the repeated applications for judicial review which were heard in the Pinochet case. Appeals to the House of Lords will only be taken on points of law.

In cases involving requests for extradition from outside the EU, Whitehall civil servants will take over the role of the home secretary at the beginning of the process but he will keep his final discretion in cases which have political implications or where the fugitive may face the death penalty if they are sent back.
