webTitle: NHS cash lures for GPs and nurses

fields.headline: NHS cash lures for GPs and nurses
fields.trailText: A golden handcuff scheme to keep GPs working until 65 and more generous bursaries to attract student nurses will be announced by the government today to address the staffing crisis in the NHS.
fields.body:
A golden handcuff scheme to keep GPs working until 65 and more generous bursaries to attract student nurses will be announced by the government today to address the staffing crisis in the NHS.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will promise to spend £56m each year on a range of incentives to ensure that the NHS expansion plan is not derailed by labour shortages.

Newly qualified GPs will get £5,000 golden hellos to work in "under doctored" areas in England where there are less than 52 GPs per 100,000 patients.

There will be a £10,000 loyalty bonus for GPs who soldier on from 60 to 65 to deter premature retirement. They will be allowed to invest a nest egg in an ISA or other security to mature on their 65th birthday. Pro rata payments will be offered for those who undertake the task but have to drop out early through ill health.

Student nurses, midwives and therapists will get a 10.4% increase in bursaries currently worth £4,085 for those on diploma courses. There will be a 24% rise in the £1,900 grant for nursing degree students.

The money will come from the pot worth £835m over three years offered by the chancellor last week for the health service in England. Over the next three years, £56m a year will be spent recruiting and retaining staff to end the chronic shortages of doctors, nurses and midwives.

It follows warnings from doctors' and nurses' leaders that government plans to appoint 20,000 extra nurses and 10,000 more GPs by 2004 will fail unless more is done to retain existing staff and provide incentives for newcomers.

webTitle: Analysis: the Budget and the environment

fields.headline: Drive on
fields.standfirst:
The Budget gave some ground to motorists and hauliers with cuts in car tax and fuel duty. The environment did less well

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The Budget gave some ground to motorists and hauliers with cuts in car tax and fuel duty. The environment did less well.
fields.body:
As far as the environment went, the Budget sent messages of varying hue. Motorists, including hauliers, benefited from a £1.7bn package. Middle and higher income households gained most from the cuts in fuel duty, while low-income households, especially rural ones, gained more from the extension of the £55 cut in road tax (vehicle excise duty) to cars up to 1,549cc.

The reason for the distribution of impacts is that richer households consume more fuel but road tax is a flat payment and car ownership is higher in rural areas. The chart shows some of these effects.

As for the environment: cuts in fuel duty will result in more traffic and more pollution, in particular more of the carbon dioxide emissions that are the main cause of climate change. The cut in road tax is likely to have a negligible environmental impact, making car ownership slightly more affordable but encouraging the ownership of smaller, less gas-guzzling cars.

As David Begg, chair of the commission for integrated transport, noted on this page last week, one of the factors behind the very small increase in road traffic last year was the hike in petrol prices. In defence of cutting fuel duty, the government would argue that oil price rises have ensured that the price of petrol is now about the same as it would have been if Gordon Brown had not stepped off the fuel duty escalator in November 1999. The logic of this position is that if and when oil prices come down again, the chancellor should put his foot back on.

If the chancellor's cuts in diesel and petrol duty are at best environmentally dubious, a lower rate of duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol (ULSP) than on conventional unleaded petrol is more soundly based. There will be a 3p per litre differential when the temporary cut in duty on unleaded petrol is undone in mid-June, after independent retailers have had a chance to secure supplies of ULSP.

Cars using ULSP emit fewer nitrogen oxides and other pollutants that contribute to poor air quality and can exacerbate cardiovascular illnesses. ULSP is also needed for direct fuel injection engine technology, which burns fuel more efficiently and produces less carbon dioxide than conventional combustion.

The Budget also cut the rates of duty on compressed natural gas (CNG) and liquified petroleum gas (LPG) to maintain the differential between these cleaner fuels and petrol and diesel, and promised not to increase them before 2004. However, for buses the effect is negated by the 80% rebate on diesel duty that bus operators now receive, worth £330m last year. The Budget offered no extra for the programme run by the Energy Saving Trust that provides grants to help purchase clean fuel vehicles, including electric and hybrid vehicles as well as those running on CNG or LPG.

In the November pre-Budget report, Brown launched the "green fuels challenge" to promote the long-term development and use of alternative fuels, such as hydrogen and others produced from renewable sources. From next year, Biodiesel produced from vegetable oils will have a duty rate 20p per litre lower than that on ultra-low sulphur diesel produced from fossil fuels. Pilot projects for hydrogen, methanol, bioethanol and biogas will also be supported with further duty reductions or exemptions.

The halving of road tax rates for lorries will harm the environment by making road haulage less expensive in comparison with rail and ensuring that it pays less of its environmental and social costs of pollution, noise and road wear. It is unlikely to do much to reduce competition from overseas. There is no domestic competition from foreign hauliers, since more than 99.9% of deliveries made from and to places within the UK are by UK hauliers.

More defensible is the announcement on how some of the £100m haulage modernisation fund will be spent. Some £30m is for fitting older lorries operating in areas of poor air quality with emissions reduction devices, such as particulate traps. Another £15m is for advice on saving fuel. From December 2001, the new lower road tax rates for lorries will be rationalised into seven bands according to size and emissions standards. The government is also consulting on the introduction of a "Britdisc" charged on both foreign and UK lorries.

The Budget introduced modest measures to promote green commuting and business travel, such as cycling, works buses and car sharing subsidised by employers. These include an increase in the tax-free mileage rate for cycling to 20p per mile and the introduction of a new tax-free car passenger rate of 5p per mile from April next year. However, the government is sending mixed messages on business car mileage by levelling the authorised mileage rates for all cars to 40p per mile and 25p per mile above a set distance in the tax year but increasing the threshold from 4,000 to 10,000 miles.

Overall, the government might be excused for its concessions to motorists in the face of the protests last year and in an election year. Though its actions could have been more socially progressive and more environmentally sustainable it has managed to do some good as well as some harm. It has yet to grasp the full magnitude of the climate change impacts of road transport, which accounts for nearly a quarter of the UK's carbon dioxide emissions.

 Tony Grayling is at the Institute for Public Policy Research

webTitle: Cooperation vital for successful scrutiny of health service

fields.headline: Cooperation vital for successful scrutiny of health service
fields.standfirst: For local councillors to be able to effectively scrutinise health services, they must ensure the climate is one of mutal trust and understanding, writes Steve Bullock
fields.trailText: Comment: For local councillors to be able to effectively scrutinise health services, they must ensure the climate is one of mutal trust and understanding, writes Steve Bullock.
fields.body:
A few weeks ago I witnessed a group of NHS chief executives being grilled by councillors. The tension rose as the councillors, prompted by their advisers, got close to the "killer" question which would expose the frailty of the chief executives' arguments for closing a district general hospital and moving all the services miles away.

The question never came and for some reason the councillors turned their attention to the council leader who had been watching with amusement from the sidelines up to that point. Then the organisers announced that time had run out and we all departed to hear the health secretary, Alan Milburn, tell us about the value of modern matrons.

This was only a simulation, but it was one that brought together a wide range of people who will be involved in making the scrutiny of the NHS by local councillors a reality in the months ahead.

In a few hours squeezed in among the hectic programme of Labour's spring conference in Glasgow, we could do little more than scrape the surface of the issue. Some interesting lessons emerged, nonetheless.

To be effective, the process needs to be a collaborative one where mutual trust and understanding can develop. There is a fine balance to be struck between aggressive questioning and being polite to the point where no information of value is gleaned from the process.

It is never comfortable to face questioning about the decisions you have made or to be asked to explain poor performance. But well-informed, challenging questioning has the capacity to expose the flaws in what we have done or propose to do, which can in turn lead to real improvements.

NHS colleagues should be reassured by the fact that those councillors and officials responsible for the delivery of council social care services will face the same process and, where appropriate, will be sitting alongside their NHS counterparts during scrutiny sessions.

Local authorities are undergoing radical change and the significance of separating executive and scrutiny roles is not yet widely understood, but as the Local Government Act 2000 begins to bite we will see the emergence of a new cadre of local councillors who develop real investigative skills.

Not that councillors should act in isolation. They will want to make sure that there is both input from health service users and access to independent expert advice. The advent of a patient-centred health service is long overdue and the NHS plan has brought it centre stage.

The organisations which will succeed in the future will be the ones that are open about their failures as well as their successes and also have the ability to engage in genuine dialogue with those who use their services.

Local councillors, NHS managers and non-executive directors as well as clinicians may find that by working together they can win the confidence of communities as we try to build a health service for the 21st century.

 Steve Bullock has been a community health council chief officer, and is currently chairman of Lewisham hospital NHS trust board.

webTitle: Parkinson's miracle cure turns into a catastrophe

fields.headline: Parkinson's miracle cure turns into a catastrophe
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Hopes of an early cure for Parkinson's disease by the implantation of foetal cells into the brain have been dashed by the devastating results of the first full trial of the technique, which found that a number of the patients were left with tragic side effects which cannot be undone.
fields.body:
Hopes of an early cure for Parkinson's disease by the implantation of foetal cells into the brain have been dashed by the devastating results of the first full trial of the technique, which found that a number of the patients were left with tragic side effects which cannot be undone.

The results of the trial will dismay Parkinson's sufferers around the world who had hoped the controversial treatment, which has been available in experimental form since the 1980s, might eventually spell an end to the crippling disease.

The American scientists who conducted the research found the therapy did not benefit patients over the age of 60 at all. Some of the younger patients did improve, but for 15% of those who received the implants, the outcome was worse than the disease.

After a year of apparently doing well, these patients began to writhe, jerk their heads uncontrollably and throw their arms about involuntarily as the foetal brain cells that were intended to produce dopamine, the chemical that is depleted in Parkinson's sufferers, went into overdrive. The cells appear to have grown too well and are producing excessive amounts of the chemical. The scientists have no way bringing the dopamine levels back down.

Paul Greene, a neurologist from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York, who was one of the researchers, said the results were "absolutely devastating" for the five patients who cannot control their movements.

"They chew constantly, their fingers go up and down, their wrists flex and distend," he told the New York Times. "It was tragic, catastrophic. And we can't selectively turn it off."

One man now has to be fed through a tube because he can no longer eat while another periodically becomes unintelligible during the day when the side effects, which in his case come and go, set in.

Dr Greene says the technique must go back to the laboratory. "No more foetal transplants," he said. "We are absolutely and adamantly convinced that this should be considered for research only. And whether it should be research in people is an open question."

The shocking results of the study are a setback for the scientists who hope that research into stem cells - the basic cells formed by the splitting of a fertilised human egg - may lead to cures for degenerative brain diseases.

While scientists cultivating stem cells will have a much clearer idea of the quality and quantity of the material they have than those using foetal tissue, the theory behind the implantation technique - to "seed" the brain and encourage regeneration - is the same.

The foetal tissue technique has not been used in the UK since an outcry over the use of aborted foetuses put a stop to such research in the 1980s. Brain cells that produce dopamine are extracted from the foetus and cultured. The tissue strands that result are implanted into the areas of the brain that are supposed to produce the chemical.

The US trial was the first to be properly controlled. Forty patients, aged from 34 to 75, were randomly assigned to receive either the foetal cells or nothing. To ensure that the results were due to the treatment and not a placebo effect, all the patients underwent surgery - four holes were drilled in the brain, whether foetal cells were put in or not.

The outcome, reported in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine, will force a rethink over the treatment.

Gerald Fischbach who was director of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke which funded the study, said that this was the first time a technique which some neurosurgeons promoted as miraculous had been thoroughly evaluated.

"Ad hoc reports of spectacular results can always occur," he said. "But if you do these studies systematically, this is the result you get."

The surgery in the study was carried out at the University of Colorado School of Medicine in Denver, while the evaluation was done in New York.

Robert Meadowcroft, director of policy and research at the Parkinson's Disease Society in the UK, said the results were disappointing but did not, in his view, spell the end of any attempt to "seed" the brain with either foetal cells or, in the future, stem cells.

"We need to learn how to switch these cells off once they have done their work," he said.

Within a couple of years, there may be trials of techniques to implant stem cells into the brains of people suffering from degenerative diseases in this country, following the decision by parliament to allow stem cell research.

Martin Edwards, chief executive of Reneuron, a UK company working on developing stem cell lines for medical treatment, said he believed the problem with using foetal cells was that nobody could be sure how much dopamine-producing tissue was being implanted.

But he said he was convinced that scientists would eventually succeed in helping patients with these distressing brain diseases. "There are some upsides. The cells have survived and a proportion of patients benefited. I interpret this with cautious optimism."

webTitle: 'Golden hellos' will not produce more GPs, says BMA

fields.headline: 'Golden hellos' will not produce more GPs, says BMA
fields.trailText: No additonal medical students will become GPs as a result of health secretary Alan Milburn's plan to offer £5,000 'golden hellos' to newly-qualified GPs if they work in deprived areas, according to the British Medical Association.
fields.body:
No additonal medical students will become GPs as a result of health secretary Alan Milburn's plan to offer £5,000 'golden hellos' to newly-qualified GPs if they work in deprived areas, according to the British Medical Association.

Mr Milburn announced this afternoon that he would spend £56m to encourage doctors to join and stay loyal to the NHS, but he might fail in his main aim, getting more GPs into surgeries particularly in deprived areas, because he is not addressing medical studentsÕ concerns.

"We welcome any admission by the government that thereÕs a problem of recruitment and retention of GPs. Although they are targeting deprived areas, there is a bigger issue for us. From our point of view thereÕs a time bomb going on, with a lot of general practitioners wanting to retire because of the stress and workload, and a lot of junior doctors being put off becoming GPs," said Michael Phillips, a BMA spokesman.

Mr Phillips admits there has been an increase in the number of medical students choosing to become GPs, according to the most recent report from a BMA study. But he argues that increase will not be enough to meet demand.

"The government claim we still need 2,000 more new GPs, the BMA say we need 10,300. Either way, these measures won't address that kind of shortfall," said Michael Phillips.

Medical students agree that the measures announced today are not enough.

"It's going to take more than a simple golden handshake to entice students into a career that's getting more intense and seen as not getting much support," said Jason Rach, the editor of the students' British Medical Journal.

According to some medical students, the problem is not just that the money announced today will not make more students become GPs, but it will not even make more new GPs work in deprived areas, its stated aim.

"I don't think it will make anyone be a GP who wouldn't have done, and of those who want to be GPs, I don't think it will make them work in the city. If they cared about the money, they wouldn't go into general practice. There is more money in hospitals and private practice. Most people becoming a GP will look for a nice area where they can raise children," said Lorne McEwan, Imperial College's medical school student union president.

However, not everyone agrees that the health secretary's plans will fall on deaf ears. The honorary chairman of the Royal College of General Practitioners, Maureen Baker believes the reason for medical students not becoming GPs lies in the medical colleges, not the career and that Alan Milburn's announcement could make a difference.

"The money is key, thank you very much. But it isn't about the money, it's the sentiment behind the money, the recognition of the value of general practice. That can put an incentive value on becoming a GP beyond the £5,000. There are many factors that push against people choosing general practice, not least of which is that doctors still get no real careers advice and medical colleges still work around medical hospital much more than surgeries."

webTitle: Cambridge 'overstates the benefits' of its expansion plans

fields.headline: Cambridge 'overstates the benefits' of its expansion plans
fields.trailText: Cambridge University has exaggerated the local benefits that will occur under a planned expansion, according to the city council.
fields.body:
Cambridge University has exaggerated the local benefits that will occur under a planned expansion, according to the city council.

A scheme announced yesterday to accommodate 5,000 new students in the north west of Cambridge over the next 25 years has met with criticism from local environmentalists and with scepticism from the cityÕs council.

When vice-chancellor Professor Sir Alec Broers announced that his university plans to grow larger than Oxford University, he made glowing predictions about the expansion's impact on the local population.

"The university has been key to the economic success of the region and makes a significant contribution to national life. We want to make sure that any new development brings benefits to everyone, whether it be realistically priced houses, more access to open spaces, or improved public transport," he said.

But according to Peter Studdert, Cambridge City councilÕs director of environment and planning, Sir Alec is overestimating the proposed development's impact: "At the moment, the council has to provide 2,800 new homes per annum in the Cambridge area. This university development over 25 years is not going to be hugely significant to that. This will only be one small part of improvements to the entire areas," said Studdert.

Going further, environmentalists argue this new development has nothing to do with the cityÕs needs and everything to do with CambridgeÕs egotism.

"The cityÕs expansion is an incredibly intricate question involving housing, waste-disposal and transport. The university is making it more difficult without realising the problem. They are concerned with their power base, their prestige and so they want to expand," said Mary Edwards, regional campaigns coordinator for the east of England for Friends of the Earth.

She does not believe university expansion to the north west of Cambridge will meet any of the cityÕs problems: "The university really thinks this will keep CambridgeÕs economic growth boiling. The idea that we need more employment here is crazy, one of the major problems is affordable housing, not just for the new residents but for people providing services for those houses. If you are going into the green belt, the only thing you should be looking at is affordable housing."

Housing prices have reached extraordinary levels in Cambridge, with a small one bedroom flat recently selling for £200,000. Friends of the Earth also believe that the universityÕs plans should be scrutinised more closely. "If a housing developer came along, there would be an almighty outcry. A lot of people here are saying, Ôlooks like the university once again gets its own wayÕ".

Peter Studdert denies that the university is being given any special treatment: "The development still has not been approved. And, a recent report by Colin Buchanan did not pick this area as somewhere it would be suitable to develop on greenbelt land. The university will have work hard to show that the questions Buchanan raised are not important."

The university feels prepared to meet its critics head-on. The head of planning and property in the university's estate management service, Lindsay Dane believes that housing provided to university staff can relieve pressure on the city's housing and that the new development can improve public transport links to Cambridge's outskirts.

"The Buchanan report is a hurdle, but they did not look at university owned land, in fact I wonder whether they assumed it would eventually pass into use," said Mr Dane.

fields.headline: Anna Rutherford
fields.standfirst: Flying the flag for post-colonial literature
fields.trailText: Ceaselessly energetic in her organisational and publishing activities, Professor Anna Rutherford, who has died aged 68, was revered in Commonwealth academic circles for her efforts to establish the study of post-colonial literature in Europe.
fields.body:
Ceaselessly energetic in her organisational and publishing activities, Professor Anna Rutherford, who has died aged 68, was revered in Commonwealth academic circles for her efforts to establish the study of post-colonial literature in Europe.

For 28 years, from 1968-96, she directed the Commonwealth Literature Centre at the University of Aarhus, Denmark, organising symposia, seminars and readings involving leading scholars and writers as varied as Wilson Harris, Sam Selvon, Timothy Mo, Buchi Emecheta, Olive Senior, Shiva Naipaul and Mordecai Richler.

She introduced African and West Indian courses and, in 1971, organised the first European conference on the Commonwealth novel, a project involving many future professors - Louis James (Kent), Paul Edwards (Edinburgh), Hena Maes-Jelinek and Victor Raniraj (Calgary) - who went on, in their own universities, to promote the research that gave the discipline of Commonwealth literature intellectual respectability.

Sonja Bahn, of Innsbruck University, called Anna the "mother of most of our generation of teachers". She was the first woman chair of the Association of Commonwealth Language and Literature Studies, which draws scholars from 300 universities, and, in the 1970s, founded the association's European branch, which became a powerful lobby for the expansion of the English literature curriculum in European academies.

Her house in Aarhus was so open to visiting Australian writers that the country's leading poet, Les Murray, called it his nation's embassy in Europe. From there, with her partner Kirsten Holst Petersen, Anna ran Kunapipi, Europe's leading post-colonial literary journal, and a small publishing house, the Dangaroo Press, which issued works by established, as well as first-time, writers.

Anna was born in Mayfield, Newcastle, which she once described as "the industrial working class city of Australia". Her father died shovelling coal on the open hearth at the local steel works. She was fiercely proud of her working class origins and Irish-Catholic roots, and her sense of being an outsider - Catholics were educationally deprived in a state system heavily weighted in favour of Protestants - meant she forged abiding friendships with similar individuals, irrespective of race or nationality.

After primary and secondary education by Dominican nuns, Anna briefly taught music - and represented New South Wales in basketball and swimming. She then studied literature as a mature student at Newcastle University.

The Canadian writer Gerry Turcotte once described her as a "combination of Muhammad Ali and a great white shark". But Anna's fierce presence disguised a gentleness and generosity which she lavished upon new writers, publishing their poetry in beautiful volumes, and often bearing the cost from her own pocket.

It was her love for the finely produced book, and her disdain for the slick commercialism of the publishing industry, that attracted writers to her small press. Every year, laden with a huge rucksack of new books, she would trudge along Charing Cross Road, calling in at various bookshops to sell a copy here and there. It did her back in, but there was something of the martyr in her. She loved books in all their stages - from the editing of manuscripts to the supervision of printing and the placement with the bookseller.

In later years, the constant struggle to access small grants to subsidise her books or conferences wore Anna down. She began to suffer from physical ailments, and then severe depression. She resigned from Aarhus and wandered the world disconsolately, ending up at Warwick University in 1998 as a visiting fellow.

Finally, she returned to a flat overlooking Nobby's Beach, Newcastle, a place of beloved childhood memories. She had been slowly recovering but died suddenly in her sleep, at a friend's house in Sydney.

Anna Rutherford, academic and publisher, born November 27 1932; died February 21 2001

fields.headline: Campus revolt challenges Yale over $40m Aids drug
fields.standfirst:
University claims its hands are tied by deal with drug firm

Special report: Aids
Guardian Unlimited Education
Yale Medicine: how d4T has boosted Yale's patent royalty income tenfold
Zerit.com
fields.trailText: Yale University is under growing pressure from its students to put conscience before profit and allow an Aids drug invented in its laboratories to be made affordable to millions of sufferers in developing countries.
fields.body:
Yale University is under growing pressure from its students to put conscience before profit and allow an Aids drug invented in its laboratories to be made affordable to millions of sufferers in developing countries.

Yale earns $40m a year in licence fees for the drug, d4T, but the university administration insists its hands are tied by an agreement signed with Bristol-Myers Squibb giving the giant pharmaceutical company exclusive manufacturing rights.

However, the university has so far refused to publish the agreement, outraging Yale students who say they do not want to be part of an institution complicit in denying essential medication to the poor.

An Indian drug producer has offered to produce d4T, an antiretroviral treatment otherwise known as stavudine or by its brand name Zerit, at a thirty-fourth of the price charged by Bristol-Myers Squibb, which would put it in range of hard-hit health systems in sub-Saharan Africa.

The case has highlighted the growing tension in US universities between their identity as icons of academic independence on one hand and wealthy "profit centres" for corporate sponsors on the other. Yale received a $250,000 donation from Bristol-Myers Squibb three years ago, and there are other close ties between research staff members and the pharmaceutical industry.

Most of the academic staff interviewed by the Guardian asked not to be quoted by name, saying the issue was too sensitive within Yale's administration. But the drug's inventor, Professor William Prusoff, now semi-retired, expressed support for a student campaign to make his discovery more affordable.

Pressure group

Some Yale law students have formed a pressure group aimed at shaming the university into taking greater responsibility for the social impact of the inventions it licenses for profit. The group, the Yale Aids Action Coalition, announced its first victory yesterday, an offer of a meeting from Yale's Office for Cooperative Research (OCR), in charge of patents.

One of the student group's founder members, Amy Kapczynski, said it was still not clear whether the OCR would relent from its earlier refusal to make available a copy of the Bristol-Myers agreement.

"We really hope they would give us a chance to look at this in a creative manner," Ms Kapczynski said. "There are probably things Yale can do to be a model actor in this situation."

The managing director of Yale OCR, Jon Soderstrom, issued a statement to say the university's hands were tied when it came to granting permission to other companies to produce d4T.

"Although Yale is indeed the patent holder, Yale has granted an exclusive licence to Bristol-Myers Squibb, under the terms of which only that entity may respond to a request," he said.

However, the students argue there is a lot more the university could do. They are backed by Prof Prusoff. Although he shares in Yale's Bristol-Myers royalties, Prof Prusoff has called on the company to make the drug affordable in poor countries.

"One of the things that should be done is that the pharmaceutical firms should reduce their prices and the industrialised nations, the US, Britain, France and Germany should give the WHO (the World Health Organisation) a certain amount of money to distribute to countries where the medication is needed."

The students have also allied themselves with the French-based medical aid agency, Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF), which is spearheading a campaign to force the pharmaceutical industry into relaxing their patent rights and allowing generic forms of Aids drugs to be marketed.

In a letter to Mr Soderstrom on Friday, MSF pointed out that in Yale's own patent policy guidelines published in 1998, the university sought to pursue "the benefit of society in general" and to draw up li cencing agreements with manufacturers to "protect against failure of the licensee to carry out effective development and marketing within a specified time period."

Toby Kasper, who runs the MSF campaign for cheaper medicines in South Africa, said yesterday: "If the university says their hands are tied, they are violating their own policy."

Mr Kasper also said the university had the right to breach the terms of its Bristol-Myers Squibb licence, allowing the production of generic versions of d4T, and pay damages to the company. Those damages, he said, would only be a small fraction of the $40m Yale makes from the patent, as sales of all drugs in the same class of antiretrovirals in South Africa only amounted to $600,000.

Ms Kapczynski said the next steps taken by the Yale Aids Action Coalition would depend on the outcome of its meeting with Mr Soderstrom at the OCR. But she added that there was a groundswell among students over the issue.

"I've been amazed at how big this issue is among students in general," she said.

A university professor, a member of a university board which oversees the granting of patents but who supports the students aims, said that if Yale had sold its freedom of action to Bristol-Myers Squibb, it had made a mistake.

"There is the question of what Yale can do now, and the question of what Yale should have done at the time, and why we shouldn't tie our hands in future," he said.

Benefits and drawbacks

The west has brought the HIV virus under control by using combinations of powerful and relatively toxic drugs, writes Sarah Boseley. The first of these invented was AZT, now a class of drugs known as nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors.

One of the big problems with this virus is that it mutates very quickly and easily if the drugs being taken are insufficient to keep the viral load low. fields.headline: Oxbridge loses corporate clout
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Britain's top bosses are more likely to be graduates of foreign universities than Oxford and Cambridge as traditional educational institutions lose their grip on corporate power.
fields.body:
Britain's top bosses are more likely to be graduates of foreign universities than Oxford and Cambridge as traditional educational institutions lose their grip on corporate power.

Almost a quarter of FTSE 100 companies are led by overseas-educated chief executives - many of whom are more familiar with the rituals of fraternity houses than punting along the river Cam.

A study by headhunting agency TMP Worldwide reveals that, from a sample of 90 blue chip bosses, Cambridge was still the top individual university, with 11 representatives, followed by Oxford with seven chief executives.

However, both were easily outnumbered by a contingent of 22 alumni from top US and European universities.

The foreign legion includes Pearson's Marjorie Scardino, who went to Baylor in Texas. Drugs group Glaxo Smith-Kline is led by Frenchman Jean-Pierre Garnier - a graduate of Louis Pasteur. Food firm Unilever's boss, Niall Fitzgerald, went to Trinity College Dublin.

Simon Rhodes of TMP Worldwide pointed to Oxford and Cambridge's lack of pedigree in developing business management courses.

"A lot of people go to university to get a general business degree. If you think about blue chip business schools, you think of places like Henley, Insead and Harvard."

webTitle: Straw attacks banks for deserting Huntington life sciences

fields.headline: Straw attacks banks that dumped protest firm
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The home secretary Jack Straw yesterday attacked the "cowardly" attitude of British banks for abandoning the research laboratory under seige from what he called "mad and bad" animal rights militants.
fields.body:
The home secretary Jack Straw yesterday attacked the "cowardly" attitude of British banks for abandoning the research laboratory under seige from what he called "mad and bad" animal rights militants.

Twenty-four hours after two women MPs confirmed they had been told by police to beware of attacks by anti-hunting campaigners, Mr Straw condemned the banks for putting profits ahead of their "wider social and business responsibilities."

He also challenged lawful animal welfare activists to stop condoning - or sheltering - extremists. "I am sometimes very concerned about the absence of a clear barrier," he said.

Both the stockbroking arm of Barclays Bank and the Royal Bank of Scotland cut their financial ties with Huntingdon Life Sciences after threats that their staff and customers might also be targeted - leaving American backers, the Stephens Group, to keep the firm afloat.

Mr Straw told MPs: "[Giving in to this kind of intimidation] undermines those who are in the frontline of this important research. They were far less likely to be personally under attack than those actually undertaking the experiments."

A group called Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, which has been protesting outside the labs in John Major's constituency for months, denies a link with attacks on staff, their homes and cars which culminated in the beating up of Brian Cass, HLS's chief executive at his front door.

Mr Straw said: "Responsibility to shareholders was no doubt the excuse in the case of the Royal Bank of Scotland or the excuse used by Barclays who sought to withdraw provision of the registrar of one of these companies on the grounds of possible intimidation or harassment. But they have wider social and business responsibilities."

Though ministers were discreetly active in helping to keep HLS in business when it met a crisis in January, they have avoided inflammatory language about opponents whose willingness to resort to violence is not universally condemned by campaigners.

Nor have most backbenchers rushed to take a stand - to the disappointment of pro-science bodies like the Research Defence Society.

Yesterday Mr Straw, one of Tony Blair's more combative ministers, took the gloves off. He condemned the "totally unacceptable" attack on Mr Cass and said that lawful animal welfare groups should be much more vigorous in condemning such incidents.

But it was the attack on big business which surprised MPs at question time. "The banks would be the first to squeal if as a result of their pusillanimous approach, part of our scientific base and therefore their financial income, was to be reduced," he argued.

Last month Barclay Stockbrokers announced it would no longer hold HLS shares on behalf of clients in Barclay nominee accounts. In January, RBS, also threatened with attacks on its branches, withdrew a £22.6m loan to HLS after threats. The Stephen Group, an Arkansas-based investment group, intially sought anonymity through the high court in London when it bought a 15.7% stake in HLS - lending it £10m and paying off £11m in debt. But its identity was discovered and Shac promised "to financially damager Stephens in Britain, Europe and America" to teach the firm a lesson.

Yesterday Mr Straw condemned extremism which involved "totally unacceptable tactics against people who are simply carrying out lawful and important duties. I have been very anxious indeed at a personal level to offer the full support of this government for the work which these people are undertaking," he explained.

webTitle: Music students introducing real life to the concert hall

fields.headline: Beyond the pail
fields.standfirst: David Ward  listens in on music students introducing real life to the concert hall - with a bang
fields.trailText: David Ward listens in on music students introducing real life to the concert hall - with a bang
fields.body:
Few student composers can secure performances by good musicians with excellent instruments. But a pioneering link between a BBC orchestra, a university music department and a conservatoire does just that. So what did Manchester postgraduate Michael Spencer pick for his first broadcast performance? Why, a bucket from a mechanical digger.

Adventurous composers have always sought out new sounds: Satie introduced a typewriter into a score, Varèse took a fancy to a factory siren and Mahler staggered in with an anvil. Alkan died under a falling bookcase, but at least he wasn't trying to play it.

But for the late-night Radio 3 audience the massive bucket played fortissimo was a world first. It was clouted during the first broadcast performance of Toxic Knuckle Bones by Spencer, 25, one of six young composers whose contrasting works were heard in a live concert by the Manchester-based BBC Philharmonic conducted by James MacMillan.

Five of the six composers are students at the University of Manchester or the Royal Northern College of Music; the sixth lectures in music at Salford University. For the northern six it was a chance to hear their works directed by one of the country's leading composers.

Spencer's 12-minute piece is based on a text on lunacy by the poet, essayist, playwright, actor and director, Antonin Artaud. The bucket makes a forceful appearance at the start when it is struck 15 times, reappears towards the middle (46 blows) and comes in again at the end (demi-semi quavers, marked fffff, which is just about as loud as sound can go).

"I heard a man knocking concrete off a digger bucket outside my friend's window and I thought it was a fantastic sound," said Spencer, now completing a PhD at Manchester University.

He now has his own bucket (complete with dried building site mud) to ensure performances can be authentic. "I got it from a construction company in Manchester. They were the only people in the city prepared to give me a bucket not attached to a JCB.

"It's made of cast iron which gives its sound a particular quality. It's different from Mahler's anvil. This a 21st century update on the blows of fate."

MacMillan described Toxic Knuckle Bones as "uncompromisingly hard-line modern" in the "in your face" style of the Greek composer Iannis Xenakis. He said the pieces played at the concert represented a variety of styles. "As part of my work with the orchestra, I like to find out what is going on in local colleges."

At rehearsals, Spencer instructed Paul Patrick, the orchestra's principal percussionist who was doubling on tubular bells, to strike a precise spot on the outside of the bucket.

"I've played some pretty peculiar things for the BBC," said Patrick as he weighed up a Stanley Dynagrip 250gm hammer. "For Sir Peter Maxwell Davies I have rattled chains and played the carving knife and sharpening steel. If it can be struck, they assume we can do it. We get to do funny whistles, too."

webTitle: Fans and their 'parasocial' relationships with celebrities

fields.headline: Dear Jill
fields.standfirst: 'Parasocial' relationships with leading celebrities are a modern phenomenon.  Chris Arnot  talks to an academic who studies fans and their behaviour
fields.trailText: 'Parasocial' relationships with leading celebrities are a modern phenomenon. Chris Arnot talks to an academic who studies fans and their behaviour
fields.body:
Television presenter Jill Dando, like Diana, Princess of Wales, before her, was mourned by thousands of people who had known her only through the media. Both have inspired websites on which members of the public can express their feelings - clear examples of the "parasocial relationships" studied by David Giles, of the Psychology Department at Coventry University.

His book, Illusions of Immortality: a Psychology of Fame and Celebrity, discusses the way soap opera fans blur the line between fiction and reality. In the first five years of his role in Marcus Welby MD, the actor Robert Young received more than 250,000 letters from viewers, mostly asking for medical advice.

Parasocial relationships are one-sided. They are conducted between one person, usually a television viewer, and an image. In extreme cases the image is a cartoon character. "Some of my students have come across a Sky TV tribute programme on which at least one person admits to feeling strongly associated with Homer Simpson," Giles smiles.

"Princess Diana and Jill Dando occupy the grey area in the middle," he says. "They were real people. Those interacting with them didn't know them, but obviously felt that they did. It takes something like the death of a media figure for the strength of that attachment to be recognised."

For a psychologist to specialise in the media is unusual in this country, but less so in the US. Giles, 36, became fascinated by celebrity during his pre-academic career in rock journalism. In late 1980, he found himself interviewing such luminaries as Tom Jones, Kylie Minogue and Olivia Newton-John, as well as members of various indie bands known mainly to readers of Melody Maker and the NME.

"I was always intrigued by the reverence bestowed on so-called stars," he recalls. "I remember going on tour with a band who were never going to be successful, yet they had real rock-star attitudes. It was intriguing to watch the record-company lackeys hanging on to every word and laughing at their terrible jokes.

"What had these people done to earn this reverence, apart from the fact that one of them used to be in Kajagoogoo?"

What indeed had Princess Diana done, apart from marry the heir to the British throne and bear his children? Yet somehow she was transformed into a worldwide superstar, albeit one all too vulnerable to the pitfalls of celebrity.

What intrigues Giles in this case is not so much the reverence bestowed on her as the familiarity vested in her by those who knew her only as a media image.

One contributor to her tribute website wrote: "Diana and I are less than a year apart in age, and over the years we had experienced some of the same things. It was great to be pregnant at the same time, watching our tummies grow."

Another assumed that her life and the princess's ran along parallel lines: "Once we reached are [sic] early 30s we had developed our personalities and begun to gain independence. Our husbands forgot how to nurture us and give us the love and friendship that we both wanted so desperately."

Giles doesn't see anything particularly unhealthy in these responses.

"I think it only becomes negative if people are too paralysed with grief to get out of bed and go to work." He does admit, however, that using websites for this sort of research could be "response-biased" insofar as the respondents need a degree of computer literacy. After all, the Jill Dando internet tribute address has nearly 50 characters.

"Academics assume that everyone's online," he concedes. "At the same time, however, those who are typical internet users are not the sort you would expect to be weeping buckets over Diana and Jill."

Indeed, many of the authors of these tributes express surprise at the strength of their reactions. "I would say that I am a fairly hard-nosed cynic," wrote one, "but tears came despite that, and I am still finding it hard to take in that she is gone."

Another described herself as "a happy and well-adjusted woman," before going on to reveal that she was "stunned by the emotions I felt and the tears that flowed".

For Giles this is more evidence of a "deep-rooted reluctance to accept the media's influence on us as individuals". It's an influence he intends to carry on exploring for some time yet.

Dr David Giles will be presenting a paper on Parasocial Interaction: A Model for Studying Relationships with Media Figures, at the British Psychology Society's centenary conference in Glasgow this month (March 28-31).

fields.headline: Into gear
fields.standfirst: If you're in year 12 you can get up to speed on universities at a higher education fair, says  John Beckett
fields.trailText: If you're in year 12 you can get up to speed on universities at a higher education fair, says John Beckett
fields.body:
 Concentrate on 8-10 universities - locate them on the plan you'll be given and head straight for them.

 Prepare 2-3 questions for each.

 If there is a recent graduate on the stand, grab them!

 Be purposeful - don't be distracted by friends who have finished their tasks.

 Call it a day after an hour or so, because it will be tiring work.

 See the convention as part of your research, not as the answer to it.

 Follow up over the coming weeks with more reading, open days, interviews with your teacher or adviser over the coming weeks.

 Don't go into hibernation throughout the spring and summer.

Spring is here and, though it is still 18 months until they start university, year 12 students are already being encouraged to think about their future plans.

Spring also sees the start of a series of higher education conventions, the ideal place to start doing some research. With more than 300 universities and colleges to choose between - many of them attending these conventions - and 40,000 degree combinations to choose from, this can be a daunting task. It is easy to get lost and despondent at such events, so a good amount of planning beforehand is vital.

There's no way you want to be carrying home 100s of prospectuses - the weight will be unbearable, you'll never read them and you'll end up more confused than when you started. A much better plan is to concentrate on a small number of universities and colleges in which you know you have an interest. This means time spent before the event finding out who does what and where and preparing some questions to ask the university reps. These could be about the course content, the entry requirements, the accommodation or graduate destinations from your course. Often you'll be speaking to a current or recent graduate who can give you the lowdown on what student life is really like. How do they get by financially? How heavy is the academic workload? Would they recommend their course?

For a second year, Ucas and the Guardian are offering a Convention Card to all visitors who have pre-registered. This can be used at stands to register an early interest in courses the university offers. The card can be used after the event at higher education open days, and it also contains key dates in the admissions cycle. Pick up prospectuses - universities can use the details on your card to send more information later.

This year university admissions and schools liaison staff can expect a whole new raft of questions relating to the new courses students are following within Curriculum 2000. For example, are vocational A-levels acceptable for your chosen course? How important is your performance in AS- levels at the end of year 12? Are key skills important and is evidence of key skills required? Will the universities use the new UCAS tariff points system when making you an offer?

It's also wise to find out about course assessment and content and how the course is taught - whether by lectures, seminars, tutorials, lab work or whatever. There will be gap-year organisations present, so see what they have to offer. A programme of seminars will provide crucial information, such as student finance. * By Easter 2001 - start research, visit higher education convention and use resources at school/college, including a higher education adviser!

 By summer break 2001 - augment research with open days. Have your course and university choices, and your personal statement, ready to go.

 September 2001 onwards - complete Ucas application

 November 2001 to April 2002 -interviews, open days, offers.

 May/June 2002 - exams!

 August 2002 - results!

 October 2002 - start university!

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

 A survey by virginstudent.com has revealed students are not the rampant sexual beasts the public thought. Of 2,600 students surveyed, one in five men and one in 10 women are still virgins. Most of the remainder have had fewer than five partners, almost half believing their current love interest will be there for life.

Politics and economics students have the poorest sex lives with 28% staying celibate for their whole time at university. Medical students were most pessimistic of lifelong happiness with their lover, only a third believing it would endure.

 No organisation was more often attacked than the Quality Assurance Agency, education minister Tessa Blackstone told a reception at the Commons to launch its annual report. It wasn't clear if this was a compliment or a new performance target for the agency to stick to.

Incidentally, QAA chief John Randall's promised "light touch" certainly applies to the THES - they got one invitation compared to the Guardian's four. Not that he loathes the Murdoch publication, you understand.

 Bolton Institute is basking in post TQA glory - one of only 11 institutions to win three 24s from the agency last year (all the rest were old universities) for its departments of psychology, nursing and subjects allied to medicine.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com or lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News: Balance of mind

Who has the best thinkers? The departure of two eminent philosophers from King's College London to the University of Texas at Austin announced last week will affect the world rankings of philosophy departments, predicts Brian Leiter, who compiles The Philosophical Gourmet Report. www.blackwellpublishersco.uk/gourmet/default.htm.

King's, currently fourth in Britain, will slip "mightily" down the league after the departure of R Mark Sainsbury, who holds the Susan Stebbing Chair in philosophy, and Richard Sorabji, a renowned scholar of ancient Greek thought, says Leiter. Austin sits 21st in the US but should now make the top 20 or even top 15. Leiter, as a philosophy professor at the University of Texas, may not be seen as not completely detached, but he was accused by colleagues of being "too fair" when his university dropped heavily in the rankings last year.

King's reacted philosophically, pointing out that the university recently signed four American stars, including Adrian Hayday, a Yale immunologist, and Princeton classics professor Alessandro Schiessarro.

Research news

A scientific problem

Sir Gareth Roberts, who was recently installed as master of Wolfson College, Oxford, is to lead an independent study into the supply of skilled scientists and engineers, the government has announced. A report is due by the end of February 2002.

Trust the boffins

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers last week told MPs that he is to set out the steps needed to rebuild public confidence in science. A major speech is scheduled for next week.

Universe

Careering ahead

Work experience and career-related courses at school reduce dropout rates and increase the likelihood of college enrolment, says a report by Teachers College, Columbia University (www.tc.columbia.edu/iee)

Rewards of faith

An Oxford theologian, the Rev Canon Arthur Peacocke, has won the £1m international 2001 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion for his pioneering research into DNA. Formerly an agnostic biochemist, Peacocke subsequently became an Anglican priest.

webTitle: NUS wants students to wake up to the election

fields.headline: Time to raise your voices
fields.standfirst: The NUS wants students to wake up to the election, says  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: The NUS wants students to wake up to the election, says Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
As the election gets nearer, students are taking their voting message beyond the campus to schools and local newspapers. Before previous elections, the efforts of the National Union of Students have been focused on getting students to register to vote. Now it wants to push student concerns onto the political agenda.

Electoral registration has been simplified since the last election and the length of time reduced. But if, as expected, May 3 proves to be the general election date, yesterday was the last day registration will count.

Students will be urged to get out and vote, but they will also be going into schools in an effort to raise awareness of higher education issues.

While the election is not expected to be close overall, a dozen marginal seats have sitting MPs with a majority of under 5,000 and also a substantial student presence in the constituency.

Owain James, NUS president, said the union would not recommend a particular party or advise people how to vote. But local newspapers and radio stations would be targeted in an effort to highlight the position of the different parties.

"We want to see students out there voting," he said, "but also working in the local community to draw attention to higher education issues."

As many candidates as possible from all parties will be urged to sign pledges not to vote for higher tuition fees and to back an inquiry into student funding for England, Wales and Northern Ireland along the same lines as the Cubie committee inquiry in Scotland. "The more of an issue we can make it, the more chance there is of people integrating it into their planning next year," said James.

The NUS is also urging students to take advantage of new changes to the rules on postal voting. Up to 1997, postal votes could only be obtained for a good reason - now any registered voter can apply for one up to six days before the poll.

As many students back at college in May are not registered at their term addresses, the change has the potential to boost the level of student voting substantially.

The NUS is designing a leaflet to be used in applying for a postal vote and is using the slogan: "If your name's not down, you're not getting in!"

webTitle: Nottingham Trent's MA in investigative journalism

fields.headline: Inside story
fields.standfirst: It sounds so sexy - an MA in investigative journalism. But what's the reality like at Nottingham Trent's school for sleuths, asks  Catherine Adams
fields.trailText: It sounds so sexy - an MA in investigative journalism. But what's the reality like at Nottingham Trent's school for sleuths, asks Catherine Adams
fields.body:
All 165 prisoners on Death Row in the state of Illinois have had a stay of execution this month. They owe their lives not to a political party or lobby group, but to two young, female students of investigative journalism.

Working with their professor and a private detective, the students at the Northwestern University in Chicago uncovered evidence to clear five inmates and throw the rest of the convictions, and the whole system of capital punishment in the US, into doubt. Who said Watergate could never happen again?

On this side of the Atlantic an attempt by Nottingham Trent University to nurture the next generation of reporters like Bernstein and Woodward has so far registered no high profile successes to match that. In fact, the UK's only MA in investigative journalism now finds itself in the ironic position of itself being investigated by journalists.

Despite the glamour of the subject there are only three students left on the MA course at the highly reputable journalism department at Nottingham Trent. The rest seem to have disappeared, often disillusioned and in debt. Meeting in the Peacock pub directly across the road from the university, members of the Nottingham branch of the National Union of Journalists voted to hold a local investigation into the course.

Branch secretary Kevin Stanley told the Guardian: "We were very concerned to hear about the problems some students were experiencing with the course and the branch is going to launch a formal investigation into it. This is part of a wider remit of the NUJ to ensure that the highest standards are being maintained in the training of journalists."

It has put forward a motion to the union's annual conference at the end of this month, noting that the course was not accredited by the National Council for the Training of Journalists or the Broadcast Journalism Training Council and instructing the national executive to ask the university "for a full written explanation as to why the course collapsed, and why it was not accredited". The motion claims the course does not represent value for its fees of nearly £5,000.

Johnny Gutteridge has been unemployed since leaving Europe's first MA of its kind in November last year. He speaks of "an element of disappointment in the course".

The course was launched in a blaze of publicity three years ago, boasting celebrity guest lecturers Jon Snow, Sue MacGregor and Roger Cook, although they are primarily attached to the BA course.

The MA attracted Gutteridge, then working as a press officer for a prominent British charity. He enrolled, hoping to develop some journalistic skills to further his career and possibly move into journalism.

"I wanted to come out of it feeling I had some real professional skills. When I got there, I heard from previous students that they didn't feel they'd come out strong as journalists," he said. Hardly surprising when one of the teaching sessions apparently involved the postgrads having to rip'n'read radio bulletins.

To add to Gutteridge's unemployment problems, there is the matter of a large debt to the bank for course fees. The university charges a minimum of £4,995 to its students, some of whom are from overseas.

"You're paying all that money and there isn't even a copy of a newspaper there to read," confided one of the remaining students, Zoe Hardy.

One former student has found a job in publishing. "It's not what I want," she says. After finishing the course, she spent a demoralising year having her story ideas either turned down or pinched by newspaper editors, whom she didn't feel equipped to deal with.

But it is not the first time students who have registered dissatisfaction. Postgrads on the very first intake three years ago submitted a complaint to the university listing their concerns. Yet when he asked the course leader, Julian Ives (a former investigative TV journalist), for a copy of the complaint, Gutteridge, like other students who tried, was told he couldn't see it. To this day, the university claims to be "looking into it".

Before going on leave due to stress, Ives refused to comment on the course, referring enquiries to the university press officer, Jennifer Spencer. "We did receive a complaint from about half a dozen students but we don't disclose anything about it," said Spencer. "Our corporate complaints process is confidential. The complaint is in the process of being resolved."

Which is not much help to Gutteridge. "It's not been a great year for confidence-building," he says.

And yet the course has strengths. Situated in the heart of Nottingham Trent's successful Centre for Broadcasting and Journalism, it benefits from some of the excellent, experienced lecturers who teach the BJ degree course and has good links with the BBC. But it raises expectations from two types of applicant - those who want to gain professional journalistic skills, and those who wish to study the concept of journalism as an academic subject. It appears to fall between those two stools.

"The students are being promised something that is not being delivered," says Zoe Hardy, a part-time media studies teacher and journalist. "What are not discussed are ideas. I hoped there would be some progression, a chance to study the media critically in greater depth. Some lessons we do I teach at A-level."

The students aren't the only ones who are leaving. Hugo de Burgh is author of the huge tome, Investigative Journalism, and until recently a lecturer on one of the core modules. He has now taken a post at a London college.

"I've never taught investigative journalism," he said. "I don't know if you can teach it. What I teach is the context and the environment in which it takes place, what has been done and what is being done. Some students (at Nottingham Trent) were very happy and some were not."

Can investigative journalism be taught? The Nottingham Trent course entry requirements state that "applicants should have a good undergraduate degree and/or experience of journalism". The failure to stipulate previous journalistic work is a problem, thinks media studies lecturer Andy Harrison. "The idea that the students on an MA can be coming cold to the subject is outrageous."

Gardian investigative journalist David Hencke is convinced that you learn on the job. He edited his university student magazine and worked on a local paper, before doing a "basic training" including writing skills, law and shorthand.

"You can't come in as a high-flying reporter, you have to start with the parish fetes, the youth club and the magistrates court. I still make mistakes, but it's better to make the bog standard mistakes at a level where you can't cause too much damage."

Journalist Paul Foot agrees. "It's a side of journalism you only really pick up when you are a journalist. People only become 'investigative' journalists when they're established in their own fields. First you have to lie low and do your job, before you can say to your editor, 'Have you ever thought about looking at this?'" Angela Phillips, who trains journalists at Goldsmiths College, is adamant that the subject can and should be taught at college. "Journalists always say you can't teach journalism. It's the built-in arrogance of the profession."

John Pilger, one of the best known reporters of the enquiring kind, doesn't believe in an MA in investigative journalism. "I hate the term. Why is investigative journalism declared exotic? All journalism should be investigative, from football to cookery. A lot of university courses like this turn out elite groups who get jobs which are quite removed from the real job of journalism."

The way Pilger learned his trade in Australia, being indentured to a newspaper for four years, hardly exists in Britain today. Getting a full-time place anywhere in the media as an apprentice or trainee is a scoop in itself. Even the BBC, as a public service broadcaster, has only one trainee a year in the whole of the East Midlands.

Andy Harrison, a representative for the lecturers' union Natfhe at a Nottingham further education college, blames the culture of funding in education for the temptation to use "sexy" and potentially misleading course titles.

"It's the same cycle of problems everywhere," he says. "They take on more courses to get more funding, the staff and resources are overstretched and the standards drop."

There's also a feeling with media studies that futher education does the work and higher education reaps the results in the form of undergraduates. "I've had a lot of feedback from my former students in recent years suggesting that they go to university and start out at a lower level from when they finished college," says Harrison.

The NUJ is among those trying to keep track of the explosion of media courses in Britain. It has pledged to put together a list of courses and monitor the amount and standard of journalistic content. It's now possible to do a solid nine years of media training in the course of a normal academic career: a GCSE, followed by a BND, leading to an HND, converting to a degree and polishing it off with an MA. And your future employer won't have to pay for it.

Despite the complaints about the MA, Nottingham's advertisement for next year's course is out in the media press this week. It is still called investigative journalism but with the more modest claim to "equip students with the skills needed for research work in factual television programmes".

The course title - "slightly elitist" in John Pilger's view - should be changed, says Natfhe's Harrison, to "researching for television, if that's what it is".

And the NUJ view? Nottingham branch secretary Kevin Stanley sums it up: "I just want students to know what they're letting themselves in for."

"You can't come in as a high-flying reporter, you have to start with the parish fetes, the youth club and the magistrates court. I still make mistakes, but it's better to make the bog standard mistakes at a level where you can't cause too much damage." Journalist Paul Foot agrees. "It's a side of journalism you only really pick up when you are a journalist. People only become 'investigative' journalists when they're established in their own fields. First you have to lie low and do your job, before you can say to your editor, 'Have you ever thought about looking at this?'" Angela Phillips, who trains journalists at Goldsmiths College, is adamant that the subject can and should be taught at college. "Journalists always say you can't teach journalism. It's the built-in arrogance of the profession." John Pilger, one of the best known reporters of the enquiring kind, doesn't believe in an MA in investigative journalism. "I hate the term. Why is investigative journalism declared exotic? All journalism should be investigative, from football to cookery. A lot of university courses like this turn out elite groups who get jobs which are quite removed from the real job of journalism." The way Pilger learned his trade in Australia, being indentured to a newspaper for four years, hardly exists in Britain today. Getting a full-time place anywhere in the media as an apprentice or trainee is a scoop in itself. Even the BBC, as a public service broadcaster, has only one trainee a year in the whole of the East Midlands. Andy Harrison, a representative for the lecturers' union Natfhe at a Nottingham further education college, blames the culture of funding in education for the temptation to use "sexy" and potentially misleading course titles. "It's the same cycle of problems everywhere," he says. "They take on more courses to get more funding, the staff and resources are overstretched and the standards drop." There's also a feeling with media studies that futher education does the work and higher education reaps the results in the form of undergraduates. "I've had a lot of feedback from my former students in recent years suggesting that they go to university and start out at a lower level from when they finished college," says Harrison. The NUJ is among those trying to keep track of the explosion of media courses in Britain. It has pledged to put together a list of courses and monitor the amount and standard of journalistic content. It's now possible to do a solid nine years of media training in the course of a normal academic career: a GCSE, followed by a BND, leading to an HND, converting to a degree and polishing it off with an MA. And your future employer won't have to pay for it. Despite the complaints about the MA, Nottingham's advertisement for next year's course is out in the media press this week. It is still called investigative journalism but with the more modest claim to "equip students with the skills needed for research work in factual television programmes". The course title - "slightly elitist" in John Pilger's view - should be changed, says Natfhe's Harrison, to "researching for television, if that's what it is". And the NUJ view? Nottingham branch secretary Kevin Stanley sums it up: "I just want students to know what they're letting themselves in for."

webTitle: EU bans livestock exports from France

fields.headline: EU bans livestock exports from France
fields.standfirst:
 French government confirms case
 Non-EU members tighten controls
 Britain may be disease source
 Infected animals born in France

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 French government confirms case
 Non-EU members tighten controls
 Britain may be disease source
 Infected animals born in France
fields.body:
The European Union today banned the export of all livestock from France after the first case of foot and mouth disease was reported there this morning, suggesting that the virus has spread from Britain.

Meanwhile non-EU countries rushed to toughen their border controls, with Switzerland, Poland, the Czech Republic and Norway all announcing new measures in an attempt to keep out the disease.

The EU ban, which applies to cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and other species at risk from the disease, will come into force after it has been formally adopted by the European commission.

The EU veterinary panel which agreed the move also banned the movement of all meat products, dairy products and other products from the affected species from the Mayenne and Orne areas of north-west France. All bans will last until at least March 27.

The outbreak, on a farm in Mayenne in the Loire Valley, was earlier confirmed by the French ministry of agriculture. It is the first report of the disease in continental Europe.

While all the infected Loire Valley animals were born in France, the French government has revealed that the farm is next to one that imported British sheep in February.

Agriculture minister Jean Glavany told French radio that the case "justifies all the draconian measures that we have taken over the past 15 days".

Six cattle with symptoms of the disease have been slaughtered along with the rest of the 114-strong herd. To protect against a further spread, officials set up a one-and-a-half-mile exclusion zone around the farm.

The European commission is now considering a complete ban or partial restrictions on French exports to contain the virus. Belgium has announced an immediate ban on hoofed animals from France and the Dutch government has prohibited all transports of cattle, pigs and goats in the country.

The Swiss federal veterinary office said today it was banning the entry of all cows, pigs, sheep, goats and deer into Switzerland from EU countries. Vets are already arranging to check all 182 animals which have been imported from the EU since last July, and the 22 animals imported from France since the beginning of this year have been placed in quarantine.

Norway imposed a two-week ban from midnight on all agricultural imports from the EU, while the Czech Republic extended an import ban on cloven-hoofed animals from Britain to cover the whole of the EU and Poland. Warsaw banned the transit of French animals and animal products.

British meat and livestock exports have been banned since the beginning of the foot and mouth crisis. The agriculture commissioner, Franz Fischler, today said the other EU members were satisfied that Britain was doing everything possible to stop the disease spreading.

Seventeen new cases were confirmed today in Britain, taking the total to 200. The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said he "deeply regretted" the spread of the disease to France.

Foot and mouth antibodies had previously been found in sheep exported to the continent. However, while they showed contact with the virus, the animals had stopped short of developing the full disease.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, today began a series of talks with farmers and others hit by the crisis.

A taskforce led by the environment minister, Michael Meacher, is to be set up to examine the impact of the foot-and-mouth outbreak on the rural economy

It was revealed yesterday that up to 500,000 ewes might have to be slaughtered to halt the outbreak.

Army snipers may be used to shoot sheep on hillsides to avoid bringing them into contact with other animals. The ministry of agriculture fears that the onset of the lambing season, when pregnant ewes are moved from winter quarters, will spread the disease.

Downing Street said a decision would be made in the next 48 hours on how to tackle the problem.

Discussions are also expected over a plan to use soldiers to cull feral pigs, which pose a risk of spreading the virus.

"There is a possibility that the army may be able to help us should we decide to go after the very small population of feral pigs in East Anglia," said a ministry of agriculture spokesman.

A total of 155,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter, of which 116,000 have already been culled.

webTitle: Teacher wins case after six-year suspension

fields.headline: Teacher wins case after six-year suspension
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A teacher who was suspended on full pay for six years after he was falsely accused of sexually abusing a student has won the right to be reinstated.
fields.body:
A teacher who was suspended on full pay for six years after he was falsely accused of sexually abusing a student has won the right to be reinstated.

Anthony McNally, 51, was suspended from Woodhey school in Ramsbottom, near Bury, after a 15-year-old boy made allegations in 1995 that he had been inappropriately touched. Mr McNally was cleared by the school's governors after three separate investigations. The police and NSPCC also found no evidence to support the boy's claims.

Mr McNally, who said his life and career had been blighted by the allegations, was cleared by a disciplinary panel in 1996 and had expected to return to the school within weeks.

Bury local education authority had him suspended again after its child protection committee expressed concern about the case. Gillian Shephard, the then education secretary, asked the school's governors to investigate again. They cleared Mr McNally for a second time in July 1997.

Two years later, the education secretary, David Blunkett, asked them to open the case for a third time. Mr Blunkett intervened after the local education authority argued that the original investigation was flawed as the authority's chief education officer had not been involved in the disciplinary proceedings.

Further allegations of indecent assault were made by a former pupil last September. Police investigated but no charges were brought.

Three appeal court judges yesterday quashed Mr Blunkett's decision to order another hearing and reinstated the school disciplinary panel's original finding that there had been no misconduct by Mr McNally.

His union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, which backed his legal battle, said the suspension was a gross waste of money. The union accused Bury council of going to inordinate lengths to stop Mr McNally returning to work.

Lord Justice Kennedy said yesterday that there was no justification for intervention by the education secretary. He said it would have been contrary to justice to allow the local education authority to be present when the disciplinary panel discussed among themselves whether gross misconduct had been proved.
