webTitle: Teachers scorn Blunkett's tough stance against industrial action

fields.headline: Teachers scorn Blunkett's tough stance against industrial action
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Simmering tensions between the government and the teaching unions over staff shortages broke out into open warfare yesterday, after union leaders dismissed threats by the education secretary, David Blunkett, that he would take a tough line against teachers taking part in industrial action as "emotional claptrap".
fields.body:
Simmering tensions between the government and the teaching unions over staff shortages broke out into open warfare yesterday, after union leaders dismissed threats by the education secretary, David Blunkett, that he would take a tough line against teachers taking part in industrial action as "emotional claptrap".

Speaking on the eve of potentially damaging industrial action close to the general election, a defiant Mr Blunkett accused members of the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers of abandoning their pupils and putting their education at risk.

But the unions counter attacked, dismissing Mr Blunkett's comments as "emotional claptrap and blackmail" which would only stiffen their resolve and encourage more teachers to support their action.

Mr Blunkett was speaking during a visit with Tony Blair to Southfields community college in Wandsworth, south-west London, where he announced the details of a £200m package designed to ease problems of teacher recruitment and retention.

From this week, pupils at up to 1,000 schools in Greater London and Doncaster could be forced into part time schooling as members of the unions stop covering unfilled posts and absences for more than three days. The results of further ballots in Leicester, Middlesbrough, Nottingham, Southampton and Portsmouth are due this week.

Mr Blunkett said: "I'm seriously concerned that any teacher should want to take action that increases pressure on their colleagues, that diminishes the chance of high achievement in tests and in GCSEs by students this summer, and actually diminishes the growing commitment of the public to teaching. I could understand better what they were doing if we weren't taking action to help."

Refusing to be drawn on what sanctions he might impose, he said: "I'm just sending a message to the teacher unions. We are moving up to the teacher conferences and they also know there is going to be a general election. I think it would be very remiss of them to believe this is a time when the government is simply going to roll over. Our job is to get teachers in the classroom, not simply to jump every time the unions bang the drum."

Mr Blunkett said he appreciated many teachers had had to cover for colleagues, but insisted the new measures he was putting in place would reduce their workload and ensure an adequate supply of teachers in the longer term. As expected, he announced bonuses of a minimum £2,000 to entice teachers back to the profession, backed up by money for childcare, housing and transport, for headteachers to use at their discretion.

But union leaders poured scorn on the minister's remarks. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, commented: "The government is rattled. Every day the government is forced to come forward with another initiative to deal with the crisis over teacher supply. Each panic measure justifies our action."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, added: "Children have been abandoned by this government, not by their teachers."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, commented: "While we welcome extra money going into schools, yet more initiatives from David Blunkett will do little to solve the immediate crisis they face. Conservatives will never support industrial action because it harms children's education. David Blunkett has dithered while our schools have plunged further into crisis."

webTitle: Heads suspended in 'ghost pupils' cash row

fields.headline: Heads suspended in 'ghost pupils' cash row
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Two primary school headteachers have been suspended amid allegations that "ghost pupils" are being added to school rolls to secure more funding and resources from a local authority.
fields.body:
Two primary school headteachers have been suspended amid allegations that "ghost pupils" are being added to school rolls to secure more funding and resources from a local authority.

Scotland's biggest education authority launched an inquiry after a whistleblower revealed that a Glasgow primary school had 20 more pupils on its roll than were actually attending the school.

It is alleged that two additional teaching posts, worth a total of around £50,000, were granted to the school on the basis of the inaccurate pupil count. The headteacher of that school was suspended two weeks ago.

But a second headteacher was also suspended last weekend after auditors discovered pupils on her roll who had long since left the school. It is not yet known if that school benefited financially.

There are now fears that Glasgow may have a significant problem with "phantom pupils" and the city council is checking all its 203 primary schools.

If the problem is shown to be prevalent in Glasgow, it is likely to lead to authorities across the country checking schools with a worried eye on funding levels.

The first headteacher to be suspended, Lesley Dalgleish, 46, of Mount Florida primary school, Glasgow, will appear before a hearing shortly.

The second headteacher, Maire Whitehead, 60, of St Mirin's Roman Catholic school in King's Park, Glasgow, was suspended last Friday.

Ms Whitehead is vice president of the Association of Headteachers in Scotland, and it is alleged that nine pupils were kept on her school's roll despite not having attended St Mirin's for some time.

Ken Corsar, director of education services at Glasgow city council, said: "It is very serious for an education authority not to have accurate details of the number of pupils present at any school, and their names, on any given day.

"We are also clearly concerned that we are targeting the resources we have towards real children with real educational needs."

Ann Hill, chief executive of the Scottish School Boards' Association, said the cases called into question the whole issue of school funding. "If the teachers have falsified rolls to obtain more funding, the only motive can be to get a better standard for the children. It is a breach of trust and we would certainly not condone it, but I could understand it."

Although the sums of money involved are relatively small - with each pupil being listed at a cost of around £3,000 a year, it would amount, in these cases, to £100,000 - the extra resources could help headteachers cut class sizes and employ extra teachers to free more senior staff for other work.

However, Jim Smith, general secretary of AHS, said he believed any discrepancies would prove to be merely administrative oversights.

"There are all sorts of reasons why there could be errors in the roll - from Asian children going on lengthy home visits with their families to parents taking their children from school without telling you," he said.

"If you are saying the headteacher deliberately left additional pupils on a school roll, you are saying teachers were also complicit in the deception, and I simply don't believe that would happen."

Shortly before she was suspended, Ms Whitehead publicly defended Ms Dalgleish. "If Lesley has done it, there was no personal gain for her, it could only be for her pupils. I think it is tragic teachers could be forced into a situation like this," she said.

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: The Making of the United Kingdom, 1500-1750 | Galaxy Evaluation Package
fields.body:
The Making of the United Kingdom, 1500-1750
AVP, £81.07 Age: KS3-4

The title supports the teaching of any historical topic or period from 1500-1750. High-quality pictures and clear sound make it a valuable package of particular help to the less able. The quality of the images is superb. The language, style and navigation enable children to use it with little or no adult assistance. The facility to store graphics, text and notes and work with them in any packages is a real highlight. Teachers can also build trails through the material so that pupils can undertake a journey that covers all the relevant areas of their study - this is an outstanding feature that opens up several possibilities for classroom use.

Galaxy Evaluation Package
(Sunshine Multimedia Co), Price £25.81 inc vat
Age: 4-6 yrs

This software provides a fun way of reinforcing literacy and ICT skills in the classroom with young children. It supports sequencing skills, letter formation, word recognition and sentence structure. A genuinely interactive title, it is quite addictive and is supported by a series of books that offers help in delivering the literacy hour. It also teaches young children the basic skills of using a PC. There are four levels to cater for different ages and abilities. This program can be used successfully by young learners and is suitable for both independent and supported learning.

You can read full evaluations of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

webTitle: New army training scheme for disaffected children

fields.headline: Short sharp shock
fields.standfirst: When he visited an army training scheme for disaffected children, John Crace expected a boot camp. Instead, he found a surprising success story
fields.trailText: When he visited an army training scheme for disaffected children, John Crace expected a boot camp. Instead, he found a surprising success story
fields.body:
I suppose it was inevitable really. At the first hint of an emergency, the government is generally quick to announce its plans to send in the troops to mop up the floods or drive the ambulances and fire-engines. So the only surprise is that it is has taken this long for the army to be sent into schools.

After successful trials in Norfolk and Newcastle, the government last week confirmed that it was planning to spend a further £600,000 to hire members of the armed forces to work with 14- to 16-year-olds in schools in Manchester, Merseyside, Leicester, Bristol, the West Midlands and London. The scheme, called Skill Force, which is targeted at those teenagers who are already disaffected or perceived to be at risk of becoming so, aims to work with the school system to reduce truancy and disruption by teaching practical and vocational skills at KS4 instead of a modern foreign language and a science subject.

Put the words army and school in the same sentence and you automatically think Willie Whitelaw, "short, sharp shocks" and boot-camp discipline. And when I arrive at Methwold High School, one of the three Norfolk schools taking part in the project, that looks exactly what's on offer. Eighty pupils - some from Methwold High, the rest from the other two schools taking part, Hamond's High School in Swaffham and Wayland Community High School in Watton - are gathered in the hall while two soldiers in combat fatigues patrol the front of the stage waiting for an army recruitment video to begin.

"Er, it's unfortunate that you've come today," says Captain Brett Jarvis, the course leader who is dressed in civvies and looking every inch the teacher. "I know it looks terribly militaristic, but it isn't really. Part of the Skill Force course involves potential employers giving a presentation to students about what they do and what sort of people they are looking for. Today it's the army's turn."

But it's no coincidence that two of the half dozen or so employers to have made presentations so far are the navy and the Royal Air Force. The Ministry of Defence is supplying the trainers for the course, recruitment levels are down and any quid pro quo is gratefully received. For their part, the children are completely unfazed by any military overtones. Some are planning to enlist on leaving school anyway, and those who aren't seem to reckon that anything is better than sitting in classes. "I thought it was going to be all marching when I signed up for this option," says Richard Mather, a year 10 student at Wayland, "but I didn't mind as I don't like foreign languages."

Marching isn't on the menu, and PT is the closest anyone gets to basic training. "It can't be a military operation," jokes Capt Jarvis, " as the transport doesn't turn up two hours late." What is on offer are basic key skills incorporated into the bronze and silver Award Scheme Development and Accreditation Networks (Asdan) syllabuses, together with the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh's award, the St John's lifesaver awards and some outdoor environmental experience.

Were Alastair Campbell to set foot in Wayland Community High School, he would no doubt immediately declare it a "bog standard comprehensive". It has the usual range of abilities and social groupings; its GCSE attainment levels are slightly above the national average but, like most schools, it has its fair share of problems - including disaffected and disruptive pupils. For the school, the relaxation at KS4 that allows the national curriculum to be disapplied under certain circumstances has been something of a godsend, and when it was approached to join in the army's pilot scheme it responded enthusiastically.

At all three schools in the Norfolk project, the pupils were given the final say on their participation, but in all cases it seems that a fair degree of social engineering was involved in deciding who should be offered the option in the first place. Methwold took the route of asking for volunteers from those who were lacking in self-confidence and were unlikely to cope with the GCSE syllabus, Hamond's opted for a mix of the non-academic and those with behavioural difficulties, while according to Brett Jarvis, Wayland went the whole hog and put forward 22 of their most disruptive kids.

Chris Dix, Wayland's headteacher, is slightly defensive at this suggestion. "We followed the guidelines that were put forward by the army," he says. "We chose from across a range of academic abilities those who were disaffected or in danger of becoming so. I would accept, though, that some of the students are quite challenging."

Dix need not have been so protective of his students' sensibilities; they wouldn't see their behaviour as challenging so much as the stuff of nightmares. "I'd been suspended twice for swearing at teachers and messing around in class and was regularly picking up four detentions a week," admits Mather. "My parents were starting to have a real struggle getting me to go to school in the morning." Mather's was a familiar story. "I'd been suspended at least twice for swearing and talking back to teachers," says Barry Ford. And so on. Martin Gisborne had been in constant trouble for fighting and backchatting. "The school split me up from the group I used to hang around with and put me in isolation," he says. "It just frustrated me even more so I started messing around even worse."

The point is, though, that after six months on the course they all claim - and the school agrees - that their behaviour has improved beyond all recognition. "I've only had one detention and I haven't felt like bunking off," says Mather. "I thought it was about time I sorted myself out," says Gisborne. There has also been a further knock-on benefit of improvements in their GCSE curricular work. So what is the secret?

Brett Jarvis acknowledges that it was an uphill struggle for the first few months as the kids pushed the limits to see what they could get away with, but believes that it was their interest in what they were doing and the strength of the relationships that he and the two sergeants, Tony Shuttleworth and Bertie Burtenshaw, were able to forge that proved the clinching factor. "I think they liked the fact that we didn't come across in the same way as the teachers they have known," says Jarvis. "The two sergeants have proved to be extremely effective role models. Neither were particularly academic at school, but by applying the very principles we are teaching here, have gone on to be successful."

The kids see it slightly differently. They enjoy the work - "less boring, more useful" - and the sanction of being slung off the course is a great deal more effective than being banned from maths, but what they really seem to appreciate is being treated as adults. "If you get wound up and think you're going to lose your temper they let you take five minutes out," says Matthew Balls. "A teacher would think you were trying to skive off if you asked for time out." "They don't say 'Do this' or 'Do that'," says Mather. "They tell you what's expected and let you get on with it. If you need help they'll give it but they let you complete the work to your standard, not some curriculum standard. So you feel like putting more effort in."

Skill Force is no panacea. Some of those on the course have a reading age of seven, many are statemented and some are on medication for behavioural problems, and the course does not replace all the usual pastoral measures to cope with disruption. What it does do at the very least is contain the problem. The pressure on teachers' time is horrendous at the best of times and disruptive kids take up more time than most. With the disaffected channelled into something that interests them, teachers are free to give their time to the 28 kids who want to learn rather than the two who don't.

There is a danger that such schemes will introduce a two-tier system at KS4 and Mather acknowledges that his father had reservations about him dropping Double Science. But Dix thinks such worries are an irrelevance. "The students will still be doing GCSEs," he says, "but in any case there always was a two-tier system. Kids are very quick to identify their levels of ability, and many of the less able quickly recognised that they weren't going to be able to cope with the curricular work early in year 10 and identified themselves as failures. With Skillforce we are providing a course at which they can succeed and thereby raise their self-esteem."

Endorsements for the scheme have come from all quarters. Allan Rimmer, the administrator for the Association of Workers for Children with Emotional and Behavioural Difficulties, is pleased that the course recognises the importance of continuing to teach key skills, such as numeracy and literacy. "Disruptive children need the curriculum, too, and we welcome anything that finds an effective way of teaching it," he says.

Jenny Mosley, one of those at the forefront of introducing Circle Time into school, is also in favour. "You can't underestimate the importance of team-building and leadership in helping those with emotional difficulties," she says. "What I would want to make sure is that there was time included in the course for reflection. Experiences are often very immediate, and you only get to understand the processes involved by thinking about them at a later date. That is very often where the learning takes place."

The one dark cloud on the horizon is money. Despite the new funding, no one seems to have worked out that if you want to continue the scheme it will involve running two parallel groups. Wayland plans to continue the current course when the year 10s move into year 11, but has a queue of year 9 punters eager to sign up for the autumn. "The army is trying to accommodate us by offering us more time," says Dix, "but even so it would involve an overall reduction in the time each year group would get. We think this sends out all the wrong messages to the students."

Joined-up government only goes so far, it seems.

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at True Believer by Virginia Euwer Wolff, and Mega and Micro by Barbara Taylor
fields.body:
True Believer, by Virginia Euwer Wolff
Faber, £9.99 (£4.99 paperback)
Age: 12-16 yrs

The author revisits LaVaughn, a key player in her acclaimed novel, Make Lemonade. Like that book, this reads as if a photographer accompanied LaVaughn's every move and thought. Growing up with her driven mother, she has expectations of her future, expectations that may be unusual in her neighbourhood. Her mother dreams big dreams for her, consequently making big sacrifices that she chooses not to conceal. And although LaVaughn tries to fulfil her mother's ambitions, she can't avoid the usual teenage preoccupations - love, friendship and families. It's tough, but so is she. This is wonderful, accessible, honest writing.

Mega and Micro (one of a series of four Weird and Wonderful Guides) by Barbara Taylor
(OUP), Price £5.99
Age: 7-11 yrs

Biggest, smallest, highest, heaviest, largest, rarest - stunning photographic evidence of the extremes of the natural world abound, accompanied by attention-grabbing bites of narrative information. This series of books is a splendid source of conversation-stoppers - did you know, for example, that the tongue of a blue whale weighs more than 35 people? Or that a great white shark can swallow a dolphin whole? The spreads are also dotted with True or False sections highlighting other amazing facts. Such books are irresistible; they stimulate conversation, imagination, curiosity and, maybe, the odd nightmare.

webTitle: On the Web: The Civil Wars and Environment

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.trailText: The Civil Wars | Environment
fields.byline: Compiled by Amanda Grimwood and Jim Merrett
fields.body:
Civil wars

General information (1)

easyweb.easynet.co.uk/~crossby/ ECW/index.htm

Suitable for: KS3

An extensive site that covers the events, personalities, battles, technology and tactics. The text is accessible and the site is easy to navigate with useful cross-links.

General information (2)

www.british-history.com

Suitable for: KS2/KS3

This is part of a British history web-ring and includes other events. The site relies heavily on photographs of re-enactments of key battles from English Heritage events. There are accessible narrative and visual sources, both primary and secondary. Pupils might need some guidance.

Cromwell

www.cromwell.argonet.co.uk

Suitable for: KS3/KS4/teachers

Everything there is to know about Oliver Cromwell, produced in association with Cambridgeshire Education, Libraries and Heritage.

Coins

www.nmgw.ac.uk/archaeology/treg_cat.html

Suitable for: teachers

A possible source for artefacts to illustrate the tumult of the civil war years is the hoard of coins held in the Tregwynt Treasure Trove, in Wales.

Primary source documents

www.hillsdale.edu/academics/history/Documents/War/index.htm

Suitable for: KS4/A-level/teachers

A collection of primary sources, including letters from a Parliamentarian soldier, Sergeant Nehemiah Wharton, offering a fascinating insight into the life of an ordinary soldier during the campaign, as well as a Royalist account of the Battle of Edgehill and Cromwell's account of a soldier's death at Marston Moor.

Diggers and Levellers

www.mindspring.com/~strecorsoc/world.html

Suitable for: KS4/A-level/teachers

Many primary documents from the Diggers and Levellers, providing an overview of the radical ideals of these groups. The site has a clear political purpose which teachers might like to view before recommending to students.

Re-enactment groups

www.sealedknot.org
www.english-civil-war-society.org
www.siegegroup.co.uk
Suitable for: teachers

All use photographs from enactments, with varying levels of interpretation and explanation - some also include brief features on the role of women and children in the army camps. Useful for finding out when and where re-enactments are taking place.

Environment

Environment Agency

www.environment-agency.gov.uk

Suitable for: KS1 teachers, KS2 teachers & pupils

Includes flooding advice, flood warning codes and new flood plain maps plus an education section with numeracy and literacy pages. The numeracy material comprises worksheets aimed at levels 2 to 4 with well-defined objectives. Fiction and non-fiction books, with an enviromental theme, are suggested in the literacy section.

Friends of the Earth

www.foe.org.uk

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

The Factory Watch pages give a guide to local polluters but even better are its extensive links to other environmental sites, put into sections such as transport, youth, planning, news and waste.

Recycling

www.ollierecycles.com

Suitable for: KS2 teachers

Offers helpful lesson ideas aimed at juniors. Also carries a survey on recycling habits, which can be printed out, providing useful data and plenty of lively discussion points.

Alternative Technology

www.cat.org.uk/indexnf.tmpl

Suitable for: KS1 & KS2 pupils & teachers

The "Education" section gives details of school visits, courses for teachers and competitions. The site includes features on energy conservation, building design, transport and recycling.

Department of the Environment

www.schools.detr.gov.uk

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

Select the "7-11 years" option for interesting facts on global warming, d activities, a quiz and helpful links.

Children of the Earth

www.childrenoftheearth.org

Suitable for: KS1 & 2 teachers & pupils

Carries several features suitable for teachers' research but its best aspect is a set of multimedia presentations, with a commentary and colour cartoons. Recycling, rainforests, deforestation and global warming are all included.

Thinkquest

thinkquest.org/26026

Suitable for: KS2 teachers and pupils

Sift through 400 articles across 811 pages on the environment. Select "Classroom Connections" and you can register with Thinkquest and let pupils learn and be tested on environmental material.

webTitle: The merger of the teaching unions

fields.headline: In harmony?
fields.standfirst: ATL, AUT, NUT, NASUWT: from the alphabet soup of teacher trade unionism, a new unity is emerging, says  Will Woodward - something to make teachers celebrate and governments tremble
fields.trailText: ATL, AUT, NUT, NASUWT: from the alphabet soup of teacher trade unionism, a new unity is emerging, says Will Woodward - something to make teachers celebrate and governments tremble
fields.body:
Is this the start of a beautiful friendship? Something odd is happening to the teacher trade unions. They appear to be getting on with each other.

Take two events in the last week alone. First the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and the Association of University Teachers launched a strategic alliance that is likely to lead to eventual merger. Peter Smith, the ATL's general secretary, described it as "the most serious attempt yet by unions within the notoriously factious education world to collaborate rather than compete". A few days afterwards it emerged that the ATL, the National Union of Teachers, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, and the Welsh union UCAC, for the first time are presenting joint motions threatening to take industrial action to limit teachers' working time to 35 hours a week. Of all the main rank-and-file teaching unions in England and Wales, only the no-strike Professional Association of Teachers has not signed up to it.

"Brilliant," says Hank Roberts, organising secretary of Professional Unity 2000, a group of teachers campaigning for their unions to merge. "They are realising that they have got to act and pull together." These are just the latest signs that the alphabet soup of teacher trade unionism may eventually rationalise into something more manageable and - arguably - more powerful. No other sector has so many large, competing unions. Polls in the past have shown that teachers want their unions to unite; and it suits the government if they stay divided.

But the last year has been a "historic period" for teacher organisation, says NUT general secretary Doug McAvoy. The ATL's affiliation to the Trades Union Congress has made it easier for the three unions to work together. The big three have put two joint motions to the TUC congress, and a joint submission to the School Teachers' Review Body on pay and conditions. The TUC's general secretary, John Monks, has been actively encouraging the unions to work towards alliance and eventual merger. Though the NUT has some headteacher members, the prospect of one union for the whole school sector looks implausible. But two - one for heads, another for classroom teachers - is a feasible goal.

Last June the NUT and the NASUWT came together to launch a campaign against teacher workload, and again this year to announce joint industrial action on teacher shortages. McAvoy and his NASUWT counterpart, Nigel de Gruchy, are holding joint press conferences so often that they have agreed to take turns in going first. Significantly, Peter Smith has complained to the TUC that his union wasn't asked to join the action. McAvoy concedes that was a mistake and has apologised.

"The more teachers can be seen to be working together, the better for teachers and the better the message gets out to government that there is a problem to be dealt with," McAvoy says. This is more than flirtation: this looks like a relationship.

Sweetness and light, then? Hardly. These union leaders are old hands with big memberships and have egos on the large side, too. Things have improved since the nadir of the mid-1980s, when then NUT general secretary Fred Jarvis, writing to NASUWT oppo Terry Casey, began his letters "Dear Casey". But relations are still awkward, as they have been ever since the National Association of Schoolmasters was formed in 1919 in opposition to NUT support for equal pay for women teachers.

It's only a few months ago that de Gruchy demanded a public apology from McAvoy for an "outrageous accusation" over performance-related pay, and the two unions were at loggerheads when the NUT took the government to court over the issue (PRP). There have been times before now when unions have collaborated, only to separate again.

Michael Barber recalls in his book The Learning Game how, as an NUT official in the early 1990s, he drafted "more statements on behalf of all unions than - I guess - any official in the history of education. It was a tortuous business, and depended, above all, on careful drafting and phoning the various general secretaries in the right order. The key was to leave the most doubtful of the six to last, and then shame them into signing by informing them that the other five had signed up. Sometimes one had to stretch the facts slightly . . ."

De Gruchy, for one, believes the current era of cooperation could just as easily collapse as continue. "It's far too early to say. I just take things a step at a time. Where there are genuine differences of view it is no good pretending there is a spurious unity." He regards the NASUWT's longstanding cooperation with the Secondary Heads Association as more significant than the AUT/ATL link up. He points out that the ATL and AUT are not in serious competition for members. He favours ad hoc alliances on issues where the unions agree, rather than merger.

There are many well-placed sources who say the NUT leadership, which officially campaigns for union unity, is not that bothered about achieving it. In policy terms the NUT is perhaps closest to the ATL; but the backgrounds of the two organisations are chalk and cheese. Every union, from leadership to sleeping member, has people with an intense loyalty to their particular organisation who would be reluctant to see it diluted by other members from a different tradition.

But look into the crystal ball and there are other trends that make unity more likely. The unions are bitterly opposed to attempts by the new General Teaching Council for England to become the "voice of the profession". Says Hank Roberts: "The GTC can only do that whilst we have such a manifold division in the teaching trade unions."

De Gruchy will retire next year. His replacement, Eamonn O'Kane, is much more popular with the other unions. McAvoy and Smith aren't that far off retirement either. Though some worry that the tendency of unions to appoint their general secretaries from within will continue to reinforce their tribalist approach, most believe the new brooms will be less weighed down by the battles of old, more willing to embrace cooperation. Look at the example of the National Association of Head Teachers and the Secondary Heads Association. Whereas the NAHT's David Hart and the previous SHA general secretary did not get on, nowadays he and John Dunford cooperate well.

"There is hardly a cigarette paper between us on all the issues that matter," says Hart. Though no serious talks on merger have yet taken place, there is a good chance it will happen within the decade and possibly even half that time.

And yet there are few within the leadership of the NUT, NASUWT and ATL that will predict unity for them. The history of their relations is much too chequered for anyone to speculate confidently on that score. One well-placed union source said: "The desire for unity is a bit 'wouldn't it be lovely?' - without any really deep-seated desire." Observes Hart: "I think they still think in a way that says 'we all have distinct characters and really we can't bridge the divide'." Union marriage is possible - even more possible than it was. But it would be a foolish person who bought the wedding presents just yet.

General secretary: Doug McAvoy

Salary: £84,000

Retires: 2004

Takes qualified teachers only, strongest in primary. Has held off challenge from NASUWT to stay as biggest union. Hard left noisy at conference but has large moderate membership.

National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT): 186,000 members

General secretary: Nigel de Gruchy

Salary: £76,000

Retires: Easter 2002

An unashamed "members first" trade union, across the UK. New general secretary Eamonn O'Kane takes over next year.

Association of Teachers and Lecturers (ATL): 150,000 members

General secretary: Peter Smith

Salary: £90,000

Retires: 2005

Does well in secondary and independent sectors. Linked up for "alliance" with Association of University Teachers as a precursor to likely merger.

Professional Association of Teachers (PAT): 34,000 members

General secretary: Kay Driver

Salary: £52,000

Leaving: March 31

No-strike organisation struggling for members, who come increasingly from early-years sector. Other unions predict its demise.

Educational Institute of Scotland (EIS): 52,000 members

General secretary: Ronnie Smith

Salary: £60,000

Due to retire: 2111 (not required to seek re-election)

Biggest teaching union in Scotland, keen on alliance and eventual merger with Scottish Secondary Teachers Association (7,500 members).

National Association of Head Teachers: 31,000 members

General secretary: David Hart

Salary: £86,000 last year

Up for re-election: 2004

Powerful voice of headteachers, mainly in primary though has some secondary heads.

General secretary: John Dunford

Salary: £65,000

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
The resignation of Mrs Anthony, both as chair of governors and from the governing body itself, has a series of immediate consequences. The first is that we have a constitutional crisis: we cannot perform our functions without a chair, so we need to elect a new one.

Not only does the chair occupy a critical role on several committees, but in the case of the headteacher's performance management assessment the chair acts as the review officer. Without a chair, the whole assessment will be held up - and indeed it has been in any case (the original end-of-January deadline having long since elapsed). The government has set a new deadline for schools in April, presumably because so few schools had managed to complete their assessments - mainly because it proved impossible to obtain an early appointment with an external assessor).

The election of a chair could not be done at the meeting where we learnt of Mrs Anthony's departure because, legally, it must be an item on the agenda, so that those governors who were absent at that last meeting might have a chance to be present for the process of nomination and election. Legally, also - the clerk informs us - governors must be given a full week's notice.

The clerk (aka Joan Furby, the school's secretary) has suddenly become the fount of all knowledge. Knowing the statutes and regulations confers a definite type of status: although the clerk is nominally there to "serve" the governing body, we governors feel oddly sheepish in this situation where we need to be told what the protocol is. It is an unnerving feeling, being almost literally "herded" towards the decisions and actions we need to take. I imagine that clerks in magistrates' courts, with their professional knowledge of law and court procedure, exercise a similar, unseen but felt power. Joan exercises hers with tact, but the repressed martinet tendency is struggling within to be born, I suspect.

Because the next meeting to elect a new chairperson has to be "quorate" - that is, it must muster a two-thirds majority of the governing body - there is another thing we learn from the clerk. I was more or less aware that a governor who does not show up at meetings for six months can be summarily struck off, but it now appears this can occur even if the governor sends apologies. In other words, apologies are merely a courtesy: the clock starts running at the first missed meeting even if you apologise.

Fascinating stuff, I know! But oddly important: without all these rules, drafted by some anonymous but diligent civil servant and passed into statute, who knows how and when and where, the machinery of everyday school administration would grind to a halt. The clerk is like an engineer in overalls, tipping an oil-can here and there to keep it all running smoothly.

A date for an extraordinary meeting is set and we move on to other business. You can almost hear the lay governors like myself sigh with relief and rub our hands at the prospect of expressing opinions on something we actually know about (or think we do). Next item up: dinner money arrears. This is our chance to feel useful, to be important executives again, as we weigh up this delicate issue. On the one hand, we wish to be compassionate towards those in economic hardship. "Some people are really on the breadline," says Miss Roberts (a teacher). "The excuses are so plausible."

On the other hand, the governors' duty is to safeguard the school's interests and the general good. To permit dinner money arrears to get out of hand sets a bad precedent: why should anyone keep up with their payments if some don't have to? Like the Chancellor, we must be prudent. Tough love is our doctrine. "There comes a point where you have to be a bit hard-faced about it," says Mrs Mills, the deputy, as usual first to say what we've all been thinking.

But how big is the problem? There are two people in arrears of three figures, and two more in high two figures: a total debt of around £350. I was imaging scores of indebted families; a mountain of backdated copper and silver. But, after all, it doesn't seem that the school will have to go to the IMF. We agree to re-schedule these individual debts and decide on a new policy of swift and efficient warnings to prevent new debts mounting up. I have a slightly uncomfortable feeling that, not unlike the magistracy, here we have middle-class worthies dispensing justice to the "lower orders". But somebody has to take responsibility, right?

At least one of the parents in question, it transpires, should be eligible for free school meals, but needs further encouragement with the form. That is the most eye-opening revelation of all: that someone could be too hard-pressed and struggling to manage the task of filling in a form. It is an education, this governor business.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: I have two children aged nine and 11. Their school offers lots of extra-curricular activities. The trouble is that they tend to take up things with great enthusiasm - piano one week, tennis the next - then drop them again as soon as any real effort is required. How can I encourage them to persevere?
fields.trailText: Leading experts answer your problems
fields.body:
Children need to practise being in different situations, but these two may actually want to be at home. The parents may need to work out a timetable for time spent outside school and allocate time to activities; and if there's homework involved, such as practising scales, see how much time the children can realistically set aside. It may be a question of time rather than their commitment.

If the children are saying they don't want to do things because they're too much effort, they need to have something in their home life that is an effort - such as sweeping up leaves. Having something that is your responsibility and that you have to do even if you sometimes don't feel like it is a tremendous life skill.

The parents also need to help them to recognise that it doesn't matter if something is hard. They need to learn that you don't simply abandon things that are hard. And something else that's a hobby-horse of mine is doing something for somebody else: helping to clear a park, or a community-based project, where you can see the results and feel proud that you've helped.

Jean Robb
Co-author with Hilary Letts of several books about children

Creating Kids Who Can, Creating Kids Who Can Concentrate, and Succeed In Exams, Triumph in Tests, all by Jean Robb and Hilary Letts, published by Hodder & Stoughton.

It sounds as though this parent is doing a great job helping the children to try things out. It's very healthy to have children who want to try different activities. I can see where this parent is coming from and it can be difficult to juggle the family timetable, but I'm not sure that wanting to try out lots of activities is bad news.

At that age, children should be supported by their parents in trying new things. At Sport England we believe children in the younger age groups need a range of experiences to develop a healthy and active lifestyle later on. Who knows what sport they'll eventually home in on? But a healthy grounding will stand them in good stead in later life.

Sport England is running a scheme that encourages primary schools to promote physical activity by giving them an award called Activemark. This doesn't just mean official sports lessons, but schemes like encouraging the children to walk to school. Some schools have been quite innovative, running after-school skipping sessions, or inviting grandparents in to teach the children the games they used to play. Promoting exercise is so important; this parent should be pleased and encouraged.

Dave Renshaw
Head of the Active Schools programme at Sport England

Children today have information fed to them so fast, they want to be constantly excited and they want everything to be bite-sized and extreme. The laborious discipline that's needed to master a musical instrument is difficult and children need to be introduced to music in a way they will enjoy. Playing an instrument is a skill, and you don't get the benefits without commitment; the majority of children who begin to learn do give up.

At the Voices Foundation, we believe passionately in singing as the first exposure to music. Everyone has a voice, you don't need to practise, and instruments can follow later when the foundations of musicianship have been laid. My inspiration for the foundation came when I was travelling in Hungary, where music education was recognised by the whole community for the development of the child. Children who develop musical thinking also do very well at other subjects like maths and languages, and it extends their communication and listening skills. When we surveyed primary schools nationwide, we found that many teachers just didn't have the confidence, skills and resources to deliver the classes. We address this through teacher training in primary schools. The children quickly develop a musical ear; then they can apply themselves to learning an instrument.

Susan Digby
Founder and principal of The Voices Foundation, a music education charity

Coming next

My 15-year-old son was a chatty little boy, but is now more interested in his computer than anything else. He is doing well academically, but is quiet in general and I'm worried that he has no friends.

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? webTitle: So you want to learn about...judges

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...judges
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Is that you, Bumface? Silence in court!

Surely you remember me! Not another word or I'll have you removed!

We were both at Charterhouse. Take the prisoner! Are you sure?

Absolutely. You're still the same bossy Bumface. Hang on. I don't remember you.

You wouldn't. I was your fag. You beat me with a cricket stump. Good lord! I do remember that. And what brings you to the Old Bailey dock?

Little misunderstanding, old boy. But how on earth did you become a judge? The Queen appointed me. She appoints circuit judges on the recommendation of the Lord Chancellor.

What's a circuit judge? We are assigned to a particular circuit of courts and may sit at any of the Crown and county courts on that circuit. Circuit judges are normally appointed to hear both criminal and civil cases.

And where did the Lord Chancellor find you? I applied. Advertisements are placed in some national newspapers and legal journals, usually in May, inviting applications to fill expected vacancies. Selection is then by interview.

Can anybody apply? Don't be foolish. The Lord Chancellor selects from two sections of the legal profession - solicitors and barristers. Candidates need to have had the right of audience in a Crown Court or county court for at least 10 years. They are normally aged between 45 and 60 and should be of good health and character.

Any other requirements? There's a list of desired criteria, including legal knowledge and experience, integrity, intellectual and analytical ability, fairness, sound judgement, decisiveness, courtesy and humanity.

You didn't show me much of that with the cricket stump. Can we forget the cricket stump?

I can't. What about High Court judges? They're also appointed by the Queen on the Lord Chancellor's recommendation, he customarily consults senior judges. The statutory qualification is a 10-year High Court qualification or to have been a circuit judge for at least two years. High Court appointments have generally been made from barristers who have been in practice for perhaps 20 or 30 years and hold the rank of Queen's Counsel. However, suitably qualified solicitors can now be appointed to the High Court Bench.

How do you become a solicitor? It normally takes a degree - not necessarily in law - and a Common Professional Examination or Postgraduate Diploma in Law. Trainee solicitors may also be a fellow of the Institute of Legal Executives and have five years' qualifying legal experience. The choice is then a one-year Legal Practice Course followed by a two-year training contract to become a qualified solicitor or to complete the Bar Vocational Course and complete a period of pupillage to become a qualified barrister.

You will be kinder than you were with the cricket stump, won't you? Unfortunately, old man, I can't hear your case. I've got to declare an interest.

 The Lord Chancellors Department www.gnet.gov.uk/lcd

 The Law Society

fields.headline: Life in wonderland
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones has a frabjous day slaying the further education jabberwock
fields.trailText: Janet Jones has a frabjous day slaying the further education jabberwock
fields.body:
"You must," Mr Jones advised me the other Tuesday, "be careful not to seem to be too cynical about further education."

Cynical? Hm. What is cynical?

According to my favourite dictionary cynical is "churlish, captious; incredulous of human goodness, sneering".

So, I've had to look up "captious" to see what that means. I thought it might have something to do with "frabjous".

It doesn't. In fact "frabjous" is the complete opposite of "captious". Unless we've all been misunderstanding the Jabberwock since Lewis Carroll thought it up.

For the sake of Furthermore, therefore, and in the interests of accuracy, I've now had to set about looking up "frabjous". It's not in my favourite dictionary. But I have found it in the third (and final) dictionary. And it is that mixture of joyous and fabulous and ravishing that we all thought it was.

We can go ahead at last then, get to the point, and have a look at the frabjousness of further education, from a frabjous point of view.

Further education has many of the same qualities as motherhood and apple pie. Who can be against it? You cannot disapprove of it. The debate is about how it should be delivered - not whether it should exist.

The comparison with motherhood and apple pie continues: methods of delivering babies usually excite discussion. How you serve your apple pie may only worry the cognoscenti. But nobody doubts that babies should be delivered and pies should be served.

Further education therefore, like motherhood and apple pie, is with us.

And what does it do?

It does the same as motherhood and apple pie, of course. It nurtures and feeds. It provides opportunity. It opens doors. (I know you have never seen an apple pie opening a door - but that is getting pedantic.)

"Remember the pastry chef," was how Mr Jones rounded off his advice to me, that Tuesday. I do remember the pastry chef. Her pastries were more exotic than apple pie: she was the pastry chef in an olden-days male preserve in Pall Mall, London W1. She was happy with pastry and she was happy as chef but she hated - and I mean - hated the kitchen. She hated the language she heard there. And she hated the spitting. She decided to get out. After working in the kitchen from before dawn, she came to us in the evenings and took her GCSEs. When she had done that, she came to us in the evenings again and took her A-levels. She chose London University and she chose classics. When she had just missed a first, she gave a party to celebrate. It was a Roman party and she had found recipes from Ancient Roman. It was a spectacular meal.

Her doctorate, three years later, was in Ancient Roman food. And when I last saw her she was cooking again; she had helped to make a film about the food of Ancient Rome and she had cooked for the cameras.

Well, that story slays the jabberwock of cynicism? ("O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!") Though I don't think Mr Jones would care to be seen as the "beamish boy" whose "vorpal blade went snicker-snak" when he did the deed.

fields.headline: College Days
fields.standfirst: Andy Robinson
fields.trailText: Andy Robinson
fields.body:
Born: April 3, 1964

Occupation: Senior coach for the England rugby team; former open-side flanker for Bath and England

Attended: Richard Huish College, Taunton

Dates: 1980-82

Courses: Maths, geography, sociology A-levels

A tutor recalls: "He scowled even in those days. We were both rugby crazy. It was a period when England weren't doing very well. I particularly remember that he was very critical of the England players' attitude at the time - they didn't seem to take the game seriously.

"He wasn't academically outstanding, but he was a good, hard-working student."

fields.headline: Vital statistics
fields.standfirst: Colleges suffer from too much information says  John Brennan
fields.trailText: Colleges suffer from too much information says John Brennan
fields.body:
"Half of all students fail, report reveals". It is an easy headline to write in the face of the evidence presented in the recent report from the National Audit Office on how English further education colleges can improve student retention and achievement. This evidence shows that overall success rates in the sector - the proportion of students achieving the qualification on which they embark - are only 56% for 16-18s and 51% for adults. But the headline profoundly misrepresents the real achievements of further education, and does little justice to the thoughtful and thorough analysis embodied in the report.

Consider the theory behind the statistics. Presentation of success rates as percentages implies that 100% success is a possibility. In reality, as the report recognises, students fail to complete their courses for many reasons. Some find the teaching inadequate, or the material irrelevant. Many others are interested only in a part of the skills and knowledge contained in a course and leave when they have what they need. Others are offered a job while studying and take it rather than stay until the end. Yet others drop out because of financial or domestic pressures. Not all of these withdrawals can be laid at the door of colleges. Some cases - for example, those leaving for employment - would in other circumstances be judged a success.

Not all students will achieve the level of skills and knowledge to satisfy awarding bodies. If all succeeded, would there not be an outcry that the system is too easy, and standards are in decline? Pass rates for A-level now stand at about 89% - which some would say means the examination is insufficiently rigorous - and those for many other qualifications are deliberately held much lower. Moreover, the funding council's methodology for calculating achievement counts each qualification separately. A student passing two out of three A-levels is attributed a 67% success rate - although many would regard two A-levels as a considerable success.

The implication that 100% success is attainable is both unrealistic and probably undesirable. The figures beg the question of what would be a reasonable expectation for performance. Some comparisons with other sectors are instructive, if only because the first thing they demonstrate is how far further education is ahead of almost every other education and training sector in measuring performance. The comparisons which the National Audit Office report makes are impossible for schools, simply because there is no systematic collection of the necessary data. Limited data suggest that completion rates for A-level students in schools - about 88% - are almost identical to those for both general further education and sixth-form colleges.

Higher education comparisons are similarly difficult, but the Higher Education Funding Council's data show that despite much greater selectivity in recruitment and higher levels of prior attainment, full-time degree course success rates average about 77%.

In contrast, comparison with work-based training shows further education in a substantially more favourable light. Even with the rather less rigorous definition of success adopted for advanced modern apprenticeships, only 48% of those completing achieve the intended NVQ level 3. But modern apprenticeships are very popular with employers and regarded a great success. Is there not a paradox here?

No one would disagree that there is much room to improve present success rates, and that this must remain a priority for the foreseeable future. The National Audit Office report has made some valuable recommendations that will help colleges in tackling these issues. But it is plain that the further education sector achieves a great deal with learners who in many instances start from poor levels of attainment. In doing so, all the available evidence suggests success rates compare reasonably with those of other lifelong learning providers. So rather than adopting statistical comparisons based on an intrinsically flawed methodology, would it not be better for all the agencies involved to devote some of their energies to developing a more valid and consistent basis for assessing performance across all sectors of post-16 learning?

Dr John Brennan is director of further education development at the Association of Colleges.

webTitle: David Melville on the future of further education

fields.headline: Good times boy
fields.standfirst: As he steps down, the funding council chief tells  Peter Kingston that further education has had its heyday
fields.trailText: As he steps down, the funding council chief tells Peter Kingston that further education has had its heyday
fields.body:
One question remained unanswered as the dawn of the new learning and skills era loomed closer. What was David Melville going to do?

Since before Christmas other big names in the Further Education Funding Council had been taking up invitations to join the new show or not.

But when the passing weeks brought no answer about the top man's intentions this only heightened the sense, which inevitably comes with revolution, that the ancien régime was somehow discredited and to be written out of history.

Now, in the final days of his command, it is announced that Professor Melville is returning to universities. He is not going back to the magnetic properties of blood - his research area as physics professor at Southampton University two decades ago. He is to be vice-chancellor of Kent University, and he is clearly excited by the prospect. And no, he declares, he is not in the least cross about the demise of his demesne.

Far from it, he says with a smile. After all, who was it who had told the government that the post-16 sector needed to be completely reorganised in the first place?

"I proposed this rationalisation a long time ago because it became obvious to me that we had two bodies - the TECs and the funding council - and two funding streams.

"They were overlapping, they weren't doing things in the same way, and there was difficulty tracking the students.

"Bringing them together in a single body made a lot of sense."

Nevertheless, the turkey which votes for Christmas does not necessarily believe things are going to get better.

"I have a letter in my briefcase from a college principal," Melville says. The gist of it is that the funding council's lifespan coincided with the sector's best days.

"People will look back on it as being the golden age for further education."

This is not intended as a boast but it is said with obvious pride.

"If you think about it, it covers the period when the colleges were given their freedom from local education authority control."

He accepts the apprehension in the wind that the learning and skills set- up will bring back more local control and open up opportunities for intervention in colleges' affairs.

"That's not my opinion," he says before adding "but I think it was a golden age. It was the first time that colleges were brought together and thought of themselves as a sector.

"The first time they were inspected in the same way. The first time they had common funding."

The full benefits of this last point may not have been instantly obvious to all 450-odd colleges at the time.

Did it feel like a golden age to him at the time?

"I would say I've enjoyed almost all of it."

The best of it for him has been taking policy and funding decisions which have benefited thousands of students. And the growth of the beast.

"Each year there are nearly a million more students in further education than there were when the council started."

And he has enjoyed visiting colleges. Either that or it has been a peculiar penance, because he has been to more than 300.

"I set a target to visit one or two colleges a week and I've averaged two a week over the four years."

Over most of that time he has felt the added buzz of a government which is serious about further education.

"The thing that's distinguished this government is that it's seen a purpose for further education in its broad agenda." The proof of this came in the first grant letter David Blunkett sent him. This annual missive from secretary of state for education to the funding council chief lays out the money that's coming, the student numbers that are required and the priorities.

"Under the Tories the letter was about a page and a quarter. The first letter from Blunkett was 14 pages."

This would confirm some people's suspicions of Labour's interventionist instincts. Melville doesn't demur at the suggestion.

"If the government is becoming more prescriptive I believe that that's a natural consequence of increasing investment: the government wanting something for something."

He has no problem with that because he senses that Labour and the sector broadly want the same things. For example, the government took on the Kennedy report on widening participation, "Learning Works", which was commissioned by the funding council.

So. What has happened under his stewardship which ought to have happened, and what not?

First the good things: the creation of a sector, common approaches to information gathering and inspection, self-assessment by colleges, recognition of the best colleges by the "accreditation" scheme.

He pauses mid-list and remembers more: "A huge improvement in buildings - 26% of all buildings in the whole of the sector have been either rebuilt or refurbished."

It's a telling statistic, not just for the amount of scaffolding it represents but because it symbolises the near obsession with measurement that now grips further education.

Melville cheerfully admits that his manor has become by far the most measured of the three education sectors with its atomised funding system and thrice-yearly censuses on student numbers.

It means that the Commons public accounts committee, for instance, can more easily swing its boot into further education than into schools or higher, because it has the data. It meant that when the Halton College scandal erupted, funding council auditors were able to go back five years into its records and tot up that £10m should be clawed back.

The college scandals which have made headlines such as Halton and Bilston have been among Melville's obvious disappointments. They have tarnished the sector's image, he accepts, but they have been a very small minority.

In September, when, after a decent break sailing his boat, he takes up his post at Canterbury, he will be the first person to have made the transition from a former polytechnic - he was vice-chancellor of Middlesex university before the funding council job -to an "old" university. He is not going there with any intention of tacking comfortably to retirement.

He wants to be in the vanguard of what he sees as the next big development in widening participation. It was a similar instinct - that further education's time had arrived - which lured him from his previous vice-chancellor's job to the funding council.

After scanning the field with care, he decided that Kent University would be the ideal pioneer for a venture which "pushes collaboration to the limits".

Within easy reach of the university there are: Christ Church College, Canterbury, a higher education institution with an excellent reputation, the Kent Institute of Art and Design, and two further education colleges.

"I think the future lies in what I call the 'multiversity'," he says.

"There's a model to be created of a new kind of conglomerate university."

It's a telling statistic, not just for the amount of scaffolding it represents but because it symbolises the near obsession with measurement that now grips further education. Melville cheerfully admits that his manor has become by far the most measured of the three education sectors with its atomised funding system and thrice-yearly censuses on student numbers. It means that the Commons public accounts committee, for instance, can more easily swing its boot into further education than into schools or higher, because it has the data. It meant that when the Halton College scandal erupted, funding council auditors were able to go back five years into its records and tot up that £10m should be clawed back. The college scandals which have made headlines such as Halton and Bilston have been among Melville's obvious disappointments. They have tarnished the sector's image, he accepts, but they have been a very small minority. In September, when, after a decent break sailing his boat, he takes up his post at Canterbury, he will be the first person to have made the transition from a former polytechnic - he was vice-chancellor of Middlesex university before the funding council job -to an "old" university. He is not going there with any intention of tacking comfortably to retirement. He wants to be in the vanguard of what he sees as the next big development in widening participation. It was a similar instinct - that further education's time had arrived - which lured him from his previous vice-chancellor's job to the funding council. After scanning the field with care, he decided that Kent University would be the ideal pioneer for a venture which "pushes collaboration to the limits". Within easy reach of the university there are: Christ Church College, Canterbury, a higher education institution with an excellent reputation, the Kent Institute of Art and Design, and two further education colleges. "I think the future lies in what I call the 'multiversity'," he says. "There's a model to be created of a new kind of conglomerate university."

webTitle: First major survey shows that new curriculum is a hit with students

fields.headline: We want to work
fields.standfirst: First major survey shows that new curriculum is a hit with students. By  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: First major survey shows that new curriculum is a hit with students. By Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Student drop-out rates in further education colleges appear to have fallen since the launch of Curriculum 2000.

The heavier workload involved, far from causing more 16- and 17-year-olds to give up, as some feared, seems to be having the opposite effect.

According to the biggest survey of the new curriculum since its introduction last September, colleges are reporting nearly a 10% boost in retention rates over the same term last year.

In nine out of 10 colleges, students have seized the opportunity offered by the reforms to take up the wider choice of studies.

"What is clear from this, the largest of the surveys done into the workings of Curriculum 2000, is that it's the further education sector which is leading the way in its development," said Maggie Scott, the Association of Colleges' quality adviser, who carried out the study.

"Curriculum 2000 has had a very, very good start."

Despite the survey's evidence of student enthusiasm for the reforms, there remains uncertainty because of universities' reticence in making clear their attitude about them.

"It's the Ivy League of our universities that need to give a much clearer indication of their views of the broader curriculum."

The Curriculum 2000 Initial Implementation survey canvassed all the Association of College's member institutions. Returns came from 151 colleges, 35% of the sector.

The most significant post-16 curriculum changes in a generation are intended, at one end of the student spectrum, to broaden the typical three A-level experience for university entrance. Students can now take four or five AS-levels in their first year, narrowing down to three or four A-levels in their second.

It also offers opportunities to mix vocational and academic courses to a much wider extent than before.

Where a student's main subjects don't cover maths, English and information technology they are encouraged to take "key skills" courses in these areas.

Ministers have pushed the reforms as a means of providing a more rounded education, while making young people better equipped for a wider range of job opportunities than before.

Scott says that her survey shows that the take-up of the key skills options has been more wholehearted in colleges than in schools, where the early evidence suggests a wait-and-see attitude.

Roughly a third of students have chosen to broaden their range of subjects by doing the extra course(s) outside their core arts or science package.

A third are enhancing their existing package of subjects. And nearly a third again are doing key skills on top of what they would have done last year. Only 3% of students are pursuing a similar package to what was offered in the past. Some subjects have proved so popular as the extras that they have significantly exceeded planned provision.

In a quarter of colleges, the demand for psychology has exceeded forecasts, and in a fifth of colleges more students than expected wanted to do IT and computing.

The demand for science was greater than predicted in 12% of the colleges, and in nearly a third of the tertiary colleges in the sample.

webTitle: Lecturing agency is drawn into crisis at troubled college

fields.headline: Tangled web
fields.standfirst: Lecturing agency is drawn into crisis at troubled college. By  Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Lecturing agency is drawn into crisis at troubled college. By Francis Beckett
fields.body:
The company which owns the largest lecturing agency in the country, Education Lecturing Services (ELS), purchased one of the tangled web of companies set up by the troubled Barnsley College, where the Further Education Funding Council is to conduct a forensic audit. In August last year, just before two other companies run by Barnsley College went into liquidation, a third company was sold to Protocol Associates, which owns ELS.

A bewildering array of companies was set up under the direction of college chief executive David Eade. Eade has been off work for several months following a serious operation, and last week the college stated that it terminated his contract because of his illness.

By last summer, the companies were beginning to prove a serious embarrassment to the college. Their investments included £21,000 to set up a surfing magazine run by Eade's stepchildren, and £1.3m in Barnsley-based Sheldale Water, which produces bottled water.

Barnsley College is one of ELS's biggest customers. About a third of Barnsley's courses are taught by ELS-supplied teachers - one of the highest proportions of ELS teachers of any college in the country. The company which the college sold to ELS's parent company is Barnsley-based Step Direct, which offers training in retail skills. This makes it, at least potentially, a competitor to Barnsley College. It means that Protocol owns one company which supplies a third of all Barnsley College's teaching hours; and it owns another company which competes directly with Barnsley College. This does not seem to be a good deal for the publicly-funded college. Getting your staff from your main competitor is not normally considered clever commercial practise, since your main competitor does not have a vested interest in your success. But Protocol denies that it has any conflict of interest, because "ELS and our training division, which includes Step Direct, are entirely separate companies" according to Protocol's Richard Eve.

The college expects a £6m shortfall in its budget this year. The liquidators of one of its companies are to claim about £1.5m from the college. To offset against this, the liquidators believe the bankrupt company owes the college £256,000. The funding council will be claiming £5.9m which the college is said to have overclaimed.

Nonetheless, some of the money from the sale seems to have gone into the creation of yet more companies, even though the previous companies had failed and the college was piling up debts. Late last year the college set up Axion Services with £50,000, and Axion's managing director Allan Child, a former college employee, has told Natfhe officials that Axion is buying one of the college's bankrupt companies from the liquidator for £60,000. Over the last five years the college has put at least £10m of public money through its various companies.

Sergeant Mick Dransfield of the South Yorkshire CID says: "A number of allegations have been made to us about the college and its associated companies and we are awaiting the result of the forensic audit." He had hoped that the forensic audit would be completed by now, but the funding council is still in the process of tendering for a company to conduct it. The company will be appointed within the next two weeks.

The college's acting chief executive, Michelle Squires, and another senior manager were suspended on February 5, and the funding council has told the governors to bring in an experienced principal from another college to sort the college out in the short term. In principal the governors can choose whomever they like. In practice the funding council will make sure a safe pair of hands is appointed.

Branch secretary Paul Heggie is furious about the delay in the appointment of an acting chief executive and the forensic audit.

Natfhe general secretary Paul Mackney says Barnsley College fits a pattern. Eade's £101,000 salary was the second highest of any college principal in Britain, and the college had said it could not meet in full the lecturers' pay rise.

"Sadly, in further education four things often go together: feline obesity at the top, no pay rise for staff, heavy use of agency staff, and commercial ventures which display a cavalier attitude to public money."

Mr Eade is unavailable for comment and the college had no comment to make.

webTitle: New pages from Anne Frank's Diary reveal family conflict

fields.headline: New pages from Anne Frank's Diary reveal family conflict
fields.trailText: Five previously un-published pages from Anne Frank's Diary, which were released yesterday, throw new light on the state of her parents' marriage and the troubled relationship she had with her mother. The hand-written pages, part of a new edition of the famous book, have been kept hidden for over 40 years.
fields.body:
Five previously un-published pages from Anne Frank's Diary, which were released yesterday, throw new light on the state of her parents' marriage and the troubled relationship she had with her mother. The hand-written pages, part of a new edition of the famous book, have been kept hidden for over 40 years.

The additional pages reveal Anne's concerns about her parents' marriage as she laments that they were not in love and that their marriage, which seemed perfect on the outside, was simply a marriage of convenience. Anne also portrays her mother, Edith, as having "cold eyes" and complains that it is difficult to talk to her.

The pages were released for publication three years ago after a close friend of Anne's father revealed that Otto Frank had given him the pages before his death in 1980 with clear instructions not to publish them until he and his second wife were both dead. A complex legal dispute over copyright delayed publication until now.

Anne began her diary in June 1942, whilst confined in a tiny attic with her family in Amsterdam to evade the Nazis, and her last entry was on August 1 1944, three days before they were discovered. She and her sister, Margot, died of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in the spring of 1945.

Otto Frank never concealed the fact that the original published diary was incomplete. He acknowledged that he omitted to include passages which he thought might be offensive to people still living and refused to include remarks about his wife "that didn't concern anyone else."

The Diary of Anne Frank has sold 25 million copies in 55 languages since it was first printed in 1947.

fields.trailText: • The government is determined to improve the quality of social care - it plans to monitor and assess how standards are rising through a new system of regulation and inspection.
fields.body:
 The government is determined to improve the quality of social care - it plans to monitor and assess how standards are rising through a new system of regulation and inspection.

 Key pieces of legislation include the Care Standards Act 2000 in England and Wales, the health and social services bill in Northern Ireland and the regulation of care (Scotland) bill in Scotland.

 Three separate organisations will be set up in England, Scotland and Wales to regulate the workforce.

 Four organisations will be set up in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to regulate services.

 Concerns have been voiced about how these and other regulatory or inspection bodies will work together.

fields.headline: Disney spares Go.com
fields.trailText:
Disney has reversed its decision to axe its Go.com portal, reports Amy Vickers.

Mar 1: Disney slashes web jobs

Feb 6: Disney suffers online losses

Jan 30: Disney pulls plug on Go.com
fields.body:
Disney has reversed its decision to axe Go.com, just weeks after it announced the portal would fall victim to the internet division's widespread cost cutting. It is thought the u-turn came about because Disney executives realised the traffic-driving strengths of Go.com far outweighed the value of shutting it down and selling the snappy domain name. Rather than closing the website, Disney will maintain the site using a former rival's technology to power its search engine and use it to showcase Disney content.

However, Disney will not make any further investment in the portal.

Disney has now quietly relaunched the site, replacing its articles and powerful Infoseek search engine with links to content on other Disney-owned sites.

Search engine technology from former rival GoTo.com has been integrated into Go.com.

Disney last year lost a copyright-infringement lawsuit to GoTo.com and was forced to pay its rival $21.5m.

Now it seems the dispute - which centred on their logos - has been put behind them. In the past few months, Disney has been busily laying off staff.

To date, it has axed more than 550 workers and observers predict another round of cuts as Disney redefines its new media strategy.
