fields.headline: Reaction to Milburn's proposals
fields.trailText: Reaction to the health secretary, Alan Milburn's, proposals.
fields.body:
Reaction to the health secretary, Alan Milburn's, proposals.

British Medical Association
The BMA claimed the move reflected the success of its campaign to persuade ministers to acknowledge the staffing crisis in GP practices. It said: "The government is now acknowledging that there are serious and long-standing problems in GP recruitment and retention."

Royal College of Nursing
Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "For many nurses, the only thing preventing them returning to nursing has been the lack of financial support while they are on essential return to practice courses. Providing £1,000 for each nurse will go a long way towards addressing this problem."

Royal College of General Practioners
Professor Mike Pringle, chairman of the RCGP, said: "We welcome the government's recognition of the problems recruiting and retaining GPs but this should only be seen as a first step and a lot more needs to be done to get staff numbers to where they should be."

Unison
Unison head of nursing Karen Jennings said while the increase for student nurse bursaries was "a step in the right direction", the rise was equivalent to just 11p an hour - from £2.60 to £2.71. She added: "Although many students will welcome the extra cash, Unison wants to see an increase to above the minimum wage."

The Conservative Party
The shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, said: "If Labour seriously wishes to increase recruitment, Alan Milburn should get off doctors' backs and allow them to spend more time seeing patients and less filling in forms.

"When it comes to nurses, the government is guilty of rank hypocrisy.

"In his evidence to the nurses' pay review body, Alan Milburn stated that there was no need for a pay increase on the grounds of recruitment problems. Three months later, he is admitting that the opposite is the case. Even by Labour's standards, today's announcement is an astonishing attempt at deception."

webTitle: European media on foot and mouth

fields.headline: 'Farmers hold their breath'
fields.standfirst:
As the first case of foot and mouth is confirmed in France, Gwyn Topham and Kate Connolly assess press reports from France and Germany
Special report: foot & mouth
fields.trailText:
As the first case of foot and mouth is confirmed in France, Gwyn Topham and Kate Connolly assess press reports from France and Germany
Special report: foot & mouth
fields.body:
The media view: France

For Le Monde, foot and mouth - "la fièvre aphteuse" - is the latest in a series of disasters: "mad cows, oil slicks, rail accidents, foot and mouth". But while these may not appear to be linked, Yves Mamou argues that closer examination reveals they share a common cause. Namely, a desire for profitability that pushes operators to cut costs - safety costs - to increase their margins.

Foot and mouth is no exception. The epidemic, he says, arose partly as the consequence of a cost calculation. Quoting the European commission's website, he says vaccination was abandoned in 1991 "because the European community had succeeded in eradicating the disease. This decision represented a saving of over 1bn euros."

In a Q&A published in Le Figaro before the first French case was confirmed, Marie-Christine Tabet asks why there are so many precautions in place. With the government having instigated drastic measures, she says, it's all as if France really is contaminated.

It is a "political decision": the French ministry of agriculture has "opened its umbrella to the maximum", rather than contenting itself with normal disease surveillance.

Prophetically she asks: "Can one conclude that the government is hiding a more serious reality - that of full-blown cases of disease - ahead of the municipal elections"? Farmers suspect that test results on animals could have been delivered far sooner.

Today, as the French press concentrates on the outcome of nationwide elections, the first case has been confirmed.

The media view: Germany

"German farmers are holding their breath," said the lunchtime news broadcast of television channel ARD. "They're looking westwards with fear, hoping they're not going to be the next culprits," following the discovery of the first case of foot and mouth virus over the border in neighbouring France.

Other news channels were studying the direction of wind currents in an attempt to assess the chance of the disease finding its way via air to Germany.

According to the German news agency DPA, the spokesman for the agricultural ministry of the state of Lower Saxony, Hanns-Dieter Rosinka, warned people not to celebrate prematurely. Earlier, tests on 99 calves on a farm near Hanover showing symptoms of fever and foaming mouths proved negative. Experts later concluded the animals had herpes.

"The danger is far from over," Rosinka said. "After the outbreak in western France it has in fact increased significantly." He added that the virus could be carried in a huge variety of ways: via letters, packages, car tyres or the soles of shoes, and therefore Germany was in grave danger.

Yesterday airports in Germany were continuing to insist on travellers from Britain walking over disinfected mats, and having their bags checked for sandwiches and packs of bacon. According to Spiegel magazine's online site, a further suspicious case in Schleswig-Holstein has been cleared, following tests on 60 pigs, but in North Friesland, a single pig has been the cause of concern after demonstrating foot and mouth-like symptoms.

Even before the continent's first case came to light, the Tagespiegel was celebrating the advances made by 'Green alternatives' in the French elections.

"Environmental themes are becoming ever more important in France, as the BSE crisis has shown," the paper said, indicating that Germany, with its Green agricultural minister, Renate Künast, is hoping to find a new ally in France in order to strengthen a lobby within the European Union which is pushing for a change in farming methods.

Today's German papers came out too late to report France's first case of the virus. But they were full, nevertheless, of articles on foot and mouth and concerns over BSE which hit the country in November and has devastated the beef industry.

"BSE is endangering 40,000 meat industry work places," blared Die Welt in a headline story on its economy pages. Head of the national union of the German food industry, Peter Traumann, told the paper: "BSE is the most serious crisis that we've ever experienced - even more serious than Chernobyl." The demand for beef has slumped by 67 per cent, the paper continues. Such an already beleaguered meat industry could hardly bear the fall-out a foot and mouth incident would undoubtedly cause.

Meanwhile the tabloid Bild concentrated its coverage on the plight of a flock of sheep close to Berlin. Three sheep were killed and another broke its leg after a sport plane ran out of fuel and crash-landed into them at the weekend. "I felt sorry most of all for the sheep," the 58-year old pilot said. "They've got enough problems at the moment as it is."

fields.bodyText: The media view: France For Le Monde, foot and mouth - "la fièvre aphteuse" - is the latest in a series of disasters: "mad cows, oil slicks, rail accidents, foot and mouth". But while these may not appear to be linked, Yves Mamou argues that closer examination reveals they share a common cause. Namely, a desire for profitability that pushes operators to cut costs - safety costs - to increase their margins. Foot and mouth is no exception. The epidemic, he says, arose partly as the consequence of a cost calculation. Quoting the European commission's website, he says vaccination was abandoned in 1991 "because the European community had succeeded in eradicating the disease. This decision represented a saving of over 1bn euros." In a Q&A published in Le Figaro before the first French case was confirmed, Marie-Christine Tabet asks why there are so many precautions in place. With the government having instigated drastic measures, she says, it's all as if France really is contaminated. It is a "political decision": the French ministry of agriculture has "opened its umbrella to the maximum", rather than contenting itself with normal disease surveillance. Prophetically she asks: "Can one conclude that the government is hiding a more serious reality - that of full-blown cases of disease - ahead of the municipal elections"? Farmers suspect that test results on animals could have been delivered far sooner. Today, as the French press concentrates on the outcome of nationwide elections, the first case has been confirmed. The media view: Germany "German farmers are holding their breath," said the lunchtime news broadcast of television channel ARD. "They're looking westwards with fear, hoping they're not going to be the next culprits," following the discovery of the first case of foot and mouth virus over the border in neighbouring France. Other news channels were studying the direction of wind currents in an attempt to assess the chance of the disease finding its way via air to Germany. According to the German news agency DPA, the spokesman for the agricultural ministry of the state of Lower Saxony, Hanns-Dieter Rosinka, warned people not to celebrate prematurely. Earlier, tests on 99 calves on a farm near Hanover showing symptoms of fever and foaming mouths proved negative. Experts later concluded the animals had herpes. "The danger is far from over," Rosinka said. "After the outbreak in western France it has in fact increased significantly." He added that the virus could be carried in a huge variety of ways: via letters, packages, car tyres or the soles of shoes, and therefore Germany was in grave danger. Yesterday airports in Germany were continuing to insist on travellers from Britain walking over disinfected mats, and having their bags checked for sandwiches and packs of bacon. According to Spiegel magazine's online site, a further suspicious case in Schleswig-Holstein has been cleared, following tests on 60 pigs, but in North Friesland, a single pig has been the cause of concern after demonstrating foot and mouth-like symptoms. Even before the continent's first case came to light, the Tagespiegel was celebrating the advances made by 'Green alternatives' in the French elections. "Environmental themes are becoming ever more important in France, as the BSE crisis has shown," the paper said, indicating that Germany, with its Green agricultural minister, Renate Künast, is hoping to find a new ally in France in order to strengthen a lobby within the European Union which is pushing for a change in farming methods. Today's German papers came out too late to report France's first case of the virus. But they were full, nevertheless, of articles on foot and mouth and concerns over BSE which hit the country in November and has devastated the beef industry. "BSE is endangering 40,000 meat industry work places," blared Die Welt in a headline story on its economy pages. Head of the national union of the German food industry, Peter Traumann, told the paper: "BSE is the most serious crisis that we've ever experienced - even more serious than Chernobyl." The demand for beef has slumped by 67 per cent, the paper continues. Such an already beleaguered meat industry could hardly bear the fall-out a foot and mouth incident would undoubtedly cause. Meanwhile the tabloid Bild concentrated its coverage on the plight of a flock of sheep close to Berlin. Three sheep were killed and another broke its leg after a sport plane ran out of fuel and crash-landed into them at the weekend. "I felt sorry most of all for the sheep," the 58-year old pilot said. "They've got enough problems at the moment as it is." What's going on? fields.body:
Anthea Turner is facing a second eviction ordeal after being nominated again for removal from the Celebrity Big Brother house.

The former GMTV presenter will have to endure another public popularity contest, according to the programme's website.

Four contestants remain in the house following Vanessa Feltz's eviction, which viewers can see on Channel 4 and BBC 1 tonight.

Turner was nominated by Boyzone hunk Keith Duffy and grumpy comedian Jack Dee.

But she will be vying with Duffy and Dee for eviction - the popstar was the least favourite in the house with three votes while Dee received two nominations - one of them from Turner.

Brookside's Claire Sweeney received just one nomination and is now favourite to be the winner in the Comic Relief grand finale on Friday.

Although the latest round of nominations took place last night, the three celebrities will have to wait until tomorrow night to hear which one of them will follow former daytime TV host Vanessa out of the Celebrity Big Brother house.

The phone lines will be open for 24 hours from 9.30pm tonight. Viewers will not know of Anthea's latest ordeal until the programme is screened tonight.

So far the eviction phone lines have raised £224,000 for Comic Relief.

Turner may survive on a public sympathy vote. She has already been nominated for eviction and looked on the verge of tears when she learned the news.

In the event her rival Chris Eubank received more votes from the 750,000 calls made to the eviction line on the first night.

Last night, Dee survived his first eviction nomination when Feltz was voted out.

Prior to the announcement of her eviction, viewers saw the strain getting to Ms Feltz, who burst into tears and scribbled the words "incarcerated" and "frustrated" on a table in chalk.

She appeared at the end of the her tether and was then summoned into the house diary room where she told Big Brother to "fuck off".

Once in the diary room, Ms Feltz told the cameras: "I don't think I can possibly endure the mass humiliation of everybody hating me so much - however many people voted and said 'fuck off Vanessa'."

Following the announcement of Feltz's eviction, Jack Dee visited the diary room and asked if the next vote could be fixed so he could leave the Big Brother house.

But he was told "Big Brother cannot rig the election."

fields.headline: The Guardian Graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: This week the Association of Graduate Recruiters reported that the recruitment of grads over the internet doubled last year and two thirds of employers intend to use the web to lure the best students into work next year. With that in mind, here is this week's Email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.
fields.body:
This week the Association of Graduate Recruiters reported that the recruitment of grads over the internet doubled last year and two thirds of employers intend to use the web to lure the best students into work next year. With that in mind, here is this week's Email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

As usual, we take a look at the best graduate jobs offered by Jobs Unlimited - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies. We also review last Saturday's Rise and get a look at next week's issue. In addition we've included a link to a past article featured in Rise that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold.

If you were too busy surfing the web to get to the newsagent, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday March 10)

Are you a potential psychopath at work? If you think you might be, or you want to know how to detect one at interview, take a look at Hilary Freeman's chilling dissection of work place bullies. Be afraid, be very afraid.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,449356,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Last week's Sixty Seconds talked to the man tasked with designing the interiors of Virgin's new tilting trains, and there was a look at student counselling and how it can keep you on the straight and narrow when the going gets tough.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,449359,00.html?bnr=email.grad

NEXT WEEK'S RISE (Saturday March 17) follows one group of people who all did the same degree but ended up in different careers. It looks at how to persuade you employer to let you share your job with another, and there is our definitive guide to all the postgraduate courses around the country.

This week's RISE GOLD is a look at teaching from a slightly different angle. With Chris Woodhead doing his best to keep the profession in the news, Miles Brignall talked to some people who took up teaching after pursuing other, less rewarding careers.

http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3969991,00.html?bnr=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP

If you are reading this then you probably do it already, but the advice of the week has got be start searching the web for that vacancy. Employers are actively moving graduate recruitment into cyber space - make sure you're on top of what's happening out there, and if you're not, get some advice.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS

Music for Nations, the UK's largest independent music group (no I've never heard of them either), wants a graduate to work as press officer. Rather worryingly, they want someone with a sense of humour.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108133,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Aviation Industry Conferences is looking for someone to do exactly what it says on the tin: help it run conferences for the aviation industry. Only one problem, it pays £16K and is based in central London, so you do the maths.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108102,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you always harboured a dream to go to Oxford but didn't have the points, Elsevier Science is looking for an editorial assistant in the spired city to work on its scientific and technical journals. If you're still reading at this point, the job's probably yours.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888107952,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you've always wanted to teach English but you couldn't be arsed to do a TEFL course, your prayers have been answered. A Japanese language school wants to fly you out there to teach around 32 hours a week.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108399,00.html?bnr=email.grad

The University of California is looking for a programme officer to be based at its new site in, wait for it, Bloomsbury, London. While there's no trip to LA, you do get to help manage the exchange programme and up to £22,000.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108331,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If the thought of big money turns you on, Pacific Continental Securities is looking for grads to join its equities department advising clients on their investments. You could be earning £60K at this US bank.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108115,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Continuing the financial theme, Zurich Financial Services is looking to fast-track graduates into any one of its various organisations and it's claiming you could end up working virtually anywhere in the world. Several roles, all requiring a 2:1 or better.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108095,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you have an excellent knowledge of classical music plus some secretarial skills, the Philharmonia Orchestra wants to appoint you as full time assistant to its Development Department - although it doesn't actually say what the department actually does.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888108046,00.html?bnr=email.grad

And finally, Birmingham-based book publisher Friends Of seeks determined self-starters of graduate calibre to join its expanding editorial team, to help produce books on all aspects of web design. It's promising editors jobs in the future.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888107668,00.html?bnr=email.grad

webTitle: UK net traffic reaches record high

fields.headline: UK net traffic reaches record high
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: UK internet traffic has reached a landmark peak figure of six gigabits per second, according to figures published by the country's main internet exchange.
fields.body:
UK internet traffic has reached a landmark peak figure of six gigabits per second, according to figures published by the country's main internet exchange.

The London Internet Exchange (Linx), which records internet traffic data on a continuing basis, handles more than 90% of the UK internet's traffic flow. Its figure of 6 Gb/s is equivalent to 360,000 emails being sent every second.

The figure represents an increase of 20% on the peak traffic flow for January 2001, and is double that for June 2000.

"This entirely predicted rise has been attributed to both the steady growth in the number of internet users and each individual user's increasing demand for internet content," a spokesman said.

Chris Fletcher, head of technical development for the exchange, said there was no substantial increase in the rate of traffic growth. "We are not seeing a huge increase in growth," he said. "But it is a huge amount of traffic."

The rise in use of unmetered internet access has undoubtedly had an effect on the figures. But Mr Fletcher added there would have to be substantial growth in the take-up of ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) broadband technology before its effect would be reflected in UK traffic figures.

Traffic levels would also increase slightly over time as more ISPs signed up to the exchange, Mr Fletcher said.

At the moment, traffic peaks between about 2pm and 9pm GMT. Figures for the last 24 hours show traffic peaking at about 6.3 Gb/s at about 5pm yesterday, and sinking to a low of about 2 Gb/s at 5am today.

Linx is a non-profit partnership between ISPs, which provides a physical connection through which its members can exchange traffic. It publishes its internet traffic data on its website at http://ochre.linx.net/.

A Guardian/ICM poll in January showed that 49% of all British adults had access to the internet, either at home or at work.

fields.headline: Alli's radio bid offers Time Out
fields.trailText:
5pm: Lord Waheed Alli's London digital radio licence bid includes a service supplied by Time Out magazine, writes Jason Deans.
Feb 7: Labour peer bids for digital radio licence
fields.body:
The London digital radio licence bid backed by Lord Waheed Alli has unveiled an 11-station proposal including a service supplied by listings magazine Time Out.

The Digital Radio Group bid, which is chaired by Lord Alli and also backed by a consortium including GWR, Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group and SMG, will offer entertainment and information service Time Out Live.

Other services in the DRG London digital radio bid include children's format AbracaDABra, Chrysalis adult rock format the Arrow and Liquid, a current and chart music station from Virgin.

The DRG line-up also features the Storm, a GWR pop and rock music format, and services aimed at London's Asian and student communities.

Today is the final deadline for submissions for the third London digital radio multiplex licence.

A decision is expected from the Radio Authority in the summer.

fields.headline: PR industry faces outside threat
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: The UK PR industry has been warned it is under threat from other businesses offering PR advice, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The UK public relations industry is under attack from management consultants and accountants offering PR advice, new Institute of Public Relations president Ian Wright has warned in his inaugural speech.

Mr Wright, Diageo group communications director, called on the industry to unite in order to fend off the threat from other businesses intent on offering PR and communications advice themselves or acquiring agencies in order to do so.

His rallying cry comes as PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest professional services company, prepares to enter the PR arena by training its staff to offer PR advice to clients.

"Increasingly accountants and management consultants are set to move into the territory currently occupied by public relations professionals," said Mr Wright.

"They will do so by expanding their own operations, but they will also do so by acquisition.

"It is almost certain that in the next few months at least one - and probably more - of the consultancy networks will be acquired by a leading accountancy practice.

"When that happens our business will change forever," added Mr Wright.

He calls for the industry to present a united front under the IPR, the Public Relations Consultants Association and non-industry body members.

Mr Wright is IPR president for 2001. Prior to joining Diageo, he was director of communications for Boots the Chemist.

He also acted as press spokesperson to Paddy Ashdown during the 1997 general election and 1999 European election campaigns.

fields.headline: Milburn labelled a 'hypocrite' over spending plans
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has been branded a "hypocrite" after he unveiled a package of cash handouts to recruit scarce health workers just months after he declared that pay increases would not solve staffing problems. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has been branded a "hypocrite" after he unveiled a package of cash handouts to recruit scarce health workers just months after he declared that pay increases would not solve staffing problems.

The measures, which will cost £56m a year, aim to tackle shortages of GPs and nurses. The initiative follows chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget announcement of £135m for NHS recruitment.

Mr Milburn today announced a series of incentive payments to attract young doctors into general practice, persuade older GPs not to retire early and to boost the income of nurses in training.

The measures include one-off £5,000 "golden hello" payments to newly qualified GPs, with an extra £5,000 for those who take jobs in deprived areas, where staff shortages are most acute.

GPs nearing retirement age will receive a £10,000 "golden goodbye" if they agree to work up to their 65th birthday, while trainee nurses are to get an increase of between £200 and £500 in their student bursaries.

Mr Milburn said: "The initiatives I am announcing today will mean we can make an extra effort to recruit and retain the NHS doctors and nurses we need, as well as encouraging those who have left to return."

But the shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, accused Mr Milburn of "rank hypocrisy", pointing out that his evidence to the nurses pay review body last autumn argued that recruitment problems could be solved through non-pay measures, such as training and childcare provision.

He said: "In his evidence to the nurses' pay review body, Alan Milburn stated that there was no need for a pay increase on the grounds of recruitment problems.

"[Now] he is admitting that the opposite is the case. Even by Labour's standards, today's announcement is an astonishing attempt at deception."

The government's evidence to the doctors and dentists pay review body last September also played down staffing problems, declaring that "the overall recruitment and retention position (for doctors) remains healthy".

It also argued that money had little effect on GPs retirement intentions, claiming that "only 6% [of doctors] quote financial considerations as the reason" for leaving the service.

The government will argue that the cash handouts are "targeted measures" at problem areas, which will prove effective than across-the-board rises; but it is also an admission that its attempts to solve the NHS staffing crisis are in need of a boost.

Ministers know that the scheme is crucial to the government's ability to meet its own targets for increasing the numbers of staff in the NHS. The NHS plan, published last year pledged, an extra 20,000 nurses and 2,000 GPs for England by 2004. Under the scheme, ministers also hope to lure back former GPs who have left the profession with a £5,000 cash incentive.

There will be £1,000 and £1,500 bonus payments for qualified nurses, and midwives respectively who complete refresher courses to prepare them for a return to the NHS.

webTitle: Universities losing maths students by giving poor feedback

fields.headline: Unsolved equation
fields.standfirst: Universities are losing maths students by giving poor feedback, reports  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Universities are losing maths students by giving poor feedback, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
As many as two in three students are failing to complete some maths degree courses, quality watchdogs have warned. While many students bail out of courses because of rising debts, inspectors say that fewer students would drop out of universities and colleges if academics gave more feedback on course work.

Poor assessment procedures are the one major blemish for academic institutions, which have otherwise been given a clean bill of health for teaching standards in the latest tranche of subject reviews by the Quality Assurance Agency. The reviews summarise the findings of inspections carried out over the past two years, covering university departments in the medical sciences and biosciences, as well as physics, maths and art and design.

"Progression rates from first to second-level [year] averages 80%, with a maximum of 98% in the best case, but this masks disappointing rates at a number of institutions, where progression rates have been found to be as low as 30%," says the QAA's overview report on maths degree courses. The inspectors were told that many students drop out because they underestimate the challenge of studying university level mathematical subjects compared with A-levels. Others withdraw for personal reasons, often citing financial problems.

At the Bolton Institute of Higher Education, for example, only 34% of full-timers enrolled on maths courses in the mid-90s graduated. At Edge Hill College and Greenwich University just over half the students finish degree courses.

Among the universities criticised for high numbers of maths dropouts are City, Derby, De Montfort, Liverpool John Moores, London Guildhall, Middlesex, Manchester Metropolitan and Queen Mary, Royal Holloway, Goldsmiths and King's College, London.

At Liverpool John Moores, where a third of students fail to finish maths degree courses, the inspectors reported that "progression rates have declined worryingly in recent years". At Derby a quarter of students only managed to graduate after exam resits. And at King's College London reviewers highlighted disappointing completion rates and degree results.

A widespread problem is the need for remedial classes to bring students up to the level of university mathematics courses - a situation which has led many academics to question the school maths standards.

About one in six students drop out of degrees across the academic sector, as the higher education funding councils revealed last year when they published dropout rates for institu tions as a whole. But the QAA inspections are the only official source of information on dropout in individual departments.

Outside maths, the inspectors found that drop out rates are much lower in the other subject areas. But one recurring academic failing emerges from all the inspections: poor communication with students. Students are often found to be unsure of assessment criteria, and receive little feedback on their work.

QAA's chief executive, John Randall, said: "Overall the picture is one of institutions performing well, but where we do have concerns is weaknesses in academic assessment and feedback, which may lead to higher student dropout rates. The way that institutions assess students still leaves a lot to be desired."

Similar concerns led inspectors to conclude that some of England's top medical schools, including Oxford and Cambridge, are failing to provide the best possible training for future doctors.

The poor record on assessment procedures could dent academic ambitions for less intrusive quality inspections in the future. The QAA has already promised a "lighter touch" under a new system based on shorter visits to institutions. But there has also been talk of introducing less frequent inspections for universities with high standards of assessment.

The high dropout rates are likely to provide more ammunition to those calling for extra cash in universities to help retain students from non-traditional academic backgrounds. The inspections have revealed high numbers of dropouts from departments with students from poorer households.

Later this month MPs are expected to recommend more money for academics to help reduce the number of students failing to finish degrees.

fields.headline: Shell bypasses Barrett board
fields.trailText: Shell yesterday raised the stakes in its hostile $1.8bn (£1.2bn) bid for Barrett Resources by making a direct cash offer to shareholders. But there is increasing scepticism that the offer, described by Shell as final, will be enough.
fields.body:
Shell yesterday raised the stakes in its hostile $1.8bn (£1.2bn) bid for Barrett Resources by making a direct cash offer to shareholders. But there is increasing scepticism that the offer, described by Shell as final, will be enough.

The world's second-largest oil major, awash in profits from high crude prices, is offering $55 per share to win control of choice gas assets owned by the US target.

Last week the Barrett board rebuffed an approach by the Anglo-Dutch company and said it would ask Shell and others to submit improved terms for a takeover.

Shell said last night it was offering a "full and fair price" for the relatively small US company .

Walter van de Vijver, president and chief executive of Shell Exploration & Production, said: "We consider it a positive sign that [chairman and chief executive] Peter Dea and Barrett's board of directors have said they are considering strategic alternatives, but it is not clear that they are committed to the sale of the company.

"That is why Shell has chosen to take its offer directly to the Barrett shareholders rather than participate in the auction process proposed by Barrett's board."

Analysts said Shell might have set itself a difficult task given the recent increase in the Barrett's share price.

webTitle: Japanese PM calls early party elections

fields.headline: Japanese PM calls early party elections
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said today that the ruling party will move forward the date for its leadership elections, a step that will most likely hasten his departure from office.
fields.body:
The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said today that the ruling party will move forward the date for its leadership elections, a step that will most likely hasten his departure from office.

Pressure has been building on the highly unpopular prime minister to step down soon amid the nation's economic turmoil, and a member of his ruling coalition said he was willing to leave office within a month.

Mr Mori told a convention of his ruling Liberal Democratic party in Tokyo today that an election for party president would be held sooner than the previously scheduled one in September.

In a short speech, he said: "We will move up the party presidential election. We are discussing the timing and the way in which we will carry out that election."

Mr Mori has not said whether he would run for re-election as party president. Due to the party's power in parliament, the LDP party president is usually elected prime minister. If the election is moved, a vote could take place as soon as next month.

Mr Mori's support ratings are below 10%, and some LDP members are worried his unpopularity could hurt the party in upper house elections in July.

Meanwhile, Japan's media continued today with their calls for Mr Mori to quit. "We can't afford a political blank at a time when a deflationary crisis looms and the economy is in a crucial situation," the nation's largest newspaper, the Yomiuri, said in an editorial.

The party convention took place hours after opposition groups submitted an unsuccessful censure motion against the scandal-prone premier.

Kozo Tanaka, an LDP member and member of the Tokyo city assembly, said: "Mori has lost support within the party and naturally he should resign."

Mr Mori has said he wants to see the budget for the current fiscal year through parliament. Its passage is expected before the end of the month.

Opposition leaders grilled Mr Mori in parliament yesterday, saying confusion over whether he intends to step down has created a political vacuum. Mr Mori has been under fire almost constantly recently for a string of gaffes and scandals, which have already forced three of his ministers to resign. He has faced two no-confidence votes in the past five months.

However, no clear replacement for Mr Mori has emerged. Party stalwart Hiromu Nonaka is seen as a strong candidate, but has said he will not seek the office.

fields.headline: Viewers tune in to Vanessa's trauma
fields.trailText: 3.15pm TV overnights: Vanessa Feltz's tears attracted the largest audience yet for Celebrity Big Brother, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's Celebrity Big Brother continued to prove a top draw last night.

The biggest audience so far tuned in to watch Vanessa Feltz getting tearful as the eviction decision approached.

Celebrity Big Brother attracted 4.5m viewers and a 17% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

The Channel 4 show was broadcast between 9pm and 9.30pm.

It was followed by a 15-minute BBC1 repeat at 9.45pm, which pulled in 5.1m viewers.

New BBC1 detective drama the Inspector Lynley Mysteries opened respectably between 8.30pm and 9.45pm.

It was up against Airline and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? on ITV.

The drama was adapted from Elizabeth George's novels and starred Nathaniel Parker as the eponymous posh copper and Sharon Small as his working-class sidekick.

It attracted 7.7m viewers and gained a 30% share.

Meanwhile, Airline had 9.2m viewers and Millionaire pulled in 9.4m.

The Inspector Lynley Mysteries was given a boost by the continuing strength of EastEnders in the aftermath of Phil Mitchell's shooting. Last night, 14.4m tuned in to the soap.

Elsewhere, Channel 4's the Best of Borat, featuring Sacha Baron Cohen's Kazakhstani character, lost out to BBC2 sitcom Two Pints of Lager and a Packet of Crisps.

The Best of Borat gained 1.9m viewers and an 8% share while Two Pints drew 3m and 12% of the audience.

fields.headline: Premier profits from Burma stand
fields.trailText: Premier Oil's decision to defy British government demands and stay in military-run Burma has paid off. The company yesterday reported its first profits in three years.
fields.body:
Premier Oil's decision to defy British government demands and stay in military-run Burma has paid off. The company yesterday reported its first profits in three years.

Chief executive Charles Jamieson claimed the political climate in Burma was improving. He expressed "cautious optimism" that the future of the country would reduce pressure on Premier.

Production started from Premier's Yetagun gas project in Burma last May and it is now Premier's largest asset. Gas is moving from Burma by pipeline to Thailand.

Pre-tax profits on ordinary activities bounced to £17m in the year to December 31, compared with a £16.7m loss last time. Turnover rose from £89.5m to £115.7m.

Profits would have been higher if Premier had not been forced to put in place an oil price hedge at $19.54 per barrel when the average price over 2000 was $28.39.

The hedge was imposed by Amerada Hess and Petronas, its two major shareholders in return for an investment of £136m in November 1999.

Premier has also left nearly £12m of extra revenues out of its immediate turnover on the grounds they are part of a take-or-pay contract and therefore must be treated as debt for the time being.

Like other oil companies, Premier has increasingly switched its attention to gas and concentrated on south-east Asia. Its other major asset is in Indonesia where Premier has just brought on stream its West Natuna gas scheme six months ahead of schedule.

Mr Jamieson said the commercialisation of its Asian gas business, successful exploration work and a growing base of reserves put Premier in a strong position for the future.

Progress was also being made in talks with Amerada Hess and Petronas about in creasing shareholder value. These two companies hold 50% of Premier and effectively rule out any outside bid for it. This has held back the price of the company.

Recent speculation that US-based Amerada might sell down or out its 25% stake sent the share price up from 12p to 20p. It has since dropped back and ended the day down 0.75p at 17.75p. Mr Jamieson said various options were being looked at and he expected a decision before the end of the year.

Analysts said the Premier results were encouraging but they remained sceptical about talk of a corporate shake-up.

fields.headline: Princess Anne fined £400 for speeding
fields.trailText: Princess Anne was today convicted of speeding in her Bentley after admitting driving at 93mph in a 70mph zone in Gloucestershire. The princess was fined £400, ordered to pay £30 costs and given five penalty points on her driving licence.
fields.body:
Princess Anne was today convicted of speeding in her Bentley after admitting driving at 93mph in a 70mph zone in Gloucestershire. The princess was fined £400, ordered to pay £30 costs and given five penalty points on her driving licence.

In her written evidence to the magistrates court, the Princess Royal said she thought the police cars on her tail were providing her with an escort.

She said she had been on her way to an official engagement when she was caught in a line of slow-moving traffic on the A417 dual carriageway near Brockworth.

She said she had pulled out and accelerated to a clear part of the road so the officers could see her.

When a police car pulled out behind her and flashed its blue light, Princess Anne said she thought this was a sign acknowledging that the car was following her and carried on speeding.

The chairman of the bench, Graham Sacker, said: "We have taken into account Her Royal Highness's immediate guilty plea.

"This was an offence of average seriousness by a person of high means."

He added that the princess's clean driving licence had also been taken into account when considering a penalty.

A spokeswoman for Buckingham Palace said the princess accepted that she was subject to the normal rule of law. She will be paying her fine accordingly.

The princess has been in trouble with the law several times before for breaking the speed limit.

In November 1972 she was given a written police warning after being driving at between 80mph and 90mph on the M1. Thames Valley police decided not to prosecute.

On January 21 1977 the princess, then 26, was fined £40 at Alfreton Magistrates in Derbyshire for doing 96mph in a 70mph limit on the M1.

On October 22 1990 she was fined £150 and banned from driving for one month by magistrates in Stow-on-the-Wold, Gloucestershire, after admitting two speeding offences. On that occasion she claimed she was "late for an engagement".

The princess's daughter Zara, 19, overturned a Land Rover in December last year but escaped without serious injury.

fields.headline: e-district's numbers overstated
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The dot.com claims revenues may have been overstated by around £1.7m over a two-year period, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The fraud squad has been informed of further investigations at online entertainment service e-district after a preliminary probe by the company alleged the firm's revenues and user numbers had been exaggerated.

In a statement today, the company claims revenues may have been overstated by around £1.7m over a two-year period.

The results of the initial investigation, which was released to the Stock Exchange, alleged that documents claiming the company was making money were forged.

Initial reports claim that while the company's financial statements claimed revenues of £781,571 for the 17 months to the end of 1999, figures obtained from agents selling advertising suggest the actual figure was just £98,000.

There were also conflicting figures for the first half of last year.

Unaudited accounts report sales of just over £1m.

"Based solely on information obtained from the sales agencies during the investigation, these revenues were approximately £32,000," e-district said.

The company added there appeared to be a "substantial overstatement of registered users, page impressions and revenues".

The investigation follows just weeks after the sacking of chief executive Steven Laitman, who owns 44 % of the e-district shares.

Mr Laitman's assets have been frozen by the company but he is expected to contest the order.

He was not available for comment.

Internal figures suggested the company had 89,429 users in February and page impressions of 56.8m.

However, between May and June last year, page impressions fell from 150m to less than 9m.

As yet the company cannot explain the drastic drop.

The company has launched a civil action against Mr Laitman and said today it had reported its continuing investigations to the Metropolitan Police fraud squad.

fields.headline: Touch the Truck crashes in the ratings
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Channel 5's new gameshow Touch the Truck has crashed in the rating, writes Lisa O'Carroll
Useful link: Touch the Truck website
fields.body:
Channel 5's new gameshow Touch the Truck has crashed in the ratings.

After just one night, the reality game show fronted by Dale Winton is struggling with just 500,000 viewers and a miserly 2% of the audience.

It launched on Channel 5 on Sunday night with 1m viewers.

But up against EastEnders last night audience levels halved.

Channel 5 executives nevertheless hope it will take off in the ratings tonight.

The show, which has been adapted from an American shopping mall game, has intrigued and baffled viewers and critics alike.

In a competition reminiscent of the children's favourite "first-one-to-blink", it involves 20 contestants battling to keep their hands on a truck longest.

The last person touching the truck wins the vehicle.

Contestants are allowed food and toilet breaks but do not get time off for sleep.

All 20 participants survived to the second show. But overnight and this morning eight contestants have fallen.

The first to go was Sophie Braka, a lawyer turned dancer who knocked off her bottle of water and in a lapse of concentration removed her hand from the £33,000 truck.

Another of the eight was forced to retire because he needed an unscheduled toilet break. Colyn Caffrey was forced to take his hand off the truck to run to the toilet.

The Kent service engineer was told he was not allowed to relieve himself in a bowl or wet himself.

"I was busting for a pee for about 10 to 15 minutes," he said. "It's sickening to leave that truck behind me but I couldn't hold out anymore."

Another contestant has been eliminated after doctors found he had dangerously high blood pressure.

Favourite Tim Ashby said he could quite easily have continued but judges forced him to quit after medical advice.

The station has scheduled the programme until Thursday but will continue if the battle continues into Friday.

fields.headline: Terre'Blanche cooks up tourism fantasy
fields.standfirst: The South African neo-Nazi is dreaming of reinventing himself and his home town as visitor attractions. Fortunately, though, he is still in jail, writes Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: 13 March: The jailed South African neo-Nazi is trying to reinvent himself as visitor attraction, reports Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
Of all the reasons to lock up Eugene Terre'Blanche, the news that the neo-Nazi leader plans to turn himself into a tourist attraction had many people grateful that he is back in jail.

The founder and once feared "fuhrer" of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement (AWB), who once threatened a bloodbath if black people were allowed to rule South Africa, spent his first night in prison on Monday sharing a cell with a few dozen black men.

ET, as he is universally known in South Africa, was locked up after his thuggish past finally caught up with him. An appeal court upheld his conviction for the attempted murder five years ago of a black worker on his farm.

Paul Motshabi was left seriously brain damaged by the attack, which appears to have been for no other reason than Mr Terre'Blanche was in a temper.

There was a time when white men could murder black people and not spend a day in jail. No more.

Mr Terre'Blanche is beginning his second stint in prison after serving six months last year for assaulting a petrol pump attendant.

His arrest for attempting to murder Mr Motshabi established that the neo-Nazi leader did not have free rein to assault black people. In the five years since the arrest, Mr Terre'Blanche has watched his AWB crumble away as supporters proved to have little stomach for the fight against black rule.

Life was still too comfortable, even under the despised Nelson Mandela, to give up the swimming pool for a prison cell or a coffin.

But ET is not one to be discouraged. Forced out of the revolution business, he leapt into tourism. Mr Terre'Blanche planned to attract visitors to his tiny and, frankly, ugly little hometown by offering personalised introductions to Ventersdorp.

The AWB has long been the most interesting thing about the "dorp", as it's known in Afrikaans. The organisation's headquarters sits on the main street with a large steel eagle and its swastika-like badge hovering above the entrance.

But since the heady days of threatening revolution, Ventersdorp has been blessed with a black mayor who is not in the slightest bit intimidated by Mr Terre'Blanche's bluster.

In addition, much of the white population - tired of being vilified and lumped in with the AWB - are openly thankful that its intimidating grip on the town has been broken.

So ET had to drop the role of "fuhrer" in favour of offering tourists the chance to get to know a man who claims to be a true Boer. An exhibition - "The man and his history" - aimed to lay bare the full scope of Mr Terre'Blanche's struggle for the "volk", as ungrateful as they now seem.

Visitors were also to be treated to a barbecue with the AWB leader, and the opportunity of a ride with ET on his jet black horse, Raaf, meaning raven.

South Africans are well acquainted with Raaf after Terre'Blanche tumbled off the beast while leading a march through Pretoria. As the neo-Nazi leader went over his horse's head, the AWB's elite "Ystergard" or "Iron Guard" swarmed around him and tried to keep the cameras at bay.

But there were enough pictures on South African television news that night to pour more scorn on the AWB myth. The story had it that ET was drunk, a not uncommon occurrence (he favours brandy and Coke).

But the disturbing high point of the ET experience was to be the reading of the poetry he wrote during his last bout in jail.

Among the gems is "A letter to a friend", a futile plea that he is a victim of injustice. "They do not know what they are doing," it goes. "It is winter in my life again, and I long for the freedom of the farm."

Mr Terre'Blanche's many delusions included a belief that the appeal court would set him free. That did not happen and so disappointed tourists will have to wait a few years for the ET experience in Ventersdorp.

But if they are wondering how Eugene Terre'Blanche feels about his present predicament, they need only read his poetry. "Alone I feel in the iron cage Like a lone cattle on the farm."

webTitle: Kursk may remain in underwater grave

fields.headline: Kursk may remain in underwater grave
fields.standfirst:
The operation to raise the Kursk nuclear submarine has been postponed, raising fears that it may never happen, writes Amelia Gentleman

Special report: Kursk submarine
fields.trailText: The operation to raise the Kursk nuclear submarine has been postponed, raising fears that it may never happen, writes Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
The operation to raise the ravaged hull of the Kursk nuclear submarine from the bottom of the Barents Sea has been postponed, prompting fears that the salvage plan may be abandoned altogether.

The deputy prime minister of Russia, Ilya Klebanov, announced on Sunday that the project had been put back from a provisional start date in July until a later point, some time towards the end of summer or autumn.

Various reasons have been given for the delay, with Mr Klebanov stating that it was "technologically impossible" to begin the operation any sooner. He also conceded that there was a delay in the signing of a contract commissioning the work, linked to problems "with raising the necessary funds".

Rio Praaning, the secretary of the International Kursk Foundation - the Brussels-based body set up to orchestrate the salvage operation - said yesterday that, unless a solution to the current obstacles was found very soon, the submarine would remain at the bottom of the Barents Sea.

He added that preparation for the operation needed to begin in the next few weeks if it was to go ahead at all this year. Once the weather in the Barents Sea begins to deteriorate with the onset of winter, it will be unsafe for divers to begin their work. Experts are uncertain whether it will be possible to pursue the mission to recover the remains of the wreck if it has been underwater for much longer than a year.

In the emotional aftermath of the tragedy last August, Russian President Vladimir Putin made a firm commitment to the families of the 118 submariners who died that the hull would be raised this year. For relatives the recovery of the wreck is seen as crucial - not least because the investigation committee looking at the causes of the tragedy has postponed making any conclusions until the submarine has been examined.

The main purpose of raising the vessel is to stave off the risk of potential contamination. Russian officials initially said that the Kursk's nuclear reactors were automatically shut down when it sank, making the hull safe for at least 10 years. However, environmentalists fear that radioactive material could leak from the vessel once seawater and strong currents begin to corrode the hull.

Mr Klebanov warned last November that, as a result of the explosions that shattered the submarine, cracks might have appeared in the encasement, through which radioactive materials could seep. Seeking to dispel fears that the latest problems would lead to the project being abandoned, Mr Klebanov stressed yesterday: "Neither the president nor the government has cancelled the operation to lift the Kursk."

Wrangling over financial commitments lies behind the delay. Russia is obliged to pay around a third of the total estimated $70m cost of the operation, between $20 and $25m. Dismissing speculation that Russia was unable to provide its share of the money, Mr Klebanov stated that the sum had already been allocated in the 2002 budget.

The rest of the money will be supplied by the Kursk Foundation, with EU countries, as well as Japan, America and Canada, being asked to contribute millions of dollars to the operation.

The signing of the contract appears to have been put back because of fraught negotiations over Russia's commitment to clearing the Barents Sea of other rusting submarines. The business daily newspaper, Kommersant, stated that Russia had been given an ultimatum by EU officials that, unless the Kremlin agreed to full involvement in an EU plan to clear the area known by some as "the world's biggest nuclear graveyard", no money would be granted for the Kursk raising project.

Concerned about issues of military secrecy, and reluctant to let Western officials inspect top security weapons, Russia has introduced various obstacles to the Multilateral Nuclear Environment Programme for Russia (MNEPR), launched in 1999.

EU officials estimate that there are about 100 Russian submarines rusting in waters to the north-west of Russia; the project aims to remove the nuclear fuel and reactors from the abandoned vessels to prevent the risk of radioactive materials leaking into the ocean.

Russian officials are said to be prepared to agree to make the raising of the Kursk conditional on long-term involvement in the MNEPR project, but have stressed that the West must provide the salvage money first. The issue is set to be discussed on March 21, at a summit between Russia and the European Union in Stockholm.

fields.headline: Neighbourhood renewal: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: Neighbourhood renewal is the government's ambitious 20-year plan to narrow the gap between the country's richest and poorest communities. But there are concerns that implementation of the strategy may not match ministerial rhetoric
fields.trailText: Neighbourhood renewal was a term first used by the government's social exclusion unit for tackling problems in Britain's most deprived areas. It is now used to describe an ambitious 20-year project to narrow the gap between these areas and the rest of the country
fields.body:
Neighbourhood renewal was a term first used by the government's social exclusion unit for tackling problems in Britain's most deprived areas. It is now used to describe an ambitious 20-year project to narrow the gap between these areas and the rest of the country.

Within a few months of coming to power in 1997 the Labour government launched the social exclusion unit to first analyse problems in the 1,300 most deprived neighbourhoods. The unit, a small group of civil servants and seconded external experts, was set up within the cabinet office. Its first report, launched by the prime minister and deputy prime minister on an estate in Hackney, attacked the way that central and local government had failed these neighbourhoods in the past. Too much emphasis had been placed on physical regeneration and not enough on the communities themselves, the report found. It also claimed that previous efforts and funds had been wasted because of a lack of co-ordination centrally and locally.

A further 18 policy action teams were set up to analyse specific problems in these areas from housing management to the lack of financial services. Each team was given a "ministerial champion", in the words of prime minister Tony Blair, to "galvanise government as never before". New Labour's persistent use of the phrase "joined up thinking" is most prevalent in this area.

The work of these 18 teams forms the basis for the national strategy for neighbourhood renewal launched in January 2001. This involves a series of targets across Whitehall to improve the figures on employment, crime, health, education and the physical environment in the poorest neighbourhoods. It aims to ensure that spending across the public sector is used to tackle these problems. But there is also a £800m neighbourhood renewal fund for the 88 most deprived areas.

A number of specific initiatives are associated with the strategy. Local strategic partnerships (LSP) are to be set up at district level. The idea is that these bodies will bring together different agencies to ensure that initiatives are co-ordinated rather than contradictory. LSPs will be expected to give a stronger voice to people within the various communities involved. Neighbourhood managers are to be appointed at a level below LSPs, who will act as visible figureheads, charged with taking responsibility at the sharp end.

At a national level a neighbourhood renewal unit head by Joe Montgomery has been set up to co-ordinate efforts in Whitehall. The unit will work closely with neighbourhood renewal teams set up in each region.

If reality is to match rhetoric from ministers then Whitehall departments and local bureaucrats will have to abandon traditional rivalries and become more flexible than in the past.

But concerns remain about how the neighbourhood managers system will work locally. Some managers have said that their efforts could be frustrated unless they are given genuine powers and resources. There is also a worry that parachuting in highly paid managers may cause resentment among the local communities.

fields.headline: Les jeunes et le suicide
fields.standfirst: Every year, 800 young people in France kill themselves. A survey of 21 French schools shows that of the teenagers who go to see the school nurse (for any reason) one in five girls and one in 10 boys have already attempted suicide. Karine Vandenhove asks young people for their views
fields.trailText: Every year, 800 young people in France kill themselves. A survey of 21 French schools shows that of the teenagers who go to see the school nurse (for any reason) one in five girls and one in 10 boys have already attempted suicide.
fields.body:
Le suicide: 800 jeunes de 15 à 24 ans en meurent chaque année en France. Il constitue la deuxième cause de mortalité dans cette tranche d'âge, après les accidents de la route. On estime à 40 000 le nombre de tentatives de suicide (hospitalisées) chez les jeunes de moins de 25 ans.

Une enquête menée auprès de 21 établissements scolaires de Gironde (un millier d'élèves âgés de 11 à 21 ans ont été interrogés) montre qu'une fille sur cinq et un garçon sur dix fréquentant l'infirmerie scolaire de leurs collèges ou lycées ont fait une tentative de suicide. Pour Xavier Pommereau, psychiatre, coauteur de cette étude, « les jeunes à tendance suicidaire sont en difficulté identitaire. Ils ont du mal à se reconnaître une place et une identité acceptables au sein de leur famille et du corps social. Par la mort, ils veulent que cessent leurs souffrances ».

Les évènements qui poussent ces jeunes à passer à l'acte sont 1) une rupture sentimentale, 2) les conflits de famille, 3) l'échec scolaire, 4) le deuil récent d'un être cher. « Ces évènements 'déclenchants' sont des gouttes d'eau qui font déborder le vase », commente le psychiatre. « Le passage à l'acte peut également être provoqué par la résurgence, à l'adolescence, d'évènements traumatiques (violences physiques). On peut aider les jeunes, non pas en les empêchant de se suicider mais en restaurant leur envie de vivre. Pour cela, il faut que l'ensemble du corps social - médecins, enseignants, parents - prenne conscience que nos jeunes ont plus de difficultés qu'auparavant à trouver leurs marques. Il faut leur donner un rôle social et un but dans la vie. »

Nous avons interrogé deux jeunes filles directement concernées par ce problème:

Pourquoi y a-t-il tant de jeunes qui se suicident ?

Anaïs, étudiante, 22 ans: Ils manquent de repères, se sentent seuls et ont peur de l'avenir, plein d'incertitudes. En plus, la pression scolaire et la peur de l'échec sont telles qu'ils baissent les bras.

Sandrine, 23 ans, vendeuse: À cause du manque de dialogue et de compréhension avec les adultes. C'est difficile de confier ses angoisses, ça nous ronge jusqu'au jour où la coupe est pleine.

Connaissez-vous un jeune qui a fait une tentative de suicide ?

Anaïs: Oui, ma sur, après la mort de mon père. Après sa TS, on a essayé d'tre proches d'elle et à son écoute, mais elle était renfermée et ne voulait pas communiquer avec nous.

Sandrine : J'ai fait deux TS, à 21 ans, avec des médicaments et de l'alcool. J'étais boulimique et donc, très mal dans ma peau. Je pensais que je n'arriverais jamais à m'en sortir toute seule, et que la seule solution pour que ça s'arrête, c'était de me foutre en l'air. J'étais spectatrice de ma vie, je n'arrivais pas à réagir. J'étais dans une détresse telle que j'envisageais le suicide comme une délivrance, la fin de mes souffrances.

Avec le recul, j'ai réalisé que je ne voulais pas vraiment mourir. C'était un appel à l'aide, pour qu'on me prenne en main, qu'on s'occupe de moi car je n'y arrivais plus toute seule. Après mes TS, j'ai été prise en charge par un psychologue. Je suis restée 3 semaines à l'hosto, j'ai eu le temps de cogiter ! Depuis, je suis une psychothérapie, ça me fait du bien, j'ai compris des tas de choses. J'ai passé le cap, et repris le dessus.

Que peut-on faire pour 'sauver' ces jeunes ?

Anaïs: Les soutenir, les rassurer, leur parler et les comprendre. Être à leur écoute et surtout, ne pas les faire flipper.
Sandrine: Être plus attentif car il y a toujours des signes avant-coureurs qui précèdent le passage à l'acte. Il faut développer des structures et centres d'accueil adaptés pour ceux qui ont besoin de se confier. Enfin, les parents devraient être moins exigeants avec leurs enfants, et les accepter tels qu'ils sont, avec leurs qualités et leurs défauts.

fields.headline: PFI: the basics
fields.trailText: • The private finance initiative (PFI) was first introduced in 1992 and is now one of the main ways of building new public sector buildings.
fields.body:
 The private finance initiative (PFI) was first introduced in 1992 and is now one of the main ways of building new public sector buildings.

 PFI schemes involve transferring the risk of designing, building, financing and operating public projects to a private consortium in a contract that typically lasts for 30 years.

 Private consortiums are paid a regular fee depending on how the service they provide performs.

 Critics point out that PFI schemes are a costly form of hire purchase and only necessary because of overly restrictive public borrowing rules.

 The government says PFI provides a way of upgrading Britain's old infrastructure on a large scale without increasing the burden of public debt.

fields.headline: Flagship council criticised over performance
fields.trailText: A flagship Labour council that has pioneered the local government modernisation agenda is set to face strong criticism of its services in an independent report due for release later this year. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
A flagship Labour council that has pioneered the local government modernisation agenda is set to face strong criticism of its services in an independent report due for release later this year.

A preliminary presentation by inspectors from the local government Improvement and Development Agency (Idea) says "poor service delivery" is undermining Brighton and Hove city council's credibility.

It adds that access for local people to some services is "poor" and, ultimately, that the authority "needs to live up to the expectations it has helped set".

Sources close to the inspection team have confirmed that the report will be embarrassing for the council's Labour administration, formerly headed by Home Office minister Lord Bassam.

Brighton and Hove piloted best value, the government's service improvement regime, and was an early adopter of Westminster-style council cabinets, which were introduced in May 1999.

Conservative group leader Geoffrey Theobald said the findings backed up his criticisms of the council: "What we've been saying for some time is that council tax payers have been paying an enormous increase and we've seen a reduction in services and poor service delivery."

The inspectors did, however, praise the council for boosting its national reputation with a range of new initiatives that have also helped to bring more funding into the city. They also say that Brighton and Hove, a unitary council created in 1997, has done a good job of bringing the services of its predecessor authorities into one organisation.

Chief executive Glynn Jones said: "A number of messages from this review seem to me very clear. One is that we have achieved a lot in a short time Brighton and Hove council provides a tremendous range of services. We do some of these brilliantly, we do some of these averagely and frankly we don't do some of them very well at all."

He also admitted that the council needed to reconnect with communities and focus more clearly on the expectations of residents.

The criticisms come at a difficult time for the Labour administration, which was last month hit by a humiliating backbench revolt when rebels voted with opposition parties to defeat the council's plans for a referendum on a directly elected mayor.

Brighton and Hove had hoped to be the first authority in the country to take this step, and was planning to hold the poll on May 3. The defeat also infuriated ministers, who argued that the vote was an attempt to deny local people their right to choose how the council is led.

Council leader Lynette Gwyn-Jones has since announced that she will stand down in April, although it is not clear whether her decision is linked to the defeat.

The inspectors were invited in by Brighton and Hove as part of Idea's peer review programme, which puts together teams of local government professionals and politicians to assess the performance of councils and help them improve.

fields.headline: Bob the Builder
fields.standfirst: The BBC TV favourite has conquered America. Here's our guide to the best sites on the world's cuddliest construction worker
fields.trailText: The BBC TV favourite has conquered America. Here's our guide to the best sites on the world's cuddliest construction worker.
fields.body:
1. Bob the Builder is poised to become the biggest children's television export since the Teletubbies.

2. Bob is not without his critics. But his appeal crosses cultural boundaries - from line dancers to pasta munchers.

3. Now America has taken Bob to its heart, breaking all records for a debut show on the Nickelodeon channel.

4. The company which owns the US franchise, Hit Entertainment, has reported soaring profits after successfully deflecting a scandal involving Bob using four-letter words.

5. At Christmas Bob stormed the charts with his hit single Can We Fix it? Parents slept easier, because Bob's success saved Britain's youth from the threat of Eminem.

6. In fact, Can We Fix it? was the biggest selling single of 2000.

7. Neil Morrissey can take some credit for Bob's success - the Men Behaving Badly star provides Bob's voice.

8. Can We Fix it? was written by Paul Joyce, who also penned the TV themes for Noddy and The Worst Witch.

9. A range of Bob-related merchandise is already available.

10. Even though he is undeniably a builder called Bob, Bob the Builder is not to be confused with other builders called Bob.

webTitle: Mental health national service framework: the issue explained

fields.headline: Mental health national service framework: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: The mental health national service framework (NSF) sets out for the first time how services are expected to develop across the NHS, social care and independent sectors. Linda Steele and Sophie Petit-Zeman explain the main targets and milestones
fields.trailText: The mental health national service framework (NSF) sets out for the first time how services are expected to develop across the NHS, social care and independent sectors.
fields.body:
What is it?
The national service framework (NSF) for mental health, launched by the government in September 1999, is the first comprehensive statement describing what is expected of health and social services in England. The document sets out how mental health services will be planned, delivered and monitored until 2009. Similar documents are being produced in other health care specialties. Mental health and coronary heart disease were the first two frameworks to be produced, as they are significant causes of illness and disability.

What does it say?
The NSF lists seven standards that set targets for the mental health care of adults aged up to 65. These span five areas: health promotion and stigma, primary care and access to specialist services, needs of those with severe and enduring mental illness, carers' needs, and suicide reduction.

Who does it cover?
The standards are relevant to NHS, social services and independent sector providers.

What is the first step?
Improving services for people with severe and enduring mental illness is the first big milestone. Full implementation of the NSF across the NHS, social services and other agencies could take up to 10 years.

How is it implemented on the ground?
Local milestones for each standard will be reached according to time scales agreed with the NHS executive and social care regional offices. Progress will be monitored, milestones will be reviewed and new ones will be set regularly.

Five underpinning programmes will support change: these cover finance, workforce, research and development, clinical decision support, and information strategies.

How did the NSF come about?
The NSF was developed with the advice of an "external reference group" chaired by Professor Graham Thornicroft of the Institute of Psychiatry, London. The group included health and social care professionals, managers, service users and carers. A wide range of evidence was drawn together and graded, using systems such as Bandolier (a health evidence-grading system).

The NSF fleshes out the policies first announced in Modernising Mental Health Services, a government white paper.

What about the money?
About £700m has been allocated over three years to help mental health services to hit its early targets.

From this budget, £40m will be spent via the NHS modernisation fund mainly to promote services for the severely mentally ill, such as assertive outreach, 24-hour access and secure beds. Social care receives £106m in two parts: £22m via the mental health grant to improve services in areas of poor provision, to help the homeless mentally ill outside London and to boost social care partnerships. The remaining £84m will be spent supporting core services.

Why did the government bring in the NSF?
Change in mental health was long, long overdue.

When he launched the framework Frank Dobson, then secretary of state for health, pointed out that many people who suffer from mental illness "have not been getting the treatment and care they need". Dobson said, "The government is committed to do whatever is necessary to deliver a modern and dependable health service for the new century. Mental health services, and the professionals who provide them, will get the attention and resources they deserve."

How's it going?
Most professionals agreed that the NSF was a force for good. Since the NSF was published it has been joined by the government's 10-year plan for the NHS, (which will be implemented largely through a forthcoming Health and Social Care Act) and the recent white paper proposals for updating the Mental Health Act 1983.

The feeling is that, together, the NSF and mental health white paper have the potential to revolutionise mental health care (although there are doubts about some areas of the legislative overhaul). Regional implementation teams have been unveiling local plans and starting work aligning services with the seven standards.

Workforce planning, education and training (among the five national "supports" aimed at underpinning local activity) are critical for progress on the NSF. An interim report by the workforce action team published in September 2000 provided a major update on progress. The main message was that, "local services should feel empowered to adopt flexible and innovative approaches to workforce planning to deliver services which meet the needs of service users." The action team's final recommendations are due any day now.

webTitle: All BBC shows to be interactive

fields.headline: BBC's Highfield to make all shows interactive
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: The BBC will only commission programmes from now on that come with online elements attached, writes Amy Vickers.
Feb 12: Working with dinosaurs
fields.body:
BBC new media chief Ashley Highfield, has told programme-makers that from now on the BBC will only commission shows that come with online and interactive elements attached.

"The days of commissioning programmes are over, we are now only commissioning projects that have levels of interactivity," Mr Highfield said at the Production Show in London this morning.

"It's no longer viable to take programmes pitches without interactive elements such as SMS, internet or interactive TV," he added

Mr Highfield added the BBC was also looking to include interactive rights in negotiations over the terms of new commissions.

"Programmes without interactive TV rights just won't be acquired," he said.

Earlier this year, Mr Highfield described how frustrating it was to find the BBC's Walking with Dinosaurs had no internet aspect attached to it.

"Getting near the end of a four-year production and then, two months before finishing, asking the new media people to do a website is not how you do it," he said.

He also revealed that around 75% of his new media budget would go on narrowband internet projects this year.

A further 20% will be invested in interactive TV development and the remaining 5% on broadband.

The BBC spent around £70m on new media last year but Mr Highfield has not revealed how much the figure will increase this year.

He said the BBC was planning to launch a broadband portal before the end of 2001.

But he added the biggest advances in his department this year were likely to come from interactive TV.

In order to achieve its aims, Mr Highfield said the BBC would forge deals with commercial partners, including internet portals and independent TV production companies.

Mr Highfield was also critical of telecoms regulator Oftel for not forcing the pace of broadband network roll-out.

"The main thing holding back broadband progress was the indecisiveness of Oftel, he said.

"As broadcasters we need to collectively press the regulator speed up roll-out."
