fields.headline: Farmers reel at double onslaught
fields.standfirst:
Already knocked sideways by BSE, French farmers are now steeling themselves for further cases of foot and mouth, reports Jon Henley

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: 13 March: Knocked sideways by BSE, French farmers are now steeling themselves for foot and mouth, writes Jon Henley.
fields.body:
Every possible precaution was taken on both sides of the Channel, but it wasn't enough: France today confirmed the first outbreak of foot and mouth disease on the continent, dealing a bitter blow to farmers already reeling from the consequences of the mad cow scare.

As beef, pork and lamb wholesalers protested around the country at a catastrophic fall in meat consumption triggered by French fears about BSE, the agriculture minister Jean Glavany warned that more cases of the highly infectious foot and mouth disease could be expected soon.

There seems no doubt that British animals were the cause of the outbreak.

The 114-strong herd of French cattle that was slaughtered last night and will be incinerated today belonged to a farm bordering one that imported a flock of British sheep in February.

Along with dozens of other farms in the north-western Mayenne region, that farm - in the small village of La Baroche-Gondouin - had already been put on high alert against the spread of foot and mouth.

"The neighbouring farm that imported the British sheep was placed under quarantine on 27 February, and strict protection and surveillance perimeters were set up," the agriculture ministry said.

"The British sheep, as well as all animals that had come into contact with them, were destroyed from that date onwards."

France has so far ordered the destruction of 20,000 sheep imported from Britain after 1 February, as well as 30,000 French sheep that had contact with them. The government also banned the export of all animals at risk from the disease, and halted most livestock movements.

Mr Glavany revealed that half of all the British sheep slaughtered in recent weeks showed traces of the disease, adding that it was "clearly very possible that they contaminated many of the French animals with which they came into contact before they were put down".

The failure of Britain's drastic efforts to stop the disease spreading like wildfire around the United Kingdom suggests there is now little to stop foot and mouth from wreaking havoc on the continent too.

In Italy, a senior veterinary official said 390 sheep imported from France had been quarantined after preliminary blood tests showed antibodies for the disease. Further blood tests were being carried out to see whether or not the infection itself was present.

Farmers in Mayenne, France's second-biggest cattle-farming region, were devastated by this morning's news of the outbreak, which confirmed the view last week of the health minister, Bernard Kouchner, that it would be a "veritable miracle" if France escaped the plague.

"This is really the worst of all possible news," said Jean-Claude Dumond, one local farmer. "I've already lost something like half my business over the past year - no one wants to buy beef any more. If we now get a case of foot and mouth disease and my herd has to be slaughtered, I have no idea how I will survive."

The outbreak is also a blow to the hard-pressed government, which is still trying to work out a compensation deal for 40,000 French beef farmers thrown into financial crisis by the mad cow scare.

The scale of the BSE epidemic in France does not begin to compare with Britain's. France has reported a total of 270 cases against 80 a day at the height of the scare in Britain, but Gallic beef consumption has still fallen by about 25%.

Yet despite all this, no one in France - not even the media - has yet turned in righteous fury on Britain, which - whether by accident or negligence - is responsible for the arrival of both BSE and foot and mouth disease on French soil.

If the reverse was the case, the headlines in the British press can only be imagined.

fields.headline: Pearson slashes web spend by 50%
fields.trailText:
11.15am: Pearson is expected to slash its investment in its award-winning FT.com site by half, reports Claire Cozens.
Mar 5: Pearson to cut internet spending
fields.body:
Pearson is slashing spending on its Financial Times website by more than half.

According to reports today, the company will invest just £40m-£50m in its internet operation this year.

It is believed the award-winning FT.com swallowed up around £100m last year.

This was enough to wipe out profits from the Financial Times, which had recorded increases in advertising and circulation.

The company last week revealed total investment on internet services had reached £196m last year, almost five times the investment levels of previous years.

While Ms Scardino said FT.com played an important part in the growth in circulation of the Financial Times in the US, analysts were downbeat.

At the weekend, an analyst at US firm Bernstein Research said: "Time Warner, pre-AOL, with revenues of five times Pearson, spent about $60m less on net development."

Pearson last week reported a 17% fall in pre-tax profits for last year to £333m, in spite of a 16% increase in sales to £3.8bn.

Ms Scardino promised the cost of developing its online education activities and putting the FT on the web would "decline significantly in 2001".

Pearson was unable to comment on the figures today.

But a spokesman said: "Up to now we have concentrated on getting our user figures up and raising the number of page impressions. This year the focus is changing to boosting revenues."

The company said its policy had not changed because of the changing sentiment in the market.

"The key thing last year was building one of the world's foremost sites. This year the total investment will fall away," the company spokesman added.

fields.headline: Beckham dips with the best
fields.trailText: If David Beckham has become increasingly fraught in recent weeks, the Manchester United midfielder should console himself with the notion that even the most stout-hearted of men are affected by passing moments of insecurity.
fields.body:
If David Beckham has become increasingly fraught in recent weeks, the Manchester United midfielder should console himself with the notion that even the most stout-hearted of men are affected by passing moments of insecurity.

In the late 20s a young right-half by the name of Matthew Busby, struggling to make the grade at Manchester City, wrote to his fiancee Jean and included the revealing line: "I feel out of my sphere in this game." This future doyen of footballing excellence was so ridden by self-doubt that he nearly returned to the Lanarkshire pits.

For all the pontificating about Beckham's recent spell of peripheral activity, he should also remember the slogan Ian Botham sported on a T-shirt during one lean spell: "Form is temporary, class is permanent".

In football, however, patience is seldom afforded to those at Beckham's level and, with the Champions League knockout stages attainable tonight even with a 1-0 defeat by visiting Sturm Graz, United are reaching the point where they cannot afford Beckham to remain in hibernation.

Whenever the England captain is scrutinised, of course, there is a tendency to exaggerate the situation. Unless this malaise drags on, it would be surprising if he were not nominated alongside his team-mates Teddy Sheringham and Fabien Barthez for the Professional Footballers' Association's player of the year award.

Yet there is no disputing that there have been times recently when the foot-loose and fancy-free Beckham of earlier in the season has played as though in a straitjacket.

Coming, as it has, as the England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson experiments with his options, the timing could hardly be worse and, while Beckham has yet to confront the issue publicly, he has felt compelled to seek advice.

"No one is more concerned than David," said United's assistant manager Steve McClaren. "It's the job of all the coaching staff to speak to the players, David included, but maybe there are times, when world-class players like him go through a dip in form, that only they can find the answer. He is one of the best players in the world but, yes, he is going through a dip."

What exactly is causing the problem remains a cloudy issue. That every player has to endure the occasional slump in form is not just an excuse conveniently wheeled out for the benefit of those in the game. And it is conceivable, though merely speculation, that, given United's talent for keeping things in-house, something may have happened behind the scenes.

Yet the most likely explanation is that, slowly but surely, opposition defenders are cottoning on to Beckham's strengths and weaknesses.

Undeniably his greatest asset has always been an uncanny knack of receiving the ball, nudging it forward and spearing a whipped ball into telling areas without needing to beat his marker. He does not have the trickery to spin past defenders but 30, 40 or 50 yards from goal, his right boot can be an instrument of torture.

To combat this Roberto Carlos forced Beckham either backwards or inside when Real Madrid beat the Premiership champions last season, and now it seems that others have grown wise to similar containment ploys.

In particular he seems to struggle whenever Ryan Giggs is missing. Rather than being fretful of the Welshman's potency on the left, opposing defenders have started doubling up on Beckham on the right, particularly in Europe. So the news that Giggs will miss tonight's game, having recovered from a hamstring problem only to catch flu, is a damaging blow to Beckham.

"When Ryan is out it definitely makes it easier for whoever we are playing against to deal with David; there's no doubt about it," Sir Alex Ferguson said yesterday. "It changes the focus of their defending but we will have to find a way round that. Even though he's right-footed, maybe we need to bring in Luke Chadwick to give us the pace and penetration that Giggsy can provide."

The question has popped up so frequently recently that the next person who inquires about Beckham's form to Ferguson should expect to have his eyebrows singed by a hot blast of the "hairdryer".

Rather than focusing on individuals, United's manager prefers to deal in the collective. But there is no doubt his No7 was among those he was referring to when he added "too many players have not been reaching their capabilities in the last few weeks.

"Those players have decent self-regard, they know they have been letting down the team and pride should come into it now. I'm sure they want to do something about it."

Form, however, cannot be guaranteed. "It is like a bird that passes by," Ruud Gullit once said. "Sometimes you have it around you all the time, sometimes it just flies away and you don't know what the reason is." Beckham must hope that it flies back sooner rather than later.

Manchester United (possible, 4-4-2): Barthez; G Neville, Brown, Stam, Silvestre; Beckham, Scholes, Keane, Chadwick; Yorke, Cole.

Sturm Graz (possible, 3-5-2): Sidorczuk; Neukirchner, Ibertsberger, Strafner; Schopp, Schupp, Fleurquin, Korsos, Minavand; Haas, Vastic

Referee : V Ivanov (Russia).

webTitle: Idea for US-style drug courts gains momentum

fields.headline: Idea for US-style drug courts gains momentum
fields.standfirst: The prime minister has said he wants to introduce US-style drug courts, where offenders can have treatment for their addiction instead of being jailed. Wakefield has launched a pilot scheme based on this model. David Mitchell finds out how successful it has been
fields.trailText: The prime minister has said he wants to introduce US-style drug courts, where offenders can have treatment for their addiction instead of being jailed. Wakefield has launched a pilot scheme based on this model. David Mitchell finds out how successful it has been.
fields.body:
It used to be said that when the US sneezes, Britain catches a cold. Perhaps it's not the best analogy to use when talking about tackling drugs, but one idea from the US certainly seems to be catching on.

Specialist drug courts, where people who commit drug-related offences are coerced into accepting treatment and monitored by trained judges, have been operating in the US since 1989. There are now more than 450 in 50 states and all the evidence shows a clear reduction in drug use and reoffending.

Now the prime minister, Tony Blair, says he wants to introduce a network of drug courts throughout England and Wales, based on a successful pilot scheme in Wakefield. The Scottish executive has also announced plans to launch a drug court in Glasgow by the autumn.

The moves follow the introduction last October of drug treatment and testing orders, where drug abusers with lengthy criminal records can have their addiction treated instead of being jailed or heavily fined.

The rationale behind drug courts is clear. Almost a third of all crime against property is drug-related and it is estimated that almost two-thirds of persistent offenders misuse hard drugs. Traditional punishments have failed and so a new approach is being tried.

According to judge Jo Ann Ferdinand, a leading light in New York's drug courts circuit: "The emphasis on treatment instead of jail recognises that drug use is not simply a law enforcement problem but very much a public health issue. Drug courts are a success and are based on the belief that treatment works and that legal coercion can be effective in getting people to enter treatment."

The Wakefield project started after a visit by Keith Hellawell, now the government's UK anti-drugs co-ordinator or drug "tsar" but then chief constable of West Yorkshire police, to the world's first drug court in Miami in 1995. Following a multi-agency approach, Britain's first court began sitting in Wakefield and Pontefract in 1998.

Using specially trained magistrates, it offers rigorously enforced treatment programmes with routine and random tests, sanctions and incentives, monthly review hearings and graduation for those completing the programme. So far 170 court orders have been made and around 40% of offenders have successfully completed their programme.

Val Barker, assistant director, public health for Wakefield Health Authority and chairwoman of the Wakefield drug action team, says: "We really believe we have started something that works and we know from some of the successes in Wakefield and abroad that they do work.

"I'd be delighted if drug courts took off in the rest of the UK because what has been done up until now hasn't worked, what we have done on our own hasn't worked, but joint initiatives to tackle the drug-crime link really make a difference to people's lives."

David Edwards, executive director north for Turning Point, which provides treatment services for the Wakefield project, says it's the most exciting development he has seen in 30 years.

"The only service we know serious drug users come into contact with is the criminal justice system. Either we bang them all up or try a carrot-and-stick approach to do something about it. It can't be done on a voluntary basis because it won't hit the heavy, difficult, entrenched end of drug abuse," he says.

Drugs and legal charity Release supports the idea of drug courts but warns there must be proper access to treatment for them to be effective.

"It is not a panacea - it is part of the solution, not the whole solution. There is a shortage of skilled drugs workers at the moment and that is the real issue. How do you get new people into these posts?" says deputy director Ian Robinson.

The Scottish drugs forum welcomes the initiative in Scotland but says drug courts need to be clear about what group they are targeting.

"This is a more expensive intervention, more than community-based drug services, which needs to be targeted at high tariff offenders who need it most. The key issue is about the balance of provision - whether too many or not enough people are being pushed through the criminal justice system," says director Dave Liddell.

Paul Turnbull, deputy director of the criminal policy research unit at South Bank University in London, helped carry out the recent Home Office evaluation of drug treatment and testing orders, which he describes as "promising but not yet proven".

"Recent evidence on the drug court movement in the US is reasonably robust but there is no hard and fast evidence to show that having an established relationship between judge and offender produces positive results," he says.

"What we can say is that the whole package provided through the court process is of benefit. The courts are only a part of that and the fact that they can offer treatment and integrated systems for getting people back into a normal lifestyle is part of the process."

webTitle: Brown accuses EC of regions aid delay

fields.headline: Brown accuses EC of regions aid delay
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday launched his second attack upon the Brussels bureaucracy in as many months, accusing the European commission of dragging its feet over a crucial aid package to the regions worth £1bn.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday launched his second attack upon the Brussels bureaucracy in as many months, accusing the European commission of dragging its feet over a crucial aid package to the regions worth £1bn.

Mr Brown condemned the commission for "unjustified" delays in approving his so-called venture capital funds for Britain's regions.

His comments came after meeting the commissioner in charge of the approval process, Mario Monti, to voice his concerns. "I have left him in no doubt that the delays being experienced for getting permission for the new venture capital funds are unjustified and it is very important that we get a decision on this very quickly."

But the commission yesterday rejected his accusations. "It has to be a transparent procedure," a spokesperson said. "We need to respect procedures, translate it into 11 languages and wait for people to comment. In this case we have done all of this extremely rapidly." It was essential, Mr Brown stressed, that what he called "a very substantial injection of new capital" was approved so that small and medium sized firms outside London and the south-east could benefit.

At the moment there is a severe imbalance in venture capital funding which means that the south-east attracts more money than the rest of the country put together. The £1bn package includes money from the government, the private sector and the European Investment Bank.

Mr Brown's determination to speed up the provision of aid to the regions is backed up today by a renewed call from the cross-party campaign for English devolution supported by scores of MPs, MEPs, local councillors, academics and clergymen for regional assemblies.

The junior agriculture minister, Joyce Quin, has joined them in calling for legislation early in the next parliament to trigger regional referendums to test support for English devolution. The initiative has been welcomed by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who is pressing Tony Blair for a green paper soon after the election setting out the arguments for English devolution.

In an advertisement from the Campaign for the English Regions in today's Guardian, the signatories back a statement which says: "We believe it is the right for the English regions, that so choose, to create their own democratically elected assemblies. We call upon Westminster to legislate early in the next parliament to allow each region the opportunity to demonstrate clear popular consent and create its own assembly."

Peter Mandelson, MP for Hartlepool and former Northern Ireland secretary, added his voice to the debate at the weekend, saying one of the themes of the election was "spreading prosperity around the country. I would like to see this become a more prominent feature of the party's campaign in the coming election because ... there are very wide disparities".

fields.headline: Dot.coms fall foul of consumer protection laws
fields.trailText:
1pm: Many companies advertising goods for sale online are breaching trading standards regulations, writes Claire Cozens.
OFT guide to home shopping
fields.body:
Many companies advertising goods for sale over the internet are breaching trading standards regulations, according to a report from the Office of Fair Trading.

An inspection of 637 websites in the UK selling a range of products found more than half failed to meet basic legal requirements.

Trading standards inspectors surfed websites selling products such as books, music, toys, software and clothes and found 52% broke consumer-protection laws.

One of the most common failings was not providing information on refunds and exchange.

The OFT is working with trading standards authorities to ensure the websites are amended to comply with the law.

Consumers shopping over the internet are entitled to protection under the distance-selling regulations, which came into force last October.

This includes the right to clear information before placing an order, written confirmation of a purchase, a cooling-off period during which an order can be cancelled and a full refund if goods are not provided by an agreed date.

"Consumers are now entitled to clear information when they buy from home, whether over the internet, telephone, digital TV or by mail order," said John Vickers, director general of the OFT.

"Failure to tell consumers about their right to cancel and to a full refund is a breach of the new regulations and must be put right.

"It is in the interests of consumers and good businesses to make ways of buying from home as robust as possible."

The publication of the report coincides with the launch of an OFT campaign to raise consumers' awareness of their rights.

Advice is available on the OFT website and a new consumer information leaflet has been published.

webTitle: Israel reduces pressure on West Bank

fields.headline: Israel reduces pressure on West Bank
fields.standfirst:
• Israel loosens West Bank blockade
• Patten criticises pressure on Palestinians
• Sharon tells cabinet to be 'polite'

Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Following international criticism, Israel's army has  eased its chokehold on the town of Ramallah, the Palestinians' political and commercial centre, and loosened its blockade of four other West Bank towns.
fields.body:
Following international criticism, Israel's army has eased its chokehold on the town of Ramallah, the Palestinians' political and commercial centre, and loosened its blockade of four other West Bank towns.

In Ramallah, soldiers opened the southern and northern access roads, but traffic was backed up for miles as troops searched each car. Israeli prime minister Ariel Sharon has said the tight closure on Ramallah was imposed because Israeli security forces were trying to catch would be car bombers in the area.

Chris Patten, the EU commissioner for external affairs, said after meeting Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat in Gaza that the collapse of the Palestinian authority under economic pressure would not augur well for peace. "We think it would be extremely bad for the prospects of peace if the [Palestinian] administration here was simply knocked to smithereens over the next few months," said Mr Patten, who is travelling with Swedish foreign minister Anna Lindh.

"If more people are plunged into poverty, that in our view is going to further radicalise opinion and make it more difficult to get people to accept the need for a political accommodation."

In Washington, the US state department said Israeli economic pressure on the Palestinians does not enhance security but causes hardships for Palestinian families. State department spokesman Richard Boucher called on Israel to release tax revenues to the Palestinians, and said it was important for the Palestinians to stop shootings and incitement and "take steps to end the violence."

The Israeli army, meanwhile, denied reports that it tried to assassinate Marwan Barghouti, the head of Mr Arafat's Fatah movement in the West Bank, during a clash with Israeli troops in Ramallah yesterday.

A Palestinian intelligence officer, 28-year-old Abdel Kader Abu Akroub, was killed by a shot to the chest as he stood near Barghouti during the confrontation. Israel has accused Mr Barghouti of directing gunmen who have attacked Israelis. Israel army radio quoted Fatah officials as saying Mr Barghouti had been the real target. "I don't think they can justify their accusation," he said, adding that he would make some changes in his daily routine.

The Israeli forces also destroyed two buildings today in the West Bank town of Beit Omar, near Hebron, saying Palestinian militants had used the structures for cover during recent shooting attacks.

The strict closure on Ramallah was imposed on Sunday, after Israel said it had hard intelligence that a band of militants was planning to leave Ramallah for Jerusalem with a car bomb. Hamas has threatened to greet the new Sharon government with 10 suicide bomb attacks and took responsibility for two blasts in Israel this month, killing four Israelis.

 Manners maketh the cabinet for Ariel Sharon, who has ordered the 25 politicians at his cabinet table to be punctual and polite.

Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth listed the prime ministerial marching orders in an article today: be on time, keep comments to a minimum at government meetings - and never shout down a cabinet colleague.

Sharon assembled his new troops for the first time yesterday. Yedioth Ahronoth said it was the first time ever a cabinet had begun on time. "In the new government they treat time as if we were in England, not in Israel," housing minister Natan Sharansky complained.

fields.headline: Aegis set for European buy-up
fields.trailText:
1pm updated: Aegis is set to make a series of acquisitions across Europe over the coming year, reports Julia Day
10.30am: Aegis bullish in face of slump
fields.body:
Aegis is set to make a series of acquisitions across Europe over the coming year.

Aegis chief executive Doug Flynn said the media group was looking to bolster its market research business by acquiring European companies following the £11.3m acquisition of US marketing consultancy Copernicus.

"We intend to make appropriate acquisitions in Europe and the likelihood is that we will make multiple acquisitions rather than one large one," said Mr Flynn.

He said UK companies will be potential targets. Aegis recently bought Pegram Walters Market Research Group, its first European market research acquisition.

Aegis is consolidating its Market Facts in the US, Asia Market Intelligence in Asia and PW in the UK under the Aegis Research banner to provide a consistent set of services and products worldwide.

Mr Flynn said the downturn in the advertising market showed advertising spend returning to more consistent levels in line with steady growth shown over the past 15-20 years.

It was not, he said, an indicator of long-term problems.

Aegis is predicting a global advertising spend growth of 5.7%, broadly in line with other forecasts.

It expects US advertising spend to grow at 4.5%, down from last year's 8% and puts European growth at 6.4% and Asia at 6.3%.

But Deutsche Bank analysts believe that Aegis's forecasts may be subject to downward revision.

The bank says advertising giant WPP is budgeting for a 2-3% growth in advertising spend this year.

Aegis's media buying network Carat is reaping cost savings from companies consolidating accounts across Europe.

However, Mr Flynn said account consolidation on a global level will not happen in earnest until 2003.

"Because of the logistics - technology, management structures and the way companies operate - global consolidation will happen in two or three steps over the next couple of years," he said.

Aegis chief financial officer Jeremy Hicks said investment in 2001 on property, people and systems will be slightly less than the £26.9m spent in 2000.

This figure increased from £13.1m capital expenditure in 1999.

Related story

webTitle: Sun can be sued for distress, court rules

fields.headline: Sun can be sued for distress, court rules
fields.trailText: A judge has held that victims of media reports which cause "alarm or distress" can sue for damages for harassment, reports Clare Dyer.
fields.body:
A judge has held that victims of media reports which cause "alarm or distress" can sue for damages for harassment, in an unprecedented judgment that opens a new route of redress against newspapers.

The Sun is appealing against the unpublicised ruling, won last week by Esther Thomas, a civilian clerk for the City of London police, who sued the paper under the Protection Against Harassment Act.

The act was brought into force in 1997 to protect the victims of stalkers but it does not spell out what behaviour amounts to harassment. It simply says that speech is covered, that there must be a "course of conduct" and that the conduct must cause the victim alarm or distress.

For celebrities and others, it could open an easier and simpler means of redress than the privacy law emerging under the Human Rights Act, whose limits are still undefined.

Geoffrey Bindman, a media solicitor who acts for Keith Vaz, Anna Ford and other high profile clients, said: "It's very good news. It is highly desirable that there should be a remedy for innocent people who are hounded by the media and whose lives are seriously damaged by media harassment."

In a private hearing at Lambeth county court in south London, the Sun asked Judge Roger Cox, the senior judge at Lambeth, to strike out the action or enter judgment in its favour. It argued that the case was hopeless and had no legal basis. But the judge ruled last week: "The act does give to the claimant a right to protection from harassment by all the world, including the press."

The articles reported that a complaint by Ms Thomas, who is black, against four officers over their behaviour when a Somali asylum seeker sought help had led to the demotion of two sergeants and a £700 fine for a PC.

In the first article, under the headline Beyond a joke: Fury as police sarges are busted after refugee jest, the paper quoted a "fellow cop" as saying: "It was essentially light hearted banter in private and the Somali never heard. This is political correctness gone mad."

Ms Thomas, who was named in the article and described as a "black clerk", received race hate mail at the police station. The following week the paper published a selection of readers' letters attacking her for making the complaint and ruining the sergeants' careers. These were followed by a story seeking readers' contributions to pay the PC's fine.

The Sun admitted the pieces were "strident, aggressive and inflammatory", but denied they were racist. The judge said that in his opinion the description "racist" was justified.

The ruling is not limited to racial harassment, but covers anything causing alarm or distress if at least two articles are published. If only one was published it would not satisfy the requirement for a "course of conduct".

The judgment has alarmed newspaper executives, who are seeking legal advice on its implications. The Sun's counsel, Matthew Nicklin, told the judge that if newspaper reports were covered by the act it would turn the Sun into a "parish gazette" and transform media law in Britain. The case is expected to go to the court of appeal later this year.

Lawrence Davies, Ms Thomas's solicitor at the London Race Discrimination Unit, said: "I think it will go all the way to the House of Lords."

Robert Clinton of Farrer & Co, the Sun's solicitors, said: "It's effectively a brand new course of action. It would be an extraordinary further string to the bow of potential claimants. Any investigative journalism you do now that amounts to more than one article could make you liable under the act."

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours spice up their rather mediocre photo collection by adding a clutch of naked urinating seven-year-olds
fields.trailText: Leeds and Man Utd will battle it out for full-back Michael Ball this summer. The Mirror quotes a source "close" to the £6m-rated England man as saying: "Those two clubs have made it clear that they will be in the bidding for Michael in the summer." Leeds would be prepared to offer Danny Mills or Jason Wilcox as part of any deal.
fields.body:
Leeds and Man Utd will battle it out for full-back Michael Ball this summer. The Mirror quotes a source "close" to the £6m-rated England man as saying: "Those two clubs have made it clear that they will be in the bidding for Michael in the summer." Leeds would be prepared to offer Danny Mills or Jason Wilcox as part of any deal.

Gianluca Vialli could become the coach at Serie A Udinese, according to the Mirror. Current coach Luigi De Canio has presided over a terrible run of results recently, and Vialli is seen as the man to sort it out.

Fulham midfielder Fabrice Fernandes looks set for a move to Rangers. Fernandes, who is on loan at Craven Cottage from French club Rennes, said: "I have spoken to David Murray and Dick Advocaat and they have impressed me very much, I have now set my heart on joiniing them. It may only be a loan deal until the end of the season but I know when I get up there I will be one of the best players in Scotland. I can convince Rangers the deal should be permanent."

Tranmere star Jason Koumas will move to Fulham, say the Mirror, as soon ass Tranmere's battle to avoid relegation is over. The 21-year-old, who is also the subject of an international tug-of-war between Wales and Cyprus, would cost £3m.

Rangers, Chelsea and Newcastle are all interested in signing Southampton's Hassan Kachlou when his contract expires at the end of the season.

Walter Smith has been in Copenhagen to check out AB pair Brian Steen Nilsen and Martin Albrechtsen, according to the Daily Express. Nilsen, a midfielder, played for Denmark in Euro 2000, while centre-half Albrechtsen, 20, is tipped for great things.

Danny Dichio wants to leave Sunderland because he is fed up of being second choice to Niall Quinn. The Daily Express suggests that Ipswich, Derby and Crystal Palace have all watched the striker in recent weeks.

fields.headline: Rail chiefs unveil 10-year plan
fields.standfirst: Strategic agenda - strategic rail authority
fields.trailText: Rail chiefs today published a 10-year blueprint to reverse the "lack of vision and decades of under-investment", which have plagued the railways and eroded public confidence.
fields.body:
Rail chiefs today published a 10-year blueprint to reverse the "lack of vision and decades of under-investment", which have plagued the railways and eroded public confidence.

The strategic rail authority (SRA) criticised Railtrack, beleaguered by recent rail tragedies, and signalled a downscaling of its role in funding major projects.

An agenda put forward by the SRA suggested that what was required was fewer and stronger franchises on the railways, which are currently broken down into 25 separate train operating companies.

It states: "Public resentment of overcrowded, dirty and unreliable public services, particularly when some train operators benefit from large public subsidies, is very understandable and carries within it a backlash".

The authority described the railways as "an ageing network facing a conflict of priorities".

Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA's chairman, warned passengers not to expect improvements overnight and that it was the growth in passengers, unforeseen at the time of privatisation, that had "brought great pressure onto an ageing, under-invested system".

He said the document was neither a call for re-nationalisation nor for revolutionary structural change, but "a call to the industry for a radical improvement in management, in operations, in method and performance and in service culture in the railway".

Of Railtrack, the SRA said the company had to "rebuild confidence in its capabilities" and that it had "for so long resisted a proactive approach to accommodating modern trains on its frequently erratic, often unmeasured infrastructure".

The agenda has been drawn up against a government wish to invest £60bn in the railways over the next 10 years. Around half this money will have to come from the private sector.

Today, the SRA published a huge list of possible rail projects to be started over the next few years.

The report said: "There is now a consensus that Railtrack ... does not have sufficient financial and management capability simultaneously to monopolise this second business."

Instead, the SRA is suggesting a rail modernisation fund - public funding managed by the SRA - to provide a flexible approach to developing enhancement projects on the network. However, Sir Alastair said it was "highly unlikely" that all the projects would be completed and there was no commitment or date for delivery of all the projects.

The SRA said the Hatfield crash last October, which claimed four lives, had "established itself as a pivotal episode in the post-privatisation evolution of Britain's railways, the consequences of which are not yet fully revealed."

webTitle: The town has been uncannily quiet

fields.headline: The town has been uncannily quiet
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited is talking regularly to a small panel of people whose lives and livelihoods have been  directly affected by the foot and mouth crisis. Derek Brown reports from Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire in our latest series of interviews on the front line
fields.trailText: Derek Brown reports from Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire in our latest series of interviews.
fields.body:
The town has been almost uncannily quiet for more than a week. It's not exactly the height of the tourist season, but even at this time of year we expect a constant stream of traffic heading west into the Cotswolds. Some of it passes straight through, but a fair proportion of travellers pause to explore our beautiful little market town.

The passing trade is important for local shops and caterers, but these days they seem to be barely ticking over. Worse, the hotels and guesthouses have lost the annual fillip of the Gold Cup meeting at Cheltenham, which is just forty minutes drive away.

The restaurateur

Brian Galbraith, who runs Stones restaurant-bar in the heart of the town, has taken a double hit in recent days. Not only is the restaurant uncomfortably quiet, but his other business - a chauffeur service using Brian's own and his clients' cars - has been clobbered by the Cheltenham postponement.

"Normally this week accounts for up to a quarter of all our annual business. We have some really good clients who are prepared to spend a lot of money at Cheltenham. We knew that the Irish and the French probably wouldn't come, but we were still hoping for a good week. As it is, we can only hope that it will take place later," he said.

The story of the restaurant is almost as gloomy. Although Stones has a growing local reputation and a loyal band of regulars, its central location in a striking old stone building normally guarantees it a handsome passing trade. The only problem is, not many people are passing now.

On Sunday, Brian and partner Jan Blackburn normally expect to serve around 60 lunches. On one exceptional day just two weeks ago, they managed to serve 93. This Sunday, it was down to 20.

"It's really bad. Most of the people we had in on Sunday were locals, not passersby. There seem to be fewer and fewer people around as this thing goes on. The fact is, people are seeing now that the crisis is not going to go away. They're not seeing it as a thing that is going to go away in five minutes," said Brian.

Jan, meanwhile, is having to cope with steadily increasing prices in the kitchen where she produces homecooked meals - for the most part from locally supplied produce. The price of bacon, for example, has gone up around 40% in the past week. The chances are that Stones will have one fewer waitress next weekend, as Brian and Jan struggle to contain costs.

The butcher

The meat served at Stones comes from John Kench the butcher, on the other side of the main street. The wholesale price of bacon rose sharply last week, and chicken is also more expensive. But meat prices in general have remained remarkably stable in view of public uncertainties about availability. John's supplies in fact have been virtually unaffected. He buys premium beef from Scotland, and top quality lamb and beef from Orkney.

Both suppliers are still delivering weekly, and the shop is well stocked. Pigs were more problematic in the first week of the crisis, but now John is getting what he needs from local suppliers. Interestingly, demand is picking up, with more new customers coming into the small shop.

"I get the impression that this crisis has made people more aware of quality, which is just what I want. I may be wrong, but I think a lot of the new customers are supermarket shoppers who are thinking more now about what they are eating," said John.

The supermarket

The town's Co-op is also well supplied, with no sign of the panic buying which has gripped some supermarkets last week. Pork, beef and lamb are all available, and prices have not shifted in the past week. The Coop manager, Tony Hatch, has been warning that special offers would be suspended, but today the shelves are dotted with little yellow labels announcing "low low prices" on some meat lines.

The Co-op has an advantage over other chains, as apart from retailing it is also Britain's biggest commercial farmer and thus, to a large extent, its own supplier. Even so, the restrictions on animal movements have taken their toll. A new notice on the meat shelves tells customers that the Co-op's policy is to support British meat producers, but that in present circumstances it has had to look for overseas supplies.

Already, New Zealand lamb is prominently on offer, and pork is being brought in from Spain and Belgium.

The farmer

The very idea of importing meat is anathema for many farmers. Marilyn Ivings of Mill Farm at Church Enstone, is more concerned about the double standards in the regulation of the food industry which, she says, imposes unfair burdens on domestic producers.

The Food Standards Agency, she points out, has no jurisdiction whatever over imports, except on specific health issues. Thus chickens are being legally brought in from places like Brazil and Thailand, where they are given growth promoters which are banned in Britain.

Marilyn also laughs scornfully at the notion that intensive farming methods, coupled with overuse of chemicals, antibiotics and other animal drugs, have contributed to the present crisis.

"People should realise how unintensive most farms really are. We had to give antibiotics to one of our cows last week, because she had mastitis. It was the second entry in our medicine book since the beginning of last year - that's just twice in 13 months."

The other widespread public assumption which tends to make Marilyn say "don't get me going on that one" is that farmers affected by the foot and mouth outbreak get automatic compensation.

"People will keep saying that the farmers are reimbursed. Well, those who have livestock slaughtered are reimbursed, but the people whose farms are prevented from working, who cannot move their animals or sell them - they don't get any compensation. It's not as clear cut as some people seem to think," she said.

webTitle: Regulating social care: the issue explained

fields.headline: Regulating social care: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: The government plans to improve standards in social care by monitoring and assessing performance against agreed standards. A range of regulatory and inspection bodies are being set up to monitor the workforce and improvements in services
fields.trailText: Regulating, monitoring and assessing improvements in social care will require detailed legislation as well as the setting up of several new organisations to regulate the workforce. How will the proposed regulatory bodies drive up standards in social care?
fields.body:
Regulation, regulation, regulation: are those the words on every politicians' lips?
Well, if not on their lips, perhaps in their minds (along with much darker thoughts in some cases, some social care staff fear). Standards, frameworks, indicators, benchmarks, registration and regulation - make no mistake, public services are going to have to come up to scratch.

So, social care staff are chafing under the yoke of their authoritarian political masters?
Now that Milosevic's star has waned some local authority staff may think that their leaders and self-styled mayors are lining up to take on his mantle of tyranny.

No, no. National government. New Labour, new centralisation, that kind of thing
Well, you'll not find many people who will argue with the concept of regulation, despite niggling doubts about some of the details. There is general agreement that staff who work closely with vulnerable people should be regulated, if not professionally registered. Social care staff - including qualified social workers - have long envied the status enjoyed by their colleagues in nursing and medicine, and have wondered if a more professional set-up would boost their poor public image.

So, what's new in the field of social care?
Well, nothing much is new because the idea of regulation has been around for some time. But the issue is new in the sense that the whole of the UK is gearing up to introduce organisations to regulate social care staff and services.

And what exactly will those organisations be?
Are you sitting comfortably? This could take some time. The Care Standards Act 2000 paves the way for a general social care council (GSSC) to regulate the workforce and a national care standards commission (NCSC) to regulate services in England from 1 April 2002.

The act also provides for a care council for Wales, to oversee staff, and a commission for care standards in Wales to regulate services. In Northern Ireland, where they seem happier with the idea of regulation of services, the assembly is debating a health and social services bill, which will create a Northern Ireland social care council to regulate the workforce.

Once the regulation of care (Scotland) bill is passed (the first reading is in March 2001), Scotland will have a Scottish social services council (SSSC) from this October and a Scottish commission for the regulation of care from April 2002, both based at the same offices in Dundee. Some staff will have to be registered as a condition of employment. At first this is likely to be limited to qualified social workers.

And how will these bodies keep their beady eyes on staff and services?
The finer points have yet to be decided - not least because the organisations do not yet exist. But each council will have a personal code of conduct to which staff must commit themselves. It will be up to employers to enforce these. The office for public management has drawn up some draft codes of conduct, while the national institute for social work is looking at other aspects of regulation, including involving carers and users.

Anything else I should know?
Just that a plethora of regulatory and inspection bodies, which already exist or will soon come into being, also have an impact on social care. There is the social services inspectorate, the best value inspection team at the Audit Commission, and the joint review team of the social services inspectorate.

There is also the commission for health improvement (inspecting private hospitals), the proposed new mental health commission, the housing corporation (which regulates housing associations - some of which provide sheltered or supported housing with a social care element), and the new, early years inspection team at Ofsted - the education inspectors - colloquially known as Oftot.

And will they all work smoothly together, in a joined up fashion?
I couldn't possibly comment. Let us just say that some social service directors have been heard muttering darkly about the amount of time they spend being inspected and providing different data about the same services to multiple monitoring teams rather than getting on with the job of providing and improving services.

fields.headline: Internet traders 'breaching regulations'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Many companies advertising goods for sale over the internet are breaching trading standards regulations, the Office of Fair Trading said today.
fields.body:
Many companies advertising goods for sale over the internet are breaching trading standards regulations, the Office of Fair Trading said today.

An inspection of 637 UK websites selling a range of products found that 52% failed to meet basic legal requirements.

Consumers shopping over the internet are entitled to protection under the Distance Selling Regulations, which came into force last October.

These include the right to clear information before placing an order, written confirmation of a purchase, a cooling-off period during which an order can be cancelled and full refunds if goods are not provided by an agreed date.

Inspectors from 28 trading standards authorities and the OFT surfed websites for products including books, music, toys, software and clothes.

One of the most common failings was not providing information on refunds and exchange.

John Vickers, director general of the OFT, said: "Consumers are now entitled to clear information when they buy from home, whether over the internet, telephone, digital TV or by mail order.

"Failure to tell consumers about their right to cancel and to a full refund is a breach of the new Distance Selling Regulations and something which must be put right.

"It is in the interests of consumers and good businesses to make ways of buying from home as robust as possible."

The OFT's results have been forwarded to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, for inclusion in an international survey. These will be published shortly by the Australian body.

webTitle: In brief: Brosnan wants his last Bond to be the best

fields.headline: Brosnan wants his last Bond to be the best
fields.standfirst: Plus: Clint brings mystical bestseller to screen; Academy loses appeal case over sale of Oscar tickets; Collymore follows Vinnie to Hollywood; Rutles evolve in Eric Idle's star-filled movie
fields.trailText: Plus: Clint brings mystical bestseller to screen; Academy loses appeal case over sale of Oscar tickets; Collymore follows Vinnie to Hollywood; Rutles evolve in Eric Idle's star-filled movie
fields.body:
 Pierce Brosnan has been making provocative noises about the next Bond film, which is in development. "We finally have a script now," reports the Irish smoothie. "So we'll be forging ahead with the next film. I'm on record as saying that I want this next Bond to be the most surprising and realistic of any I've done. I don't know why that frightens the studio and the producers so much."

 Clint Eastwood is to bring the bestselling thriller Mystic River to the silver screen. Eastwood will produce and direct the story of three childhood friends who split up after a tragic incident, but who meet years later when they get involved in a murder investigation.

 The Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences might have to go to trial to prove that tickets to Oscar night are non-transferable, after a three-judge panel ruled that the California Court of Appeal was wrong last year to prohibit the company World Sports Group from buying and selling Academy Award tickets. Academy spokesman John Pavlik said, "The Academy will continue to prosecute this case until it is resolved." The Academy pressed charges after the 1998 Oscar bash, when it learned that company chief Rey Olsen was selling tickets to the event. On Oscar night, a couple, who had won tickets sold by a former member of the Academy in a radio contest, were asked to leave. The latest hitch for Oscar organisers comes a week after they attempted to force website Taketoauction.com to stop its auction of tickets to the movie beanfeast (see earlier story).

 Recently retired footballer Stan Collymore wants to follow Vinnie Jones' example by becoming a Hollywood star. Amid press reports claiming that the wayward striker has already had offers from film companies, Collymore's agent Ian Monk told the Daily Star, "He's had a couple of offers which we haven't looked at in detail yet. But Vinnie has shown how an ex-footballer can make it big in movies and I'm sure Stan could be a success too."

 Former Python Eric Idle is at work on a sequel to his spoof 1978 documentary The Rutles, which parodied the success of The Beatles. Idle claims to have unearthed outtakes and unseen film from the movie, which he is editing into a new film, The Rutles: Evolution. "I have an extraordinary cast," says the 57-year-old wag. "Tom Hanks, Robin Williams, Steve Martin, Salman Rushdie, Garry Shandling - they are all talking [in the new film] about the influence of the Rutles on their lives and music."

webTitle: Brown's round table generals draw up battle plans

fields.headline: Brown's round table generals draw up battle plans
fields.standfirst:
In the second of a series examining the readiness of the three main parties for the general election, we look inside Labour's war room

Graphic: inside the war room
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: In the second of a series examining the readiness of the three main parties for the general election, we look inside Labour's war room.
fields.body:
"This is very different to anything we have done before," admits a veteran of three previous Labour war rooms, including the 1997 election landslide. "Last time, most of us were together in one building for more than three years. This time, right up until the moment the election is called, the team is physically separated - some in the party and some in government.

"Last time, we were in opposition and this time we are defending our record - and with the polls as they are, the danger is that the media make the election nothing but a scrutiny of us. Last time, we chalked off each day without a mistake as one day nearer to victory. This time we cannot afford a quiet campaign, or for Hague to be ignored. The size of our majority will depend on a high turnout."

These are not the only differences. In 1997 Labour targeted 90 seats; now, because the party did so well last time, there are an extra 60 seats to defend - the so-called far side seats. Labour took a decision 18 months ago to defend every one of them. It means Labour will have to rely less on organisation on the ground and more on the quality of the national political message. "Altogether, it makes for a much more complicated campaign," says the veteran. "A lot will depend on how quickly we gel when we all get together."

On day zero, an army of special advisers from government will be banging on the door of the open plan Millbank office - all allocated desks by Jackie Stacey, the logistics chief.

But the gelling process will take place around a central round table in the middle of the war room on the first floor of Millbank headquarters. This table represents the command and control HQ. Many of the familiar faces of the 1992 and 1997 election campaigns will have seats at the table, making Millbank by far the most experienced of the election teams.

With Mr Blair on the road and returning to London most evenings, Gordon Brown, chairman of election strategy and the morning press conferences, will be the dominant force. From his weekly campaign meetings in the Treasury, he has overseen the key messages, the grid and the preparation of the war book, setting out the chosen dividing lines for the election. Not surprisingly the key message will be the economy, jobs and historically low interest rates.

Mr Brown will work directly with Philip Gould, who will no longer have Peter Mandelson as his preferred conduit. Mr Gould remains as the provider of the focus group research, the strategic advice on the public mood and one of Mr Blair's most trusted advisers.

Mr Gould's mood can fluctuate with the latest poll, but is steadied by the long term in-house pollster "Mystic Greg" Cook. He also oversees the voluntary call centre operation, which has transferred from Millbank to a professional call centre on Tyneside. This will keep Labour in touch with swing voters, who are more honest on the phone than if faced by a doorstep canvass. Resources set aside for the call centre are much higher than in 1997: as many as 10,000 phone calls can be made a night.

Also sitting at the central table will be Margaret McDonagh, the party general secretary, who organised the key seats strategy in 1992 and 1997.

David Hill, Labour communications director from 1991 to 1997, and subsequently employed by Good Relations, will return to Millbank as a senior press spokesman alongside Lance Price, the current press director, who is assembling a more fractured and differentiated press campaign. Also returning to Millbank, along with a host of special advisers, will be Michael Craven to act as John Prescott's eyes and ears at Millbank while the deputy prime minister is on the national battle bus. Mr Craven, now a successful Notting Hill-based lobbyist, has known Mr Prescott since he worked as a researcher in the mid-1980s.

Two places on the central table are reserved for a pair of Scots, Pat McFadden and Douglas Alexander.

The self-deprecating Mr McFadden shares the same dry humour as his former boss, the late Donald Dewar. He migrated to Downing Street handling constitutional affairs before being promoted to Mr Blair's deputy chief of staff. Following Millbank's poor showing in the European elections, Mr Blair wanted someone whose political judgment he trusts at Millbank.

Mr Alexander, a 33-year-old protege of Gordon Brown, was appointed election co-ordinator a year ago. The fall of Mr Mandelson has enhanced Mr Alexander's status as the politician managing the Millbank detail. Credited with organising the party's successful Scottish parliament election campaign, he is one of the brightest figures on the circuit.

Dozy bloodhound

Also moving around Millbank is Fraser Kemp, the MP and a former national election co-ordinator from 1994-96. He wears the look of a dozy bloodhound, but is one of Alastair Campbell's most trusted operators. Following any political mugging of a Conservative MP, Mr Kemp can often be found somewhere near the scene of the crime.

The attack, or rapid rebuttal, unit is directed by Spencer Livermore, an LSE graduate and another former adviser to Mr Brown. Mr Livermore has at his disposal not just a reworked Excalibur computer, but also a more sophisticated regional intelligence gathering operation. It has already been used to counter Mr Hague at prime minister's questions.

Millbank has also improved its internal party communication. The party's regional offices have access to an email system giving them lines to take, as well as the ability to post urgent messages of local developments and the responses of local politicians.

Labour has a new advertising agency for the campaign. Following the on-off-on association with BMP and its chief executive Chris Powell, Mr Mandelson switched to Trevor Beattie's agency, TBWA. They generated the French Connection "fcuk" campaign and the Wonderbra "Hello boys" billboards. Their first outing for Labour came with the thank you adverts last autumn. This tried to address the issue of arrogance and reassert the link between voting and social change, a necessary message for a country cynical about the relevance of politics.

Turnout is the single issue that obsesses Labour. Mr Prescott has been on a two-month Get Ready roadshow, drumming the message into activists that if one in five Labour voters from 1997 do not bother to vote this time, then Labour will lose 60 seats. The same message has been emailed daily to MPs. Some analysts, such as Bob Worcester from Mori, predict an even lower turnout than in 1997, which was the lowest figure since the war. He is predicting a turnout of 67% or 68%, costing Labour 25 to 30 seats.

Labour has found surprisingly little evidence that its organisation on the ground affected the 1997 turnout. In 1997 the Labour vote fell by 1% more in Labour-held seats than in Conservative seats. The fall was especially pronounced in the north.

Just 68% turned out to vote in the average Labour seat, compared with 74% in the typical Conservative seat. There is little evidence that Labour turnout was higher in its target seats than the far-side seats - the seats Labour never expected to win.

Many independent surveys again predict traditional Labour supporters are still disproportionately less likely to vote. These apathetic Labour voters tend to be semi-skilled or unskilled manual workers, in their 20s and 30s and living on relatively low incomes. They also tend to be female and regular users of public services.

Last week's budget, with its help for women and the emphasis on extra help for public services, was aimed especially at these groups.

fields.headline: Drugs and alcohol: the basics
fields.trailText: • Drug use among schoolchildren has risen from 10 to 11% with more than one in 10 children aged 11-15 admitting to using drugs over the past 12 months.
fields.body:
 Drug use among schoolchildren has risen from 10 to 11% with more than one in 10 children aged 11-15 admitting to using drugs over the past 12 months.

 One in 10 British adults uses cannabis - higher than anywhere else in Europe. And Britons use more than twice as much amphetamine as others in the EU.

 Since publishing its 10-year strategy, Tackling Drugs to Build a Better Britain, in 1998, the government has unrolled a wide range of initiatives to tackle the problem.

 The latest round in the drugs war is a £200m fund to help police and local authority drugs coordinators fight drug-related crime.

 Alcohol abuse is estimated to cost the British economy £3.3bn a year, mostly through premature death, unemployment and drink-related illness.

 The long awaited national alcohol strategy, similar to the drugs strategy, is not now likely to be implemented until 2003 at the earliest.

fields.headline: Drunken passenger stabbed air hostess
fields.trailText: An air hostess who needed 18 stitches after being stabbed and slashed with a broken vodka bottle by a drunken passenger yesterday admitted she was now scared of flying and announced plans to sue the Airtours charter airline.
fields.body:
An air hostess who needed 18 stitches after being stabbed and slashed with a broken vodka bottle by a drunken passenger yesterday admitted she was now scared of flying and announced plans to sue the Airtours charter airline.

Air hostess Fiona Weir, 32, of Wimbledon, south-west London, gave a Spanish court a horrific account of the Airtours flight from Gatwick to Malaga with a drunken passenger, Steven Handy, in October 1998.

"He nearly took my life. He has practically ruined it," she said after testifying against Handy, 39, at Malaga's provincial court.

"The airlines need to make sure that there is safety for everyone."

Ms Weir said Handy, who admitted drinking almost a litre of vodka, had been allowed on to the flight although he had obviously already been drinking.

"I had my reservations so I informed the supervisor," she told the court.

Handy was told to sit at the back of the plane away from other passengers beside an emergency exit. The cabin crew were ordered not to serve him alcohol. He began to shout at the hostesses as soon as the aircraft doors were shut. Soon after take-off he disappeared into the toilet and smoked a cigarette. Ms Weir said that when she told him not to smoke again he shouted: "I am not smoking, you fucking bitch."

Handy would only calm down when approached by the male cabin staff, but as soon as they disappeared he would become abusive again.

He also beat his head against the seat in front of him, trying to make himself sick, before dropping into an alcoholic slumber. "The passengers were petrified. We had children crying," said Ms Weir.

Ms Weir said none of the crew noticed that Handy continued drinking during the two and a half hour flight from a vodka bottle hidden in his hand baggage.

She complained to her supervisor several times during the flight and eventually told the captain she thought Handy should be arrested at Malaga. When the aircraft landed the captain announced over the tannoy to the passengers that they were waiting for police. This started other passengers swearing at Handy.

Ms Weir stepped in to try and calm everyone down. Suddenly, Handy swung the bottle at her head. "He smashed a litre bottle on my head and I raised my arm to protect my face. He continued smashing the jagged bottle down."

Fellow hostess Nicola Costalas told how Handy pulled the broken bottle from Ms Weir's arm and then plunged it into her back as she lay huddled in the aisle.

Ms Weir said she eventually ran out of the emergency exit and on to the tarmac, where she collapsed. "I received a cut to the left hand side of my head, on the temple, and injuries with lacerations on my right arm and hand," she said. She was still seeing a psychiatrist in an attempt to get over the trauma. Aircraft now gave her claustrophobia and she did not like to go to places where people were drinking. She had worked for a year for another airline but had to stop last February.

Handy, who pleaded guilty to the attack, yesterday appeared in court with a crucifix hanging from his neck and claimed he was a born-again Christian. "I deserve a bit of punishment," he said after he was led handcuffed into court. "I was totally drunk at the time. I remember hitting someone but I don't know why I did it."

Spanish prosecutors yesterday demanded that Handy should receive a six-year prison sentence for attacking Ms Weir and a police officer at a Malaga hospital. The case was adjourned until April 5.

Handy, who fled Spain after the attack, was extradited to Malaga from Britain last year.

Airtours spokeswoman Deborah Sadler said yesterday the airline had not received formal notification of any action by Ms Weir. But Ms Weir's spokeswoman, Caroline Latta, said her lawyers were in contact with Airtours.

webTitle: Albanians sign truce as Serbs enter buffer zone

fields.headline: Albanians sign truce as Serbs enter buffer zone
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanian guerrillas occupying southern Serbia signed a ceasefire yesterday, hours after Nato agreed to allow Yugoslav troops to enter the disputed buffer zone.
fields.body:
Ethnic Albanian guerrillas occupying southern Serbia signed a ceasefire yesterday, hours after Nato agreed to allow Yugoslav troops to enter the disputed buffer zone.

Shefret Miliu, the rebel commander, ordered a 20-day halt to attacks from one minute past midnight, easing fears that the Yugoslavs' arrival would escalate the conflict, which has destabilised the Balkans.

Pieter Feith, the Nato special envoy who mediated the truce, hailed it as a big step towards ending the guerrillas' attempt to make the Presevo valley, which has an ethnic Albanian majority, part of a greater Kosovo.

The Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac, known by its Albanian initials UCPMB, has killed 34 people since moving into the three-mile buffer zone set up in June 1999 keep the Yugoslav army away from Kosovo.

Only lightly armed Serb police were allowed into the strip, putting them at the mercy of about 2,000 rebels armed with mortars, Kalashnikovs and mines.

Covering less than 180 sq km (70 square miles), the zone was turned into a training ground, supply depot and smuggling route for Albanian extremists who now also threaten neighbouring Macedonia.

Under yesterday's accord, Yugoslavia is expected to deploy the 7th Battalion of the Yugoslav 2nd Army into a 16 sq km patch of land adjoining Serbia's border with Macedonia.

Nato and Macedonia are to also step up their patrols.

There are big doubts about the ceasefire, however. At least four factions of the clan-based UCPMB are known to exist, and at some points their trenches are less than 200 metres from Serb positions, putting the rebels' anti-tank rockets easily within range.

Commander Miliu, who only two days ago vowed to fight to the last man, reportedly added a clause saying he could not guarantee the safety of Yugoslav units. "My commanders and I cannot accept responsibility for spontaneous actions of local Albanian elements in [the buffer zone]."

webTitle: Cash boost for black and Asian film-makers

fields.headline: Cash boost for black and Asian film-makers
fields.trailText: The Film Council hopes that the money will encourage black and Asian film-makers from the fringes of British cinema into the mainstream
fields.body:
The Film Council has appointed a full-time executive to encourage Black and Asian film-making in the UK, reports the BBC. Himesh Kar - a former development producer at Tony Garnett's World Productions - will lobby film-makers from the black and Asian communities to apply for the Council's New Cinema Fund - a £5m pot of lottery and other public money.

The move, which seeks to attract black and Asian film-makers from the fringes into the mainstream of British cinema and to allow them to make a broader range of pictures, has won support within the industry.

"From my experience of working in the UK," Elizabeth director Shekhar Kapur told the BBC, "I've recognised the need for a move towards the active promotion of black and Asian film-makers. I think Himesh will bring about an awareness and create and environment that is essential for the growth of talent working here today."

A Film Council representative added, "We never dictate the content of films that come to us. But we would like to not just highlight stories from individual communities, but to get them working in the mainstream."

Kar's scope will range across the genres of horror, romantic comedy, thriller and teen flick - areas in which ethnic minority film-makers are seen as being under-represented.

fields.headline: Sectarian killing spree takes hold
fields.standfirst: More than 40 people have been killed in the past fortnight in tit-for-tat fighting between Sunnis and Shias,   writes Rory McCarthy
fields.trailText: 13 March: Tit-for-tat attacks have claimed 40 lives in the past fortnight, writes Rory McCarthy.
fields.body:
For months after the military took power in a coup 17 months ago, the streets of Pakistan appeared finally rid of the plague of sectarian killings that have claimed thousands of lives in the past decade.

Now the drive-by shootings, murders and attacks are back. More than 40 people have been killed in the past two weeks alone in fighting between extremists from the Sunni and Shia Muslim sects.

Pakistan is a largely Sunni nation and most live happily side-by-side with the Shia minority, who make up 20% of the 140m population.

Extremist groups from both sects, however, are heavily armed and intent on murder.

Nine Sunnis saying evening prayers in a mosque in Lahore yesterday were shot dead and another 11 people were injured.

On Sunday gunmen ambushed a bus in Parachinar, in the North West Frontier, and shot dead seven Sunnis.

The two attacks appear to be retaliation for the murders last week of 12 people in a Shia community in Sheikhupura, in the Punjab.

Police blamed the Sunni militant group Lashkar-e-Jhangvi for the Sheikhupura attack, which they believe was in turn revenge for the execution earlier this month of a Sunni extremist convicted of the murder of an Iranian diplomat a decade ago.

Haq Nawaz Jhangvi, a member of Sipah-i-Sahaba Pakistan (SSP), or the Guardians of the Friends of the Prophet, was found guilty of murdering Sadiq Ganji, the director of the Iranian cultural centre, in Lahore in December 1990.

Jhangvi lost his final appeal earlier this year and was hanged at dawn on February 29.

The next day 14 Sunnis and Shias were killed in a daylight gun battle in the bazaar in Hangu, a small town in the North West Frontier.

In the days before the execution, police had arrested at least 900 SSP members fearing a wave of revenge killings. Now the regime has again warned it will take action against the extremists.

"I want to say this very categorically that anyone who has indulged in such killings and whosoever is behind these killings will be taken to task sternly," Pakistan's military ruler General Pervez Musharraf said.

But some doubt the government's ability to get to the heart of this problem. Attempts in the past year to ban illegal weapons have come to little, other policies appear limited.

In the wake of the latest attacks, the Punjab government banned pillion passengers riding on motorcycles and outlawed the scribbling of slogans in chalk on walls. Both steps, it said, would help prevent such drive-by killings.

Tehrik-e-Jafria, the largest Shia party, said it will launch a protest movement this week to demand the resignation of the Punjab governor for failing to protect their community. The threat comes ahead of the Shia religious festival Muharram, on March 26, which is often a time of sectarian tension.

Last month Pakistan's interior minister, Moinuddin Haider, banned fundraising by militant groups fighting against the Indian army in Kashmir. He has also promised to tackle sectarian violence.

"The provinces have been clearly told to strictly deal with those who cause sectarian violence and indulge in acts of terrorism," Gen Haider said. "Islam does not allow such grisly acts."

fields.headline: Don't get cocky now
fields.standfirst: It's roomy, it's great value and it doesn't look anything like a tea-chest. No wonder Skoda is getting so bigheaded
fields.trailText: It's roomy, it's great value and it doesn't look anything like a tea-chest. No wonder Skoda is getting so bigheaded
fields.body:
The point has been made on this page before (and with due ruefulness) that the golden age of the Skoda joke is over. This seismic development in the history of humour was noted here a while ago in a survey of the Octavia 4x4 - the former communist company's first and celebrated attempt at a four-wheel drive vehicle - and we will have cause to make the point again now in considering the brand new Fabia estate.

Ten years into their association with VW, which brought this seemingly knackered Czech company into revivifying contact with brilliant western innovations such as switches that worked and doors that both opened and closed, Skoda is quite rightly celebrating one of the greatest image turnarounds since Sting remodelled himself as someone with a warm and self-deprecating sense of humour.

Nevertheless, even as one stands to applaud this unlikely recasting, one might have a little difficulty swallowing the use by the company, in some literature regarding the new Fabia, of the phrase "Skoda's traditional values".

It is, after all, a mere decade since Skodas were routinely associated with litter bins. Unless you were going to obliterate history altogether (and there was certainly, for a while, a vogue for that, where Skoda come from), Skoda's "traditional values" would have to include crumbly welding, cow-like sluggishness and a commitment to the tea-chest as a source of aesthetic inspiration. The company has definitely been excitingly reborn, but "traditional values"? There's no need to get cocky.

Needless to say, the Fabia estate doesn't reflect Skoda's traditional values at all. Rather it stands as a shining, silver (in the case of the one that I drove) testament to the company's modern values, which include comfort, roominess, a modicum of unforced style and - even if the days of buying a Skoda for a loaf of bread and a pat of butter are now behind us - extraordinary value for money.

Those values found their best expression yet in the Fabia, in its original, five-door hatchback form, which is like a VW Polo only much smarter to look at and which could even, at a quick glance, be mistaken for something by Audi. The new estate version, in pursuit of further roominess, balloons the car into something far less pretty - but that's the effect with any estate version of any car. The important thing is that the longer Fabia retains the comfort and value for money aspects of the original, which it easily does.

Being a prolonged hatchback, rather than a prolonged saloon, it's not the largest estate car in the world. Country types with Volvos the length of cricket pitches might even scoff at its pretensions to cater for a properly rural life, with all the farming equipment and livestock that inevitably entails.

And true, the Fabia does feel a little more urban than that. It's hard to imagine using it to menace, say, sheep. Still, urban people have their paraphernalia too, and the Fabia is capacious enough. With one of the rear seats down, you could get a coffin in and still have room for a couple of children.

If you're in the market for an estate car, it goes without saying that you have already decided, whether willingly or not, to let your life's baggage take precedence over the pleasures available to you in driving. No one ever got behind the wheel of an estate expecting to raise the hairs on the backs of their hands with the car's performance - except maybe on a winding mountain road. The Fabia is, naturally enough, completely unthrilling to drive. But it moves tightly and tidily and gives no impression that it's about to slew into oncoming traffic at corners, and one can ask for no more from a car this shape.

A problem this expanded Fabia may face - even with its roof rails on - is that estate cars in general are not presently the most alluring or fashionable choice on offer to the urban motorist who is looking for room to stow clobber. These days there is a host of sports utility vehicles and people carriers (both mini and full-size) that come with whole warrens of storage space and allow you to drive around with your spare wheel mounted like a hunting trophy on the back door. (Top Gear magazine has taken to referring, unimprovably, to vehicles at the top-end of this group as "toff roaders".)

But of course it's not everyone's ambition to sit 5ft off the ground in a car that looks like it may originally have been designed to see active service in Korea. For fans of the traditional estate shape, yet ones who don't necessarily need to move grandfather clocks on a regular basis, the compact Fabia may represent the smart selection.

Incidentally, my mother-in-law drives a Skoda. That's not the beginning of a joke. It's a fact.
