fields.headline: A subdued swansong as McQueen leaves Givenchy
fields.standfirst: British designer denied a blaze of glory as he departs fashion house under a fractious cloud
fields.trailText: British designer denied a blaze of glory as he departs fashion house under a fractious cloud.
fields.body:
If Alexander McQueen planned to end his contract with Givenchy in a blaze of glory, he has been disappointed. The Parisian fashion house yesterday announced that Friday's big Givenchy catwalk show, showcasing McQueen's final collection, has been replaced by two low key presentations at the Givenchy salon with fewer than 90 guests at each.

Katie Weisman, international communications director of Givenchy, would say only that "this is a transitional period for Givenchy, and we felt the best way to show the collection was in an intimate show". She confirmed that McQueen will be present at the shows, but it has long been fashion's worst kept secret that there is little love lost between the British designer and the French house.

The final straw in a fractious relationship came late last year when McQueen announced the sale of 51% of his own name collection to Gucci - the fierce rivals of Givenchy owners LVMH. Yesterday's announcement was predictable: why would LVMH shell out for an expensive catwalk show to showcase the talents of a designer who is about to cross the line to the enemy camp?

Friday's audience will be mostly buyers. LVMH may be loth to promote McQueen at this time but naturally it has no intention of forfeiting profit from this collection. A few editors and stylists, mostly from the glossy magazines with whom Givenchy advertise, will be present.

McQueen's replacement at Givenchy is expected to be announced during this Paris fashion week. Main contenders are thought to be Oliver Theyskens, a 24-year-old Belgian, and the 39-year-old Israeli-American Alber Elbaz. Theyskens, admired by Madonna, is a cutting-edge designer whose gothic-leaning creations have sparked arguments over whether they are ugly or brilliant. He is wanted by those at LVMH who crave a designer who will grab headlines for Givenchy. Elbaz favours a less abrasive, more elegant look and won praise during a spell at Yves Saint Laurent.

Another LVMH label, Louis Vuitton, also took to the catwalk yesterday. Under US designer Marc Jacobs, the label has become highly influential and massively profitable. The collection featured plenty of the irony-meets-luxury touches admired by Jacobs' many fans: pom-pom mink buttons on wool twill coats, tiny travel wallets in monogrammed patent leather to swing from the wrist. There were nods to the emerging baby doll trend in a rather frumpy calf-length empire line dress, and in a much nicer big-buttoned short coat.

fields.headline: Public relations: the basics
fields.trailText: • Increased competition among charities for funding means that they are competing to attract public attention.
fields.body:
 Increased competition among charities for funding means that they are competing to attract public attention.

 Managing image, profile and reputation is just as important for charities as running services or other core functions.

 Good public relations is not just about getting more media coverage - communicating with key audiences is more important.

 Celebrity endorsement has become a crucial way of raising the public profile of charities.

 Increasing the media profile of your charity will lead to closer scrutiny of your work.

fields.headline: Public relations: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: Charities seeking to maximise public relations opportunities should also be aware that they may face increased scrutiny from the media about how they operate. Adam Woolf outlines several points to bear in mind when courting the press
fields.trailText: Although there are still a few traditional charities that continue to spurn public relations opportunities, their numbers are dwindling fast. Most charities now realise that if they are to succeed they can ill afford to ignore the ever-growing importance of public relations.
fields.body:
Although there are still a few traditional charities that continue to spurn public relations opportunities, their numbers are dwindling fast. Most charities now realise that if they are to succeed they can ill afford to ignore the ever-growing importance of public relations.

Public image and profile has always been important to charities. Charities need to persuade, convince and reassure the public that the money they donate is well spent and is going to a good cause. The public gets little in return except perhaps a positive feeling from having been involved with the charity. How the public perceives your charity and understands the issues it works with has therefore always been crucial.

Charities now operate in an increasingly competitive environment. There are a growing number of "worthy causes" all competing to attract the public's attention and affection. Although there is a limited amount of money the public can donate, there appears to be a limitless number of charities to give to. Charities are keen to work together and to present a "united front". However, ultimately they are competing with each other. They need to make themselves distinct and stand out from the crowd.

For this reason charities are committing more resources to raising their public profile and managing their reputation. Yet generating more press coverage and profile could be a double-edged sword for some charities. The public is now much more discerning about which charities they wish to support. The media is also more cynical and less deferential compared with the past. Although media organisations may cover a newsworthy event, especially if celebrities endorse it, bear in mind that they will also be only too willing to expose any charity that does not live up to the standards it sets for others.

Huge banner headlines in the tabloid press are not necessarily what every charity needs. The key to good public relations is in knowing which audiences are important to the charity to help it achieve its objectives. For example, if a charity is lobbying doctors and hospital administrators then the medical press is crucial. If it is trying to recruit volunteers for a flag day in the local high street then the local paper must be targeted.

The internet has also changed the way charities conduct their public relations. The internet allows charities to bypass other more traditional forms of media and communicate directly with the public. While this gives charities opportunities to develop stronger relationships with supporters and donors, it also means that charities have to become more transparent. They will need to give the public much more access to information about their work and place more importance on how that information is presented.

Most charities now realise that if they are to succeed they can ill afford to ignore the ever-growing importance of public relations. Public image and profile has always been important to charities. Charities need to persuade, convince and reassure the public that the money they donate is well spent and is going to a good cause. The public gets little in return except perhaps a positive feeling from having been involved with the charity. How the public perceives your charity and understands the issues it works with has therefore always been crucial. Charities now operate in an increasingly competitive environment. There are a growing number of "worthy causes" all competing to attract the public's attention and affection. Although there is a limited amount of money the public can donate, there appears to be a limitless number of charities to give to. Charities are keen to work together and to present a "united front". However, ultimately they are competing with each other. They need to make themselves distinct and stand out from the crowd. For this reason charities are committing more resources to raising their public profile and managing their reputation. Yet generating more press coverage and profile could be a double-edged sword for some charities. The public is now much more discerning about which charities they wish to support. The media is also more cynical and less deferential compared with the past. Although media organisations may cover a newsworthy event, especially if celebrities endorse it, bear in mind that they will also be only too willing to expose any charity that does not live up to the standards it sets for others. Huge banner headlines in the tabloid press are not necessarily what every charity needs. The key to good public relations is in knowing which audiences are important to the charity to help it achieve its objectives. For example, if a charity is lobbying doctors and hospital administrators then the medical press is crucial. If it is trying to recruit volunteers for a flag day in the local high street then the local paper must be targeted. The internet has also changed the way charities conduct their public relations. The internet allows charities to bypass other more traditional forms of media and communicate directly with the public. While this gives charities opportunities to develop stronger relationships with supporters and donors, it also means that charities have to become more transparent. They will need to give the public much more access to information about their work and place more importance on how that information is presented.

webTitle: Natural Born Killers lawsuit finally thrown out

fields.headline: Natural Born Killers lawsuit finally thrown out
fields.trailText: The long-running case which alleged that two killers had been driven to their actions by Oliver Stone's 1994 film has been rejected by a Louisiana judge
fields.body:
The long-running lawsuit filed against Oliver Stone's 1994 movie Natural Born Killers, regarding a 1995 robbery that was said to have been inspired by the film, has finally been thrown out by a Louisiana judge.

The suit was brought to court by relatives of shop assistant Patsy Byers who was shot during the crime and later died. The 18-year-old killers, Sarah Edmondson and Ben Darras, both now serving long-term jail sentences, told police that they had watched the film multiple times before committing their crimes.

Judge Robert Morrison ruled that the film, which starred Woody Harrelson and Juliette Lewis, was protected under the First Amendment, America's free speech statute. The case was first dismissed in 1998, but Byers' relatives won their appeal to the Supreme Court - their claim that Natural Born Killers actually intended to incite crime circumventing the free speech defence. That claim has now been disproven.

Said director Stone yesterday: "The lawyers told me this is a huge victory, but I don't think so. I sympathise with the Byers family, but it's Sarah Edmondson who shot Patsy Byers. It's depressing that a suit that should have been thrown out on the first pass could result in such a waste of time, energy and money. We've created a new legal hell where everyone is entitled and no one is responsible."

Stone's attorney David Wood added: "Litigation of this type chills creative activity." According to a spokesperson for Warner Bros, who produced the film: "Today's decision is an affirmation of the rule of law that we don't hold moviemakers and songwriters and authors liable for the criminal misdeeds of people who don't understand what they're watching, hearing or reading'.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week 28. The experts view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week 28. The experts view
fields.standfirst: With three of our punters losing, has new Blue Square expert The Camel still got the hump? Last week's bets
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £165.54
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £24.08
Paul MacInnes = £20.01
Sean Ingle = £19.82
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £165.54
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £24.08
Paul MacInnes = £20.01
Sean Ingle = £19.82

Scott Murray: Arsenal v Blackburn: Blackburn to win £5 @ 7/1 Bet lost; Blackburn lost 3-0.

Betting for profit is all about obtaining value. 7/1 about Blackburn beating Arsenal at Highbury suggested they had a 12.5% chance of winning. If they had a greater chance than this 7/1 is a value bet. If you consistently back selections whose chance is greater than the odds suggest you will make a long-term profit from gambling.

I must admit, my only bet on this weekend's football was on Blackburn to win (8/1) or draw (4/1) this fixture. The bookmaker's odds gave them a 31.11% chance of achieving this. Given Arsenal's poor recent league form, the fact that they have a massively more important fixture in Munich on Wednesday, Blackburn's huge resurgence in recent weeks and their excellent cup record in recent years, no-one could convince me that this wasn't a value bet.

Opposing teams with important European fixtures on the horizon has proved a profitable source of winners for me over the years.

So, you backed a loser on this occasion. But don't worry because punting is a long-term strategy. If you make bets like this often, you will be a winner in the long run.

Mark Gribbler of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Tottenham to win at West Ham £5 @ 2/1 Bet won £10; Tottenham won 3-2.

Trying to find a value bet in the West Ham v Tottenham clash was impossible. Injury doubts prior to a game make punting a hazardous occupation - and West Ham had worries over Carrick, Stimac, Kanoute and Pearce, while Tottenham were obliged to play Iversen as a wing-back.

Furthemore both teams had indifferent league form in the weeks preceding this match, and the FA Cup was the only possibly route to success for either team this season and both wanted to win this game desperately.

Games with so much at stake rarely provide good betting opportunities. Any of the three possible results wouldn't have surprised me, and therefore I wouldn't have a bet on the outcome of the game.

You correctly predicted an away win. Congratulations. But, I don't think it was a value bet all the same.

The Prince of Punts: West Ham v Spurs: Last goalscorer, Paolo di Canio - £5 @ 11/2

You can approach gambling from many different angles. But the ultimate question you have to answer is: are you betting for fun or profit? If the answer is the former, then Di Canio was a good bet. A last goalscorer bet keeps you interested in the game for 90 minutes no matter what the score is, provided of course your selection lasts the full 90 minutes.

Every time your man gets the ball in the opposition penalty area, your palms sweat, your pulse races and you shout obscenities at the TV screen as the ball bobbles away or he slices his shot high and wide of the target. All in all, if entertainment is your goal from betting, this bet is for you.

But, if you are trying to make a profit from your selections, last goalscorer is the first of the range of bets you would eliminate from your thoughts. Usually, there are five or six more contenders than in the first goalscorer market (the substitutes), and as the prices are identical, this means the bookmaker adds another 25% or so to his profits on the market. As I pointed out last week, first goalscorer betting is one of the most profitable areas for the bookmaker, and last goalscorer is even more valuable.

Paolo Di Canio is perhaps my favourite player in the Premiership. But, I would never back him or anyone else to be last goalscorer. You just cannot expect long term profits from this bet. Please avoid.

Sean Ingle: £5 win double - Tranmere v Liverpool, Liverpool to win @ 4/7; West Ham v Tottenham - draw @ 11/5 Bet lost; Liverpool won 4-2, Spurs won 3-2.

I certainly couldn't be confident about either of your selections. Liverpool must have been exhausted from their tough encounter at Porto on Thursday, and although their squad is as deep as any in the Premiership, I would have expected an adverse reaction in their performance on Sunday.

Before striking a bet, I need to feel confident of all factors that contribute to the outcome of the game, and I certainly couldn't be sure of all of those in this particular clash. The motivation of both teams must be questioned. How motivated will a team be, when they have Uefa cup place already in safekeeping, have a fabulous run going in this season's European tournament and are shooting for the ultimate prize of a Champions League place?

Added to all this, they are playing a team with an amazing cup record for upsetting Premiership teams, who have home advantage in front of a noisy, compact crowd. It would have been easy to see that Liverpool might have struggled. And value at 4/7? I think not.

And, as I have explained above, West Ham v Spurs was also a match to avoid.

webTitle: Angels watch over Brando in new movie

fields.headline: Angels watch over Brando in new movie
fields.trailText: Marlon Brando and American X director Tony Kaye are to collaborate on a film about the Angel of Mons, which is alleged to have appeared during a battle in world war one
fields.body:
Marlon Brando and director Tony Kaye have paid £350,000 to a Gloucestershire architect for ghostly wartime film footage that lay for years in a Monmouth junkshop. The footage, which the soldier who shot it claimed to prove the existence of the famous Angel of Mons, is to form the centrepiece of a movie on which the pair are collaborating, reports the Sunday Times.

The film will reveal the story of one William Doidge, a West Countryman who enlisted for battle in 1914. Doidge was at the Belgian town of Mons in August of that year, when angels were reputed to have appeared in the sky to hold back the advancing Germans and allow British troops to escape.

After the war, Doidge became obsessed with the apparitions, believing they could lead him to his sweetheart, with whom he had lost contact during the war. In 1952, Doidge met an American first world war veteran - to be played by Brando - who claimed that angels had presaged the drowning of American troops during a training exercise at Woodchester Park in the Cotswolds in 1944. Doidge maintained a vigil at the site until he captured the spectral image on camera.

Says Danny Sullivan, the architect who has now sold the footage: "I bought the material in August 1999, but began to look through it only last September. When I realised its significance, I returned to the junk shop, but the trunk [containing the rest of Doidge's archives] had gone."

According to Kaye, the maverick director of American History X, Doidge's story combines the drama of the sinking of the Titanic with the supernatural elements of the Blair Witch Project. "I want to include Doidge's footage of the apparition at the heart of the movie. It will be a spine-tingling moment. This is the closest we have on film to proof of an angel. I've spent much of my life looking at special visual effects, and this is an effect for which I have no explanation."

fields.headline: Aegis bullish in face of slump
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The Aegis Group is bullish about the future of advertising, despite the gloom and doom in the market. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Aegis Group, one of the world's largest media buying and market research businesses, is bullish about the future of advertising, despite the gloom and doom in the market.

The group reported a 21.4% before-tax increase in profits to £78.4m for 2000, at the lower end of market expectations.

But the parent company of media buying network Carat remains optimistic about the group's prospects for the year ahead, despite an expected downturn in the advertising market.

The group also announced the £11.3m acquisition of US marketing consultancy Copernicus by its market research arm Market Facts.

Aegis's turnover was up 19.2% to £5.7bn and the company said it was upping its full-year dividend by 15% to £1.15p per share.

The group won £2bn-worth of new business over the year, including contracts with Warner Lambert, Vodafone, Bertelsmann, Renault and luxury brands BMW and LVMH.

It claims it is benefitting from brands consolidating media accounts on a pan-European and global basis.

The group's large slice of European business will help protect the company from the US advertising slowdown. Less than a quarter of its business comes from the US.

Aegis chief executive Doug Flynn said he was optimistic about the group's prospects.

"Carat Europe remains very much the driver of Aegis's growth in 2000 due to our strong regional presence and the increasing trend toward consolidation of media accounts to a regional agency of choice," he said.

The group is consolidating its market research operations, which account for 32% of the group's revenues, into one global business, Aegis Research.

The acquisition of Copernicus is part of the group's strategy to expand the business by building a global positioning in complementary areas of media and market research.

Related story

fields.headline: Celebrity Big Brother catch-up
fields.standfirst: Your chance to catch up with events in Celebrity Big Brother house
fields.trailText: Your chance to catch up with events in Celebrity Big Brother house.
fields.body:
Mystery of the night: Anthea Turner. She says and does nothing. As Anne Robinson might say, "What is she for?".

Equally unimpressive on the talk front last night was Claire Sweeney. But at least we know she has a day job, in Brookside.

But the biggest relief of the night was Vanessa's eviction. Could she have survived another night? "I don't think I can possibly endure the mass humiliation of everybody hating me so much," she whined to the cameras.

But despite her tears, she will miss the heart-to-hearts. Earlier on she accused Jack Dee of being "ruminative" He admitted he was an oppressive presence, and the unlikeliest couple found some common ground. Could have been the start of a beautiful relationship had she not been so overwhelmingly voted out last night.

webTitle: Straw plan to give up extradition role

fields.headline: Straw plan to give up extradition role
fields.trailText: Home secretaries will no longer be involved in deciding whether fugitives should be sent back to other European countries after Jack Straw's bruising role in the Pinochet extradition case, the Home Office announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Home secretaries will no longer be involved in deciding whether fugitives should be sent back to other European countries after Jack Straw's bruising role in the Pinochet extradition case, the Home Office announced yesterday.

Mr Straw's proposals to reform Britain's 19th century extradition laws also include the introduction of a fast track system to other European Union states based on "Eurowarrants", without a British court issuing a separate warrant for the return of a criminal fugitive to face charges in Britain. Police would have new powers of detention of a fugitive on the basis of a notification through Schengen information system, the common EU police database.

The pressure to reform the extradition laws followed the outcry of the complexity and length of time it took to resolve the request from Spain for the extradition of General Augustus Pinochet to face torture charges. The endless appeals to the high court and to the House of Lords meant the process took nearly two years.

Reform would require a new extradition law approved by parliament. Most of the extradition requests Britain makes abroad involve the return of serious criminals on the run, such as the road rage killer Kenneth Noye, and many involve Spain. The new extradition procedures would also apply in Irish-British cases which in the past have been fraught with difficulties.

"No one should be able to escape justice simply by crossing a national border. The Extradition Act is now over 10 years old with some of its provisions dating back to previous centuries. We are still using 19th century mechanisms to fight 21st century crime. The proposals announced today seek to remove, where possible, delays in our present system," said Mr Straw.

The extradition proposals, which Britain intends to adopt unilaterally, would see the home secretary withdrawing from any role in deciding cases involving other EU countries. Mr Straw faced accusations of political bias from all sides when he was supposed to set aside his Labour politician's hat and act only in a neutral "quasi-judicial role" in the Pinochet case.

Requests from other EU countries are also to be streamlined so that they are decided by a single hearing before a circuit judge with only one appeal allowed to the high court rather than the repeated applications for judicial review which were heard in the Pinochet case. Appeals to the House of Lords will only be taken on points of law.

In cases involving requests for extradition from outside the EU, Whitehall civil servants will take over the role of the home secretary at the beginning of the process but he will keep his final discretion in cases which have political implications or where the fugitive may face the death penalty if they are sent back.

webTitle: But the Sun can say anything it likes. Can't it?

fields.headline: But the Sun can say anything it likes. Can't it?
fields.standfirst: When a clerk sued the Sun for harassment, the paper wheeled out its freedom-of-speech defence - and lost.  Clare Dyer on a ruling that has the tabloids in a tizzy
fields.trailText: The likes of Naomi Campbell brandishing Britain's emerging privacy laws could turn out to be the least of the tabloids' worries. Campbell, who is furious over a story about her sortie to a Narcotics Anonymous meeting, joins Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones - narked over the publication of snatched photos of their wedding in Hello! magazine - in the list of celebs invoking the Human Rights Act to defend their right to a private life. But now a new weapon has emerged which threatens not just to spike a few intrusive exposés, but to change the face of tabloid journalism. If it succeeds, a judge was told in a private hearing this month, it will "turn the Sun into a parish gazette".

She was at "rock bottom" when she read the readers' letters in the Sun a few days later. "In the article they named me, said I was a black clerk and named the station where I worked. "I just felt very vulnerable. I was in a front-line role. At any time somebody could come in and leap over the counter. The London Race Discrimination Unit, part of Lambeth Law Centre, took on her case. In a private preliminary hearing, the Sun argued that her case was hopeless and had no legal basis, and asked the judge to strike it out or enter judgment for the paper. The Sun's counsel admitted that the articles were "strident, aggressive and inflammatory" but denied that they were racist. But the judge said that adjective, too, was justified. The colour of Thomas's skin had no bearing on the matters reported, he added, unless the paper was implying that she took the action she did because of her race.

The Sun argued that the Protection against Harassment Act could cover doorstepping by reporters, but not the articles they wrote. Its counsel claimed that a ruling to the effect that the act covered newspaper reports would transform media law. He cited a statement by Lord Hoffmann, the law lord, that apart from the established exceptions or new ones enacted by parliament, freedom of speech was "a trump card which always wins".

But the judge ruled that the act was just such an exception. It required a "course of conduct", so a single article would not be enough; and harassment included causing alarm or distress. "Thus in my judgment the act does give the claimant a right to protection from harassment by all the world including the press," the judge concluded. The paper would have a defence if it could show that its conduct was reasonable.

The Sun is taking the case to the court of appeal. It could go all the way to the House of Lords. Lawrence Davies hopes that some celebrities, who could have a new and simpler route open to them if the ruling stands up on appeal, will contribute to a fighting fund for Thomas. She has no legal aid and could be liable for substantial costs if the Sun wins on appeal.

"It was so inevitable that she would receive race-hate mail as a result of that article," says Davies. "This paper has a circulation of 3m and is read by up to 12m people. I think they have a moral duty to be much more careful."

webTitle: Sun can be sued for distress, court rules

fields.headline: Sun can be sued for distress, court rules
fields.standfirst: A judge has held that victims of media reports which cause "alarm or distress" can sue for damages for harassment, reports Clare Dyer
fields.trailText: A judge has held that victims of media reports which cause "alarm or distress" can sue for damages for harassment, in an unprecedented judgment that opens a new route of redress against newspapers.
fields.body:
A judge has held that victims of media reports which cause "alarm or distress" can sue for damages for harassment, in an unprecedented judgment that opens a new route of redress against newspapers.

The Sun is appealing against the unpublicised ruling, won last week by Esther Thomas, a civilian clerk for the City of London police, who sued the paper under the Protection Against Harassment Act.

The act was brought into force in 1997 to protect the victims of stalkers but it does not spell out what behaviour amounts to harassment. It simply says that speech is covered, that there must be a "course of conduct" and that the conduct must cause the victim alarm or distress.

For celebrities and others, it could open an easier and simpler means of redress than the privacy law emerging under the Human Rights Act, whose limits are still undefined.

Geoffrey Bindman, a media solicitor who acts for Keith Vaz, Anna Ford and other high profile clients, said: "It's very good news. It is highly desirable that there should be a remedy for innocent people who are hounded by the media and whose lives are seriously damaged by media harassment."

In a private hearing at Lambeth county court in south London, the Sun asked Judge Roger Cox, the senior judge at Lambeth, to strike out the action or enter judgment in its favour. It argued that the case was hopeless and had no legal basis. But the judge ruled last week: "The act does give to the claimant a right to protection from harassment by all the world, including the press."

The articles reported that a complaint by Ms Thomas, who is black, against four officers over their behaviour when a Somali asylum seeker sought help had led to the demotion of two sergeants and a £700 fine for a PC.

In the first article, under the headline Beyond a joke: Fury as police sarges are busted after refugee jest, the paper quoted a "fellow cop" as saying: "It was essentially light hearted banter in private and the Somali never heard. This is political correctness gone mad."

Ms Thomas, who was named in the article and described as a "black clerk", received race hate mail at the police station. The following week the paper published a selection of readers' letters attacking her for making the complaint and ruining the sergeants' careers. These were followed by a story seeking readers' contributions to pay the PC's fine.

The Sun admitted the pieces were "strident, aggressive and inflammatory", but denied they were racist. The judge said that in his opinion the description "racist" was justified.

The ruling is not limited to racial harassment, but covers anything causing alarm or distress if at least two articles are published. If only one was published it would not satisfy the requirement for a "course of conduct".

The judgment has alarmed newspaper executives, who are seeking legal advice on its implications. The Sun's counsel, Matthew Nicklin, told the judge that if newspaper reports were covered by the act it would turn the Sun into a "parish gazette" and transform media law in Britain. The case is expected to go to the court of appeal later this year.

Lawrence Davies, Ms Thomas's solicitor at the London Race Discrimination Unit, said: "I think it will go all the way to the House of Lords."

Robert Clinton of Farrer & Co, the Sun's solicitors, said: "It's effectively a brand new course of action. It would be an extraordinary further string to the bow of potential claimants. Any investigative journalism you do now that amounts to more than one article could make you liable under the act."

webTitle: Cult fear hits Bush plan to fund by faith

fields.headline: Cult fear hits Bush plan to fund by faith
fields.trailText: George Bush's plan to channel US government aid to "faith-based" religious charities is being held back by the fear that it could end up funding controversial groups such as The Church of Scientology, Hare Krishna and the Unification Church - the Moonies.
fields.body:
George Bush's plan to channel US government aid to "faith-based" religious charities is being held back by the fear that it could end up funding controversial groups such as The Church of Scientology, Hare Krishna and the Unification Church - the Moonies.

The initiative, launched with great fanfare at a White House prayer breakfast in the president's second week in office, has stirred up a hornet's nest of accusations across the spectrum of religious groups and is being radically redrafted.

The decision to delay its introduction was taken at the end of last week after an unexpected war of words on the religious right threatened to derail the entire scheme.

"We're postponing," Don Eberly, deputy director of the White House office in charge of the faith-based programme, announced yesterday. "We're not ready."

The prospect of the billion-dollar initiative channelling large sums of public funds into the coffers of fringe groups is a very real one.

The groups have made it clear that they are anxious to get a slice of any government funding. For example, the Church of Scientology has said it will seek government aid for its drug rehabilitation and literacy programmes, which are based on the "dianetics" theories of the group's founder L Ron Hubbard.

The Hare Krishnas are gearing up to solicit federal funds for their prison release halfway houses and shelters for the homeless.

And the Rev Sun Myung Moon's church, now called the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification, is planning to ask for taxpayers' money to promote its sexual abstinence programmes in schools.

Conservative Christian bodies have expressed anxiety that Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam organisation, which runs several rehabilitation and education schemes for black American prisoners, might also try to become a beneficiary of Mr Bush's initiative. Mr Farrakhan has said he is not interested, however.

The furore raised by the plan - a central plank of the "compassionate conservative" platform on which Mr Bush campaigned for the presidency last year - has taken an entirely different turn from the one his advisers expected.

The administration prepared for an outcry from organisations and public figures who oppose any links between church and state.

What it did not expect was that most of the loudest criticism would come from the conservative Christian right, which was expected to be among the most vociferous supporters.

The critics include the veteran conservatives Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell, as well as Richard Land of the influential Southern Baptist Convention.

But perhaps the most remarkable opponent is Marvin Olasky, the guru of compassionate conservatism and a former Bush adviser whose ideas are at the root of the entire faith-based strategy.

In an article in the Wall Street Journal yesterday, Mr Robertson described the prospect that Scientologists might be beneficiaries of the scheme as "an intolerable situation".

Mr Falwell, in an interview last week, objected to Islamic groups having access to federal funds.

But the main complaint, which they share with Professor Olasky, is the White House declaration that religious groups which receive federal funds must not proselytise for converts. Such a condition would threaten "their very raison d' tre", Mr Robertson says.

Prof Olasky told a meeting last week: "I cannot give blanket support now because I am not willing to support discrimination in grant-making against evangelicals."

At the heart of the problem is the fact that the faith-based groups whose work he wishes to support are overwhelmingly evangelical, and see their welfare and religious roles as inseparable.

Mr Bush, on the other hand, wants to avoid being seen as the prisoner of the religious right. He said from the outset that he wished to fund the groups' welfare work but not their attempts at religious conversion. To Prof Olasky and Mr Robertson that decision negated the whole purpose of the programme.

In addition, many of the religious groups are worried about the consequences of such links with the federal government. "With the king's shillings come the king's shackles," Mr Land told an interviewer at the weekend.

The furore leaves the future of the planned White House bill on the faith-based initiative up in the air. The administration originally intended a bill to authorise federal funding of religious groups and to preserve the tax deductibility of donations to such groups.

"There is an innate mistrust of government among the religious right," said Robert Boston of Americans United for Separation of Church and State. "With government funding comes government regulations. Suddenly a lot of the groups are having second thoughts."

fields.headline: BSkyB takes option on football radio
fields.standfirst: Premier league broadcaster gets satellite platform in return
fields.trailText: BSkyB yesterday extended its influence over English football with an option to take a stake in Radio First, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
BSkyB yesterday extended its influence over English football with an option to take a stake in Radio First, the media group that plans at least four stations dedicated to premier league clubs.

The agreement also guarantees carriage for Radio First's network of stations on Sky Digital for the next five years.

Radio First, which listed on the alternative investment market a year ago, has set up joint ventures with Aston Villa, Chelsea, Derby County and Southampton and hopes to complete similar deals with other clubs. Each station will broadcast audio coverage of the club's matches as well as discussion programmes, phone-ins and music, using the slogan "Hot music, hot football". The first four will launch to coincide with the next football season.

"These are good quality general entertainment stations, which also have the strong branding of the football clubs and the rights to cover a team's matches," said Radio First's chief executive, John Aumonier, a former managing director of Talk Radio.

In return for carriage on the Sky platform, BSkyB will have an option to take 18% in the company at any point in the next five years at an agreed price. The stations will also carry Sky News Radio for news and sport bulletins.

BSkyB, which has now reached 4.7m digital homes, will carry up to eight football-related stations, each broadcast to the clubs' local region.

Last week, Radio First raised £3.6m by placing 4.5m shares with institutional investors conditional upon the deal being signed with BSkyB. Shares in Radio First, which have more than halved in value since the company joined the market, fell another 7.5p to 85p.

Ken Bates, Chelsea chairman, described the station as "another positive step in the development of our joint media activities".

The stations will be broadcast from the football stadiums and will be owned 50/50 by the clubs and Radio First.

Mr Aumonier said Radio First was in discussions with other digital platforms including the owners of the various digital radio multiplexes currently being awarded.

"These are good quality general entertainment stations, which also have the strong branding of the football clubs and the rights to cover a team's matches," said Radio First's chief executive, John Aumonier, a former managing director of Talk Radio. In return for carriage on the Sky platform, BSkyB will have an option to take 18% in the company at any point in the next five years at an agreed price. The stations will also carry Sky News Radio for news and sport bulletins. BSkyB, which has now reached 4.7m digital homes, will carry up to eight football-related stations, each broadcast to the clubs' local region. Last week, Radio First raised £3.6m by placing 4.5m shares with institutional investors conditional upon the deal being signed with BSkyB. Shares in Radio First, which have more than halved in value since the company joined the market, fell another 7.5p to 85p. Ken Bates, Chelsea chairman, described the station as "another positive step in the development of our joint media activities". The stations will be broadcast from the football stadiums and will be owned 50/50 by the clubs and Radio First. Mr Aumonier said Radio First was in discussions with other digital platforms including the owners of the various digital radio multiplexes currently being awarded.

fields.headline: Don't believe the hype
fields.standfirst: EastEnders has never enjoyed so much publicity - especially on the BBC. But has it paid off for BBC drama bosses or is a relentless stream of picture stories in the newspapers ahead of a major cliffhanger a turn-off for viewers? We analyse last week in the life of EastEnders and its ITV rival Coronation Street.
fields.trailText: Julia Day compares how the PR machines went into action for last week's EastEnders and its rival Coronation Street.
fields.body:
Soap: EastEnders
Age: 16
Distinguishing feature: Mel, actress Tamzin Outhwaite, is the week's It girl.
Storyline: Classic Albert Square whodunnit - Phil is shot following Mel and Steve's wedding.
Publicity: Blanket coverage in newspapers and on TV listings front covers.
Audience high: 15.6m, 60% of those watching TV at the time tuned in on Tuesday to see Steve find out about Mel's dalliance with Phil. Thursday's 40-minute shooting episode scored 15.4m, a 58% share.
Audience low: The build up to Mel and Steve's wedding on Monday had 14m viewers, a 53% share.
Did it pay off? Yes, everybody was talking about who shot Phil. But it pales in comparison to the 25.3m who tuned in to see Grant discover his wife Sharon was having an affair with his brother Phil.
The week ahead: Will the viewers keep tuning in to find out whodunnit, or will they get bored?

Soap: Coronation Street
Age: 40
Distinguishing feature: None, unless you count Ken's hair.
Storyline: Classic Ken versus Mike battle - this time over custody of Adam. Emma's shooting inquest is the sub-plot.
Publicity: Apart from a pair of Vera Duckworth's knickers fetching £150 at a charity auction, stories of a different kind abound - ITV executives tell producers to improve storylines.
Audience high: 14.1m, a 56% audience share tuned in on Monday to see Linda backed in to a corner by her family.
Audience low: On Friday 12.7m, a 53% share tuned in to see Emma face up to the inquest verdict.
Did it pay off? Yes. The goings-on in Albert Square dominated the headlines, but the Street managed to maintain a strong audience.
The week ahead: An hour-long special for the 5,000th episode on Sunday hopes to grab the headlines.

What the publicity machines say:

EastEnders: "Hardly a radio or TV chat show passed without an EastEnders artist on it. We promoted online, through broadcast trails and were all over the front covers, and it worked. The essence of the campaign was to attract as much attention as possible and deny that space to our competitors... It is a cyclical thing with Coronation Street but it's always satisfying when viewers vote with their remote control and EastEnders comes out on top."

Coronation Street: "Publicity goes in circles, it's swings and roundabouts. We couldn't move before Christmas for publicity surrounding the 40th anniversary and our live episode - we were even in the Wall Street Journal for that. We have not been sitting back because of what's happening on EastEnders and we also haven't thought, "Okay, what can we do as a spoiler?". For Easter we have two major storylines coming up and it's frustrating because we can't come out and say what they are."

But are all soaps the same?
Most certainly not. BBC radio institution the Archers never divulges storylines because listeners simply will not countenance it. "The Archers follows the changing seasons and its stories unfold in real time. So our listeners prefer to discover what happens in Ambridge on the day it's meant to happen - not in advance," said Archers editor Vanessa Whitburn.

Soap: The Archers
Age:50
Distinguishing feature: The Dum de dum de dum de dum theme tune. Also, the soap has attracted rabid packs of violently sectarian Archers fans, including the Archers Anarchists who believe the show's actors are impostors.
Storyline: Will scheming Kate kidnap the daughter she once abandoned and smuggle her off to South Africa? Kate's new partner Lucas has caused an unusual outbreak of restraint in Ambridge - with no one mentioning he is black. Plus the female vicar and local GP nearly had an affair, but not quite.
Publicity: The Archers cast parties the night away with Prince Charles to celebrate the programme's 50th birthday. Camilla astounds all by calling Jolene "a bit of a slapper" for having an affair with a married man.
Audience: The most up-to-date figures, for the last quarter of 2000, reveal the evening show has 2.4m listeners, the lunchtime repeat and the Sunday omnibus both attract 2m.
Did it pay off? We won't be able to tell until the next set of quarterly listening figures are published, by which time Ambridge will be embroiled in fresh drama and intrigue. Or maybe not.
The week ahead: Kate's "will-she won't she run off with the baby" saga continues.

fields.headline: Where is the sex?
fields.standfirst:
Police have warned that two photographs of naked children displayed at the Saatchi gallery could be seized under indecency laws. Tierney Gearon , who took the pictures, insists they are innocent images of her children doing 'everyday things in a beautiful way'.
Talk about it
fields.trailText:
Police have warned that two photographs of naked children displayed at the Saatchi gallery could be seized under indecency laws. Tierney Gearon , who took the pictures, insists they are innocent images of her children doing 'everyday things in a beautiful way'.
Talk about it
fields.body:
I looked at my pictures today and tried to see the bad things in them that other people have seen. But I can't. Some are describing them as pornographic, others are accusing me of exploiting my children's innocence. I don't understand how you can see anything but the purity of childhood. When the exhibition opened eight weeks ago, the Observer's art critic, Laura Cumming, wrote that I had succeeded in capturing the way that a child would look at the world, almost as though I was a child myself. The exhibition got great press, and the whole experience has been positive - until last Thursday, when I went to the gallery to do an interview and found the police waiting for me. I was completely blown away. I even started joking around with the officers because I simply couldn't believe it was happening. I don't see sex in any of those prints, and if someone else reads that into them, then surely that is their issue, not mine.

I have been documenting my family through pictures for over two years, and I take snapshots of everyday life. I think that the pictures are incredibly innocent and totally unsexual. I don't crop them, I don't retouch, and the shots are never staged. I might introduce an element, like a mask, to a given situation, but I would never insist that the child put it on. The photograph of my little boy naked on a pedestal, for example, happened completely spontaneously. My mother-in-law was going to a wedding, and she came over to the pool to say goodbye to my son, who was splashing about naked. He ran up on to the pillar and looked down at her. I happened to have my camera there, and I took the picture. That's how all these pictures come into being.

My kids - Emilee, who is seven years old, and Michael, who is four - are everything to me. Some people have asked whether I worry that they will have problems with the pictures as they get older. But I don't think they will be embarrassed because I have never made them feel ashamed of their bodies, or of their nudity. If you are raised in an open environment, and taught to have confidence in yourself and your self-image, then it's fine. As for the suggestion that these photographs represent an invasion of my children's privacy, I would counter that I've done it to myself, and to my entire family, too. And if I had had any doubts, then my kids' pride in the exhibition immediately dispelled them.

I never went to art school, and have no formal training in photography. After spending five years as a model followed by another five years working as a fashion photographer, I was thoroughly bored with the whole fashion industry. I had got married and had my two children, and was beginning to ask a lot of questions about myself. Becoming a mother is a major step for any woman: that transition from a single person doing your own thing to a person with responsibility for other human beings inevitably leads you to question your identity. Out of the blue, about two years ago, an art director friend of mine called up. He encouraged me to start documenting my family as a personal project.

About a year ago, Kay Saatchi, whom I know through mutual friends, asked me to donate one of my photographs to an auction she was organising for the children's charity, Tommy's Campaign. Then I donated another photograph to a charity exhibition raising funds for the homeless, and somebody bought it. I didn't discover until two months later that that someone was Charles Saatchi.

In April last year, I took my kids on a road trip across the States, visiting family along the way. I took more pictures, and showed the results to Charles when I returned. It was then that he decided to include my work in I Am a Camera.

I was amazed. I had had no intention of exhibiting on that scale - I had thought that perhaps I would publish a book in 20 years' time. The fact that I was showing pictures of my family in public didn't hit me until the exhibition opened and I saw those massive prints hanging on the wall. But if I had ever had any doubts, they were completely dispelled at the opening. My dad flew over from New York, my brother came with his four- year-old son, and my two children would take strangers by the hand and point out to them their favourite pictures. It was such a special moment. My kids were so proud of me and of themselves.

I would never exploit my children. They are such a huge part of my life, and I am always very honest with them. I would never take their photograph unless they felt OK with it. Some would argue: "How do you know that they really feel OK? Don't they just want to please you?" Of course I am aware of those issues. For example, when I took the photograph of my son peeing in the snow, he registered that this was something that pleased me and made me laugh. He started posing and peeing at every opportunity: "Hey, mom, I'm peeing, take a picture!" Of course I didn't, because I'm aware that there is a danger of your child doing things to please you rather than because they feel comfortable doing it. Similarly, my daughter is an incredibly sensuous little girl, and will sometimes strike poses that are rather erotic, as most little girls do. Again, I would never take a picture of her like that and exhibit it, because I wouldn't want to go there.

Of course, there is a place for censorship in our society, and I find it amazing the amount that the authorities do let slip by. But this is nothing compared to that. This is art. This is kids in masks doing a silly pose. I don't go out of my way to take pictures of them while nude. These are six images out of a show of 15, and those 15 make up a tiny proportion of the photos I have taken over a lifetime.

I find it hard to fathom why the police have picked on these particular shots in this particular exhibition. Sally Mann's portraits of her daughter, for example, are far more sexualised than mine. My pictures are about a captured moment, rather than about the person. They are about a feeling, and to that extent they preserve my children's anonymity. They are disguised somehow. I'm showing a moment of life, not part of their personality, and to that extent they could be anyone. Compare the pictures with Richard Billingham's work, where you really get to know his family. After seeing my shots, you have no idea of what my kids are about.

I have been completely taken aback by the reaction over the weekend. I appreciate that this is a difficult subject, about which people have complex and mixed feelings, but the level of reaction has surprised me.

Essentially, this is all a question of perception. It's like this: someone shows another person a blot of ink and asks them what they see. They reply: "I see a German shepherd dog." Then they show them another blot, and they see a springer spaniel, then another and they see a doberman. The first person exclaims: "Say, you sure do have an obsession with dogs." And the second replies: "You're the one who keeps showing dog pictures."

What do you think?
Talk about it

As for the suggestion that these photographs represent an invasion of my children's privacy, I would counter that I've done it to myself, and to my entire family, too. And if I had had any doubts, then my kids' pride in the exhibition immediately dispelled them. I never went to art school, and have no formal training in photography. After spending five years as a model followed by another five years working as a fashion photographer, I was thoroughly bored with the whole fashion industry. I had got married and had my two children, and was beginning to ask a lot of questions about myself. Becoming a mother is a major step for any woman: that transition from a single person doing your own thing to a person with responsibility for other human beings inevitably leads you to question your identity. Out of the blue, about two years ago, an art director friend of mine called up. He encouraged me to start documenting my family as a personal project. About a year ago, Kay Saatchi, whom I know through mutual friends, asked me to donate one of my photographs to an auction she was organising for the children's charity, Tommy's Campaign. Then I donated another photograph to a charity exhibition raising funds for the homeless, and somebody bought it. I didn't discover until two months later that that someone was Charles Saatchi. In April last year, I took my kids on a road trip across the States, visiting family along the way. I took more pictures, and showed the results to Charles when I returned. It was then that he decided to include my work in I Am a Camera. I was amazed. I had had no intention of exhibiting on that scale - I had thought that perhaps I would publish a book in 20 years' time. The fact that I was showing pictures of my family in public didn't hit me until the exhibition opened and I saw those massive prints hanging on the wall. But if I had ever had any doubts, they were completely dispelled at the opening. My dad flew over from New York, my brother came with his four- year-old son, and my two children would take strangers by the hand and point out to them their favourite pictures. It was such a special moment. My kids were so proud of me and of themselves. I would never exploit my children. They are such a huge part of my life, and I am always very honest with them. I would never take their photograph unless they felt OK with it. Some would argue: "How do you know that they really feel OK? Don't they just want to please you?" Of course I am aware of those issues. For example, when I took the photograph of my son peeing in the snow, he registered that this was something that pleased me and made me laugh. He started posing and peeing at every opportunity: "Hey, mom, I'm peeing, take a picture!" Of course I didn't, because I'm aware that there is a danger of your child doing things to please you rather than because they feel comfortable doing it. Similarly, my daughter is an incredibly sensuous little girl, and will sometimes strike poses that are rather erotic, as most little girls do. Again, I would never take a picture of her like that and exhibit it, because I wouldn't want to go there. Of course, there is a place for censorship in our society, and I find it amazing the amount that the authorities do let slip by. But this is nothing compared to that. This is art. This is kids in masks doing a silly pose. I don't go out of my way to take pictures of them while nude. These are six images out of a show of 15, and those 15 make up a tiny proportion of the photos I have taken over a lifetime. I find it hard to fathom why the police have picked on these particular shots in this particular exhibition. Sally Mann's portraits of her daughter, for example, are far more sexualised than mine. My pictures are about a captured moment, rather than about the person. They are about a feeling, and to that extent they preserve my children's anonymity. They are disguised somehow. I'm showing a moment of life, not part of their personality, and to that extent they could be anyone. Compare the pictures with Richard Billingham's work, where you really get to know his family. After seeing my shots, you have no idea of what my kids are about. I have been completely taken aback by the reaction over the weekend. I appreciate that this is a difficult subject, about which people have complex and mixed feelings, but the level of reaction has surprised me. Essentially, this is all a question of perception. It's like this: someone shows another person a blot of ink and asks them what they see. They reply: "I see a German shepherd dog." Then they show them another blot, and they see a springer spaniel, then another and they see a doberman. The first person exclaims: "Say, you sure do have an obsession with dogs." And the second replies: "You're the one who keeps showing dog pictures." What do you think? webTitle: Nancy Banks-Smith on Jack Dee's escape

fields.headline: . . . and then there were four
fields.trailText: Nancy Banks-Smith on Jack Dee's escape
fields.body:
"I am a free man!"

- The Prisoner.

When Chris Eubank was voted out of Celebrity Big Brother (Channel 4), Jack Dee made a run for it. Every single person in the house had voted for Eubank's eviction. Never again would he upstage the lot of them by whizzing across the room on a scooter in his kaftan. He left with his customary swagger, swinging his whangee cane. If it wasn't a whangee cane, you feel it should have been.

Well, you never miss your mother till she's buried 'neath the clay. As he left, Jack Dee said "He's the most entertaining man I've ever met." And that night he left too.

2.59am: Vanessa was in bed, free in sleep from the daily worry about her hair extensions turning up in the soup. Anthea, Claire and Keith, what John Cleese calls celebrity pond life, were gambolling in the celebrity pond, a hot tub in the garden. Only Dee was hacking away at the earth with a light rake, perhaps with vague memories of POWs concealing soil in their trousers. You would think that Big Brother, whose sole claim to fame is that he watches you, might have smelled a rat. Very few people garden in the dark, except Lady Dorothy Macmillan, who used to beaver away wearing a miner's helmet. The rest are burying relatives.

3.11am: Dee found a back gate open and went. "Security is immediately alerted." Shot of bloke in fluorescent jacket running about a bit.

3.31am: "Security still haven't found Jack." Shot of guard dog looking confused.

3.43am: "Jack is discovered crouching behind a security hut in the Big Brother compound and is immediately returned to the house." Shot of Jack escorted by two guards like Eugene Aram. (That is one of the things I will miss about Chris Eubank, his habit of laying decomposing old poems and rotten bits of philosophy confidently at your feet like a cat.)

The hot tubbers greeted Dee like a litter of puppies. His face was blackened with mud. He was not in merry mood but, then, how can you tell with Dee. He had, he gruffed, got to Stratford. "But I've come back. It's for Comic Relief. I just wanted to get out." And he shot a look of loathing at the camera.

Bow to Stratford is a grim yomp. On one side lie Hackney marshes, famous for being visible wiv a ladder and some glasses if it wasn't fer the 'ouses in between. On the other, the Thames. Put it this way, a man with a blackened face in a black sweater can walk from Bow to Stratford in the small hours without anyone expressing interest or surprise.

Celebrity Big Brother's psychologist (of course it has a psychologist) identified Dee at once as the alpha male, apparently on his ability to open a bottle of champagne, but the show's bookmaker, assessing the odds, noted "Jack Dee can't contain his indifference." In other words, he could win but he can't be bothered. In any prisoner of war film, Jack would be the one who got shot for saluting sarcastically. If he is voted out on a Free Willy wave of pity, we will be left with minnows.

webTitle: Blair to tighten law after internet babies scandal

fields.headline: Blair to tighten law after internet babies scandal
fields.trailText: The government is planning to rush out a bill before the election to encourage a 40% increase in legal adoptions and stop parents bringing children into Britain after irregularly taking control of them abroad.
fields.body:
The government is planning to rush out a bill before the election to encourage a 40% increase in legal adoptions and stop parents bringing children into Britain after irregularly taking control of them abroad.

Legislation will be published on Thursday to implement proposals from a white paper in December. Health ministers had not intended to proceed with them in a second Labour term, but they have been overruled by Tony Blair.

He ruled that more urgent action was required following hostile public reaction to the case of the internet twins, brought into Britain in January after adoption in an Arkansas court by Alan and Judith Kilshaw. The Kilshaws bought the babies through an internet site run by a Californian child broker.

Parliamentary draftsmen were understood last night to be working on a comprehensive overhaul of adoption law. It is expected to make it illegal for Britons to adopt children at home or overseas without first being judged suitable by an approved adoption agency.

fields.headline: John West lands best advert of the year
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The John West Salmon advert featuring a fisherman fighting a grizzly bear has been hailed as the best TV advert of the year. By Claire Cozens.
Picture gallery: the winners
See the advert: Adcritic.com
Jan 25: Web watchers follow the bear
fields.body:
The John West Salmon commercial featuring a fisherman in hand-to-hand combat with a giant grizzly bear has been lauded as the best TV advert of the year.

Leo Burnett's creation, which has already achieved cult status around the world, swept the board at last night's Creative Circle awards, picking up a platinum award as well as two golds, a silver and a bronze.

The quirky advert, which shows a giant grizzly bear fighting a fisherman over one of his freshly-caught salmon, became an international cult phenomenon after it appeared on the US website adcritic.com.

It was the only advert to pick up a platinum award, the Creative Circle's top accolade.

Dave Waters, creative director of Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters and the chairman of the judges, said the advert was a very fresh script, was directed with great style and energy and was the only advert that had made the entire room erupt with laughter.

Other gold winners in the TV category were Leagas Delaney's Anthony Hopkins commercial for Barclays Bank, Saatchi & Saatchi's TV advert for Club 18-30 and Miles Calcraft Briginshaw Duffy's advert for the now-defunct internet service provider Breathe.

Fallon's campaign for Skoda, which was widely credited with transforming the fortunes of the car manufacturer, also picked up several awards.

The "Motorshow" commercial won two gold awards in the TV category, including one for most encouraging change of advertising direction.

The agency also picked up golds for best house advert and best specialist press advert for an advert that ran in the trade press and read simply, "There's a waiting list for the new Skoda".

Leo Burnett maintained its strong performance in the press category, picking up two golds for its Heinz Salad Cream campaign.

The campaign, which uses the line "Any food tastes supreme with Heinz Salad Cream", has also been credited with turning around an ailing brand.

webTitle: Foot and mouth's impact on tourism

fields.headline: Daffy Caffy not so much a goldmine, more a liability
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The six-week boom which makes the Daffy Caffy a little goldmine has become the latest victim of foot and mouth, whose devastating effect on rural tourism has now closed the unique wild daffodil valley of Farndale.
fields.body:
The six-week boom which makes the Daffy Caffy a little goldmine has become the latest victim of foot and mouth, whose devastating effect on rural tourism has now closed the unique wild daffodil valley of Farndale.

No one will take the path tramped every year by some 35,000 visitors in March and April when drifts of the species cover the banks of the River Dove in north Yorkshire.

"It's heart-breaking, especially for small businesses at the head of the dale," said Bill Breakwell of the North York Moors national park, which has had to close all footpaths and bridleways.

The Daffy Caffy's owner, Joanne Marshall, surrounded by empty tables, takes a stoical view, after surviving a poor season last year when rain saw visitor numbers well down.

But the quarantine imposed on the national park, which has also seen the authority cancel the Farndale daffodil bus, which gets visitors to the remote valley, is causing increasing alarm.

The daffodil tourist invasion ranks among the North York Moors' top earners, with millions of bulbs forming an unforgettable sight.

webTitle: Dealer seeks amnesty for help in tracing infected sheep

fields.headline: Dealer seeks amnesty for help in tracing infected sheep
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The dealer who allegedly brought foot and mouth disease to Northern Ireland has made an appeal for amnesty in return for information which would allow all the sheep he imported from Carlisle to be fully traced.
fields.body:
The dealer who allegedly brought foot and mouth disease to Northern Ireland has made an appeal for amnesty in return for information which would allow all the sheep he imported from Carlisle to be fully traced.

John Walsh, from Offaly in the Irish republic, made the offer on RTE radio to be passed on to Irish agriculture minister, Joe Walsh.

But the minister replied that while immunity from charges was a matter for the department of public prosecution, he was in no mood to give any amnesty. He said: "People have a duty to give information."

John Walsh said: "I said I could satisfy Joe Walsh and Brid Rodgers [Northern Ireland's agriculture minister] with 100% trace or accountability of the sheep, and all I asked for was special conditions."

Northern Ireland has so far had just one confirmed outbreak, in south Armagh, where 21 of Mr Walsh's Carlisle consignment were later destroyed.

Another 270 sheep from the consignment are thought to have been illegally transported into the republic, where there have been no reports of the virus.

webTitle: Farmers protest at plan for huge cull of sheep

fields.headline: Farmers protest at plan for huge cull of sheep
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Britain faced a precautionary mass cull of sheep yesterday as the foot-and-mouth virus spread further through the country.
fields.body:
Britain faced a precautionary mass cull of sheep yesterday as the foot-and-mouth virus spread further through the country.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, revealed that up to 500,000 ewes might have to be slaughtered to halt the outbreak, as the Ministry of Agriculture confirmed 19 more cases, taking the total to 183.

Tony Blair promised to begin a series of talks tomorrow with farmers and others hit by the outbreak.

Officials were making it a priority to discover how the virus spread to the West Midlands, which reported its first case in a herd of cattle at a farm in Little Wyrley, Pelsall, near Walsall.

The disease has now been found in 23 counties, although most cases are clustered around Devon, Cumbria and Northumberland.

Jim Scudamore, the government's chief veterinary officer, said that the cases identified so far had been spread as a result of livestock movements through Longtown market in Cumbria and a sheep dealer in Devon.

So far around 120,000 animals have been killed and a further 40,000 await slaughter.

Farmers reacted angrily to the proposals for mass slaughter of sheep. The ewes need to be moved from winter quarters for the lambing season, and to free pastures for cattle in the spring, but could spread infection if moved.

"This plan is absolutely ridiculous," said Anthony Gibson, director of the National Farmers Union in the West Country. "I can understand why they do not want sheep being brought back to home farms but the sensible thing is for them to give birth where they are.

"A lot of farmers have already made arrangements to do this. It is sometimes inconvenient, but sheep have been giving birth to lambs unaided for thousands of years."

Mr Brown admitted yesterday that the outbreak was of a "different order" than previously thought, but continued to insist it was under control.

He added: "There has been a tremendous amount of disease incubating in the national flock. We are now dealing with the problem which is on a different scale to the one it was three weeks ago."

New regulations to fight the disease came into force at the weekend after the European commission ordered that the tyres of vehicles leaving the UK must be disinfected.

Mr Scudamore said that the current movement ban in infected areas - 30 days after slaughter and initial disinfection - could be extended.

But there was fresh criticism from Ireland as another minister attacked Britain's handling of the crisis.

"There are new areas with outbreaks all the time. They don't seem to have got it under control, and that is of major concern to us here, because what happens in Britain could have disastrous consequences for this country," said junior agriculture minister Eamon O'Cuiv.

Stormont minister Brid Rodgers confirmed that department of agriculture vets were investigating a suspected case in a sheep in Augher, Co Tyrone, which had been taken to an abattoir in Dungannon.

There has only been one confirmed case in Ulster, on a farm in Meigh, south Armagh, which is believed to have orig inated from a market near Carlisle where almost 300 sheep were bought and taken to Northern Ireland.

But Mrs Rodgers said the consignment might have been larger than previously thought and some animals could have been smuggled into the Irish Republic, which so far remains clear of the disease.

The republic has introduced emergency legislation to crack down on illegal dealing and police and soldiers have mounted a massive operation at the border to prevent the spread of the virus. Major events have been cancelled, including this Saturday's St Patrick's Day parades in Dublin and Belfast.

Mr Brown said: "It is not right to say that we are not dealing with it correctly. The important thing is that we stick together. The whole of the European Union has a vested interest in eradicating this disease in Britain."

fields.bodyText: Britain faced a precautionary mass cull of sheep yesterday as the foot-and-mouth virus spread further through the country. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, revealed that up to 500,000 ewes might have to be slaughtered to halt the outbreak, as the Ministry of Agriculture confirmed 19 more cases, taking the total to 183. Tony Blair promised to begin a series of talks tomorrow with farmers and others hit by the outbreak. Officials were making it a priority to discover how the virus spread to the West Midlands, which reported its first case in a herd of cattle at a farm in Little Wyrley, Pelsall, near Walsall. The disease has now been found in 23 counties, although most cases are clustered around Devon, Cumbria and Northumberland. Jim Scudamore, the government's chief veterinary officer, said that the cases identified so far had been spread as a result of livestock movements through Longtown market in Cumbria and a sheep dealer in Devon. So far around 120,000 animals have been killed and a further 40,000 await slaughter. Farmers reacted angrily to the proposals for mass slaughter of sheep. The ewes need to be moved from winter quarters for the lambing season, and to free pastures for cattle in the spring, but could spread infection if moved. "This plan is absolutely ridiculous," said Anthony Gibson, director of the National Farmers Union in the West Country. "I can understand why they do not want sheep being brought back to home farms but the sensible thing is for them to give birth where they are. "A lot of farmers have already made arrangements to do this. It is sometimes inconvenient, but sheep have been giving birth to lambs unaided for thousands of years." Mr Brown admitted yesterday that the outbreak was of a "different order" than previously thought, but continued to insist it was under control. He added: "There has been a tremendous amount of disease incubating in the national flock. We are now dealing with the problem which is on a different scale to the one it was three weeks ago." New regulations to fight the disease came into force at the weekend after the European commission ordered that the tyres of vehicles leaving the UK must be disinfected. Mr Scudamore said that the current movement ban in infected areas - 30 days after slaughter and initial disinfection - could be extended. But there was fresh criticism from Ireland as another minister attacked Britain's handling of the crisis. "There are new areas with outbreaks all the time. They don't seem to have got it under control, and that is of major concern to us here, because what happens in Britain could have disastrous consequences for this country," said junior agriculture minister Eamon O'Cuiv. Stormont minister Brid Rodgers confirmed that department of agriculture vets were investigating a suspected case in a sheep in Augher, Co Tyrone, which had been taken to an abattoir in Dungannon. There has only been one confirmed case in Ulster, on a farm in Meigh, south Armagh, which is believed to have orig inated from a market near Carlisle where almost 300 sheep were bought and taken to Northern Ireland. But Mrs Rodgers said the consignment might have been larger than previously thought and some animals could have been smuggled into the Irish Republic, which so far remains clear of the disease. The republic has introduced emergency legislation to crack down on illegal dealing and police and soldiers have mounted a massive operation at the border to prevent the spread of the virus. Major events have been cancelled, including this Saturday's St Patrick's Day parades in Dublin and Belfast. Mr Brown said: "It is not right to say that we are not dealing with it correctly. The important thing is that we stick together. The whole of the European Union has a vested interest in eradicating this disease in Britain." What's going on?
