fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Lambing looms - we could be working our socks off day and night, and all for nothing

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Lambing looms - we could be working our socks off day and night, and all for nothing
fields.body:
We're very impressed. We've had an acknowledgement from Maff almost by return (posted from Carlisle on Sunday) regarding our occupational movement licence, allowing us to move our animals up to 500m around the farm. Here's hoping we'll now get one. The staff at the regional service centre at Carlisle (and all around the country) must be working flat out.

Tempers are frayed (Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, is quite right); although this is normal at lambing time, our lambing is still two weeks away. One of the worst problems affecting farming families is the isolation. All sheep farmers expect to grind their way through lambing and not see anybody for three to six weeks, depending on the number in their flocks. But the present shutdown of the countryside is causing serious hardship and unhappiness.

We have two flocks, so we stagger the starting dates. First we do the Mule ewes then, 14 days later, the Scottish Blackfaces start. If we did not do this we would be overwhelmed by the number of lambs: we are expecting around 1,890. We had the ewes scanned in the new year to find out which are having one, two or three lambs. The scan is an invaluable aid to shepherding. The ewes are marked according to the number of lambs they carry. When lambing starts we find it much easier to match up ewes with only one lamb with a spare lamb from a ewe with three. Ideally, every ewe would rear two lambs as each has two teats, but of course this does not always happen, and the scanning helps us to prepare. We would hate to return to the dark ages when every time a ewe lambed we wondered how many she would have.

Peter is dejected this morning. He fears that stock farms, including ours, may be hit by this virulent disease, but possibly not until after lambing. So we would all work our socks off day and night for weeks and then perhaps succumb. It is not a pleasant thought, but there is another reason for his deep-grounded fear.

In 1980, during a routine annual blood test for brucellosis - a contagious disease in cattle which causes abortion - a large percentage of cows on this farm were found to be "reactors" and the herd was condemned.

According to our farm records the fateful testing procedure was carried out on February 5 1980 and the results came through on the 19th. Of 211 cows tested, 105 were infected. On February 22, Peter and his late father, William, were informed that the cows were to be taken. Three days later the herd was valued and the next day they were all rounded up and driven away. Peter says he will never forget the loading of the wagons, especially the lifting on, by hand, of the smallest and newest calves; nor the silence after the wagon convoy had left the farm.

Peter is welding the trailers, in readiness for when we have our occupational licence. I am making plans to get the precious licence laminated when it arrives, as the rules stipulate we have to carry it with us at all times when moving animals around the farm. This could be wearisome, as when lambing is fully under way the trailers go back and forth from field to shed all day long and the licence will have to go too.

This year is one we will never forget. We will always think of this outbreak as farming's millennium bug. Nature cannot be thwarted, except perhaps by the most stringent precautions, and although looking at our questionable import strategies may be unpalatable for some, it is essential to prevent such a tragedy happening again.

We have just heard the BBC news. One of the latest options apparently put forward is to kill half a million sheep trapped away from home on winter grazing, and to hold the local elections in May as normal. Voting is the last thing on our minds, but finding out more on this proposed cull of presumably healthy, uninfected sheep is a must. I don't know enough to comment just now but Peter and I are quite shocked. And our friend Jane Murray has just phoned to say they still wait to be released from quarantine by a vet.

On a happier note, a new bull calf was born this afternoon. He is up on his feet and sucking lustily from his mother's udder.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She is writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

fields.headline: Savill jumps to racing defence
fields.standfirst:
Board chairman says the show goes on as farmers' threats subside
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: British Horseracing Board chairman, Peter Savill, yesterday strongly defended the decision to carry on racing in the face of the present foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
British Horseracing Board chairman, Peter Savill, yesterday strongly defended the decision to carry on racing in the face of the present foot and mouth crisis.

Savill made his comments, his first public utterances on the subject, at Plumpton where he is also chairman and which had come under fire from angry local farmers for its decision to go ahead with the meeting.

Savill's blunt message was that despite a great deal of emotion on the decision to carry on, racing's heart should not rule its head.

He said: "The outbreak is a concern not just for the farming fraternity but to the whole of the country. The outbreak is under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Agriculture.

"There is no doubt in my mind that if they believed that there was any risk whatsoever of racing continuing and adding to the dangers of spreading the outbreak then they would have come to the decision that racing should not continue. They would have instructed us to introduce a ban.

"As long as the ministry is happy for racing to continue we have a responsibility to our own industry and not to put the 100,000 or so people employed in racing at risk. It is a huge industry, and the seven- day break we have had already showed what damage a ban could do."

Savill likened the outbreak to the HIV virus some years ago. "When people thought that being in the same room as a sufferer put you at risk. Of course, that was not true, but the public was not ready to accept the medical evidence put before them and I fear we may have the same situation here. I have to leave the emotional side out of it and go by the scientific evidence of the ministry."

When asked why Ireland had banned racing and Britain had not, he replied: "When should we say we will be governed by another country's decision? Our government is the British government and therefore we must be guided by what they say.

"But of course we understand the emotional pressure a lot of farmers are under in their daily fears when inspecting their stock. I know that generally throughout the farming community there is a strong feeling that they would prefer racing not to take place. However, farmers and rural people are the backbone of the National Hunt sport.

"Look at the entries in hunter chases which are farm-based - there is still strong support for that type of race. If the decision to carry on racing had been the reverse, how many people would we have in our own industry who would be up in arms?"

Savill pinpointed how betting turnover was dramatically down in the week-long break which proved that British racing was fundamental to the betting industry, and added: "I think we have set an example as a sport to other sports in the way we have dealt with this.

"On the Irish decision - and I live in Ireland a lot of the time - that country is much more rural and agriculturally based than ours. They make their own rules, but I fear that if they stay closed for a long time they will come under fire."

The threats of roadblocks and the course being ploughed up by irate farmers failed to materialise. There was a strong police presence in surrounding lanes but the only action reported was that road signs to the circuit had been turned round to point in the opposite direction.

Yet there could not have been a more ironic result to the first race when Leggies Legacy, trained by Lawrence Wells, who runs a 100-head long-haired Ireland cattle herd alongside his stables at Billinghurst in West Sussex, romped in at 20-1.

Wells was embarrassed by the win. "I would have preferred that racing would have been off. This is a very touchy subject and I know all my farming friends think we should not be racing.

"I think the BHB should have called the sport off altogether earlier and not resumed. Yet I have owners who want to race and I've got to listen to them. I can't just sit at home."

fields.headline: 'Depressed farmers left to languish'
fields.trailText: Rural doctors and nurses have warned that the foot and mouth outbreak could leave stressed farmers without access to adequate support, as surgeries in affected areas are closed and home visits cancelled. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Rural doctors and nurses have warned that the foot and mouth outbreak could leave stressed farmers without access to adequate support, as surgeries in affected areas are closed and home visits cancelled.

Doctors fear farmers already reeling from the impact of BSE will suffer serious mental health problems as the crisis continues. A Devon GP has counselled three suicidal farmers in the past week, while helplines for stressed farmers have been inundated with calls.

There are now 183 confirmed cases of across the country, with 935 farms under restriction and 116,000 animals already slaughtered.

The department of health and Wales' chief medical officer Dr Ruth Hall have issued emergency guidelines about working in affected areas to all primary health care professionals via their health authorities and local health groups.

They are:
 Park vehicles at farm entrances rather than taking them on farmland;
 Disinfect vehicle wheels before your journey;
 Give farmers advance notice of visits;
 Vehicles should cross straw soaked in disinfectant when entering or leaving farms;
 Wear wellington boots and disinfect them leaving or entering a farm.

Devon GP Dr Asad Al-doori was forced to close his branch surgery in Winsford last Wednesday after several cases of the disease were confirmed.

He has visited affected farms to counsel suicidal farmers. "I've dealt with three serious cases of farmers contemplating suicide in the past week, as well as five seriously depressed families and another nine or 10 people who were just extremely upset."

But because Dr Al-doori has visited infected farms he has been barred by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food officials from visiting any other farms for five consecutive days.

He said: "I had to deal with a suicidal farmer on the phone because there was a suspected case on his farm. The health authority has provided me with a locum in case there is an emergency on another farm."

Farmers have the highest occupational suicide rate in the UK, with 79 farm owners and managers, horticulturists and farm workers in England and Wales killing themselves in 1999.

Nurse Jon Munsey, community mental health team leader for Torridge, north Devon, said the macho culture of the farming community meant many people in desperate need did not ask for help.

"Unfortunately, suicides have always been high as most farmers have access to shotguns," he said.

Carolyn Davies, director of the Rural Stress Information Network, said: "People are breaking down in tears on the phone. They're shell-shocked.

"We're speaking to the benefits agency to see whether they can arrange crisis loans - at 0% interest - for all workers affected by the outbreak."

Community psychiatric nurses fear that restrictions on home visits will lead to vulnerable patients deteriorating. Phil Brace, charge nurse at the mental health resource centre in Ystradgynlais, near Swansea, said there had been a 20% reduction in home visits locally.

He said: "Even routine visits are essential as we're the only people checking up on farmers in isolated areas. They may forget to take their medication because they're stressed about their farms and become more depressed. But it's difficult to adequately assess the risk of suicide without seeing them."

Health visitor Alison Allen, south-west chairwoman of the Community Practitioners and Health Visitors Association, said: "Some of our local members are feeling fairly desperate as they are married to farmers. So they can't get out to help their patients and are worried about their own farms."

Powys GP Dr John Wynn-Jones, director of the Institute of Rural Health, warned health services could not cope if more staff were barred from visiting patients. "They're aren't enough doctors to provide cover in north Wales.

But Dr Nicol Black, consultant in communicable disease control health said only essential home visits would be approved. "Just going to check up on granny Smith to see whether she's ok is not really justifiable," he warned.

fields.headline: Short sharp shock
fields.standfirst: When he visited an army training scheme for disaffected children, John Crace expected a boot camp. Instead, he found a surprising success story
fields.trailText: When he visited an army training scheme for disaffected children, John Crace expected a boot camp. Instead, he found a surprising success story.
fields.body:
I suppose it was inevitable really. At the first hint of an emergency, the government is generally quick to announce its plans to send in the troops to mop up the floods or drive the ambulances and fire-engines. So the only surprise is that it is has taken this long for the army to be sent into schools.

After successful trials in Norfolk and Newcastle, the government last week confirmed that it was planning to spend a further £600,000 to hire members of the armed forces to work with 14- to 16-year-olds in schools in Manchester, Merseyside, Leicester, Bristol, the West Midlands and London. The scheme, called Skill Force, which is targeted at those teenagers who are already disaffected or perceived to be at risk of becoming so, aims to work with the school system to reduce truancy and disruption by teaching practical and vocational skills at KS4 instead of a modern foreign language and a science subject.

Put the words army and school in the same sentence and you automatically think Willie Whitelaw, "short, sharp shocks" and boot-camp discipline. And when I arrive at Methwold High School, one of the three Norfolk schools taking part in the project, that looks exactly what's on offer. Eighty pupils - some from Methwold High, the rest from the other two schools taking part, Hamond's High School in Swaffham and Wayland Community High School in Watton - are gathered in the hall while two soldiers in combat fatigues patrol the front of the stage waiting for an army recruitment video to begin.

"Er, it's unfortunate that you've come today," says Captain Brett Jarvis, the course leader who is dressed in civvies and looking every inch the teacher. "I know it looks terribly militaristic, but it isn't really. Part of the Skill Force course involves potential employers giving a presentation to students about what they do and what sort of people they are looking for. Today it's the army's turn."

But it's no coincidence that two of the half dozen or so employers to have made presentations so far are the navy and the Royal Air Force. The Ministry of Defence is supplying the trainers for the course, recruitment levels are down and any quid pro quo is gratefully received. For their part, the children are completely unfazed by any military overtones. Some are planning to enlist on leaving school anyway, and those who aren't seem to reckon that anything is better than sitting in classes. "I thought it was going to be all marching when I signed up for this option," says Richard Mather, a year 10 student at Wayland, "but I didn't mind as I don't like foreign languages."

Marching isn't on the menu, and PT is the closest anyone gets to basic training. "It can't be a military operation," jokes Capt Jarvis, " as the transport doesn't turn up two hours late." What is on offer are basic key skills incorporated into the bronze and silver Award Scheme Development and Accreditation Networks (Asdan) syllabuses, together with the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh's award, the St John's lifesaver awards and some outdoor environmental experience.

Were Alastair Campbell to set foot in Wayland Community High School, he would no doubt immediately declare it a "bog standard comprehensive". It has the usual range of abilities and social groupings; its GCSE attainment levels are slightly above the national average but, like most schools, it has its fair share of problems - including disaffected and disruptive pupils. For the school, the relaxation at KS4 that allows the national curriculum to be disapplied under certain circumstances has been something of a godsend, and when it was approached to join in the army's pilot scheme it responded enthusiastically.

At all three schools in the Norfolk project, the pupils were given the final say on their participation, but in all cases it seems that a fair degree of social engineering was involved in deciding who should be offered the option in the first place. Methwold took the route of asking for volunteers from those who were lacking in self-confidence and were unlikely to cope with the GCSE syllabus, Hamond's opted for a mix of the non-academic and those with behavioural difficulties, while according to Brett Jarvis, Wayland went the whole hog and put forward 22 of their most disruptive kids.

Chris Dix, Wayland's headteacher, is slightly defensive at this suggestion. "We followed the guidelines that were put forward by the army," he says. "We chose from across a range of academic abilities those who were disaffected or in danger of becoming so. I would accept, though, that some of the students are quite challenging."

Dix need not have been so protective of his students' sensibilities; they wouldn't see their behaviour as challenging so much as the stuff of nightmares. "I'd been suspended twice for swearing at teachers and messing around in class and was regularly picking up four detentions a week," admits Mather. "My parents were starting to have a real struggle getting me to go to school in the morning." Mather's was a familiar story. "I'd been suspended at least twice for swearing and talking back to teachers," says Barry Ford. And so on. Martin Gisborne had been in constant trouble for fighting and backchatting. "The school split me up from the group I used to hang around with and put me in isolation," he says. "It just frustrated me even more so I started messing around even worse."

The point is, though, that after six months on the course they all claim - and the school agrees - that their behaviour has improved beyond all recognition. "I've only had one detention and I haven't felt like bunking off," says Mather. "I thought it was about time I sorted myself out," says Gisborne. There has also been a further knock-on benefit of improvements in their GCSE curricular work. So what is the secret?

Brett Jarvis acknowledges that it was an uphill struggle for the first few months as the kids pushed the limits to see what they could get away with, but believes that it was their interest in what they were doing and the strength of the relationships that he and the two sergeants, Tony Shuttleworth and Bertie Burtenshaw, were able to forge that proved the clinching factor. "I think they liked the fact that we didn't come across in the same way as the teachers they have known," says Jarvis. "The two sergeants have proved to be extremely effective role models. Neither were particularly academic at school, but by applying the very principles we are teaching here, have gone on to be successful."

The kids see it slightly differently. They enjoy the work - "less boring, more useful" - and the sanction of being slung off the course is a great deal more effective than being banned from maths, but what they really seem to appreciate is being treated as adults. "If you get wound up and think you're going to lose your temper they let you take five minutes out," says Matthew Balls. "A teacher would think you were trying to skive off if you asked for time out." "They don't say 'Do this' or 'Do that'," says Mather. "They tell you what's expected and let you get on with it. If you need help they'll give it but they let you complete the work to your standard, not some curriculum standard. So you feel like putting more effort in."

Skill Force is no panacea. Some of those on the course have a reading age of seven, many are statemented and some are on medication for behavioural problems, and the course does not replace all the usual pastoral measures to cope with disruption. What it does do at the very least is contain the problem. The pressure on teachers' time is horrendous at the best of times and disruptive kids take up more time than most. With the disaffected channelled into something that interests them, teachers are free to give their time to the 28 kids who want to learn rather than the two who don't.

There is a danger that such schemes will introduce a two-tier system at KS4 and Mather acknowledges that his father had reservations about him dropping Double Science. But Dix thinks such worries are an irrelevance. "The students will still be doing GCSEs," he says, "but in any case there always was a two-tier system. Kids are very quick to identify their levels of ability, and many of the less able quickly recognised that they weren't going to be able to cope with the curricular work early in year 10 and identified themselves as failures. With Skillforce we are providing a course at which they can succeed and thereby raise their self-esteem."

Endorsements for the scheme have come from all quarters. Allan Rimmer, the administrator for the Association of Workers for Children with Emotional and Behavioural Difficulties, is pleased that the course recognises the importance of continuing to teach key skills, such as numeracy and literacy. "Disruptive children need the curriculum, too, and we welcome anything that finds an effective way of teaching it," he says.

Jenny Mosley, one of those at the forefront of introducing Circle Time into school, is also in favour. "You can't underestimate the importance of team-building and leadership in helping those with emotional difficulties," she says. "What I would want to make sure is that there was time included in the course for reflection. Experiences are often very immediate, and you only get to understand the processes involved by thinking about them at a later date. That is very often where the learning takes place."

The one dark cloud on the horizon is money. Despite the new funding, no one seems to have worked out that if you want to continue the scheme it will involve running two parallel groups. Wayland plans to continue the current course when the year 10s move into year 11, but has a queue of year 9 punters eager to sign up for the autumn. "The army is trying to accommodate us by offering us more time," says Dix, "but even so it would involve an overall reduction in the time each year group would get. We think this sends out all the wrong messages to the students."

Joined-up government only goes so far, it seems.

fields.headline: KitKat games to appear on mobile phones
fields.trailText:
8.30am:Nestle is to promote its Chunky KitKat bar with interactive games on mobile phones, writes Julia Day.
Feb 23: Labour joins text message frenzy
Feb 22: Phone companies crack down on 'spam'
Feb 22: January text messaging breaks records
Feb 7: Lastminute strikes text message deal
Feb 1: McDonald's plans text message marketing blitz
fields.body:
When it was first coined, the slogan "Have a break, have a KitKat" was all about putting your feet up during your coffee break.

Now, however, food giant Nestle is preparing to launch KitKat games on mobile phones.

The interactive games will be used as an advertising vehicle for Chunky KitKat.

This is the first time the packaged-goods giant has used mobile phones for marketing.

Nestle is expected to start integrating mobile marketing into its future marketing strategies following the trial of the KitKat games in Germany.

"Marketing via mobile phones is an interesting way of communicating - we wanted to try it out," said Frank Schuebel, marketing director at Nestle.

Mobile phone service company 12snap is masterminding the campaign for Nestle.

McDonald's, American Express and Lastminute.com have all signed messaging deals with 12snap over the past two months.

12snap chief marketing officer and co-founder Cyriac Roeding said: "Our partnerships with McDonald's, American Express and Nestle mark a major breakthrough for mobile marketing in Europe.

"12snap offers the most direct channel to young consumers, who are often the most difficult to reach," he said.

The company operates in Germany, the UK and Italy and has more than 400,000 users.

Its campaigns have generated high response rates of between 6-12%, around 15 times higher than that for traditional direct marketing campaigns.

Mobile phone text messaging is rocketing in the UK. A record-breaking 929m text messages were sent in Britain last month, according to official figures from the Mobile Data Association.

Related stories

Feb 7: Lastminute strikes text message deal

fields.headline: BBC to swipe rugby rights from Sky
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The BBC is set to secure the TV rights to England's autumn home rugby union internationals, writes Jason Deans.
Mar 8: Tetley Bitter renews rugby deal
fields.body:
The BBC is set to secure the TV rights to England's autumn home rugby union internationals from BSkyB.

ITV has decided against bidding and it is thought the Rugby Football Union is close to sealing a deal with the corporation.

If the deal goes through it will provide a much-needed morale boost to the BBC sports department, which has been battered by a series of devastating losses over the past five years.

Negotiations are still continuing with the Rugby Football Union for a range of TV rights to England rugby union internationals and club fixtures.

These will be part of a three-year package estimated to be worth around £150m in total.

But BBC Sport insiders are privately confident they will win back rights to the three Twickenham internationals.

The matches are held before Christmas each year against southern hemisphere opposition such as New Zealand, Australia and South Africa.

BSkyB snatched the rights to all England's home international fixtures, including the autumn matches and post-Christmas Five - now Six - Nations games and domestic club rugby in an £87.5m deal three years ago.

The satellite broadcaster's international contract runs for another season but the club rights are up for grabs from the end of this season.

The RFU came in for much criticism within the sport for entering into the exclusive deal with BSkyB.

Dissenting voices argued that by signing up for satellite TV, which draws lower audiences than terrestrial coverage, rugby union's profile was diminished along with the revenue earning potential from sponsorship.

Now it is thought the RFU is looking favourably on the BBC's bid to win back exclusive live rights to the England internationals.

The BBC's confidence will also have been boosted by the knowledge that ITV, its main terrestrial rival, is not bidding.

ITV did not submit a bid before the RFU's January 31 deadline, arguing the autumn internationals were not worth having without live Six Nations coverage.

The commercial broadcaster is understood to have reassessed its commitment to rugby union.

It is also not expected to bid for the Six Nations or the 2003 World Cup when the rights come up.

ITV will concentrate instead on its existing portfolio of live Champions League football, Premier League highlights and live Formula One motor racing.

Related story

fields.headline: City watchdog clamps down on media leaks
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The FSA is revising guidelines that state companies must not leak sensitive information to papers, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The UK's financial watchdog is launching a renewed crackdown on the notorious "Friday night drop".

The Financial Services Authority is revising guidelines that state companies must not leak sensitive information to newspapers.

Regulators are determined to stamp out the practice of companies leaking news to Sunday newspapers instead of announcing it to the stock market - a practice known as the Friday night drop.

"People are becoming more conscious of this issue and we need to clarify it.

"The guidance will make it clear the Friday night drop is against the rules," said an FSA spokesman.

The FSA will emphasise that when the Stock Exchange's regulatory news service closes at 6.30pm, information that could affect a company's share price must be released to two news wires and two newspapers.

The information must then be announced on RNS at the start of trading on the following day.

However, the FSA spokesman said the guidelines will focus on listed companies and not journalists.

"We are not talking about journalists here. Our rules apply to listed companies, so this updated guidance will not cause any upset for journalists," added the spokesman.

But the news will add to the pressure on financial journalists, who already have the Financial Promotion Act hanging over their heads.

The act proposes journalists tipping shares they own must declare an interest.

This has provoked a furious reaction from UK newspapers, which claim it subjects journalists to criminal controls.

webTitle: Jamjar's £10m spend produces few car sales

fields.headline: Jamjar's £10m spend produces few car sales
fields.standfirst:
Advertising brake

More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Direct Line admitted yesterday it is selling only 500 cars a month through its jamjar.com website, despite spending £10m on television advertising. By Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Direct Line admitted yesterday it is selling only 500 cars a month through its jamjar.com website, despite spending £10m on television advertising.

On that basis the commercials cost £1,666 for every car sold, but jamjar.com says it expects sales to double by mid-year. Direct Line, owned by Royal Bank of Scotland, is investing £50m in jamjar and expects to break even this year.

Jamjar said it was selling as many cars in a day as a small forecourt dealer would in a month. However, even if it achieves 1,000 sales a month its share of new car sales will remain below 0.1%.

About 2m new cars are sold annually in Britain, and the biggest dealer, Dixons Motors of Doncaster, account for 75,000 of them.

Jamjar spokesman Justin Skinner said: "What we are building is the UK's leading online car retailer. We are not saying that it will replace traditional dealerships. The advertising campaign has resulted in very high name awareness; the cost per customer at the moment is misleading because what we are doing is building a brand."

Jamjar claims to have saved its customers a total of £2m since launch nine months ago by undercutting manufacturers' list prices. It said its best-selling car is the Ford Focus, where it offers savings of more than £2,000 on Ford's list price.

webTitle: Ebookers signs up for London listing

fields.headline: Ebookers signs up for London listing
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Online travel firm Ebookers.com has announced it is to list its shares on the London Stock Exchange, reports Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Ebookers.com, the online travel firm, yesterday announced it is to list its shares on the London Stock Exchange, shrugging off the turmoil in the hi-tech sector.

The London-based firm, already listed on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt and the Nasdaq, also confirmed that it aims to move into profit by 2002.

Navneet Bali, Ebookers' chief financial officer, said the company was seeking a London listing to give it access to future funding from UK-based investors, even though it is not raising any new money at the moment. Despite the negative sentiment about online companies, it had decided to stick to its plans rather than waiting for a market recovery.

"The move brings us closer to our investor base in our largest market," Ebookers said. "It is expected to allow us access to institutional funds that could not previously buy Ebookers.com stock."

Mr Bali emphasised that the firm, which raised $45m from European institutional investors last July and has $50m in the bank, has enough cash to take it into profitability.

"We are not raising new money." said Mr Bali. "It is just a technical listing that allows our ordinary shares to be traded." Ebookers hopes London trading in its stock will begin before the end of March. It has no plans to change its listings on Nasdaq and the Neuer Markt at present.

The news came as the company reported a fourfold increase in fourth quarter sales to $36m (£24.5m), up from $9m for the same period in 1999. Full year sales reached $123.5m, up from $23m in 1999, with registered users increasing from 740,000 at the end of the third quarter to 850,000 at the end of 2000.

Ebookers said its pre-tax loss, excluding stock compensation, was $40m - compared to $7m in 1999.

Chief executive Dinesh Dhamija said: "Losses have gone up so much because we spent a lot more on sales and marketing in the first half of last year."

Mr Bali said sales and marketing costs would continue to be reduced. As a percentage of sales, they fell from 34% in the first quarter of 2000 to 17% in the fourth quarter.

"Since mid-1999 we've grown tremendously, and obviously we've had to invest a lot in technology as well as sales and marketing to build a brand," Mr Bali said. "All that is behind us now."

Analysts were yesterday positive about Ebookers' results.

"They seem on target to be profitable at the end of 2001 or the start of 2002, and revenues were pretty good for an online business", one analyst said.

However, the analyst was sceptical about the interest the firm could expect to receive from institutional investors because of the relatively small size of the business.

Mr Dhamija also admitted yesterday that Ebookers, which has expanded into 11 countries including Spain, Switzerland and Ireland, is on the hunt for acquisitions.

"We want to go into Italy and into the business side of travel," he said. "I would also like to acquire larger leisure companies in Germany and France." Shares in the company have plunged in line with the rest of the technology sector - from a high of 44 euros in March they fell yesterday by 0.27 euros to 3.33 euros.

webTitle: CNN obtain photo of Taliban destroying statues

fields.headline: CNN obtain photo of Taliban destroying statues
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: CNN is claiming to have secured an exclusive picture of the destruction of the two Buddha statues by the Taliban, writes Jason Deans.
fields.byline: Jason Deans; additional reporting by staff and agencies
fields.body:
CNN is claiming to have secured an exclusive picture of the destruction of the two Buddha statues by the Taliban earlier today.

The photo of the demolition of one of the huge stone statues - carved into a cliff in the Bamiyan valley, in central Afghanistan - which has been condemned by the UN, was taken by an amateur Afghani freelance photographer.

CNN declined to give further details of how they obtained the image, for fear of giving away the identity of the photographer.

The hardline Taliban regime in Afghanistan had tried to prevent any photographs or footage of the destruction of the statues.

The news that an international outcry had failed to save the monuments, carved more than 1,500 years ago, came from the Unesco director general, Koichiro Matsuura, whose special envoy, the French diplomat Pierre Lafrance, confirmed that the statues had been destroyed.

webTitle: Bob the Builder builds ratings empire in the US

fields.headline: Bob builds ratings empire in the US
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Bob the Builder, the animated construction worker and idol of a generation of pre-schoolers has succeeded where some of Britain's brightest hopes have failed and cracked the lucrative American entertainment market.
fields.body:
Bob the Builder, the animated construction worker and idol of a generation of pre-schoolers has succeeded where some of Britain's brightest hopes have failed and cracked the lucrative American entertainment market.

Ratings released yesterday for the Nickelodeon children's cable television channel showed that Bob had broken all records for a debut show and was attracting around 5m viewers every day.

HIT Entertainment, the British company that created him, believes the character, whose voice is provided by actor Neil Morrissey, could now become the biggest domestic children's television export since the Teletubbies.

"We're already getting reports from Florida of British children on holiday being rugby tackled by American kids looking to snaffle their Bob branded towels and clothes," said HIT chief executive Peter Orton.

Ratings for the show are regularly beating classic children's favourites such as Winnie the Pooh and Sesame Street. Such popularity virtually guarantees the British company a multimillion pound windfall from sales of associated Bob the Builder videos and merchandise.

Bob's first pop single - named after his catch phrase "Can you fix it?" - beat controversial US rapper and fellow dungarees wearer Eminem to the Christmas No 1 in the UK.

Not all popular British children's television characters have lived up to expectations in the US. Sooty never really achieved the same standing as he had at home and Budgie the Helicopter, the Duchess of York's creation, failed to take off in America.

fields.headline: ITV braced for advertising fall
fields.trailText: The ITV network faces a dire April with advertising revenues forecast to be 15-20% lower than the same month last year.
fields.body:
The ITV network faces a dire April with advertising revenues forecast to be 15-20% lower than the same month last year.

The forecast comes from investment bank Merrill Lynch, which yesterday issued a research note suggesting ITV advertising would tumble next month after an already weak first quarter. It refers to an "unprecedented uncertainty and lack of visibility in ITV".

The figures will be disappointing for ITV which has scored a number of ratings winners in the first three months of the year, most notably Popstars.

"We always believed the second quarter would be down (by around 5-7%), with June the worst, but this is far worse than expected," the note said. It forecast that May and June would be down 13% and 16% respectively.

ITV is expected to recover in the second half of the year although not enough to stave off an overall 1% fall in revenue. Merrill Lynch originally predicted 3% growth.

The network maintains that it is facing unflattering comparisons with a strong previous year, which included a number of big one-off sporting events that inflated revenues, including Euro 2000.

But the network has lost advertising revenues from big-spending car and telecoms companies. The note also placed some blame on the foot and mouth crisis, which has curbed spending by meat producers. More importantly, large US consumer goods firms are hesitant to commit to marketing spend because of the economic uncertainty in their domestic market.

The bank has revised downward its full-year forecasts for advertising revenues at both Granada and Carlton, the two largest ITV companies. Merrill Lynch believes the pair will now see revenues down between 5% and 6% for their financial year to September, against its previous forecast of a 1.5% drop.

fields.headline: Horse racing
fields.trailText: 1. Foot and mouth disease is having a devastating affect on farmers and the countryside.
fields.body:
1. Foot and mouth disease is having a devastating affect on farmers and the countryside.

2. Many leisure pursuits are curtailed - among them rambling, hunting and, in some cases, gambling.

3. The temporary suspension of horse racing meant that those who enjoy a punt on the nags were forced to pursue non-equine alternatives.

4. Racing is now back on but Cheltenham, the traditional highlight of the sport's calendar, is postponed until April.

5. In the meantime, the Racing Post is offering a virtual Cheltenham featuring the main French and Irish contenders.

6. It wasn't always this way - during the 1967 outbreak there was a complete drought: "It was all off for six weeks [] I just don't know how they did it," remembered one Yorkshire gambler.

7. Satellite TV rode to the rescue during British racing's brief hiatus at the beginning of the crisis. South African horses (and courses) became a fixture in many betting shops.

8. Clairwood (South Africa), Pisa (Italy) and Nad Al Sheba (UAE) have joined Goodwood in the lexicon of the Great British gambling public.

9. Fancy a gamble yourself? Of course, you can still bet on the likelihood (or not) of a May general election

10. But don't hold out too much hope that the foot and mouth outbreak will be over quickly.

fields.headline: . . . and then there were four
fields.trailText: Celebrity Big Brother | The Inspector Lynley Mysteries
fields.body:
"I am a free man!"

- The Prisoner.

When Chris Eubank was voted out of Celebrity Big Brother (Channel 4), Jack Dee made a run for it. Every single person in the house had voted for Eubank's eviction. Never again would he upstage the lot of them by whizzing across the room on a scooter in his kaftan. He left with his customary swagger, swinging his whangee cane. If it wasn't a whangee cane, you feel it should have been.

Well, you never miss your mother till she's buried 'neath the clay. As he left, Jack Dee said "He's the most entertaining man I've ever met." And that night he left too.

2.59am: Vanessa was in bed, free in sleep from the daily worry about her hair extensions turning up in the soup. Anthea, Claire and Keith, what John Cleese calls celebrity pond life, were gambolling in the celebrity pond, a hot tub in the garden. Only Dee was hacking away at the earth with a light rake, perhaps with vague memories of POWs concealing soil in their trousers. You would think that Big Brother, whose sole claim to fame is that he watches you, might have smelled a rat. Very few people garden in the dark, except Lady Dorothy Macmillan, who used to beaver away wearing a miner's helmet. The rest are burying relatives.

3.11am: Dee found a back gate open and went. "Security is immediately alerted." Shot of bloke in fluorescent jacket running about a bit.

3.31am: "Security still haven't found Jack." Shot of guard dog looking confused.

3.43am: "Jack is discovered crouching behind a security hut in the Big Brother compound and is immediately returned to the house." Shot of Jack escorted by two guards like Eugene Aram. (That is one of the things I will miss about Chris Eubank, his habit of laying decomposing old poems and rotten bits of philosophy confidently at your feet like a cat.)

The hot tubbers greeted Dee like a litter of puppies. His face was blackened with mud. He was not in merry mood but, then, how can you tell with Dee. He had, he gruffed, got to Stratford. "But I've come back. It's for Comic Relief. I just wanted to get out." And he shot a look of loathing at the camera.

Bow to Stratford is a grim yomp. On one side lie Hackney marshes, famous for being visible wiv a ladder and some glasses if it wasn't fer the 'ouses in between. On the other, the Thames. Put it this way, a man with a blackened face in a black sweater can walk from Bow to Stratford in the small hours without anyone expressing interest or surprise.

Celebrity Big Brother's psychologist (of course it has a psychologist) identified Dee at once as the alpha male, apparently on his ability to open a bottle of champagne, but the show's bookmaker, assessing the odds, noted "Jack Dee can't contain his indifference." In other words, he could win but he can't be bothered. In any prisoner of war film, Jack would be the one who got shot for saluting sarcastically. If he is voted out on a Free Willy wave of pity, we will be left with minnows.

In the gold rush to find a mother lode as rich as Inspector Morse, BBC1 has come up with The Inspector Lynley Mysteries .

Elizabeth George, who wrote them, is clearly familiar with Dorothy Sayers. Her detective is the eighth Earl of Asherton. This is flung in his face so often you are reminded of Alec Douglas Home's only known witticism that, if he was the 14th Earl, then Harold Wilson was the 14th Mr Wilson.

In the book Lynley is described as having "A Grecian face that bore the unmistakable stamp of aristocracy." You have to clutch at a passing peer not to fall about. Lacking anyone of this superior stamp, we settle for the darkly presentable Nathaniel Parker, son of the former chairman of British Rail. His sergeant (Sharon Small) is as abrasive as he is smooth.

You wonder if Elizabeth George is also familiar with Cold Comfort Farm. A Great Deliverance is virtually smothered in sukebind. It starts with something spectacularly nasty in the cowshed, the quota of lunacy is high even for Yorkshire, and the relationships are serpentine. A Great Deliverance ends tonight but Shelock Holmes solved this sort of story when he said "It is my belief, Watson, that the lowest and vilest alleys in London do not present a more dreadful record of sin than does the smiling and beautiful countryside."

It was shot on location and the beautiful countryside yoo-hoos over everybody's shoulder.

fields.headline: Syria looks to the future
fields.standfirst: One eye on the old guard, President Bashar applies reformist zeal with caution
fields.trailText: Syria is finally allowing the world's media off its leash as it thinks about reform
fields.body:
Journalists used to return from visits to Syria with tales of government paranoia, of being escorted everywhere by government minders or tailed by the secret police -and eventually devising some brilliant ruse to give them the slip.

Today, on that score, Syria is a big disappointment. Walk along an empty street, stop, turn around, pretend to look in a shop window, and there is nobody behind.

The change came more by accident than design. When President Hafez al-Assad died in June so many reporters covered his funeral that the minders gave up.

Having nervously allowed the world's media off its leash, the authorities were surprised that nothing untoward happened. The coverage was largely positive, at least where the incoming president, Hafez's 34-year-old son Bashar, was concerned.

Syria is a country tempted to loosen its grip but fearful of what may ensue.

It is a country where orderliness greets you at the airport. A few feet in front of the passport desk there is a red line on the floor which you must not cross until it is your turn.

Compared with the mayhem of Cairo or the chaos at Beirut, Syria is an orderly place. In the eyes of many officials, reform threatens to destroy that orderliness. They fear the same fate as the Soviet Union.

Syria has been thinking about reform for at least 15 years. In 1986 a foreign exchange crisis prompted a three-year study of the economy which produced what, in Syrian terms, were radical proposals: reform the public sector, encourage the private sector, and let the two compete.

The ruling Ba'ath party was not enthusiastic. "Competition and profit were ugly words," says Nabil Sukkar, a consultant on the project.

One new investment law was approved. "That should have been the first step, but it turned out to be the end," Dr Sukkar says.

"It was a good recipe for change, but it did not happen, because of oil, which started bringing in $2bn [£1.36bn] a year and generated a sense of complacency."

Today, the plans are back on the table and Dr Sukkar is updating them. But this time the climate is different. The Ba'ath party is less averse to new ideas and the youthful President Bashar is in charge.

Nine months after succeeding his father, he is talked about in glowing terms: articulate, thoughtful, focused, shrewd, popular and in control. The latest foreign digni tary to visit - the US secretary of state Colin Powell - was, by all accounts, much impressed.

Not bad for a meek-looking eye doctor who was suddenly put in charge of one of the Middle East's most complex countries.

Some wonder if he is up to the task, but others point out that he grew up at the feet of an old political master and had six years of intensive grooming after the death of his elder brother, Basil.

But there is no doubt about the scale of the challenge. The Ba'ath party has agreed to reform the public sector (without privatisation) but is worried about the social consequences: it insists that there must be no jobs lost.

Economists say that if this is the only way to start reform, then so be it. Privately, they acknowledge that putting the public sector on a commercial footing without job losses is impossible: at best it can can be delayed until the private sector offers alternative work.

But the private sector also has a mountain to climb. Most businesses are small and family-run, there is little management expertise, and the way to succeed in business has been, until now, to throw your lot in with the regime.

There are no private banks, so many businesses have to use those in neighbouring Lebanon and Jordan.

"The party has now consented to private banking," Dr Sukkar says. "That's a shift in ideology, a very significant departure from the past.

"Within one year we'll have private banks, but they must have a good regulatory system: establish proper rules and enforce them."

Enforcement, rather than the rules themselves, is likely to be the problem. In much of the Middle East enforcement is optional, depending on whether a person has the right connections or enough money to pay bribes.

The party has also agreed to establish a stock market.

Years of socialism has not obliterated the money-making instinct: Syria, in the eyes of some, is the natural home of commerce, the Ba'athist period just an interruption of its centuries-old tradition of trade.

For new markets, Syrians look to Baghdad. Iraq has a surplus of capital, Syria a surplus of labour: an ideal match. But there is the small matter of sanctions.

None of this can be isolated from politics. If Syria is not to follow the Lebanon into a shark's paradise, creating the right business environment will require an accountability and transparency in government it has not seen before.

It is also plain that reform cannot go far without touching some raw nerves. If President Bashar forces the pace, he risks provoking a backlash from the old guard.

He urges patience. Most of the old guard are well into their sixties and will be gone soon, he tells friends.

Meanwhile he has brought in a few dedicated new ministers. One of them, the development minister Hassan Nouri, came from industry and reportedly took a pay cut to join the government.

But even dynamic ministers are likely to have trouble pushing new policies through - civil servants are often under-motivated, invariably underpaid and ill-trained.

"The vision is there, but the machinery to implement it is not," a western diplomat says.

President Bashar's insurance policy against a revolt is to establish himself as a populist leader. Last autumn he cheered up civil servants with a 25% pay rise: their first for six years.

His British-born wife, Asma, could be a political asset too, but so far she has not appeared in public. The couple married privately last January.

To cultivate his man-of-the-people image, the president sometimes travels around the country incognito, popping up in the unlikeliest places. In Aleppo a traffic warden allegedly fainted upon learning who the latest offender was.

But some are starting to suggest that the new president could become too popular for his own good: the danger is that people will expect too much, too soon. And then the old guard will say: "We told you so."

Compared with the mayhem of Cairo or the chaos at Beirut, Syria is an orderly place. In the eyes of many officials, reform threatens to destroy that orderliness. They fear the same fate as the Soviet Union. Syria has been thinking about reform for at least 15 years. In 1986 a foreign exchange crisis prompted a three-year study of the economy which produced what, in Syrian terms, were radical proposals: reform the public sector, encourage the private sector, and let the two compete. The ruling Ba'ath party was not enthusiastic. "Competition and profit were ugly words," says Nabil Sukkar, a consultant on the project. One new investment law was approved. "That should have been the first step, but it turned out to be the end," Dr Sukkar says. "It was a good recipe for change, but it did not happen, because of oil, which started bringing in $2bn [£1.36bn] a year and generated a sense of complacency." Today, the plans are back on the table and Dr Sukkar is updating them. But this time the climate is different. The Ba'ath party is less averse to new ideas and the youthful President Bashar is in charge. Nine months after succeeding his father, he is talked about in glowing terms: articulate, thoughtful, focused, shrewd, popular and in control. The latest foreign digni tary to visit - the US secretary of state Colin Powell - was, by all accounts, much impressed. Not bad for a meek-looking eye doctor who was suddenly put in charge of one of the Middle East's most complex countries. Some wonder if he is up to the task, but others point out that he grew up at the feet of an old political master and had six years of intensive grooming after the death of his elder brother, Basil. But there is no doubt about the scale of the challenge. The Ba'ath party has agreed to reform the public sector (without privatisation) but is worried about the social consequences: it insists that there must be no jobs lost. Economists say that if this is the only way to start reform, then so be it. Privately, they acknowledge that putting the public sector on a commercial footing without job losses is impossible: at best it can can be delayed until the private sector offers alternative work. But the private sector also has a mountain to climb. Most businesses are small and family-run, there is little management expertise, and the way to succeed in business has been, until now, to throw your lot in with the regime. There are no private banks, so many businesses have to use those in neighbouring Lebanon and Jordan. "The party has now consented to private banking," Dr Sukkar says. "That's a shift in ideology, a very significant departure from the past. "Within one year we'll have private banks, but they must have a good regulatory system: establish proper rules and enforce them." Enforcement, rather than the rules themselves, is likely to be the problem. In much of the Middle East enforcement is optional, depending on whether a person has the right connections or enough money to pay bribes. The party has also agreed to establish a stock market. Years of socialism has not obliterated the money-making instinct: Syria, in the eyes of some, is the natural home of commerce, the Ba'athist period just an interruption of its centuries-old tradition of trade. For new markets, Syrians look to Baghdad. Iraq has a surplus of capital, Syria a surplus of labour: an ideal match. But there is the small matter of sanctions. None of this can be isolated from politics. If Syria is not to follow the Lebanon into a shark's paradise, creating the right business environment will require an accountability and transparency in government it has not seen before. It is also plain that reform cannot go far without touching some raw nerves. If President Bashar forces the pace, he risks provoking a backlash from the old guard. He urges patience. Most of the old guard are well into their sixties and will be gone soon, he tells friends. Meanwhile he has brought in a few dedicated new ministers. One of them, the development minister Hassan Nouri, came from industry and reportedly took a pay cut to join the government. But even dynamic ministers are likely to have trouble pushing new policies through - civil servants are often under-motivated, invariably underpaid and ill-trained. "The vision is there, but the machinery to implement it is not," a western diplomat says. President Bashar's insurance policy against a revolt is to establish himself as a populist leader. Last autumn he cheered up civil servants with a 25% pay rise: their first for six years. His British-born wife, Asma, could be a political asset too, but so far she has not appeared in public. The couple married privately last January. To cultivate his man-of-the-people image, the president sometimes travels around the country incognito, popping up in the unlikeliest places. In Aleppo a traffic warden allegedly fainted upon learning who the latest offender was. But some are starting to suggest that the new president could become too popular for his own good: the danger is that people will expect too much, too soon. And then the old guard will say: "We told you so."

fields.headline: Trench war escalates on West Bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinians advanced behind a bulldozer yesterday in an attempt to cross the trenches dug on Ariel Sharon's orders around their premier academic institution, the Bir Zeit University outside Ramallah.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Ramallah and  Khaled Dawoud  in Cairo
fields.body:
Palestinians advanced behind a bulldozer yesterday in an attempt to cross the trenches dug on Ariel Sharon's orders around their premier academic institution, the Bir Zeit University outside Ramallah.

One man was killed and 40 injured when the Israeli forces fired teargas and sporadic live rounds as they marched on the two deep trenches sealing off Ramallah from the university and villages where 65,000 people live.

The protesters flung handfuls of earth into the trenches in a vain attempt to lift the siege of the West Bank city, imposed as one of Mr Sharon's first acts as prime minister.

Dozens of stranded villagers and students tried to make their way home along the roadside.

They included Hiam Ferris, who was released from hospital yesterday morning with her day-old daughter Nadine bundled in a blanket.

"God only knows how I am going to get home," she said, after a taxi dropped her at the edge of the trench and left her to walk to her village, Deyr Jareer, on the far side.

The army strengthened the siege by heaping earth on the last of the unpaved roads still accessible to motorists.

The Ramallah siege is the first concrete manifestation of Mr Sharon's strategy for dealing with the Palestinian uprising, which began five months ago.

It prompted Arab foreign ministers meeting in Cairo yesterday to urge the UN security council to call an emergency session to discuss Israel's "escalating aggression" against the Palestinians. They also asked the council to approve the immediate deployment of an international force to provide protection for the Palestinian people in the West Bank and Gaza.

Although the US is likely to block a security council condemnation of Israel, the Arab leaders wanted to send a clear message to Mr Sharon that they would stand firm against him using further on the Palestinians and turning the West Bank and Gaza into apartheid-like cantons.

According to Israeli newspapers, the government is about to unveil a "divide and conquer" plan in which the army will carve the West Bank into 60 isolated cantons, cut off from the outside world by ditches and barricades.

Palestinians say the strategy is turning the West Bank into a prison and their cities into isolated cell blocks.

"They have transformed the country into a cluster of prisons," said Mustafa Barghouti, director of the Palestinian medical relief committee.

Under the Oslo peace agreements, Israel controls all the roads to the West Bank cities, enabling it to impose the blockade which has crippled the Palestinian economy.

It has reinforced the Palestinians' sense that, six years after they achieved limited self-rule, they remain under military occupation.

Yesterday's demonstration was the first mass civilian protest for weeks.

"Even people like me who are not involved politically are going to be involved soon," said a doctor in Bethlehem.

"You are checked every 100 metres, and humiliated at every checkpoint. It is an insult to any human being."

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Many companies advertising goods for sale over the net are breaching trading standards, the office of fair trading said yesterday.
fields.body:
 Protecting Many companies advertising goods for sale over the net are breaching trading standards, the office of fair trading said yesterday. An inspection of 637 websites in the UK found 52% failed to meet basic legal requirements. Net consumers are entitled to protection under the distance selling regulations, which came into force last October.

 Shuffling Software firm Infobank yesterday announced trebled pretax losses of £36m for 2000 and a management reshuffle. Chief executive Graham Sadd becomes "founder president" while chief operating officer Jim Conning is leaving. Tony Stepanski, former president of US firm Origin Technology in Business, takes over as chief executive.

 Sharing Online auctioneer eBay said yesterday it had signed a pact with Microsoft to share net technologies and services. They will integrate eBay's online marketplace into Microsoft's existing platforms for MSN, CarPoint and WebTV later this year.

webTitle: We're staying out of the bloodbath, Emblaze insists

fields.headline: We're staying out of the bloodbath, Emblaze insists
fields.trailText: Emblaze, formerly Geo Interactive, yesterday raised itself above the gloom that has swamped the telecoms sector by reporting better than expected figures and a positive trading outlook.
fields.body:
Emblaze, formerly Geo Interactive, yesterday raised itself above the gloom that has swamped the telecoms sector by reporting better than expected figures and a positive trading outlook.

The Israeli multimedia firm said that interest in its technology, which streams video and audio to mobile devices, was so great that it would seek strategic partnerships with mobile handset manufacturers or microchip manufacturers to keep pace with demand.

Chief executive Eli Reifman also played down fears that the financial crisis of confidence that has struck many of the big telecoms network operators and equipment manufacturers would adversely affect Emblaze. "In this bloodbath of profit warnings I'm very pleased that this company has delivered something different by beating analysts' and our own expectations," he said.

"The telecoms situation is having zero effect, and all we see is a booming market, with interest from literally hundreds of firms."

Mr Reifman said that the sheer scale of demand from potential customers meant that Emblaze would look at ways of improving its ability to deliver product in large volumes. The company plans to increase staffing levels by about 40% in the coming year but Mr Reifman said that may not be enough.

"So far we've been doing things on our own, but this is increasingly a global marketplace and we will look for strategic partners," he said.

That could see big multinationals taking a minority stake in the firm, following the action of telecoms group Energis, which took a 5% stake in Emblaze last year.

In the year to December 31 revenues increased fourfold to $30.7m (£21m) but operating expenses touched $31m. However, a $26.7m injection of cash from the sale of various investments helped the group move into the black for the first time.

The figures gave Emblaze shares a kick in early trading and they rose 9%. By the close they had slipped back, ending the day down 15p at 335p. Emblaze's price performance has reflected the ups and downs of tech stocks over the last year. A favourite with private investors, the shares at one stage changed hands for £35.

fields.headline: Ericsson dives
fields.trailText: Sweden's Ericsson yesterday delivered another body blow to an already reeling technology sector when it warned that it could tumble as much as £350m into the red in the first quarter of this year.
fields.body:
Sweden's Ericsson yesterday delivered another body blow to an already reeling technology sector when it warned that it could tumble as much as £350m into the red in the first quarter of this year.

The telecommunications equipment group said sales would be flat or might even fall rather than rising by the 15% it had been expecting.

Investors were quick to head for the exit with Ericsson shares losing a fifth of their value after the profits warning, which followed similarly cautionary announcements from US technology companies Cisco and Intel.

Ericsson blamed a slowdown in orders for telecommunications equipment and mobile phones for the slump.

"Operators are focusing on optimising existing infra structure rather than investing in new ones," a spokesman said. The problem was particularly acute in the US.

The first quarter is normally a slow period for mobile phones but Ericsson said that had been exacerbated by "low replacement demand, reduced operator subsidies, high investment levels ... and continued price pressures due to excess vendor capacity. We expect sales of phones to be considerably lower than in the first quarter of last year."

As a result the group, was expecting a pre-tax loss of SKr4bn-5bn (£290m-360m).

The Ericsson spokesman said that the company was looking to cut costs by increasing productivity and by a freeze on recruitment. But he could not give a figure for the amount of money that would be saved as a result of such measures.

fields.headline: Mori? More Noh than Shakespeare
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: When is a statement of resignation not a resignation? When it is issued by the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.
fields.body:
When is a statement of resignation not a resignation? When it is issued by the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.

Two days after the unpopular premier said he would bring forward leadership elections for the ruling Liberal Democratic party - a move universally interpreted as a de facto declaration that he will stand down - Mr Mori insisted yesterday he had not made any decision about his future.

"Neither I nor the five Liberal Democratic party executives understood this as a statement of my intention to resign. I have absolutely no intention to state such plans," Mr Mori told parliament.

But with growing worries about the Japanese economy, the last thing investors want is the prospect of a prolonged period of political uncertainty. The markets reacted accordingly, with the Japanese currency dropping to a 20-month low against the dollar and the Nikkei index of Tokyo stock exchange falling sharply to levels not seen since 1986.

Investors took little heart from a government report that showed the world's second largest economy had expanded by 3.2% on an annualised basis between October and December last year.

The growth was fuelled by rises in public spending, housing programmes and business investment - all of which are believed to have slowed down or shrunk since the beginning of this year. "It's hard to feel at ease," said Taro Aso, the minister for economic and fiscal policy.

With the public keeping its purse strings tied, finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa hinted that another injection of public spending may be needed to boost the economy.

The present problems have left Mr Mori facing ratings of just 6% and opposition from many in his own party. But despite this, the prime minister said it was possible that he would run for re-election as LDP president, a position that almost automatically means selection as prime minister. "I will decide whether or not to run when the LDP presidential election is formally set," Mr Mori said at a stormy session of the parliamentary budget committee. "Now is not the right time to comment."

Nobody, however, is taking his words at face value. Instead they are seen as part of a face-saving political play that is more in keeping with the ambiguity of a Noh play than the clean-cut catharsis of a Shakespearean tragedy.

The plot of Mr Mori's de facto resignation was widely leaked by LDP officials even before it was put into practice on Saturday. It has two contradictory aims: first, to satisfy members of the coalition that he will be gone by the time of the upper house elections in July; and second, to ensure he is not seen as a lame duck ahead of parliamentary debates on the budget and summits with Presidents George Bush and Vladimir Putin.

fields.headline: Russia determined to sell arms to Iran
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
More about Iran
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin made it clear yesterday that he is determined to go ahead with arms sales to Iran
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin made it clear yesterday that he is determined to go ahead with arms sales to Iran, cementing a spirit of friendly cooperation between the two countries which is likely make the US uneasy.

On the first day of a four-day summit in the Kremlin, President Putin and President Mohammed Khatamialso announced a decision to expand cooperation on nuclear energy. Russia will help Iran to complete the Bushehr reactor, a project which Washington fears could help Iran develop nuclear weapons.

The visit represents a clear strengthening of Russo-Iranian relations as Mr Putin pursues an assertive new foreign policy, restoring ties with allies of the former USSR's and states regarded with suspicion by Washington.

In November Russia warned the US that it was withdrawing from a secret 1995 pact designed to phase out the sale of weapons to Iran, which Washington classifies as a rogue state.

Mr Putin argued yesterday that Iran had the right to defend itself and that Russia needed the business. Moscow hopes to revive its huge and under-used arms industry by selling more abroad.

The Iranian ambassador to Moscow said recently that Tehran could spend up to $7bn on Russian weapons over the next few years.

It was not said what kind of arms Russia will supply, nor the cost, but officials have indicated that Iran is interested in buying S-300 air defence missiles, fighter jets, helicopters and patrol boats.

Mr Putin stressed that Russia would not sell weapons banned by international laws designed to prevent the proliferation of nuclear and missile technology.

Officials have dismissed America's fear that the technology being shared to complete the Bushehr reactor could be used to develop nuclear weapons, saying that it can only be used for civilian purposes. The US has repeatedly demanded that Russia cancel its $800m contract to build the plant.

With an implicit nod to US disapproval, Mr Khatami said that both Russia and Iran had the right to "decide what is in our benefit and what is not".

The two countries signed an agreement opposing the construction of pipelines under the Caspian Sea, an indirect reference to US attempts to persuade Kazakhstan to ship oil across the sea and through Turkey, bypassing Russia and Iran.

But they failed to resolve a long-standing dispute over who has the right to exploit the oil resources under the seabed.

webTitle: Pakistan keeps Annan from 'world's worst' camp

fields.headline: Pakistan keeps Annan from 'world's worst' camp
fields.trailText: The military-led government of Pakistan has stopped the United Nations secretary-general, Kofi Annan, visiting a makeshift refugee camp near the Afghan border which veteran aid workers describe as one of the worst in the world.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill in the Khyber Pass
fields.body:
The military-led government of Pakistan has stopped the United Nations secretary-general, Kofi Annan, visiting a makeshift refugee camp near the Afghan border which veteran aid workers describe as one of the worst in the world.

After days of wrangling with the UN about his visit, the government surprised Mr Annan on Sunday night by saying it could not guarantee his safety if he went to the Jalozai camp, 18 miles south of Peshawar in North-West Frontier province, where Afghans have sought refuge from fighting and drought.

UN officials suspect the government was afraid that the many journalists accompanying Mr Annan would focus on its harsh treatment of the refugees.

Mr Annan, speaking yesterday at Shamshatoo, another camp 30-minutes' drive away, expressed disappointment that he had not made the visit. He told the refugees: "I had wished to go to Jalozai, but for operational and other reasons I was not able to go there."

After providing a haven for more than 2m Afghan refugees, the Pakistani government decided in November that it had had enough and closed its borders, in contravention of international legal obligations towards refugees.

Tens of thousands have been camped in the open since January and the government has refused to let the UN High Commissioner for Refugees provide basic amenities for the new arrivals.

The UNHCR said that more than 80,000 were squatting in squalid conditions on a strip of land at Jalozai, and more were arriving each day.

The camp is known to aid workers as "Plastic City", because of the cheap plastic bags being used as tents.

Faced with its overflowing latrines and limited drinking water, the refugees, particularly the children, are dying almost daily, and conditions are deteriorating.

Yusuf Hassan, a UNHCR officer accompanying Mr Annan, said: "Children are dying of preventable diseases but mainly from the cold. "It is a dreadful place. They fled Afghanistan hoping they would get help." He shuddered to think what would happen in the coming months.

Part of the underlying problem is that sympathy for the Afghans has waned in the international community; the Taliban regime's destruction of the giant Buddha statues at Bamiyan has only accentuated this.

Mr Annan tried to force the government into agreeing to his visit by saying on his arrival in Pakistan on Saturday that he intended to visit two Afghan refugee camps, Jalozai and Shamshatoo. The military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, backed down in face-to-face talks with Mr Annan and agreed that he could visit both.

But late on Sunday night the government changed its mind, telling him it did not have enough police and soldiers to protect him if the refugees in their anxiety to see him were to stampede.

Mr Annan decided he could not ignore his host. He also believed he had secured a concession from Gen Musharraf which could be more important: a promise to let the UNHCR turn Jalozai into a proper camp in return for greater international efforts to alleviate the problems of drought and internal displacement in Afghanistan.

Mr Annan is to seek Gen Musharraf's confirmation that this was agreed, but he is confident that he can persuade the international community to provide the necessary money.

In final twist, Mr Annan was assured by the government that he would be allowed to fly low over Jalozai camp for a look. But even that symbolic gesture did not materialise: the military helicopter in which he was travelling took another route.

The government's sudden changes of mind may reflect divisions in its ranks. Gen Musharraf's initial decision to let Mr Annan go to Jalozai met with the disapproval of some of his colleagues.

The provincial governor, Iftikhar Hussain Shah, opposed the visit and is also opposed to making the camp a proper one.

The government claims that most of the refugees are economic migrants fleeing the drought, but it has refused to let the UN screen those at Jalozai to discover which are fleeing poverty and which the fighting.
