After days of wrangling with the UN about his visit, the government surprised Mr Annan on Sunday night by saying it could not guarantee his safety if he went to the Jalozai camp, 18 miles south of Peshawar in North-West Frontier province, where Afghans have sought refuge from fighting and drought. UN officials suspect the government was afraid that the many journalists accompanying Mr Annan would focus on its harsh treatment of the refugees. Mr Annan, speaking yesterday at Shamshatoo, another camp 30-minutes' drive away, expressed disappointment that he had not made the visit. He told the refugees: "I had wished to go to Jalozai, but for operational and other reasons I was not able to go there." After providing a haven for more than 2m Afghan refugees, the Pakistani government decided in November that it had had enough and closed its borders, in contravention of international legal obligations towards refugees. Tens of thousands have been camped in the open since January and the government has refused to let the UN High Commissioner for Refugees provide basic amenities for the new arrivals. The UNHCR said that more than 80,000 were squatting in squalid conditions on a strip of land at Jalozai, and more were arriving each day. The camp is known to aid workers as "Plastic City", because of the cheap plastic bags being used as tents. Faced with its overflowing latrines and limited drinking water, the refugees, particularly the children, are dying almost daily, and conditions are deteriorating. Yusuf Hassan, a UNHCR officer accompanying Mr Annan, said: "Children are dying of preventable diseases but mainly from the cold. "It is a dreadful place. They fled Afghanistan hoping they would get help." He shuddered to think what would happen in the coming months. Part of the underlying problem is that sympathy for the Afghans has waned in the international community; the Taliban regime's destruction of the giant Buddha statues at Bamiyan has only accentuated this. Mr Annan tried to force the government into agreeing to his visit by saying on his arrival in Pakistan on Saturday that he intended to visit two Afghan refugee camps, Jalozai and Shamshatoo. The military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, backed down in face-to-face talks with Mr Annan and agreed that he could visit both. But late on Sunday night the government changed its mind, telling him it did not have enough police and soldiers to protect him if the refugees in their anxiety to see him were to stampede. Mr Annan decided he could not ignore his host. He also believed he had secured a concession from Gen Musharraf which could be more important: a promise to let the UNHCR turn Jalozai into a proper camp in return for greater international efforts to alleviate the problems of drought and internal displacement in Afghanistan. Mr Annan is to seek Gen Musharraf's confirmation that this was agreed, but he is confident that he can persuade the international community to provide the necessary money. In final twist, Mr Annan was assured by the government that he would be allowed to fly low over Jalozai camp for a look. But even that symbolic gesture did not materialise: the military helicopter in which he was travelling took another route. The government's sudden changes of mind may reflect divisions in its ranks. Gen Musharraf's initial decision to let Mr Annan go to Jalozai met with the disapproval of some of his colleagues. The provincial governor, Iftikhar Hussain Shah, opposed the visit and is also opposed to making the camp a proper one. The government claims that most of the refugees are economic migrants fleeing the drought, but it has refused to let the UN screen those at Jalozai to discover which are fleeing poverty and which the fighting.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Scarecrow | Evening Concert | Eye Of Nature
fields.body:
He's known in Cornwall as a bucker, in Dorset as a bugalug. There are, apparently, 27 English dialect words for The Scarecrow (9.30am, Radio 4). The earliest written record, dating from 1553, referred to a real-life farm labourer, hired to kick up a racket for hours on end. Since the later and more familiar stuffed dummy is built round a wooden cross, there are, of course, endless folk rituals associated with it.

National Orchestra Week is marked in the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) by performances from The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. This ensemble was started in 1986, when a group of Britain's best period instrumentalists pooled their funds so they could perform 18th-century works as the composer originally intended. Their reputation was soon high enough for Simon Rattle and Frans Brüggen to become their principal guest conductors.

It seems a shame, given the dismal view of life from a bowl, that evolution gave goldfish far better vision than mankind. According to Eye Of Nature (9.0pm, Radio 4), carp can see colours at either end of the spectrum that we can't even imagine. Dr Gillian Rice opens this three-part series by investigating the pathology of vision. The human eye moves three times a second to allow its 100 million receptors to record our surroundings. But, since our brains could never process that much information, it's reduced to just one million nuggets.

fields.headline: Hurrah for the end of double jeopardy in murder cases.
fields.standfirst: But why not apply it to all crimes?
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: But why not apply it to all crimes?
fields.body:
 Doing away with the double jeopardy rule and allowing defendants previously acquitted to be tried again, if compelling new evidence comes to light, is right and sensible. But I can't understand why the Law Commission proposes to limit it to murder. Its report emphasises the uniqueness and seriousness of the crime, but I don't see the point of that argument. In particular, I don't understand why rape is excluded. If we're talking about virtually irrefutable evidence that X committed the crime, DNA provides it. The identity of rapists is often proved by such evidence. Yet, according to the commission's proposal, if an acquitted rapist is later shown by undisputed DNA evidence - or by his own confession - to have done it, nothing can be done. Rapists are wrongly acquitted far more often than murderers are; why should we let them get away with crimes that we can prove they committed?

 I hear that Anna Ford has decided to start judicial review proceedings against the press complaints commission to test our new privacy laws. Geoffrey Robertson QC will be acting for her. The PCC recently ruled that the Daily Mail had not infringed Ford's right to privacy by publishing secretly taken snaps of her and her partner, astronaut David Scott, on holiday in Majorca. There are legal hurdles to overcome - including whether or not the PCC is a "public authority" subject to judicial review - but if she wins, the case will have a huge effect on the privacy rights of celebrities.

 The Office of Fair Trading's report on competition in the legal profession is not an impressive document, even if it reached some correct conclusions. The bar, predictably, moaned and complained extravagantly. I'm no apologist for lawyers, as you know, but on this one I think the bar has some justification. Its main defence to demands for the dismantling of some of its traditional restrictive practices is that they operate in the public interest. That is a totally legitimate point to raise and - without going into specific arguments - the bar has some reasonable arguments to put.

But neither the OFT report nor the consultants' survey on which the OFT based its conclusions had looked at the public-interest aspect. It wasn't part of the remit. To me, it seems absurd to reach a conclusion that this or that practice is uncompetitive and to stop there, without going on to assess the public interest argument. I know it is not in the OFT's terms of reference, but the omission seems to me to make the process unfair.

I'm not defending the QC system, nor many of the other traditions and practices criticised by the OFT; I'm merely saying that even barristers deserve a bit of justice.

 My innocent little item last week about the derivation of the late George Carman's nickname has become the subject of fierce controversy. I suggested that he was called Gorgeous George after the American wrestler of that name. Not so, according to an avalanche of letters, emails and phone calls, unanimous in claiming that the source was more likely to be the elegant French boxer of the first world war period, Georges Carpentier, whose memorable fight in 1921 against Jack Dempsey for the world heavyweight championship produced the first million-dollar gate. I watched a film of it recently. Carpentier, really a light-heavyweight, giving away 25lb, nearly knocked out the champion in the second round, probably broke his hand in the attempt and was then knocked out in the fourth.

Yes, he was sometimes called Gorgeous Georges (with that final "s", which, of course, Carman didn't have) though he was more often described as the Orchid Kid (or Orchid Man) from his habit of wearing the flower in his buttonhole. But, quite apart from the evidence of the extra "s", who, a decade ago, could possibly have remembered Carpentier and decided to saddle Carman with the same label? Apart, of course, from me and my angry correspondents.

 An apology. This column will be hit hard, as will your pockets, by the absence of next week's horse-racing festival at Cheltenham. This is traditionally the race meeting at which horses with legal tinges to their names perform with vigour and stamina. My job over the years has been to bring those contestants to your attention; yours to rush to your nearest turf financial broker and place a judicious investment. It has worked spectacularly in the past; many fortunes have been created. Alas, not this year.

webTitle: A ruling that has the tabloids in a tizzy

fields.headline: But the Sun can say anything it likes. Can't it?
fields.standfirst: When a clerk sued the Sun for harassment, the paper wheeled out its freedom-of-speech defence - and lost. Clare Dyer on a ruling that has the tabloids in a tizzy
fields.trailText: When a clerk sued the Sun for harassment, the paper wheeled out its freedom-of-speech defence - and lost. Clare Dyer on a ruling that has the tabloids in a tizzy.
fields.body:
The likes of Naomi Campbell brandishing Britain's emerging privacy laws could turn out to be the least of the tabloids' worries. Campbell, who is furious over a story about her sortie to a Narcotics Anonymous meeting, joins Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones - narked over the publication of snatched photos of their wedding in Hello! magazine - in the list of celebs invoking the Human Rights Act to defend their right to a private life. But now a new weapon has emerged which threatens not just to spike a few intrusive exposés, but to change the face of tabloid journalism. If it succeeds, a judge was told in a private hearing this month, it will "turn the Sun into a parish gazette".

A judgment delivered last week to no publicity at Lambeth county court in south London has caught news-paper executives on the hop and sent them scurrying to media lawyers for urgent advice. The senior judge at Lambeth, Judge Roger Cox, ruled that inflammatory and strident newspaper articles can amount to harassment, giving their victims the right to sue under the Protection Against Harassment Act 1997, the law designed to tackle stalkers.

Esther Thomas, 29, a former civilian clerk with City of London police, is suing the Sun over stories about a complaint she made of racist behaviour against four police officers. The incident, involving a Somali asylum seeker, led to the demotion of two sergeants and a fine against a constable.

The young Somali woman arrived at the police station penniless, claiming she had been robbed by the man who brought her to Britain. Thomas later told a disciplinary hearing - and another police officer backed her up - that the officers had been reluctant to take her to the Elephant and Castle in south London to catch a bus to the asylum centre in Croydon.

According to Thomas, one officer said: "What is this country coming to? We let everyone in," to which a second riposted: "They should be shot. That's the quick and easy way to get rid of them." The third added: "She found her own way here from Somalia; why can't she find her own way back?" Despite an order from a senior officer to take the woman to the Elephant and Castle, she was taken only to London Bridge and left with only the £2 Thomas had given her. She never arrived at Croydon and has never been traced.

The Sun tells it a little differently. The story last July, headed "Beyond a joke - fury as police sarges are busted after refugee jest", claims that one officer said: "She found her way 8,000 miles here from Somalia. Surely she can find her way four miles to Croydon." In the paper's version, Thomas, described as "a black clerk", tells the second officer: "You'd like to shoot us all," and he replies: "I'd have you shot if you don't get on with your work."

A "fellow cop" is quoted: "It was essentially light-hearted banter in private and the Somali never heard it. This is political correctness gone mad." No mention is made of the failure to comply with the senior officer's order or the asylum seeker's fate.

Two of the officers were demoted from sergeant to PC, the Sun told readers. One, a "dad of two", had lost £54,000 in salary and pension, the other £34,000. The third was ordered to pay a £700 fine. And all because a "black clerk" reported a "private remark" to her bosses.

Readers were not told that a white police officer, who had overheard the incident and made an entry about it in his pocketbook, backed Thomas up at the disciplinary hearing.

A week later the paper published 12 letters under the slogan "The Big Issue". "You were furious about our story about two police sergeants demoted for racism after joking about a Somali woman who wanted help getting to an asylum centre," read the introduction. Readers said they were "shocked" and "disgusted" and branded Thomas's action as "diabolical". Race-hate mail addressed to Thomas arrived at the police station.

Two days later the Sun ran a third story, reporting that officers who tried to organise a whip-round to pay the constable's £700 fine had been told that they could face the sack for doing so, and inviting readers to send a cheque to the Fine Fund.

Thomas, who had not been asked to give her version of events, learned of the initial story's publication when a colleague phoned her as she was getting ready to leave for work. "I was absolutely terrified. I knew what was going to happen - I was going to be targeted. I was easily recognisable. People walk into the police station and the first person they see is me."

The letters were taken away and Thomas was never shown their contents. One turned out to have a DNA fingerprint on it that matched DNA on a letter sent to Mo Mowlam. "When I was leaving the station one day, one of the detective sergeants who had read the letters stopped me and said, 'Really, be careful, because they weren't very nice, take care of yourself.' For someone to do that - and it's not a person I normally speak to - they must have been quite horrific."

She was at "rock bottom" when she read the readers' letters in the Sun a few days later. "In the article they named me, said I was a black clerk and named the station where I worked. It was almost as if they were singling me out, saying, 'Yes, get her.' When they published the letters it only added fuel to a fire that was already burning vigorously."

Already feeling vulnerable because of reaction at the station to her complaint against the four officers - "I would walk down the corridor and conversations would stop" - she left her job and now works elsewhere in the city. "I just felt very vulnerable. I was in a front-line role. At any time somebody could come in and leap over the counter. If I called for urgent assistance and a particular group or groups or particular people were on duty, I didn't know that they were going to come running to my aid."

The London Race Discrimination Unit, part of Lambeth Law Centre, took on her case. What gave Lawrence Davies, a senior solicitor with the unit, the idea of using the Protection against Harassment Act? "It was just a moment of inspiration. Sometimes when you're desperate to find a remedy for your client things just pop into your head."

In a private preliminary hearing, the Sun argued that her case was hopeless and had no legal basis, and asked the judge to strike it out or enter judgment for the paper. The Sun's counsel admitted that the articles were "strident, aggressive and inflammatory" but denied that they were racist. But the judge said that adjective, too, was justified. The colour of Thomas's skin had no bearing on the matters reported, he added, unless the paper was implying that she took the action she did because of her race.

The Sun argued that the Protection against Harassment Act could cover doorstepping by reporters, but not the articles they wrote. Its counsel claimed that a ruling to the effect that the act covered newspaper reports would transform media law. He cited a statement by Lord Hoffmann, the law lord, that apart from the established exceptions or new ones enacted by parliament, freedom of speech was "a trump card which always wins".

But the judge ruled that the act was just such an exception. It required a "course of conduct", so a single article would not be enough; and harassment included causing alarm or distress. "Thus in my judgment the act does give the claimant a right to protection from harassment by all the world including the press," the judge concluded. The paper would have a defence if it could show that its conduct was reasonable.

The Sun is taking the case to the court of appeal. It could go all the way to the House of Lords. Lawrence Davies hopes that some celebrities, who could have a new and simpler route open to them if the ruling stands up on appeal, will contribute to a fighting fund for Thomas. She has no legal aid and could be liable for substantial costs if the Sun wins on appeal.

"It was so inevitable that she would receive race-hate mail as a result of that article," says Davies. "This paper has a circulation of 3m and is read by up to 12m people. I think they have a moral duty to be much more careful."

The Sun argued that the Protection against Harassment Act could cover doorstepping by reporters, but not the articles they wrote. Its counsel claimed that a ruling to the effect that the act covered newspaper reports would transform media law. He cited a statement by Lord Hoffmann, the law lord, that apart from the established exceptions or new ones enacted by parliament, freedom of speech was "a trump card which always wins". But the judge ruled that the act was just such an exception. It required a "course of conduct", so a single article would not be enough; and harassment included causing alarm or distress. "Thus in my judgment the act does give the claimant a right to protection from harassment by all the world including the press," the judge concluded. The paper would have a defence if it could show that its conduct was reasonable. The Sun is taking the case to the court of appeal. It could go all the way to the House of Lords. Lawrence Davies hopes that some celebrities, who could have a new and simpler route open to them if the ruling stands up on appeal, will contribute to a fighting fund for Thomas. She has no legal aid and could be liable for substantial costs if the Sun wins on appeal. "It was so inevitable that she would receive race-hate mail as a result of that article," says Davies. "This paper has a circulation of 3m and is read by up to 12m people. I think they have a moral duty to be much more careful."

fields.headline: Tunnel vision
fields.standfirst: Overpaid, socially inept, obsessive: that's what your typical Italian footballer is like, isn't it? Accompanying the squad of his beloved Hellas Verona to an away match, our columnist discovers a rather more mundane reality
fields.trailText: Overpaid, socially inept, obsessive: that's what your typical Italian footballer is like, isn't it? Accompanying the squad of his beloved Hellas Verona to an away match, our columnist discovers a rather more mundane reality
fields.body:
By age 10 their skills are already evident. Their mothers are shrieking on the sidelines. Talent scouts are offering advice. By age 15 they are in a football college. Sensing they are destined for glory, they go to bed early, dreaming of the turf at the San Siro, at the Olimpico. On the telephone Mamma and Pappa urge them on. Their few old friends urge them on. They don't drink and they don't smoke. Their diet is controlled. The training is exhausting. No sacrifice is too great.

By 17 or 18 they are playing in Serie C, or sitting on the bench in Serie B. Solemn men in heavy coats gamble on their future. They are bought and sold. A billion lire this year, five the next. They are shunted up and down the length of the bel paese : Treviso, Taranto, Palermo, Turin. They know no one outside the world of football now. They hardly know what to say to a person who is not a player or a manager or a journalist. Or at least a fan.

They haven't studied. When they do their military service, it is in a special barracks for sportsmen. They train all day and return to their teams before the weekend. They haven't had time for a social life. Always supervised, they haven't had time to develop a character. They are fined if they are late for training. They are fined if their telefonino rings when the mister (coach) is speaking. Yearning to be picked for the game, what can they do but agree with everything the mister says? What can they do but carry out his every wish? Picked, they are proud and relieved; left out, they suffer all kinds of anguish.

Dreading injury, they become hypersensitive and hypochondriac. What is this twitch in my calf? The team doctor examines them, the team masseur revives them. Yearning to be adored, they are afraid people want their company only because they are famous. They watch pornography in anonymous hotels. When they win, they are worshipped. Standing, arms raised, beneath the curva , they are drenched in glory, their faces resplendent. When they lose, they are spat on. The whistles are deafening. They make for the tunnel with their head down. Lonely, they marry young. An old girlfriend, perhaps; or perhaps a young model, as lost and vain as themselves.

Waking with a headache in the middle of the night, they have to call the team doctor before they can take anything. There are dope tests. They cannot put drops in a stuffy nose. They cannot inhale Vicks. With amazement, they read about players in other countries who drink and smoke and smash up restaurants and aeroplanes. How can they do this? What would the Gazzetta dello Sport say? Italy is a Catholic country. This kind of behaviour isn't countenanced. They read that English players check the horse-racing results at half time, that they are more interested in betting than football. They do not believe it. It cannot be so.

Like Spartan soldiers, they are truly themselves only on the field of battle. Only when they run out through the players' tunnel into the big green stadium can they unleash all their pent-up emotion. Only before a huge crowd can they at last behave appallingly. They clutch their opponent's shirt. They crash into his legs before he reaches a scoring position. The crowd applaud: pull him down! Barely touched, they themselves collapse and writhe in agony. They deny the most evident truths, pretending they didn't touch a ball when everybody has seen that they did, claiming a ball didn't go out when everybody has seen that it has.

They are simultaneously infantile and mature, petulant and courageous. When they score, they lose all sense of control. They tear off their shirts, they go wild. When their opponents score, they collapse on the ground in dismay. They protest vigorously. They kick the goalposts. Interviewed after the game, they are cautious and conformist: we did our best, our compliments to the other side, we must work hard to improve, we must be humble. Next day they buy all the papers. Each sports reporter gives each player a score from one to 10. How am I doing? Will I still be in Serie A next year? Will I be playing, will I be on the bench? Immensely privileged, they are hope lessly deprived, for they have no ordinary life. Above all, they are paid huge salaries.

That, more or less, was what I thought of the Italian footballer, until I travelled with the squad of Hellas Verona for their away game at Lecce on the southernmost shores of the Adriatic. Was I right? Yes and no. What I hadn't foreseen was how pleasant, how sensible, how absolutely tame the players might be, despite the feverish world they lived in. All dressed alike in the club tracksuit, they did crossword puzzles on the plane, fidgeted with their telefonini in the foyer of the hotel, explained to me with charming sincerity that modern football is now so fast and physical you are constantly in danger of being overwhelmed. Buried in a Ken Follett novel, coach Attilio Perotti wasn't eager to talk. "We can't afford to lose this game," he conceded. "We can't afford to lose."

The squad were two days in Lecce. I think I and the acting managing director were the only ones to walk out of the hotel and take a look at the marvellous pale yellow baroque of the old city centre. The players trained and were in bed by 9.30pm.

In the stadium on the Sunday, Verona scored first using a free-kick routine I had watched them practise the day before without success. I was sitting high in the stands with the Verona staff, who leapt to their feet but couldn't exult because we were surrounded by furious Lecce fans. These excellent southern folk did not return the courtesy when Verona were torn apart in the second half. Destroyed. Pathetic. As we conceded the fourth goal, Verona club owner Giambattista Pastorello, immaculate in pale suit and bright tie, jumped up and fled. Abandoning the team and his plane ticket, he drove the 1,000km back to Verona, arriving in the dead of night with, as he later told me, a high fever and a stabbing pain in his leg.

All the other bottom clubs had won. Verona are deep in the relegation zone. The players were close to tears as they came out of the dressing room. They stood in corners, whispering into their mobiles: "No, Mamma. Miserable." In the airport, they had to suffer the smug commiserations of the general public. "Don't worry, ha ha, we were just better than you on the day!" The Hellas boys were admirably polite in their gloom.

Changing flights in Rome, we ran into other players from other teams also changing flights. It seems this is a weekly ritual. Half the Italian football world changes flights at Fiumicino on a Sunday evening. There were salutes and embraces. Old friends said never mind. Things began to cheer up. At last, towards midnight, we were back in Verona and the boys could disappear into the fog-bound city, where mothers and girlfriends were no doubt waiting up for them.

In the end, I reflected, peering through a frozen windscreen, these young men had earned, on average, a few thousand pounds each for two days in a nice hotel and a game of football. I myself had travelled entirely free thanks to the inexplicable generosity of Hellas Verona football club, whom I now take this opportunity to thank. But in the middle of the night I woke up and almost screamed: "I would have paid all my expenses twice over to see some decent football and WIN!"

 Tim Parks is writing a book about following Hellas Verona. A Season with Verona will be published by Secker & Warburg in March 2002. His website is at www.timparks.com

fields.headline: On deadly ground
fields.standfirst: On Friday, Victor Meldrew will rise from the dead in one final appearance for Comic Relief. But Richard Wilson hasn't been idle since his character was killed off. Marina Cantacuzino caught up with him - in Laos
fields.trailText: On Friday, Victor Meldrew will rise from the dead in one final appearance for Comic Relief. But Richard Wilson hasn't been idle since his character was killed off. Marina Cantacuzino caught up with him - in Laos
fields.body:
At a village outside Phonsavan in Laos, Richard Wilson, aka Victor Meldrew, sits listening intently to 14-year-old Teng's distressing tale. Six months ago he was striking the ground with his hoe when he hit a BLU-26 anti-personnel cluster bomb. It exploded on impact, leaving Teng blinded in both eyes and with most of his left hand blown away. Still in trauma, the boy talks of his long, empty days filled with regret.

The BLU-26, the most commonly found cluster bomb in Laos, is a tennis ball-shaped bomblet designed for maximum damage. Children who have seen these relics made into lamps, table legs or even cowbells find them irresistible to play with, and often die or are maimed as a result.

"Landmines just upset me," says Wilson, who is travelling in Laos with the charity Landmine Action. "The idea that they're aimed at an innocent population to maim and drain the economy is a putrid idea. How can people go to bed at night knowing they've produced them, or bought shares in armament companies?"

His purpose here is to focus attention on the cluster bombs and other unexploded ordnance. Between 9m and 27m unexploded cluster bomblets are "seeded" throughout the country, a pernicious reminder of America's mass bombing of Laos during the Vietnam war - an assault kept secret from the rest of the world. A quarter of a century later, people's lives are still being ripped apart by it. Innocent pastimes, such as hoeing a field, throwing stones into a river or lighting a fire, can have fatal consequences. Since 1973, 12,000 Laotians have been killed or maimed. "The problem," says Wilson, "is that no one will take responsibility. The Americans spent over $2m a day on the bombing of Laos, now they're only spending $2m a year to help clear it up."

Even in the furthest outreach of the backpackers' trail in Phonsavan, the dusty capital of Xieng Khouang (the most bomb- saturated province of Laos), Wilson can't get away from the business of celebrity. In the bustling Sangah restaurant - frequented by expats, travellers and roving Chinese road builders - an English student approaches, sheepishly: "Am I right in thinking . . . ?" "Yes, you are indeed right," Wilson replies, slowly and deliberately. Later the man returns with 13,000 kip (£1.30) from his depleted budget: a donation to Landmine Action.

Overseas charity trips seriously test tempers. There are endless briefings, long journeys on punishingly uneven roads, few or no creature comforts and ever changing itineraries. I had assumed that by travelling for eight days with Wilson, I would come away with some compelling insights into the 65-year-old actor. However, Wilson is so contained, restrained and mindful of the slightest indiscretion (always followed by a quick "off the record") that my most staggering revelation involves his partiality to cold baked beans, which he keeps in his fridge ready to liven up a salad.

He is prepared to answer questions on any of the following subjects: politics (he is a strong Labour supporter); theatre (he is an associate director of the Royal Court, for whom he directs one play a year); youth (he was rector of Glasgow University in the late 90s and an ambassador for VSO); the royal family (he is not a fan); the supernatural (he dismisses the notions of ghosts, horoscopes and UFOs), religion (he can't believe how intelligent people join the clergy). But he never asks questions back, and has a knack of moving the focus of the conversation to the middle distance.

Baked beans aside, Wilson doesn't see any inconsistency between his socialism and his predilection for the high life. He likes to travel first class, hires limousines for the day and has a masseuse come to his house once a week. "I'm not particularly proud that I enjoy these things, but why not?"

In Laos, the curmudgeonly Victor Meldrew only occasionally puts in an appearance, and always with irony - for instance when he hands out a packet of mints to the dry-mouthed assembled group and everyone takes one. "Well, that was a mistake," he says, cocking an eyebrow at his suddenly three-quarters-empty packet.

He is game for almost anything. When it turns out that we have to fly on a dodgy Chinese plane which lurches from Phonsavan to Vientiane instead of the spanking new French model, he shrugs. "I'm not usually scared of flying, but I was then," he later admits. Visiting the 2,000-year-old Plain of Jars, he agrees to pose for a photograph, placing himself gingerly inside one of the massive stone jars, with just his head poking out.

For such a self-possessed man he is surprisingly considerate of other people's feelings, worrying, for instance, that a solitary backpacker sitting at the end of our table "wants to talk". At the end of the meal he goes up to chat. What he dislikes is people being nosy - like the English woman at Vientiane's sleepy airport who started talking in a very loud voice as if he was a long-lost friend. "But I'm meticulous about trying to be responsible. I know it's the public who made me famous, and I owe them something."

He is not sorry to see the end of One Foot in the Grave - although Victor is making a one-off comeback for Comic Relief. "I'm relieved to see the back of him," says Wilson. "I'd played him out and there was no challenge any more." Nor is he too worried about the future. He has just finished recording High Stakes, a comedy series for ITV in which he plays a merchant banker, and is about to start on another series with Stephanie Cole for the BBC.

One of the privileges of his fame is getting access to projects and places about which he cares passionately - for instance, the rehabilitation units in Phonsavan, where amputees are fitted with prostheses. "I've always had a terror of having a bit chopped off," he says. "It's the body-image side I find quite disturbing."

The cluster bomblets cause mainly upper-body injuries - blindness and hand amputations. Many victims cannot afford surgery and long-term antibiotics, and simply die. Amputations and deaths also occur because villages are inaccessible and roads impassable. One seven-year-old boy's foot burned for eight days because there was no running water.

Visiting a school built on bombs and watching a clearance team in operation, Wilson quickly gravitates to the kids. "I love children," he says. "They're so unadulterated and open. Unfortunately they don't always stay that way. It's sad when they grow up too quickly and become manipulative, skiving and contrived."

Wilson's words could just as well apply to the perpetrators of the cluster bombings who have failed to clear up the lethal mess they left behind in Laos, Iraq, Kosovo and Kuwait; or, for that matter, to the British government, which still refuses to implement a freeze on such obscene weapons of war.

 Contact Landmine action on 020-7820 0222 or at www.landmineaction.org. The One Foot in the Grave special is showing as part of Comic Relief, 7pm, Friday, BBC1.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: La Jetée | The Commitments | The Astronaut's Wife | Papillon | Andrei Rublev
fields.body:
Films

La Jetée (Chris Marker, 1962) 7.25pm, FilmFour
The film that inspired Terry Gilliam's Twelve Monkeys, Marker's short crams more into its 27 minutes than most full-length features manage. It's a story - told almost entirely in still frames - of a man (Davos Hanich) in a post-apocalyptic world who is persuaded into a time travel experiment, to discover the meaning of a haunting memory of a woman's face at the end of a jetty. The result is stunning.

The Commitments (Alan Parker, 1991) 8pm, 1.25am, Sky Cinema
Worth watching for the tremendous r&b soundtrack: Mustang Sally, Mr Pitiful, In The Midnight Hour and all, worked over by the extraordinary 16-year-old singer, Andrew Strong. There's an exhilarating tale in there too, adapted from Roddy Doyle's novel: an account of young Dubliners getting a band together. Raucously funny.

The Astronaut's Wife (Rand Ravich, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
Astronaut Johnny Depp returns from a space mission apparently unharmed by a mysterious accident during a two-minute communications black-out; but his wife (Charlize Theron) begins to notice changes. Soon she becomes pregnant, but is she carrying human twins, or alien creatures? It's basically a sci-fi Rosemary's Baby, and Theron - in a performance containing many shades of fear, anxiety, and gutsy strength - sports Mia Farrow-style cropped blonde hair. But this is a quieter, slower movie than Polanski's.

Papillon (Franklin J Schaffner, 1973) 10pm, FilmFour
Superior prison drama based on Henri Charrière's allegedly autobiographical book about escaping the savage French regime on Devil's Island. fields.headline: No 1837 Elstree
fields.trailText: Pass notes would like to inform readers that she's barely awake this morning, and therefore takes no responsibility for the contents of this column. Another late night on the Diet Pepsi, eh?
fields.body:
Pass notes would like to inform readers that she's barely awake this morning, and therefore takes no responsibility for the contents of this column. Another late night on the Diet Pepsi, eh?

No, she nodded off over her Greater London road atlas, trying to locate the unfortunately named Borehamwood, home of the BBC's Elstree studios. It is also, according to Top of the Pops producer Chris Cowey, the most boring town in Britain. Well, somewhere's got to be, so it may as well be this deliciously verdant corner of south-eastern Hertfordshire, just a 45-minute limo ride from the Beeb's west London HQ. And if the casts of EastEnders, Grange Hill and Holby City are perfectly happy to film there (Elstree's office block is used for exterior shots in the latter), what's Cowey's problem?

Top of the Pops is due for a slick relaunch, and he says that Borehamwood is too strait-laced for his twinkly new show. Moreover, the likes of Jennifer Lopez complain it's too far from Prada. Hence, TOTP is moving to London so Cowey can fill the studio with "exotics and West End fashion victims".

Pffft! Does he not realise that Elstree has been part of British cinema history since1914? That Star Wars, Indiana Jones and Chariots of Fire were made there before the BBC bought the site in 1983? That Pass notes once visited the EastEnders set and, do you know, the houses look real, but there's nothing behind them?

It seems he is unmoved. Also, the BBC needs more space for drama, so TOTP's move suits it. "Nothing to do with Borehamwood being boring," says the Beeb. That won't wash with Lisa McIntosh, a local teenager furious that Hertfordshire is not sexy enough for a show that features Westlife every blessed week. "What a cheek," she fumed.

Don't say: What time's the next train to London?

webTitle: Jeremy Atiyah on life in Siberia

fields.headline: Winter's tale
fields.standfirst:
It's cold enough to make your eyes water - and then freeze the teardrops on your face. So what made Jeremy Atiyah swap a London flat for an apartment in Siberia?

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: It's cold enough to make your eyes water - and then freeze the teardrops on your face. So what made Jeremy Atiyah swap a London flat for an apartment in Siberia?
fields.body:
Twenty people have so far frozen to death," the BBC World reporter was explaining, in a cloud of white steam, "and hospitals in Irkutsk, Siberia, are performing 60 amputations a week on frostbite victims." That was in January, and I only took notice because, funnily enough, I was just off there myself - to Siberia, that is - for some peace and quiet to write a book. What was more, I had chosen the little town of Irkutsk on the grounds that nothing from the real world could possibly disturb me out there. And now here it was, two days before my departure, in the news.

I wasn't going to Siberia to get a tan. But writing a book in a cosy flat when it was cold outside was one thing. Writing a book in a cosy flat when it was -45C and people were dying of frostbite outside was quite another. Not that I was going to change my plans. Cold snap or not, I had picked Irkutsk because of its remoteness. Even Moscow was five time zones and 5,000km away. The nearest major city was Ulan Bator in Outer Mongolia. I wanted to live in a place that was too insignificant for anyone even to care whether it counted as Europe or Asia.

Or so I tried to reassure myself, boarding my Tupolev in Moscow, bound for one of the coldest places on earth. In fact, I was dressed in an outfit that might have saved Scott of the Antarctic. But disembarking five hours later, I discovered that the temperature had risen to -30. In my long johns, ski-trousers, down jacket and rabbit-skin hat, I found this rather comfortable. Only the instantaneous freezing of the moisture in my nostrils and on my eyelashes was unpleasant (it is a feeling I have since grown used to).

Off I drove over impacted snow, passing men with their ear-flaps pulled down, in search of my very own Siberian apartment. I had already arranged this by email, through someone I met on holiday ("Is it heated?" I remember asking, anxiously. "Of course it is," had come the terse reply). To live here for a year would cost the same as to rent out my flat in London for a month.

Furthermore, all Russian apartment blocks are communally heated: no one worries here about gas bills. They do worry that the heating might break down when the temperature is -40.

I confess that my block, when I got there, did not look much like my block back home. To open the outer door, force was needed to break ice on the hinges. Up a dark and stinking stairwell, I found old ladies peering fearfully from doorways. Unseen dogs barked. My flat turned out to have a solid steel door with eight locks on it, which, I am assured, is very fortunate for me.

Apartments right across the former Soviet Union tend to share certain endearing features such as cosy kitchens and crockery labelled "Made in the GDR". But the best aspect of my new flat, I soon found, were the radiators, which blasted heat into every room 24 hours a day (and would continue to do so for seven or eight months of the year). By now, I had seen enough television pictures of people in the Yakutia and Primorsky regions, to the north and east of Irkutsk, shivering in flats with cold radiators.

Admittedly, the insides of my windows were coated with ice-sheets so thick that I could see nothing out of them at all. I recall celebrating my arrival by quietly opening a bottle of something called Russian champagne, which then exploded all over the walls and ceiling, leaving barely a thimbleful in the bottom of the bottle.

Out in the streets, though, I found a certain pleasure in the extreme cold. Every passer-by wore a vast hat and went about enveloped in a personal cloud of steam. Exotic tapestries of frost hung from trees, walls and balconies. As for the Siberian pavement ice, I fancied that it had a mineral permanence to it: when chipped with pickaxes, it had the appearance of marble, millions of years old.

Siberian children, too, I was soon pleased to see, got their kicks from sliding on ice and attacking each other with snowballs. In the centre of town, I found an ice-chute: the children (alongside their elegant mothers in long fur coats with waists and pleats and Duchess of Windsor hats) spent their Saturdays hurtling down it on their bums with their feet in the air.

A fortnight after my arrival, we were informed on the news about the imminent invasion of more outlandish temperatures. Minus 40 and below loomed. "Have you heard?" people kept asking me, in excitement. "Are you ready for it?" Now when I went to market I found women with their faces wrapped to the eyeballs, standing behind piles of congealed fish, bent and frozen stiff. Ice-cream was sold in unpackaged, naked blobs. For a few days we went around with hats and collars covered in hoar frost.

In these bitterest days, I heard no word in the tram-stations or the bus-stops, just the sound of crunching snow and silence. For a Siberian to admit to feeling cold is as difficult as for an Italian man to admit that he is no good with women. "What?" they would shout. "If you're cold, drink more vodka!"

But we all knew that Irkutsk, unlike Vladivostok, was not suffering from energy shortages. "If our flats are warm and we can make ourselves cups of tea," one woman said, "what do we have to worry about?"

Some people did worry. In the local theatre, I heard of a troupe having to practise their dance movements in giant felt boots. Buses drove about in pairs, in readiness for the extreme likelihood of one of them breaking down during the day. Schools closed. But one teacher told me she liked the cold: "It keeps the delinquents off the streets."

Otherwise, suffering went on in silence. Walking home through the town centre one night with the temperature at -38, I came across a cluster of old women attempting to sell sunflower seeds from little paper cups. They had built a fire from cardboard boxes, which had attracted a few squabbling down-and-outs. Some of these people could not have had a life expectancy of more than a few hours.

But stories of alcoholics found frozen to death on public benches arouse little sympathy in Russia. Daily survival here in wintertime is joyless. If the peace and quiet that I came to find in Siberia was turning out (for a few winos) to be the quiet of the grave, it was hard to find people who cared. I remember wandering home that same evening in my down jacket and ski trousers, admiring the glitter of the snow under brilliant stars.

And now? Here we are already well into March. Daytime temperatures sometimes reach zero degrees and the ice on my windows is gone. Outside, long fur coats are being replaced by short ones. The pavement snow is slowly turning grey and reverting to stones and grit, and I'm still sitting here writing my book. For those who have made it, another Siberian winter seems to be almost over.

webTitle: Matt Seaton on Tierney Gearon's real crime

fields.headline: The myth of childhood innocence
fields.standfirst:
Tierney Gearon's real crime, says the Guardian's parents editor, Matt Seaton, is that her photographs makes us confront an uncomfortable truth

Tierney Gearon defends her photographs
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Tierney Gearon's real crime, says the Guardian's parents editor, Matt Seaton , is that her photographs makes us confront an uncomfortable truth.
fields.body:
One of my favourite pictures of my daughter is of her sitting on a potty, trousers down, grinning like a loon. Because of the camera angle, which looks up at her (what was I doing on the floor?), there is nothing to see of her nakedness other than her bare legs. No genitals; no excreta. It's silly and charming and quite disposable, just another family snap.

That particular picture has not made it into any of the family albums; it sits in a huge, unsorted stack inside a shoebox-sized tin on a shelf. It's not that either myself or my daughter is sensitive about its content. For a while, the photo used to sit on top of the piano.

But there are pictures in the tin I would be less casual about. I wonder how many other parents felt the same lurch in the pit of their stomach when they heard that newsreader Julia Somerville and her partner had been arrested when they went to Boots to collect some snaps that showed their daughter naked in the bath. I had certainly taken pictures of my children's mother, and she had taken pictures of me, with the children in the bath. Those pictures were for us. We didn't order copies for the grandparents - but that was because of our nudity, not the children's. Embarrassing they might be; pornographic they weren't.

Every parent must have photographs like that. Bathtime snaps, bedtime snaps, beach snaps. Not fit for a gallery wall on purely aesthetic grounds, these photographs recall private moments: moments of carefree intimacy and fun. In these pictures, we are celebrating the "golden moments" that - we would like to believe - comprise by far the largest portion of our family life. Of course, the reality is not all like that; but we need to nurture the fantasy. The idea of childhood innocence - often signified in pictures by children's unselfconscious nakedness - is a convenient myth that we parents need in order to maintain that image of ourselves as members of a contented, loving family, without the usual undercurrents of conflict, competition, jealousy and anger.

Nudity often figures in these snaps. It is generic, almost, thematic: because we delight in their lack of self-consciousness, like cherubs or Christ-children in Renaissance paintings, our unclothed children are required to signify an ideal of innocence, a perfect pre-lapsarian purity. Sexuality within the family is felt to be dangerous and threatening, but you don't need to be a shrink to see the Oedipal complex at work - you only need to have been the parent of a three- or four-year-old boy. Any boy. Or any girl, come to that. Their innocence is our construction.

And it is a construction that we put upon them: the unconscious drama behind these "innocent" family snaps involves the parents recruiting their infant children to play a role which, by denying their sexuality, is also about denying our own. I doubt that those who complain about Tierney Gearon's pictures of her children would have any problem with my bathtime pictures, but in a subterranean way, they do represent a type of exploitation. Gearon's "crime" is that she makes us think about it.

On Saturday morning a package arrived from an American friend which included a copy of the celebrated annual Swimwear issue of Sports Illustrated. Our five-year-old son promptly pounced on it.

"I can't wait till 'latency'," sighed my wife, referring to Freud's notion of the period between infancy and puberty when children's sexuality becomes submerged.

Our son is fascinated by sex and nudity. Of course, he is innocent - if we mean inexperienced - but we don't feel his interest is anything other than normal, and certainly not something he should be made to feel guilty about. But what the censorship lobby wants innocence to mean is not inexperience, but ignorance. He should not have a sexuality at his age; and, by implication, it is our duty as parents to repress it.

I suppose there may be a point during her adolescence (post-latency!) when our daughter will decide that the picture of her on the potty will belong to the class of things that are hideously embarrassing, to be denied or suppressed at all costs. But, by then, so will I. It's only natural.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: This morning, Sidelines is experiencing a variety of sensations - not hungry, not starving, not deprived and most certainly not like bingeing.
fields.body:
This morning, Sidelines is experiencing a variety of sensations - not hungry, not starving, not deprived and most certainly not like bingeing. All thanks to the delicious new cabbage diet soup which landed (lightly) on our desk today. It contains, according to the sachet, "a full complement of AIR and freeze dried vegetables" (our emphasis, unfortunate grammar), plus one of the world's top-selling diet ingredients to curb sugar cravings (not specified, doubtless to maintain an air of mystery). After waiting an indecent interval for the vegetables to rehydrate, the resulting "meal" left us feeling rather orange, inside and out. Still, if I drink three a day, I'll lose pounds (likely because I'll be ingesting only 141 calories). It's as bad as ordering salad without dressing (you know who you are).

Sidelines may be glad of the soup, of course, when the folk from the Department of Trade and Industry come calling. Along with retailers and academics, the DTI is launching a national sizing survey and wants 14,000 volunteers to take part in a £3m project to assess the shape of the nation. Volunteers will strip to their underwear and be scanned by a computer with eight cameras to capture their dimensions. (The images will later be bought by Charles Saatchi and ignite heated public debate.) The audit aims to result in better-fitting clothes. And an end to soup fundamentalism.

Sidelines would also like to apply for the job of special adviser to the threatened Minister for Men, who may well leap into the frying pan of gender politics after the election. The minister would target the growing health gap between men and women, and promote male-friendly policies. Excellent news. With Baroness Jay on the way out, there'll be a spare seat around the cabinet table. And might Sidelines suggest the new appointee takes a look at Glamour magazine for some pointers on gender difference. According to one feature, you know you're a Glamour woman if . . . losing your make-up bag is more traumatic than losing your purse; when someone offers you a baguette, you think they've been to Fendi; your handbags are too small for your purse and phone. All thanks to the delicious new cabbage diet soup which landed (lightly) on our desk today. It contains, according to the sachet, "a full complement of AIR and freeze dried vegetables" (our emphasis, unfortunate grammar), plus one of the world's top-selling diet ingredients to curb sugar cravings (not specified, doubtless to maintain an air of mystery). fields.headline: Train firm takes on Railtrack
fields.standfirst:
National Express seeks control of complete railway infrastructure in its franchise areas

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: National Express seeks control of complete railway infrastructure in its franchise areas.
fields.body:
Railtrack's position as the sole custodian of the industry's track and signalling operation was seriously challenged yesterday by Britain's biggest train operating company.

Richard Brown, chief executive of the trains division of National Express, which operates six rail franchises, called for train operators to be allowed to run the tracks and signals in their areas, a move which would rapidly diminish Railtrack's influence.

Mr Brown whose company includes ScotRail, Gatwick Express, Midland Mainline and Central Trains, said that no change in the industry five years after privatisation was not an option.

He backed the idea of vertical integration: to have a single company responsible for trains and infrastructure in a particular area of the country or on a special route.

Mr Brown said that the move would eliminate a key interface between Railtrack and a dominant train company. It would mean that all staff would be working for a company which served passengers.

He argued that the idea could only work in certain parts of the country where there were specifically defined regions, such as Scotland, Wales and East Anglia. Mr Brown, who is also chairman of the Association of Train Operating Companies, warned that the industry had spent "too much time and money reorganising rather than managing and investing".

If it carried out another round of reforms, it would need to be quite sure "about what we are trying to achieve and how we intend to get there".

Operational integration could reduce the management and financial pressures on Railtrack and let the company get on with doing its job better.

Mr Brown's comments come at a time when the industry is giving considerable thought to possible reforms at Railtrack. Another company, Stagecoach, has suggested that it would like to develop a key section of track in south London.

Railtrack's mounting financial problems, which is forcing it to make new demands on the government, could lead to it being broken up or being declared bankrupt by the rail regulator. In this situation, Mr Brown's plan could be attractive to the industry.

Mr Brown was speaking at a conference organised by Transport 2000, which discussed several options for the future of the rail system. These ranged from turning Railtrack into a not-for-profit trust to wholesale renationalisation.

Stephen Joseph, director of Transport 2000, said: "It is clear that passengers and freight operators are being failed by the structure that was put in place through privatisation in the 1990s."

Jimmy Knapp, leader of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union, argued for for a staged process towards renationalisation, involving equity in return for public funding.

webTitle: The female passion for all things equine

fields.headline: Pony tales
fields.standfirst: As a new book explores the female passion for all things equine, Sally Weale recalls losing her heart to a horse
fields.trailText: As a new book explores the female passion for all things equine, Sally Weale recalls losing her heart to a horse.
fields.body:
I can't remember how or when it started. Was it at infant school? Junior? I don't know. It was always there. I never had dolls; I wasn't interested in playing doctors and nurses, or mummies and daddies. I didn't like Sindy or Barbie, Tressie or Tiny Tears. I wasn't interested in David Cassidy or David Essex or any of the Osmonds.

My world was one of Welsh cobs and Dartmoor ponies, Hickstead and the Horse of the Year Show. My vocabulary was dominated by fetlocks, forelocks, girths, bits, bridles, dandy brushes, hoof picks, martingales. It's embarrassing, but I was horse-mad, a girl obsessed.

Me and millions of others. According to American writer Melissa Holbrook Pierson, whose new book Dark Horses & Black Beauties explores the phenomenon of female passion for horses, more than half of all little girls in the industrialised world at some point in their childhood fall truly, madly, deeply in love with horses.

In childish dreams, I saw myself as a precocious riding talent, with a glittering future in the world of showjumping and eventing. More than that, I imagined I had a rare ability to communicate with horses; I was a sort of prepubescent horse whisperer, who could subdue the most difficult creature and make him do exactly as I pleased. The more mundane reality was life in the suburbs where my contact with horses was limited to a weekly foray into the green belt to bounce around for an hour on the back of a saggy, shaggy hack at Miss Whitfield's riding school.

The thing about my horsey childhood was that my dreams were so much better than anything reality offered. I never had my own real horse - it was beyond my parents' means. But I had a whole garden shedful of imaginary ones that I used to groom, feed and exercise. I still have notebooks, filled with wildly varying handwriting, that record my horses' names, their breed, their temperament and even imaginary conversations I used to have with them. I'd lead them out of the shed after tacking up, then I'd mount; my legs became their legs, my head their head, tossing and whinnying.

At one point my parents became concerned because I couldn't stop walking like a horse, even when my horses were locked away in the shed. I wasn't even aware of it until they asked me why I was doing this funny little flick with my heels. It took me a while to shake the habit - but I can still do a very convincing neigh.

In the same notebooks, there are hilarious interviews with David Vine about my Horse of the Year show appearances - "What a brilliant clear round and you're only 11!" - (fantasy) as well as self-critical analyses of my weekly performances in front of Miss Whitfield - "Had to kick Jingles a bit too hard to get him to canter; should have used my bottom more" (fact).

My bookshelves heaved with Renee Goes Riding, Jill Wins the Gymkhana, Follyfoot Farm and Black Beauty; at the non-fiction end, Talking to Horses, Horsemanship and - my personal all-time favourite - TV Horse Vet.

My most precious single item was my bridle - a real bridle - which my friend Dawn Nicholls sometimes agreed to wear for a round of jumps in the garden. I had a halter (for catching Dawn) and a grooming kit, as well as the more usual stuff - tea towels covered in all the breeds, Princess Anne headscarves covered in horse-heads, hundreds of plastic horses and an alarmingly extensive collection of Beswick china horses.

I was even a member of the Pony Club for a short time, but it was pretty pointless for non-pony-owning girls. I had a subscription to Pony magazine (I couldn't stomach Horse and Hound even then) and entered the WH Smith Win a Pony competition every year. The questions were ridiculously easy, but the real test came at the end. Using no more than 24 words, complete the sentence: "I would like to win my own pony because . . . "

I never won that pony. Instead I worked at Miss Whitfield's where I regarded it as the most delightful privilege to sweep up horseshit, heave mountains of urine-drenched straw and soap saddles until my knuckles were cracked red and dry. Even today I can't walk past a field with a horse in it without stopping, a David Attenborough programme on wild mustangs is the TV highlight of the week and I still seek out a trekking centre every time I go on holiday.

According to Pierson, a survey a few years ago by the British magazine Gallop! found that three-quarters of women who own horses would as soon give up their husband as their horse, 90% would rather have a new horse than a new baby and the vast majority tell their problems to their horses, not their partners.

But why do we love them? What is it about girls and horses? And it is predominantly girls - in 1999, of the 33,886 members of the UK Pony Club, just 5,285 were boys.

Pierson explores some of the possible explanations: "There's the cliché - girls and horses, eh, wink, wink - and the anti-cliché cliché - no, it's really about girls empowering themselves. You know, they get to steer around thousand-pound animals and feel on top of things for a change." An oversimplification, she concludes.

"Imagining horses in a suburban setting is about imagining nature into existence, in one motion wiping away what is there and replacing it with something better, something anterior, something more primitive: horses. With them you rearrange the world to your liking." Maybe.

"Flying along the surface of the earth is a simple pleasure, irreducible and without peer . . . To borrow the power of another to achieve something so near to pure freedom without its becoming final death is an intoxication." And at another point: "But all love is at base sexual, or at base social, or perhaps even deeper at base the social is sexual, and since we don't know where these things begin and end in our daily life, we are not about to demarcate them when it comes to girls and horses either."

Was it sexual for me? I don't think so, though I did worry for a while that I would lose my virginity to a particularly broad-backed gelding called Bits&Pieces, in the same way that other girls thought they might lose it to a bicycle saddle.

But why women and not men? "For one thing, [horses] are a lot like children; we know how to take care of children - it's in our genes," Pierson writes. "We don't have anything to prove; we don't need to fix things in order to feel good. We're more patient, and horses respond best to patience. You can't use force on a horse and when many men discover that, they're out of there."

Is it what she calls "anticipatory coping"? In other words, girls practising for the real thing - boys? Is it the "impossible mixture of power and delicacy, size and fragility"?

I don't know whether it's about nurturing or sex, power or passion. For me, it was about the imagination. It was a brilliant fantasy world I inhabited for probably 10 years of my life. Had I won that WH Smith competition (did anyone ever? I doubt it), my horsey dream world would have been shattered. Who needs the harsh realities of keeping a horse - the expense, the time, the effort, the injuries - when your garden shed is full of Red Rum-like creatures who adore you, who talk to you and require attention only when you feel like giving it to them?

I still dream I might have my own horse one day. What will he or she be like? Maybe an ageing thoroughbred, who once had her own glittering future, competing over hurdles, but she threw her rider, causing them serious injury. Maybe I'll save her from the knacker's yard; I'll teach her to trust humans again, I'll be the only person she allows on her back.

Long live fantasy.

 Dark Horses & Black Beauties: Animals, Women, A Passion by Melissa Holbrook Pierson is published by Granta on March 22 at £12.99.

webTitle: Gallery gains more time in child photos row

fields.headline: Gallery gains more time in child photos row
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The threat of an immediate police seizure of the controversial Saatchi gallery photographs was lifted last night after Scotland Yard said it was now unlikely they would get a legal decision before the gallery opens again on Thursday.
fields.body:
The threat of an immediate police seizure of the controversial Saatchi gallery photographs was lifted last night after Scotland Yard said it was now unlikely they would get a legal decision before the gallery opens again on Thursday.

Chief Inspector Chris Bradford of the Metropolitan police clubs and vice unit, in charge of the inquiry, said last night: "The Saatchi gallery is a respectable establishment and seizing the photos would have been using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

"It was never our intention to take the photos away before the crown prosecution service had made its decision. Our officers thought they had made that clear when they visited the gallery last week. Something has been lost in the telling. We were trying not to be heavy handed."

Chief Inspector Bradford added that the police had hoped to give the gallery an indication of the CPS decision by this Thursday but that now seemed unlikely.

The gallery curator, Jenny Blyth, buoyed by a wave of support from cultural and artistic figures, last night stood by her belief that the pictures by an American photographer, Tierney Gearon, of her children were not pornography. "We are not going to remove the works from the show. I don't think that because a child is naked means it is indecent," she said.

The director of public prosecutions yesterday confirmed he had received the file from Scotland Yard's obscene publications unit and was now considering whether a prosecution under the 1978 Protection of Children Act should go ahead. "It is under review," a CPS spokeswoman said.

The law under which the gallery faces prosecution was put on the statute book in the aftermath of a campaign by Mary Whitehouse against "kiddie porn" and the exposure of the Paedophile Information Exchange.

Ministers gave an assurance that parents' innocent snaps of their children would not be caught by the legislation which was introduced as a private member's bill and whistled through parliament with little debate.

The law made it a crime, punishable by up to three years' imprisonment and a fine of up to £10,000, to make indecent photographs of children - anyone under 16 - and to possess, distribute and show such material. For the purposes of the act a photograph can be taken to mean a film or a video as well.

The act does not define the term "indecent" - a term which juries have notorious difficulty in defining - and a Home Office minister, during the passage of the bill, argued that nudity was not considered by the courts to be proof of indecency.

If the Saatchi case ever gets to court it is likely to turn on the issue of "indecency". The legal opinion drawn up by Geoffrey Robertson QC for the gallery is believed to argue that it is clear from precedents that indecency in law requires an element of lewdness, or sexual provocation, or a lack of innocence, which are not present in this case.

Unlike the obscenity laws the Protection of Children Act does not provide any explicit defence of artistic merit but it does give a defence of having a legitimate reason for distributing or showing the photographs. It is expected the gallery would argue that the photographs were being exhibited for a legitimate reason, artistic contemplation, and not prurient interest. The law has never been used against art exhibitions in its 22 year history.

fields.headline: Bear turns on broker
fields.trailText: Under the leadership of Terry Smith, stockbroker Collins Stewart's profile has grown
fields.body:
Pretty much everything has gone right since stockbroker Collins Stewart floated last October. Under the leadership of Terry Smith, its profile has grown and the shares (at 335p last night) are trading about the flotation price. Not a bad performance in this market.

Simon Cawkwell, the bear raider known as "Evil Kinevil", reckons the company is overvalued and has started to short the stock.

Mr Cawkwell, who predicted the demise of drug company Scotia, thinks the broker's market capitalisation of £350m is "ludicrously high" given the slowdown in corporate deals. He believes Collins Stewart is dependent for the bulk of its earnings on corporate advisory work, which he claims has "fallen off a cliff".

The market will be able to make its own judgment next week, when the stockbroker unveils its full year figures.

fields.headline: At this price?  Chubb
fields.trailText: Having been awarded £180,000 for a non-executive chairman's post at Chubb, Robert Carr must be feeling some pressure to start delivering tangible benefits for shareholders.
fields.body:
Having been awarded £180,000 for a non-executive chairman's post at Chubb, Robert Carr must be feeling some pressure to start delivering tangible benefits for shareholders.

Mr Carr and Sir Nigel Rudd made £2m each out of the break-up of Williams into Chubb and Kidde. Investors were reassured by the Chubb prospectus issued last September which promised that the security group was "well-positioned to continue its expansion".

This was followed up in December by a statement that the board "remains confident about the prospects for Chubb". But the intervening months have brought little but insecurity and Chubb shares have lost more than 40% of their value.

Yesterday salt was poured on the wounds with news that pre-tax profits slumped from £106.7m to £33.5m, damaged by the cost of breaking up Williams.

The position was made worse by poor results from recession-hit Australia where Chubb provided security staff for the Olympic games and had hopes of further gains.

Yesterday it was left to chief executive Robert Gasparini to admit that management had taken its eye off the ball.

"While it is clear that the transition undoubtedly took its toll on the results for the year, I am confident that we are now in a strong position to capitalise on the opportunities that exist and to deliver growth over the coming year," he said.

The City took the results in its stride with Chubb marking time at 143p. This should not be read as indifference so much as a feeling that the stock cannot fall any lower given its potential as a takeover target for say Rentokil, Tyco or even Honeywell.

webTitle: Head-hunters enlisted in army's hunt for recruits

fields.headline: Head-hunters enlisted in army's hunt for recruits
fields.trailText: The army has turned to the private sector to recruit thousands of squaddies.
fields.body:
The army has turned to the private sector to recruit thousands of squaddies.

Army recruiting sergeants and staff from Search, a Glasgow-based head-hunting agency, have joined forces in an organisation called Advance to provide specialist advice to help make up a serious shortfall in the number of trained soldiers.

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said the idea was to attract young people to alternatives to industry or further education. A marketing campaign would highlight the "sense of responsibility and leadership" the army offered.

Recruitment to the armed forces traditionally falls when the economy is doing well with the private sector seeking more staff.

Latest official figures published by the MoD show that army recruitment fell by over 14% during the last three months of last year, though net outflow of trained soldiers showed a small reduction.

The army has about 100,000 trained soldiers, a shortfall of 8,000 which the ministry wants to make up by 2005.

fields.headline: Don't go near the water
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: For all the talk about psychologically important index levels, the fact remains that those who control the bulk of the money in the London market do not know when the FTSE 100 is going to bottom out.
fields.body:
For all the talk about psychologically important index levels, the fact remains that the men and women who control the bulk of the money swirling around the London market do not know when the FTSE 100 is going to bottom out. And they are very nervous.

When the blue chip index regained the "important" 6,000 level last week after Goldman Sachs' revered investment strategist, Abby Cohen, advised her US clients to increase their exposure to equities, there was a feeling that, at last, it was safe to go back in the water.

On yesterday's showing, it clearly is not.

From the outset, the omens were not good. Traders arrived at their desks having to digest the implications of Friday's late news from Cisco, the internet equipment maker, that it would cut 11% of its workforce in response to the slowing US economy.

On top of that there was the awful performance of Prudential to deal with. The share price of the life assurer went into reverse after it surprised the market with the $22.3bn (£15bn) acquisition of US rival American General.

With the Nasdaq falling below 2,000 for the first time since December 1998 London's misery was almost complete - although it was left to Swedish telecom equipment maker Ericsson to deliver the last rites.

After Ericsson announced that first quarter sales would be lower than forecast and predicted a pretax loss of $400 to $500m, the FTSE backtracked to a level last seen in February 1999.

Thanks to shenanigans in the end of day auction process the FTSE 100 managed to finish off its lows, but was still down 90.8 points at 5,826.5 - its worst close in two years.

Elsewhere, things were no better. The FTSE Techmark 100 slid to its lowest finish to date - falling 81.37 points, or 3.5%, to 2,227.37, with the likes of Scoot.com , down 8.5p to 27p, Bookham Technology , off 83p to 361p, and Kewill Systems , 39p weaker at 188p, hit by what dealers described as panic selling.

"So many people have tried to call the bottom of this market so many times, but no one has succeeded.

"Confidence must be at its lowest level in a decade," one dealer said.

With a lack of corporate stories doing the rounds, all traders could do was sit back and watch the rout of tech and telecom stocks.

Marconi , which competes against Cisco, and ARM , which licenses its chip designs to Ericsson, bore the brunt of the selling, falling 34p to 447p and 29.5p to 302p respectively.

Autonomy , 104p worse at £12.05, Colt Telecom , off 84p to £11.40, and BT , 21.5p weaker at 533.5p, were also hit.

Even biotechnology company Celltech , 130p poorer at £11.70, was affected by the chill wind blowing from across the Atlantic.

Nevertheless, Prudential was the worst blue chip performer, surrendering 125p to 772p, as the City digested its all-paper acquisition of American General. Although analysts applauded the strategic rationale of the deal they were concerned about the price paid, and the possibility of a massive flowback of stock.

Many analysts fear that US institutions holding American General shares might not want Prudential paper. Furthermore, there will be some US shareholders who will be forced to sell because they are not allowed holdings in foreign companies.

The banking sector, so often the FTSE's saviour in the past year, was also struggling. HSBC lost 42p to 862p after Goldman Sachs lowered its rating on the stock and cut its profits forecast for the current year by 15%.

Selective old economy stocks provided the only pockets of buying interest, with Centrica , 10p better at 245p, Safeway , up 5.5p to 294p, and Sainsbury , 5.5p higher at 376p, all wanted for their qualities as defensive stocks.

Lower down the corporate ladder, property company Savills - up 1.5p to 254p - was in focus as ING Barings set about placing the 19.6% stake of First Pacific Davies with institutional investors at 240p.

webTitle: Surprise appointment gives Glyndebourne youngest opera team

fields.headline: Surprise appointment gives Glyndebourne youngest opera team
fields.trailText: Glyndebourne may have some way to go to match the blood and gore of Covent Garden's internal politics, but the East Sussex opera house did manage to raise a tremor last night with its appointment of David Pickard as its third general director in two years.
fields.body:
Glyndebourne may have some way to go to match the blood and gore of Covent Garden's internal politics, but the East Sussex opera house did manage to raise a tremor last night with its appointment of David Pickard as its third general director in two years.

At 40, Pickard - who began to make his mark with the late, lamented Kent Opera - will head the youngest team running a major opera house in Euorpe alongside 28-year-old musical director Vladimir Jurowski. Glyndebourne's executive chairman, Gus Christie, is a venerable 36.

Despite his eight highly successful years in charge of the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, one of the mainstays of Glyndebourne's summer festival, the choice of Pickard as a replacement for the older, but much more radical Nicholas Snowman, who left suddenly three months ago, came as a surprise.

Elaine Padmore from Covent Garden, Welsh National Opera's dynamic leader Anthony Freud and a trio of continental opera house managers were thought more likely contenders.

Snowman's decision to "spend more time with my family" came out of the blue with both he and the Christie dynasty, who own the opera house, stressing that there had been no falling out.

Rumours had been rife that the relationship was strained by Snowman's wish to break Glyndebourne's fairly rigid pay scale and his desire for more spectacular productions.

Sir George Christie, now president of Glyndebourne Productions, said Pickard was chosen as much for his artistic flair as his business sense.

"David Pickard comes straight from the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment where he has had extraordinary success, not just financially, but particularly in artistic achievement. With his appointment, at the age of 40, together with those of our new music director, Vladimir Jurowski, and Gus Christie as executive chairman, the company looks forward to a new and rejuvenated future."
