fields.headline: Botticellis brought together 500 years on
fields.standfirst: Divine Comedy drawings were scattered by winds of history
fields.trailText: The 92 surviving drawings by Sandro Botticelli illustrating Dante's Divine Comedy have been brought together for the first time in 500 years, in an exhibition opening at the Royal Academy in London on Saturday.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The 92 surviving drawings by Sandro Botticelli illustrating Dante's Divine Comedy have been brought together for the first time in 500 years, in an exhibition opening at the Royal Academy in London on Saturday.

The vast commission for a Medici prince was never completed, and the curators believe the drawings were scattered across Europe even before the artist's death in 1510. Reassembling the drawings has been a dream of the academy's secretary, Norman Rosenthal, for 15 years. When he first conceived the exhibition, it was in the realm of fantasy: some were in the Vatican, but the bulk were in Berlin - Hell and Purgatory in west Berlin, and Heaven on the other side of the wall.

The history of the Divine Comedy is a detective story which still has many mysteries, said co-curator Cecilia Treves.

The text, on the reverse of the sheets, is complete, but while some of the drawings are highly worked, and a few have been coloured, many sheets have no more than one or two wraith-like figures in lead point. "There are eight missing sheets, and I still think it is possible they exist somewhere, and may yet turn up," she said.

The drawings were scattered over centuries of European political history. Some were bought in Paris in 1650 for Queen Christina of Sweden, who took them to Rome, where they ended up in the Vatican.

The bulk of the drawings were bought in Paris, but over a century later, by the English collector William Beckford. The Duke of Hamilton inherited them and they were sold again in 1882. The then director of the Berlin drawings collection was so determined to get hold of them that he stopped the auction at Sotheby's and accepted the condition that he had to buy the entire contents of the library to acquire them.

Hein Altcappenberg, curator of drawings at the Stadliche museum in Berlin, believes they were originally given away as a diplomatic bribe. Botticelli's patron was Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco de' Medici, who at the end of the 15th century formed an alliance with the French king, Charles.

Botticelli thought so highly of the drawings that one is signed, on a tiny scroll held by a flying angel. The only other work signed by the artist is his Mystic Nativity, in the National Gallery. Dr Altcappenberg believes Botticelli signed the drawing when his great project was sent out of Italy.

fields.headline: Rare letters show Forster's shyness
fields.trailText: "I am just off to India ...", EM Forster wrote to his publisher in a letter disclosed for the first time yesterday, "I expect to have an interesting time and penetrate into queerish places."
fields.body:
"I am just off to India ...", EM Forster wrote to his publisher in a letter disclosed for the first time yesterday, "I expect to have an interesting time and penetrate into queerish places."

Any double meaning is likely to be "subconscious, not intended - he's not talking like Oscar Wilde", according to Felix Pryor, literature specialist at the London auctioneers Phillips.

The writer was a diffident, ceremonious man unlikely to risk suggestive remarks to his upright publisher, Edward Arnold. All the same, the words he wrote in March 1913, at the age of 34, came true. In India and Egypt he did reach more deeply into his homosexual nature, as well as into other regions of experience, than ever before. Out of this came first his overtly gay novel Maurice - which he suppressed for nearly 60 years.

Before he set off for the subcontinent he wrote to his publisher: "I don't suppose you want a book about India, or do I know how to write one yet. Still, if you have any ideas on the subject, let me know ..."

Summing up his masterpiece A Passage to India with rare exuberance in a letter in 1924, the year it was published, he wrote: "Not 'gorgeous' East, but real East - complex, mystic ...I saw not only Anglo-Indian but also Mohamudans [sic] and Hindus".

The letters are part of a batch of 116, unpublished and rarely seen by scholars, which are expected to fetch up to £30,000 on March 30. All dating from the most productive phase of Forster's life, they are being sold by what the auctioneer calls a private literary source.

They cover 31 years of his bond with his publishers, beginning with his third novel, A Room With a View (1908). Shortly afterwards Forster wrote shyly offering to send three draft chapters of a new story "so that you could see a little whether it is the kind of thing you would care to be connected with".

"It is more ambitious than the last book ...Its title is Howards End". Howards End (1910) brought him "quite as much praise as it deserves" but also the first of a series of infuriating surplus apostrophes which still crop up 90 years later.

"I see that in some advertisements (eg in the Times) that the book is called Howard's End," he complained to Arnold. "I should be grateful if this could be rectified as I want people to realise that it is about a place not a person."

In April 1923 he wrote to Arnold diffidently offering 40,000 draft words of A Passage to India. A year later, with the book due out, he wrote: "I have been careful not to allude to contemporary politics ... but of course it describes the social soil out of which politics spring."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Factory job losses likely
fields.body:
Factory job losses likely

More job losses were predicted in the manufacturing sector yesterday after official figures showed firms struggling to pass on rising raw material costs to their customers.

Input prices increased by 1.8% in February, more than the 0.8% expected by the City, while output prices fell 0.1%, putting additional pressure on profit margins.

The increase in input prices was driven by crude oil, which jumped 9.6% in the month, according to the ONS.

Output prices have now fallen in each of the past three months, taking the annual rate down to 1.6%, the lowest since August 1999.

'Big' boss joins C4 board

Peter Bazalgette, the television executive who brought the Big Brother phenomenon to Britain, has joined the board of Channel 4.

Mr Bazalgette, the creative director of the UK arm of production company Endemol Entertainment, is also behind popular series including BBC2's Changing Rooms and Food & Drink.

Duffield under pressure

Pressure was mounting last night on multimillionaire fund manager John Duffield after 76 of his former staff, including the brother of actress Helena Bonham Carter, signed a petition demanding immediate changes to a £117m trust set up to manage their savings.

Massow targets listings market

Financier Ivan Massow has taken a 10% stake in CapitalLive, the free listings magazine taking on Time Out in London. Mr Massow, who built his financial services business targeting the gay community into a top 10 financial advisor, will become chairman of the title.

FSA to beef up leak rules

The financial services authority said yesterday it is preparing a new offensive on the leaking to newspapers of market sensitive corporate information.

A spokesman for the FSA said revised guidelines would underline the fact that the unofficial release of information was against its rulebook.

The FSA is updating its rules, partly to reflect technological change since they were published five years ago.

A particular focus is the so-called Friday night drop, when press offices and PR companies release information to selected Sunday newspapers, often in the hope of blunting the impact of bad news.

webTitle: Serbian mayor's surrender gives ray of hope to Hague tribunal

fields.headline: Serbian mayor's surrender gives ray of hope to Hague tribunal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Efforts to persuade Yugoslavia's fledgling government to cooperate with the war crimes tribunal in the Hague were given a symbolic boost yesterday when a former mayor accused of crimes against humanity gave himself up to the court.
fields.body:
Efforts to persuade Yugoslavia's fledgling government to cooperate with the war crimes tribunal in the Hague were given a symbolic boost yesterday when a former mayor accused of crimes against humanity gave himself up to the court.

Blagoje Simic, 41, is the first citizen of Yugoslavia proper to surrender to the court for crimes allegedly committed during the 1992-95 Bosnian war.

The court's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, has lobbied Belgrade hard in recent months to get the cooperation of President Vojislav Kostunica in arresting people such as Slobodan Milosevic, Ratko Mladic and Radovan Karadzic.

But to the disappointment of many in the west Mr Kostunica has all but refused to help track down and arrest the "big fish" wanted by the court.

His foot-dragging has exasperated Mrs Del Ponte and angered Washington, which has warned the Yugoslav nationalist that his country may face US economic sanctions by the end of this month unless he begins to cooperate.

Mr Simic's surrender is seen in some quarters as a sign that Mr Kostunica may now be preparing to soften his stance.

"We asked them [Yugoslavia] to give a concrete sign of cooperation ... That's good if it's the beginning of the process," Mrs Del Ponte's spokeswoman, Florence Hartmann, said yesterday.

"If Simic is the beginning of the list and at the end we have Mladic, Karadzic and Milosevic, it's very good."

Belgrade also said yesterday that it would for the first time send a government delegation to the Hague to discuss future collaboration.

Mrs Del Ponte said Mr Simic's surrender was "the first encouraging signal from Belgrade", but made it clear that she expected further action.

Mr Simic is charged with committing crimes in 1992, when he was mayor of Bosanski Samac, in Bosnia. He vigorously protests his innocence.

He was the official in charge in April of that year when the town was overrun by Serb forces, and he remained in that post until the end of the war three years later.

Half the town's population of about 17,000 people were Croat or Muslim at the beginning of the war. By 1995 there were only 300 non-Serbs left: the rest had been thrown into Serb-run concentration camps, where many were murdered, tortured and sexually assaulted.

Mr Simic, who was indicted in 1995, is also answerable for the acts of murder and torture which are said to have been carried out by his then chief of police.

Speaking at Belgrade airport before flying to the Hague yesterday, Mr Simic said he had nothing to fear.

Blagoje Simic, 41, is the first citizen of Yugoslavia proper to surrender to the court for crimes allegedly committed during the 1992-95 Bosnian war. The court's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, has lobbied Belgrade hard in recent months to get the cooperation of President Vojislav Kostunica in arresting people such as Slobodan Milosevic, Ratko Mladic and Radovan Karadzic. But to the disappointment of many in the west Mr Kostunica has all but refused to help track down and arrest the "big fish" wanted by the court. His foot-dragging has exasperated Mrs Del Ponte and angered Washington, which has warned the Yugoslav nationalist that his country may face US economic sanctions by the end of this month unless he begins to cooperate. Mr Simic's surrender is seen in some quarters as a sign that Mr Kostunica may now be preparing to soften his stance. "We asked them [Yugoslavia] to give a concrete sign of cooperation ... That's good if it's the beginning of the process," Mrs Del Ponte's spokeswoman, Florence Hartmann, said yesterday. "If Simic is the beginning of the list and at the end we have Mladic, Karadzic and Milosevic, it's very good." Belgrade also said yesterday that it would for the first time send a government delegation to the Hague to discuss future collaboration. Mrs Del Ponte said Mr Simic's surrender was "the first encouraging signal from Belgrade", but made it clear that she expected further action. Mr Simic is charged with committing crimes in 1992, when he was mayor of Bosanski Samac, in Bosnia. He vigorously protests his innocence. He was the official in charge in April of that year when the town was overrun by Serb forces, and he remained in that post until the end of the war three years later. Half the town's population of about 17,000 people were Croat or Muslim at the beginning of the war. By 1995 there were only 300 non-Serbs left: the rest had been thrown into Serb-run concentration camps, where many were murdered, tortured and sexually assaulted. I want to clear my name and that of my family, as well as that of the Yugoslav and Serbian people," he said. He is likely to make his first court appearance this week.

fields.headline: Technophobia grips traders
fields.standfirst: Central bankers' optimism fails to prevent record drop in share prices worldwide
fields.trailText: Global stock markets fell sharply yesterday as deepening gloom in the hi-tech sector overshadowed an upbeat assessment of the world economic outlook, issued by leading central bankers.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Global stock markets fell sharply yesterday as deepening gloom in the hi-tech sector overshadowed an upbeat assessment of the world economic outlook, issued by leading central bankers.

Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George attempted to sooth frayed nerves by saying the slowdown in the US economy looked less dramatic than expected only a few months ago.

But dealers took their cue from news of severe job cuts by computer networking heavyweight Cisco Systems and a profits warning from Ericsson, the world's third-biggest mobile phone maker.

The rout began in Tokyo, where the Nikkei fell 3.62% to a 16-year low of 12,171.37 amid growing political and economic uncertainty, before spreading to Europe and America.

The FTSE 100 slid 1.5% to close at 5,826.5 while the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index lost nearly 5%, dipping below the psychologically important 2,000 level for the first time in two years.

The broader US indices were also down, with the S&P 500 losing nearly 3% in value after the opening bell and the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling more than 2%.

"The negativism is mushrooming," said Dick Schmaltz, director of investment at J&W Seligman in New York. "There are very few heroes in this market."

Speaking after a regular meeting of central bankers in Basle, Switzerland, Sir Eddie said that after a "couple of bumpy quarters" US growth would pick up in the second half of the year.

"If anything, the slowdown was maybe less abrupt than expected, certainly less than maybe had been feared," said Sir Eddie, citing encouraging employment and growth figures.

His remarks helped lift the dollar against the euro but stock markets remained unconvinced about prospects for growth and corporate profitability.

After falling more than 70 points to 1,980 yesterday morning, the Nasdaq was down almost 60% from its high of last March, marking the worst bear market in the index's history.

Art Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies and Co, a US brokerage, said: "The reason it's the worst market ever is that we had the best bull market ever. When the pendulum swings so much, the correction has to be that much more severe."

The latest blow was Cisco's statement issued late Friday that it would cut 11% of its workforce, a move which heightened concerns that there is no quick fix for the sputtering US economy.

Markets have been banking on further aggressive interest rate cuts to keep the world's biggest economy out of a recession but last week's stronger-than-expected US jobless data dashed hopes for a 0.75 percentage point cut at next week's Fed meeting.

Investors will be looking to this week's US retail sales figures for more guidance, but analysts say the markets face a no-win situation.

If the figure is worse than expected, that will increases the chances of a bigger rate cut but also fuel fears of recession, while a better-than-expected figure dims rate-cut hopes.

Swedish manufacturer Ericsson's shares fell 20% after the company shocked markets with the announcement it expected a pre-tax loss of SKr4bn-5bn in the first quarter.

Shares in Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, dropped 9.5%, while French telecom equipment maker Alcatel shed 7.84% and Marconi fell 7.5%.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: A small rash of bets has been placed on the chances of Gordon Brown soon becoming a parent (presumably involving Sarah Macaulay, his wife). Indeed Graham Sharpe, bookmaker to the stars at William Hill, is offering the relatively ungenerous odds of 2-1 that Gordon will be confirmed as a daddy within the year.
fields.body:
 There's enough idle speculation in this world without having to add to it but some things are just too good to resist. A small rash of bets has been placed on the chances of Gordon Brown soon becoming a parent (presumably involving Sarah Macaulay, his wife). Indeed Graham Sharpe, bookmaker to the stars at William Hill, is offering the relatively ungenerous odds of 2-1 that Gordon will be confirmed as a daddy within the year. This rumour could be fuelled by the fact that the Budget contained generous tax provisions for couples with children. Having just turned 50, perhaps Gordon feels his biological clock is ticking away? Several factors suggest caution. First, the lack of any substance (Gordon's special adviser, Ian Austin, was not returning calls). Second, the last Diary I worked on carried a story predicting the imminent end of the relationship only for the couple to announce their engagement two weeks later.

 There is another reason why it's an unlikely tale. When Gordon was asked what he was doing to mark his 50th birthday evening, he replied: "Watching Manchester United against Valencia." Romantic dog.

 Meanwhile, real news. Prudential unveiled its £18bn buyout of American General insurance company. The Pru has its US headquarters at Lansing, Michigan (why?), while AG has its HQ at Houston, Texas. So the new mega-corp head office is going to be in New York. But why uproot both companies? "I'm a New Yorker," mused Bob Devlin, American General's chief executive. No wonder shareholders went cold.

 Speaking of the Pru, I was intending to start a new feature called "Dog of the Day", featuring the worst bit of City advice from the previous day. The inaugural Dog was to be analyst Robin Savage at WestLB Panmure for his Friday research note uprating Prudential's stock to a "buy". After the buyout announcement, the Pru's share price sank like a stone. Talking to Robin, he seemed like a nice guy so I haven't got the heart to do it. And he's sticking to his "buy" recommendation, despite yesterday's 14% tumble. Good for you, Robin.

 As a result, the very first Dog of the Day award goes to Paul Sharma and Joel Ripley, part of the European telecoms equity research team at JP Morgan. Yesterday morning they put out a note upgrading Energis to "buy". The share price promptly fell more than 2%. Woof!

 The winter issue of the London Business School's journal, Business Strategy Review, pops up and includes a fascinating article about web portal Yahoo!. "The consolidation that is under way separates the strong from the weak," it says, "and ultimately rewards companies like Yahoo! that have a strong leadership position, financial strength, good management, a solid business model, and the resolve to take market share." The author, Tim Koogle, was chief executive of Yahoo! until last week, when it emerged that the finances were not strong, the business model was not solid, and the management felt it could do without Tim Koogle.

richard.adams @theguardian.com

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: on banning pictures of naked children

fields.headline: The voyeurs have won
fields.standfirst:
Banning pictures of naked children lets the warped view of the paedophile set the standard for what is normal

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Banning pictures of naked children lets the warped view of the paedophile set the standard for what is normal.
fields.body:
Pity the poor censor, forever destined to be sniggered at by history. Always and invariably wrong in the long run, he is the obedient but necessary slave to transient panics and passions in all societies. Was there ever a land without censorship, all unfettered licence? The causes of moral outrage may change, (ankles, popery, table legs, communism) but the tone of outrage remains universal and timeless.

"Upper-crust 'art lovers' are paying £5 a head to ogle degrading snaps of naked children plastered across the walls of one of Britain's most exclusive galleries," read the opening lines of the News of the World story. It was probably they who grassed up the gallery. Eight long weeks after the photographic show opened to no great razzmatazz or scandal, the vice squad screeched up to the Saatchi gallery demanding three photographs be taken down and a £50 art book be thrown into the fires of righteousness. When the gallery opens again next Thursday the offending items must be gone - or else. (Yesterday the "else" suddenly receded after Chris Smith's condemnation of this silliness.)

Prosecution remains in the balance in another of those wearying set-piece confrontations between the plod and the arts, philistines v aesthetes, moral degenerates v moralisers. In the bad old days there was bite to this ritual. Prison, penury, shame and ruination awaited brave transgressors. Oscar Wilde was only one of those broken on its wheel. Artists who tore down taboos took deadly risks. But now shock is de rigueur, the attribute most rewarded in money, fame and Turner prizes. Shocking is boring. How Tracy Emin and the others might have relished their debuts raided by the fuzz. How lucky for semi-professional Tierney Gearon to be shot to stardom thus.

Especially as her amateur snaps are nothing special. They are not shocking, if a bit odd. In one her naked son and daughter stand on a bright beach wearing identical blonde bimbo masks. In another her son pees in the snow. "Interesting and occasionally mildly disturbing," said one critic, politely. Critics were surprised this unknown well-heeled Atlanta ex-fashion model suddenly had a few family snaps blown up vast and given pride of place in the main room of the gallery, beside some of the most distinguished photographers.

Are they art was the implied question? But the art thing is a dangerous question critics tend to skitter past hurriedly: art is anything hung in a gallery and that's that. One or two critics hinted anyone might dig out family albums and make big blow-ups, given the gallery space. Gearon's only interview back when the innocuous show opened was with the Times women's page, wearing clothes that say "this look doesn't come cheap" and telling her interviewer, "all I ever wanted to do was be a ballerina and have loads of kids". She is such a terrible cook her friends tend to eat before coming to dinner parties in her Notting Hill studio. No word about nudity or porn - it simply was not an issue. Enfants terribles don't do dinner parties. A naif, some critics suggested because she was unknown, but that didn't quite fit her sophisticated persona either.

Now the old freedom fighters take up their rusty cudgels - the art world v the rest. The News of the World digs out a former head of the obscene publications squad to lick his old wounds: "The chattering classes believe they have an absolute right to peer at nude youngsters' genitals in the comfortable surroundings of St John's Wood." The "ultra-liberal Guardian" gets a ritual kicking for "dismissing the national outrage". But all this lacks conviction on both sides. Censorship is yesterday's cold mashed potato, a truly dead horse. Child pornography is disgusting: I saw plenty of it sitting on a Home Office committee on censorship years ago. Maybe the next Emins will win prizes tilting at this last taboo, but Gearon is not it - not porn, not much art either.

The News of the World cropped the photos to make them look worse. The only question they raise is whether any portrayal of a naked child is now officially indecent, or breaching infant privacy. If so, take down the many National Gallery paintings where the Christ child stands proud to be nude on his mother's lap, naked penis prominently verifying his humanity. Bronzino's nude cupid sucks Venus's nipple - yes, women can be paedophiles too. Cupids and putti with rippling, ripe, naked bottoms cavort shamelessly across the walls.

The 1978 Protection of Children Act, passed as all such legislation is, in a fit of private members panic after a particular case, drew assurances from ministers that it did not mean all pictures of naked children were banned. But since the fuss over Julia Somerville sending bath-time photos of her child to the chemist, that is effectively the law. This is the legacy of paedophile hysteria. Children do take their clothes off, do run about gardens and beaches and are photographed by parents to capture just such never-again innocence. But the current obsession with child sex forces everyone to view the world through paedophile eyes. The abhorrent aberrant has won, making us all dirty voyeurs by proxy.

Hypocrisy is far too weak a word for the News of the World. It is their world that has ensured "innocent" children are surrounded by sexual imagery, pert page three nipples, saucy sexy questionnaires, bonking on every page, a universe grotesquely distorted. Nine-year-olds deep into soap plots on Aids and incest are sold glittery boob tubes for pre-boob girls and bump and grind to rap artists slapping their bitches up. But wait! Here is the News of the World, defender of the innocents, riding out to protect them from the awful danger of a handful of snaps of a mother's naked children.

Andreas Whittam Smith, president of the British Board of Film Censors, is one of the few non-hypocrites to argue the case for banning these photographs (unfortunately choosing the highly hypocritical Daily Mail in which to do so). He says that although such pictures were not taken or exhibited with pornographic intent, their possible use by paedophiles is sufficient reason to ban them. Paedophiles might show such pictures to children to "groom" them, ready to take off their clothes.

But that lets paedophiles set the standard for what is normal. Their warped vision of immature genitals now has to be imposed upon us all. Nude and rude adults can be thrust obscenely everywhere, but children's bodies must be shrouded as if they were indeed sexual. This is the world upside down - the paedophile's view, not ours. It has the same perversely sexualising effect as the chador which suggests one strand of female hair would ignite sexual mayhem, encouraging lewd speculation about what lies hidden under skirts. So a ban on all child nudity powerfully suggests the very vileness it seeks to prevent.

webTitle: Matthew Engel: US drugs war is just like Vietnam

fields.headline: This drugs war is just like Vietnam
fields.standfirst:
The United States is bogged down in an unwinnable contest

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The United States is staging a new offensive in the drugs war, most forcefully on the public relations front. In Bolivia, we are assured, the production of coca - the plant which is the basis of cocaine - has almost been eradicated after a three-year US-backed campaign.
fields.body:
The United States is staging a new offensive in the drugs war, most forcefully on the public relations front. In Bolivia, we are assured, the production of coca - the plant which is the basis of cocaine - has almost been eradicated after a three-year US-backed campaign.

In Colombia, an aerial spraying campaign in the coca-growing heartland of western Putamayo has reportedly destroyed thousands of acres of crops. Colombian officials are describing the operation as "a resounding success". Two senators have just returned, praising the Colombian military's financial probity and commitment to human rights - a combination of remarks that just happens to send my personal Geiger counter, which records bullshit quotient in news reports, completely off the clock.

The word "Vietnam" still haunts policy-making in Washington, and President Bush has refused to sink further manpower into Colombia. But if you take the drugs war as a whole, the similarities are overwhelming. With the very best of intentions, Washington has committed vast quantities of resources to an unwinnable contest against a far more committed, hydra-headed enemy. And as in Vietnam, many of those resources seem devoted to kidding themselves, visiting senators and the public about operational successes.

A lot of the participants were stoned out of their brains in Vietnam too. But that war got stopped because the sons of America's suburbs started being killed and wounded in large numbers. In this war, those suffering most directly are the disempowered and voiceless: South American peasants; low-grade suppliers who get caught and jailed; addicts who end up being driven further into dependency.

It is a low-level conflict that suits pretty well everyone else: politicians who like to pretend they are taking action; recipients of their largesse who make fat livings out of the funding; the titans of the recreational drug industry who make vast and almost risk-free profits; and most of their customers, who have enjoyed a plentiful supply for decades.

Almost every action in this war has the reverse effect to what was intended. Donnie Marshall, of the US drug enforcement administration, admitted to Congress last week that the strikes against coca meant that Colombia has suspended attacks on poppy plantations, so its heroin exports have increased. Cocaine use has been dropping in the US, as the nasty effects of crack have become better known; heroin increase, however, has doubled in five years.

The Guardian reported last month that the planes were indeed successfully spraying coca crops; they were also spraying fruit trees, maize plants and schoolchildren, who were suffering from rashes, headaches and vomiting. The promised aid to the peasants had of course not arrived. A Washington Post reporter noted a week ago that on almost every farm hit by the herbicide, young coca plants were now in evidence. In Bolivia, where victory is being proclaimed, less than half the families (a UN estimate) have received assistance in planting alternative crops and most of these crops are failing. It makes British farm policy looks sensible.

There are tiny scraps of evidence that the US is starting to wake up to its folly. In its Hollywoodish kind of way, the successful film Traffic has at least made the subject topical. A new administration, in which an urge to cut costs is vying with a dictatorial nature, is showing the odd smidgin of interest.

The New York-based Drug Policy Foundation says that 500,000 Americans are now behind bars on drugs charges, compared with 50,000 in 1980. (Of course, most are black so what the heck?) The drugs war cost the US more than $40bn last year, according to the foundation: "Yet illegal drugs are cheaper, purer and more readily available than ever before." Footling with the supply chain of this brilliantly successful free market, with occasional prissy lectures to children, has solved absolutely nothing.

In Britain, the debate is still bogged down on the minor question of legalising cannabis. We desperately need someone to understand the bigger picture: that legalising, controlling, restricting, taxing and de-glamourising recreational drugs offers massive prizes by breaking the power of the cartels and gangs, emptying the jails and - if handled properly - cutting usage as well.

The crimes of about 70% of Britain's prisoners are in some way related to drugs. There's no chance of sense from the present government, petrified of both the White House and the Daily Mail. There's even less hope from Hague and Widdecombe (the Smith Square cartel). Miss Widdecombe is even now probably working on plans to outlaw sex and rock 'n' roll as well. But is it remotely possible that a chastened post-election Conservative party, searching for a big idea, might actually hit upon a good one?

fields.bodyText: The United States is staging a new offensive in the drugs war, most forcefully on the public relations front. In Bolivia, we are assured, the production of coca - the plant which is the basis of cocaine - has almost been eradicated after a three-year US-backed campaign. In Colombia, an aerial spraying campaign in the coca-growing heartland of western Putamayo has reportedly destroyed thousands of acres of crops. Colombian officials are describing the operation as "a resounding success". Two senators have just returned, praising the Colombian military's financial probity and commitment to human rights - a combination of remarks that just happens to send my personal Geiger counter, which records bullshit quotient in news reports, completely off the clock. The word "Vietnam" still haunts policy-making in Washington, and President Bush has refused to sink further manpower into Colombia. But if you take the drugs war as a whole, the similarities are overwhelming. With the very best of intentions, Washington has committed vast quantities of resources to an unwinnable contest against a far more committed, hydra-headed enemy. And as in Vietnam, many of those resources seem devoted to kidding themselves, visiting senators and the public about operational successes. A lot of the participants were stoned out of their brains in Vietnam too. But that war got stopped because the sons of America's suburbs started being killed and wounded in large numbers. In this war, those suffering most directly are the disempowered and voiceless: South American peasants; low-grade suppliers who get caught and jailed; addicts who end up being driven further into dependency. It is a low-level conflict that suits pretty well everyone else: politicians who like to pretend they are taking action; recipients of their largesse who make fat livings out of the funding; the titans of the recreational drug industry who make vast and almost risk-free profits; and most of their customers, who have enjoyed a plentiful supply for decades. fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Flight paths
fields.trailText: Flight paths
fields.body:
Cheshire

All the farmland and footpaths in the countryside around the village, including the valley itself, have been closed to public access now for almost a fortnight as I write. So far there have been no reports of any local cases of the foot and mouth epidemic but, with confirmed outbreaks to the north in Lancashire, all our farmers have been keeping a constant watch on their livestock. Through the winter months much of the grazing land around the valley is used by sheep flocks, many down from the hills of north Wales, but these have now disappeared and what little livestock there is to be seen is mainly around the local horse stables and riding schools. So, with the countryside and woodland strictly out of bounds, I have found the time to catch up on some more research into the family history, with long overdue visits to local reference libraries and churchyards, and then, with the arrival of the Cheshire and Wirral Bird Report for 1999, to enjoy a trip down memory lane.

The report is produced with co-operation from three continents, and summarises the contributor's records of the 250 species seen in the county during 1999. It has been well worth the wait, especially for the nine colour plates, which include stunning photos of dotterel, broadbilled sandpiper, and grey phalarope. Heading the list of highlights was the discovery in late April of a terek sandpiper amongst a large flock of dunlin - a first for Cheshire. Elsewhere attention is drawn to a little understood phenomenon - the presence in late summer of up to 15,000 moulting shelduck on the Mersey estuary, having forsaken their long-established exodus to Heligoland.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A column on page 9, Sport, March 10, took issue with a borough council's threat to close parts of Manchester United's Old Trafford stands unless fans stopped doing a dangerous thing: standing.
fields.body:
A column on page 9, Sport, March 10, took issue with a borough council's threat to close parts of Manchester United's Old Trafford stands unless fans stopped doing a dangerous thing: standing.

The body in question is Trafford borough council, not Stretford as written.

An item on page 4 of the Editor magazine, March 9, said that the recent bomb outside BBC-TV Centre in west London was on the 20th anniversary of the death of the Irish hunger striker Bobby Sands. The incident related to the start of his fast, March 1 1981.

A Natural History Museum fossil pictured on page 3, Science, March 8, was captioned as a dinosaur when instead it belonged to a separate type of extinct reptiles, the plesiosaurs.

A front-page trailer on March 10 incorrectly named a net work of powerful people investigated in Weekend magazine as the Bilderburg group. Weekend correctly said Bilderberg.

Writer Philip Kerr was taken aback to see himself reported on page 3, Media Guardian, yesterday as expressing a sentiment he does not share - that the Groucho Club is a ghost of its former self. The error arose when material from two reporters was merged into one story. The person quoted should have been writer and journalist Jane Thynne, whose husband is Philip Kerr.

A cartoon on page 16, March 10, shows a sheep jumping in fear when a fox snarls at it the words "Anne Robinson!" after Ms Robinson professed herself less than an admirer of the Welsh, on television.

"Diw bach!" exclaims the terrified sheep, which would have been "God!" or "Almighty!" had it been spelled "Duw bach".

Sir Anthony Acland, listed in Birthdays yesterday as turning 71, is no longer provost of Eton, having retired at 70 as the system requires.

Spelling software evidently found intolerable a reference to cornpone - a cornbread, or colloquially, something folksy in the US South - in a column about US political life on page 20 yesterday. It substituted "cornpole".

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Book now for the 3G Expo ("the event for present and future mobile telecommunications") on May 1-2. I have the brochure in front of me, and one of the three keynote speakers singled out for front-page pictures is my friend Andrew Neil: he will speak on day two on "how to succeed and prosper in the information age .. Andrew Neil will present a personal view on the opportunities," continues the blurb, "for prosperity on the web .. He is chairman of four new online publishing and e-business ventures: the European.com and Europeanbusiness.com, Scotsman.com and e-Scot." Mm. While Scotsman.com is easy to find, if not worth the journey, the others appear to have vanished from the web entirely. Calls to Neil HQ yield no hints, sparking fears that the sites may have been stolen by Andrew's enemies in the media. So a Diary bounty of £50 has been placed on each of their heads, and e-mercenaries are invited to hunt them down. Remember: they must be brought to us alive.

Calls to Neil HQ yield no hints, sparking fears that the sites may have been stolen by Andrew's enemies in the media. So a Diary bounty of £50 has been placed on each of their heads, and e-mercenaries are invited to hunt them down. Remember: they must be brought to us alive.

 Some may fret over lies to the commons, but we are more concerned about the weird, Neil-esque caramel tan on Robin Cook's face. My colleague Marina Hyde rings the FO to inquire after recent holidays, diplomatic missions or bring-and-buy arms sales to explain it. All the press office offers is a couple of days in Brussels late last month. So can this explain the orange perma-tan noted at Tribune's Michael Foot party last week? "Probably not," admits press chief John Williams, who thinks it unlikely Robin will be troubled on this one. "It was snowing there." Ah well, like Gordon Brown's hair dye (of which more tomorrow), it'll all come out in the wash.

 Following Skippy Hammond's exoneration of Mandy Mandelson, Hola! (Hartlepool One Liberation Army) is in crisis. The main group headed by Field Marshall Robert "Bomber" Harris wants to disband, with all weapons put beyond use. But a renegade group - I think you can guess which side we Diary infantrymen are on - is addicted to the adrenalin and wants to continue for the merriment under the name Real Hola!. This provisional group will, once splintered away, be operating beyond Mandy's control, and undoing all the good of the spectacular rescue mission and causing him untold damage.

 The Mirror scores again with a feature on Coronation Street actress Helen Worth, which is heralded on the front page as a "WORLD EXCLUSIVE". I email Piers Morgan to congratulate him for fending off all those cheque book-waving US papers, not to mention Stern magazine and that late foray from the national news agency of Tonga. "Helen Worth is massive in Prague actually," replies Piers, and although the rest of his response wouldn't evade our lawyers, hats off all the same and keep those world exclusives coming!

 Also in the Mirror is an anti-hack tirade from Tony Parsons, who is particularly incensed by a "hatchet job on my mate Michael Parkinson" by the Times's Caitlin Moran. Worst of all is what ensued when another Parky mate, "a respected journalist on the Daily Telegraph, dashed off a letter to fat Cait calling her 'a silly cow'". Any bells ringing yet? Miss Moran complained to the Telegraph, writes Tony, and the culprit was told off. But who was it? We are trying to contact Michael Henderson in Sri Lanka, where he is covering the cricket, to see if he can give us a steer.

 Meanwhile, Scott from Gay.com is in touch about last week's item on how gay mag Attitude is planning to feature Richard Littlejohn as a pin-up. "We wondered if someone whose capacious arse has been made infamous by the Daily Telegraph," (you will recall Hendo's reference to my bottom), "would be a more likely pin-up. So we're asking our readers." Blimey. Richard is well behind at the moment, apparently, and our loyal army of readers have two days to vote on http://uk.gay.com to ensure his victorious late surge.

fields.headline: A crisis in the country
fields.trailText: The current policy adopted to control the outbreak of foot and mouth (Ministry under fire as disease spreads, March 12) is based on economic and animal welfare arguments, appropriate and relevant in the 1950s and 1960s, but of decreasing relevance today.
fields.body:
The current policy adopted to control the outbreak of foot and mouth (Ministry under fire as disease spreads, March 12) is based on economic and animal welfare arguments, appropriate and relevant in the 1950s and 1960s, but of decreasing relevance today.

The maintenance of the economic value of stock to be exported was essential before BSE; since that time its importance in financial terms to both the agricultural and national economy has declined dramatically. Furthermore, animal welfare issues are able to be addressed by means of more effective vaccination programmes.

The slaughter policy aiming at containment only carried weight when the disease could be confined to particular geographical areas. This outbreak is spread throughout the country, partly as a result of the disastrous decisions which forced the closure of local abattoirs and the resulting extensive transport of stock.

When will the government realise that to continue with the present approach is of far greater detriment economically not only to farmers but to the community as a whole? And, furthermore, that the continued slaughter of our national herd may well wipe out British livestock?

The consequence is the likely increase in the import of meat and meat products from more dubious sources and questionable welfare systems; possibly from where the present crisis originated.
LAC Ashby
Colwall, Worcs

 With the economy having lost an estimated £1bn, surely the debate about how much the farmers will be compensated is misplaced? If foot and mouth bans are in place in order to regain disease free status and so ensure export markets for the most "competitive" farmers, then it seems only fair that the farmers should compensate losses incurred by other rural businesses and countryside users. After all, they will have helped ensure that the status is regained and hence a return to farm profitability.

By the end of the crisis, a conservative estimate of perhaps £5bn can be added to the mounting figure of what is the true cost of food production in the UK (along with BSE, water pollution, decline in farm birdland species, etc). Meanwhile, we can happily eat imported meat, some of which is produced without subsidies, begging the further question of why we are financially supporting the farmers in the first place.
Alexander Kasterine
Wye, Kent
alexander283@yahoo.com

 Foot and mouth disease was detected near Oswestry in October 1967. It was handled in the same way as the current outbreak: slaughter of affected herds, quarantine, disinfectant at farm gates and virtual suspension of social activities. These measures managed to contain the disease, yet it was not until June 1968 that the restrictions were finally lifted. We should not deceive ourselves that it can take anything less than eight months to deal with the disease this time round.
John Polley
Andover, Hants
jbpolley@netcomuk.co.uk

 We run a bed and breakfast business in the Lake District. While I have every sympathy with neighbours waiting anxiously for this horrible disease to hit them, I fail to understand how Maff can dictate to the whole population where they can walk.

All my pre-Easter bookings have cancelled, and Easter looks likely to go the same way. After a poor autumn following the fuel crisis, most of us never built up sufficient reserves to weather a major disaster.
Jane Phillips
Bassenthwaite, Cumbria
jane@parkergate.co.uk

fields.headline: How to help the poorest
fields.trailText: You quite rightly highlight (Leader, March 12) the need for benefits - and I would add, the state pension - to be linked to earnings rather than prices.
fields.body:
You quite rightly highlight (Leader, March 12) the need for benefits - and I would add, the state pension - to be linked to earnings rather than prices.

But the second of your three simple reforms is a little confused. The poorest pensioners are in fact those 500,000 individuals who do not receive the means-tested minimum income guarantee (MIG), despite being entitled to claim.

Furthermore, academics, financial institutions and the pensioners' movement are now united in the charge that means-testing is bureaucratic and costly to administer, demeaning to those who have to jump through hoops to qualify for extra money, ineffective at getting money to those who need it most and a disincentive to saving for retirement.

The answer is not therefore, as you suggest, to increase the MIG, but the basic state pension. If this were set at the new MIG levels of over £90 a week for individuals and £140 for couples, and subsequently linked to average earnings, then we could really start to lessen the plight of the poorest of the poor.
Jack Jones
President, National Pensioners' Convention

 Your strategy to help the poorest of the poor would miss the poorest: those who live on incomes below the income support and minimum income guarantee levels, the largest group of which is pensioners. Any strategy to combat poverty must pass this test.

The answer, of course, is to restore the earnings link for the basic state pension which is still the main source of income for Britain's pensioners.

I suspect that the altruism of Guardian readers would readily embrace this more efficient and more expensive approach to lessening the plight of the poorest.
Prof Alan Walker
University of Sheffield
A.C.Walker@sheffield.ac.uk

fields.trailText:
The News of the World demands the closure of the Saatchi Gallery exhibition because it is "a revolting perversion under the guise of art" (Censorship fear in Saatchi gallery row, March 12). Might I request the closure of the News of the World on the basis that it is a revolting perversion under the guise of journalism?
Vincent Finney
Edinburgh

fields.headline: My brother's murder
fields.trailText: The eight white farmers murdered in Zimbabwe (Priest curses Mugabe at farmer's funeral, March 10) are the tip of the iceberg of anti-white feeling that Zanu-PF is promoting.
fields.body:
The eight white farmers murdered in Zimbabwe (Priest curses Mugabe at farmer's funeral, March 10) are the tip of the iceberg of anti-white feeling that Zanu-PF is promoting.

I returned last week from my brother's funeral in Masvingo, 200 km east of Bulawayo. Peter, a British subject, archdeacon of the Anglican diocese of Lundi, was brutally murdered in his church on February 26. One of his assailants is suspected of having on earlier occasions savagely beaten two elderly white women of his mainly African congregation.

Because these incidents are not overtly political, they do not attract media attention in this country. However, they are political in that they reveal how years of petty official racism have in the past few months given way to a callous indifference to the safety of one part of the community, and to the official condoning of such acts of violence.

At the beginning of last week, the Masvingo police claimed to have "launched a massive manhunt" for his murderer. The truth of their efforts to trace this man was revealed to the editor of the independent Masvingo newspaper, The Mirror, on Wednesday: they had not been able to arrest him "because he was never at home when they called". The one encouraging feature is that the vast majority of African Zimbabweans are as sickened by this situation as are the whites.
Hugh Wagner
Manchester HughLWagner@aol.com

webTitle: A day's work, on trains or in hospitals

fields.headline: A day's work, on trains or in hospitals
fields.trailText: For Railtrack to condone a signaller's working more than 28 consecutive days with "the explicit authority of management" shows a degree of criminal irresponsibility that is hard to believe (Fears over rail safety revealed, March 12).
fields.body:
For Railtrack to condone a signaller's working more than 28 consecutive days with "the explicit authority of management" shows a degree of criminal irresponsibility that is hard to believe (Fears over rail safety revealed, March 12).

To have a weekly printout demonstrating their neglect and to do nothing is scandalous. GNER and Virgin Trains companies should never have allowed drivers to work 12 hour shifts and more than 50 hours in a week; nor should such work patterns be considered in the future as part of a new risk assessment. Fatigue, like drunkenness, kills.

I trust this arrogant disregard for health and safety legislation will be subject to prosecution.

I hope that it will also provide a basis for punitive damages in any action brought by families who have suffered.

Peter Matthews
Harrogate

peter.matthews@ic24

 I was interested to note that GNER/Virgin train drivers work over 12 hours in a day and sometimes more than 50 hours in a week. I agree this could be dangerous to passenger safety.

The majority of junior doctors are currently working over 70 hours per week - 48 hours at a stretch over a weekend without going off duty is not uncommon (and then doing a full working week after the weekend).

The public should be aware of this, as these doctors are treating their friends and family while in a permanent state of narcolepsy.

There needs to be a concerted effort by the government to ease this situation.

Dr DG Wrigley
Lancaster

fields.trailText: Your report (How Tories' poll plan depends on target seats, March 12) gives more information than anyone could decently need about the workings of Conservative Central Office and its arrangements for the forthcoming election.
fields.body:
Your report (How Tories' poll plan depends on target seats, March 12) gives more information than anyone could decently need about the workings of Conservative Central Office and its arrangements for the forthcoming election.

However, the accompanying "war room seating plan" does raise one interesting question, in that it names 17 men and one woman who will work in the room.

Inspection of the toilet facilities detailed on your plan shows that the men will share three urinal bowls and a wc cubicle, while the woman will have three cubicles to herself. How can anyone justify this grotesquely unfair distribution of resources?
Bob Bird
Great Missenden, Bucks Bobbirdxxx@aol.com

 In his article about the plight of the Conservative leader (Hague poll rating slumps, March 12), Michael White reports Francis Maude's complaints that the government is "casually dismantling so many of the things that make Britain distinctive". Having lived through all of the second half of the 20th century I'm certain that it was a Tory government that was the most successful in destroying much of what made Britain distinctive.

Old-fashioned concepts like tolerance, fair play and respect for others were proudly swept aside by Mrs Thatcher and her sycophantic cabinet. Are the Tories not in danger of calling the kettle black?
Brian Hughes
Cheltenham brian.hughes1@virgin.net

webTitle: Gene therapist raises £37m for new products

fields.headline: Gene therapist raises £37m for new products
fields.trailText: Gene therapy firm Oxford BioMedica has braved choppy waters to tap shareholders for up to £37m, which will fund trials for cancer and Parkinson's treatments and the opening of an offshoot in California.
fields.body:
Gene therapy firm Oxford BioMedica has braved choppy waters to tap shareholders for up to £37m, which will fund trials for cancer and Parkinson's treatments and the opening of an offshoot in California.

Chief executive Alan Kingsman has been on a whirlwind tour of 70 institutions in three weeks to drum up support. Sentiment is poor in the sector, as shown by the failure of a £64m cash call by heart valves specialist Aortech last week.

The money includes £27m which is already in the bag, through a placing of shares underwritten by broker Beeson Gregory and NM Rothschild. The firm hopes to raise £10m through an open offer at 55p a share.

Professor Kingsman said: "We're delighted to have got our money but we've had to see a lot of people to do it."

Some of the money will be used to explore new uses for the company's two lead products - breast cancer drug MetXia and colorectal cancer treatment TroVax. The funds will also pay for clinical trials of a Parkinson's drug, ProSavin.

webTitle: Cynics could put the dent in Prudential

fields.headline: Cynics could put the dent in Prudential
fields.standfirst: Brave move by an insurer scorned
fields.trailText: Out of the blue, the Pru's fresh-faced chief executive, Jonathan Bloomer, has tabled a £30bn-plus merger with its dust-free Texan rival American General, on all-paper terms that give the British company executive control.
fields.body:
On London's Holborn, and so half way between the City and the West End, stands what is commonly known as the Prudential building. This is a serious piece of Gothic renaissance knocked up by Sir Alfred Waterhouse, who had already built Manchester town hall and the Natural History Museum by the time he got round to designing this red brick extravaganza in 1879.

It remains an imposing, listed, piece of the capital's skyline - all magnificent, narrow arches and clean red spires. And it smacks of pomposity, fraudulently promoting a Victorian claim that thrift (in the form of insurance premiums, in this case) was somehow close to Godliness.

The point about mentioning it here, attractive as the building might be, is that it is no longer called the Prudential building. It now goes by the name of Holborn Bars, victim to some or other estate agent's spin and pitched in its refurbished state to attract a hotch-potch of office space renters seemingly ready to pay a premium for the cachet of sitting close by London's legal community. Chancery Lane and Lincoln's Inn are close by.

Two years ago (almost to the day) the Pru, along with its art collection, decamped to an altogether less imposing home off a sidestreet in the heart of the Square Mile. This new building is clean and light, with white walls. It is modern and functional, with an air of efficiency - a suitable sort of place from which to launch the most eye-grabbing overseas takeover attempted by a member of the British financial community.

Out of the blue (there were no leaks or false leads or massages in the Sunday press), the Pru's fresh-faced chief executive, Jonathan Bloomer, has tabled a £30bn-plus merger with its dust-free Texan rival American General, on all-paper terms that give the British company executive control.

In typically British style, this piece of adventure capitalism drew immediate castigation. Attempts by UK banks or insurance companies to move into the American market have invariably ended in tears, it was stated. And if Mr Bloomer has managed to pull off a deal recommended by the go-go Texans, then he must have paid too much, chimed the sceptics. Yesterday morning, as proof, everyone was pointing to the Pru's share price, down an uncomfortable 14% in London.

There are, of course, reasons to be sceptical (as opposed to cynical). The Americans do not have a history of being trounced in the provision of financial services by Europeans (although yesterday few commentators seemed to be able to strike out beyond the example of Midland Bank's ill-fated takeover of California's Crocker, which happened as recently as 1987).

Similarly, the Pru is proposing a make-or-break deal in a climate of absolute uncertainty in the world's biggest economy - at the apparent end of a record-setting bull run where no one can now predict the severity or speed of the downturn.

What is more, there were one or two presentation hiccups yesterday. Issuing £18bn of new equity and tying up top-line management time for two or three years in order to achieve £85m of an nual cost savings was never going to get the City's juices going. (Watch out for the Bloomer's bloomer headlines this morning.)

But sceptics and cynics alike should understand why the Pru's share price took an immediate bath yesterday. Corporate America is an inward looking place, where pension funds and other big institutional investors rarely wager more than, say, 5% of assets outside their economic backyards.

Foist £18bn of British Pru paper on them (a confusing concept when they all thought Prudential was an American corporation) and £17bn is bound to come bouncing back across the Atlantic. Throw in the bid arbitrageurs (shorting the UK's Pru, buying American General and retiring to lunch for nine months) and the selling pressure is wholly predictable - especially when AG's share price has all but doubled in the space of a year.

Such market pressures might yet soil Mr Bloomer's finest hour. But his balls-iness in taking the Pru from no 26 in the world to no 6 should not be scoffed at. Crucially, he is propelling the Pru's growth by expanding into a fragmented market where a quarter of the population are aged between 45 and 65 and ripe for a bit of financial planning.

This is not about rankling the competition authorities in the UK (as demonstrated by Lloyds TSB) or buying a parcel of suspect motor polices in Italy (as pursued by the old Commercial Union). It is not about building an imposing corporate edifice simply to amaze passers-by - as in the old Pru building on Holborn.

It is about an efficiently run British insurance company, faced with intense competition at home, taking a bold international leap. As they take to the road to sell this deal, Mr Bloomer and his team deserve to be listened to.

webTitle: DNA test allows M&S to trace bad produce

fields.headline: DNA test allows M&S to trace bad produce
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer will be able to trace the individual animal responsible for each piece of meat on its supermarket shelves under a partnership deal with a hi-tech offshoot of Kent-based engineering firm Whatman.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer will be able to trace the individual animal responsible for each piece of meat on its supermarket shelves under a partnership deal with a hi-tech offshoot of Kent-based engineering firm Whatman.

Whatman has developed a method of storing the DNA from an animal or plant simply through a swab test with a piece of paper. M&S will be able to keep a library of DNA from all its suppliers' carcasses - or of the plants on which fruit and vegetables are grown.

By taking a second swab from any suspicious cut of meat, the retailer will be able to identify the source, check farm conditions and establish whether other products from the same supplier are affected.

Whatman's chief executive, David Smith, said: "We can check whether a piece of steak really is Aberdeen Angus, or whether it's from some old French cow."

M&S is responding to a series of food scares - ranging from mad cow disease to salmonella and foot-and-mouth disease. A spokeswoman said: "Consumers are becoming far more conscious about where their food comes from. If there is any reason to trace back supplies, this will help us."

The retail chain has not yet decided how widely to use the system. It will pay Whatman a small amount for each DNA test carried out.

Dr Smith said: "We'll do all the analysis for them, in return for a fee. M&S don't have many biochemists working for them in-house."

In addition to tracking unsatisfactory products, M&S may also use the technique for pinpointing suppliers of particularly good meat and vegetables, following positive feedback from customers. M&S's spokeswoman said: "If we know something's good, we can order more from the same supplier."

Whatman's method of storing DNA on paper means samples do not have to be refrigerated. It is more advanced than most tracking methods, which involve attaching barcodes to carcasses.

The firm's technology is used by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to track suspects through blood or saliva samples.

Whatman said there was "strong demand" for DNA techniques in the human identity market, with other law enforcement organisations similarly interested.

The company originally manufactured paper, but has diversified into hi-tech filtration technologies.

Whatman's shares rose 2.5p to 212.5p. The company announced annual pre-tax profits of £33.9m, against £10.2m last year, helped by a gain of £22m on the sale of its industrial filtration and gas generation operations.

Underlying profits, from established businesses, were up 28%, with sales in Whatman's biosciences business rising 81% to £3.3m.

fields.headline: Mannesmann takeover investigated
fields.trailText: German prosecutors said yesterday they would investigate Klaus Esser, former chief executive of the mobile telecoms firm Mannesmann, on suspicion he took financial favours to push through the buyout of his company.
fields.body:
German prosecutors said yesterday they would investigate Klaus Esser, former chief executive of the mobile telecoms firm Mannesmann, on suspicion he took financial favours to push through the buyout of his company.

Mr Esser, who for months opposed takeover efforts by Vodafone AirTouch, backed down in February last year to sign a stock-swap deal valued then at £123bn, the largest corporate merger agreed up to that time.

Prosecutors in Düsseldorf are now investigating whether DM100m (£34m) in compensation given by Vodafone to Mr Esser and other top Mannesmann officials influenced their selling out to the British rival. Mr Esser stepped down in June.

Lawyers in Stuttgart requested last March that prosecutors investigate Mr Esser but the motion was thrown out. The investigation was rekindled by regional prosecutors in Düsseldorf.

"Since then information has become available that justifies an initial suspicion that financial promises to members of the leading team at Mannesmann may have led them to abandon resistance to a takeover by Vodafone," said Düsseldorf prosecutor Thomas Harden.

Mr Esser has steadfastly denied any wrongdoing and his lawyer yesterday rejected the allegations.

"The suggestion that Vodafone chief Chris Gent may have moved Esser to do something by paying money is absurd," Sven Thomas, the lawyer, said. He was confident the investigation would soon be closed.

Mr Thomas said Mr Esser had abandoned his opposition to the buyout only because his hopes of setting up a deal with the French conglomerate Vivendi had fallen through and Mannesmann's major shareholders voted to accept Vodafone's offer.
Associated Press

fields.headline: Swiss airline hits heavy weather
fields.trailText: SAirGroup, owner of Swissair, flew into heavy turbulence yesterday after reports that it is about to unveil heavy losses.
fields.body:
SAirGroup, owner of Swissair, flew into heavy turbulence yesterday after reports that it is about to unveil heavy losses.

The group, which announced at the end of last week that almost all its supervisory board members were to quit, saw its shares fall to their lowest level for five years.

The chairman, Eric Honneger, sought to reassure the group's 68,500 staff saying the airline was not "disorientated". He will be hoping to provide further reassurance later this week by announcing a top flight replacement for Moritz Suter as head of the group's SAirLines division. Mr Suter resigned last week.

SAirGroup's problems stem from an ambitious strategy of building up stakes in other airlines. These include 49.5% of Belgium's Sabena, and holdings in Air Littoral and Air Liberty in France. The strategy was ended this year, and the group is considering what to do with the stakes in the French and Belgium airlines

An SAirGroup spokesman acknowledged last night that the group would be reporting a loss when it unveils its figures at the beginning of next month but he declined to be drawn on the extent of the decline. One report at the weekend suggested that the losses could be as high as 2.5bn Swiss francs (£1.3bn), sending the shares into a tail spin.

They fell almost 14% yesterday to Sfr174, little more than a third of their all-time high, recorded in 1998.

There is increasing speculation that the group may consider a capital increase later this year, opening the way for a strategic partner, possibly British Airways, to take a stake.

fields.headline: Wonderful, foolish dome
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Since the dome's closure, pundits and politicians have been lecturing us sternly. "This fiasco must end soon." Their solutions vary: it should be demolished; it should be integrated into worthy urban regeneration; it should have "meaningful" exhibitions. But all agree on one point. The dome was a disaster because it had no brand.
fields.body:
Since the dome's closure, pundits and politicians have been lecturing us sternly. "This fiasco must end soon." Their solutions vary: it should be demolished; it should be integrated into worthy urban regeneration; it should have "meaningful" exhibitions. But all agree on one point. The dome was a disaster because it had no brand.

That's where they are wrong. The dome has a clear brand and that brand is Disaster. It cries out to be exploited as a grand folly, an emblem of muddle, hype and plain foolishness with enormous entertainment potential.

Only one person is in a position to build this dome brand. P-Y Gerbeau has a natural claim to running it on the simple grounds that he is already a recognisable national figure of fun, automatically linked in people's minds with the place. How many people would recognise Lord Falconer in the street? Or would want to? P-Y, though, with his mad haircut and manic enthusiasm is a public figure. There's no need for Mickey Mouse in the dome when there's a Mickey Mouse Frenchman to run it. Who cares if he was the car park supremo at Euro Disney? He obviously learnt a lot about entertaining the customers.

The main positive aspect of P-Y's project for the dome is to keep its fundamental structure in tact. He likes it. And so, it turns out, do we, now that we might lose it. We've become fond of the building we love to hate, the great folly, with all the entertainment it has provided stumbling from crisis to disaster. People who opposed it for environmental damage and shameful waste now realise demolition would be worse, creating just another naff business park, wasting some of the more decent infrastructure that rundown London has to offer.

The dome is a folly. That's why we've come to like it, and that's how it should be used. The only thing wrong with P-Y's current plans is that he's struggling with half-baked ideas for content, like Ministry of Sound events. At least he hasn't fallen into the trap of trying to ascribe to it some portentous meaning but he should listen to public feelings about the place.

We like its meaninglessness and its stupidity. It's a monument to political hubris - a building whose fundamental pointlessness has baffled and brought down many a proud person. Something about it chimes with the British character. We're good at disasters, at not taking ourselves seriously and delighting when things go magnificently and foolishly wrong.

The most enjoyable aspect of London's millennium celebrations was the hubris that lurked at every turn. The millennium wheel falling into the Thames on the first lifting attempt was a fine beginning, its failure to start with a laser an additional bonus. We liked the "did you actually see it?" wall of fire, and the celebrities and politicians stranded at a tube station on millennium eve. Best of all was the wobbly bridge. Most Londoners resent attempts to repair it and support the idea of reopening it. Numbers could be restricted by charging for crossings and giving warnings that people bounce across at their own peril. Not very New Labour, though.

You only have to take one of those boat trips down the Thames to know that as a nation, we revel in heroic failures. A voice straight out of Albert Square explains, "Here's the millennium wheel which wouldn't start. Here's Blackfriars station: they took away the glass roof in the war and it got bombed in storage. Here's the wobbly bridge." The culmination of this river trip is the dome: a white elephant, a national laughing stock.

This is the key to its future. We associate it with failure, pointlessness, deflated national pride, and simple foolishness, so that's what it should be devoted to. It should become a museum of disasters and follies, a history of doomed projects or unfortunate accidents. Like the unexpectedly successful Book of Heroic Disasters this is the dome's true destiny.

Some of its exhibits could be drawn from its own history. There could be daily re-enactments of the failed diamond robbery, repeats of the millennium eve fiasco - "the world's worst millennium eve celebrations". There could be a Mandelson zone devoted to the fated "dome secretary", a political laughing stock prancing around in his hard hat and staking his reputation on the fate of the structure. The faith zone could be left intact - "most doomed sponsorship deal".

P-Y's fertile mind would surely be able to develop this theme. He's got the right attitude. In spite of being French, he has all qualities of English eccentricity along the lines of Patrick Moore or John McCririck, together with a manic belief in the product. We owe it to ourselves to let him have a go.

fields.headline: Michael Elkins
fields.standfirst: BBC correspondent renowned for the integrity of his reporting from Israel
fields.trailText: To a whole, earlier generation of BBC listeners, the journalist and broadcaster Michael Elkins, who has died aged 84, was the voice from Jerusalem. And what a voice.
fields.body:
To a whole, earlier generation of BBC listeners, the journalist and broadcaster Michael Elkins, who has died aged 84, was the voice from Jerusalem. And what a voice. The timbre was gravelly, the accent one-hundred-percent American. More un-BBC you could not be. He was known worldwide. Arabists loathed him, less for the way he reported events than for the bad news - as they saw it - that he was always bringing. Yet this Zionist American Jew was always his own man. He stayed eternally independent. He had a powerful sense of justice.

Elkins scooped the world in the six-day war of June 1967. In those days, he was a stringer for the BBC, for the CBS radio network and for the magazine Newsweek. It was the third Arab-Israeli war. President Nasser of Egypt, along with the Syrians and Jordanians, had grievously miscalculated. Elkins, on day one, reported an Israeli victory. He had bumped into a politician he knew, who directed him post-haste to the war-room. The Arab air forces had been destroyed on the ground.

Israel's military censors held up his copy. Elkins proposed a deal. When you release the story, he told them, give me priority. They played ball. Our correspondent put the electrifying news out to the BBC and CBS. The BBC aired his report, though nervously because he was on his own. CBS watched the wires, waiting for confirmation of the Elkins dispatch. None came. They panicked, and sent him a terse one-liner - "You alone with Israeli victory. You'd better be right." He was, but he did not forgive CBS for doubting him.

That autumn, he visited New York and called on CBS. He was garlanded for his scoop, hailed for his journalism. "Get lost," he snarled, unforgiving, "I resign."

He told me once that CBS had then "offered him the earth" to stay as their correspondent, but he had refused. "Well done," I enthused, praising his probity. Elkins looked at me. "I have to tell you something, David," he said. "If Newsweek had not already given me the earth, I would have been sorely tempted." That was Elkins - tough-minded, but never stupid.

There was another famous BBC occasion in 1982. This time Elkins, for once, got the story wrong. The Israeli army had invaded Lebanon and surrounded Beirut. When the Phalangist militia belonging to their Lebanese allies, the Maronite Christians, began a brutal massacre of Palestinians and other Muslims in the Sabra and Shatilla refugee camps, Israeli troops simply looked the other way.

Back in Jerusalem, Elkins was, at first, misled by Israeli sources. His BBC report was inaccurate. I was in Beirut at that time. I heard the comments of French correspondents in my hotel. "Did you hear Elkins this evening? Dégotant. Disgusting."

The next morning, Elkins was on the World Service again. He had been duped, his voice was bristling with anger, his underlining of Israeli complicity now trenchant. By chance, I overheard the same French group again, this time at the breakfast table. "Did you hear Elkins this morning? Mon Dieu. Epatant," they cried. "Fantastic."

He was indeed a phenomenon, a man of parts. Born to European immigrants to the United States, he grew up in New York, and was top of the class in almost everything at school, especially English - he had an inspiring teacher. Then, as a youngster, he fell in with hoodlums, but later went west to join his elder brother, Saul, a Hollywood producer.

There, Elkins the film script-writer and trade-union organiser was born. Over the years, he scripted more than 30 Hollywood B-movies. His work as a union representative got him blacklisted by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, who accused him (falsely) of being a communist. He was no communist, but was certainly an active anti-fascist before the second world war, a supporter of the International Brigades in republican Spain.

With the war, Elkins was recruited into a shadowy, clandestine world. He joined the OSS, America's Office of Strategic Services, the precursor to the CIA, led by General "Wild Bill" Donovan. He was dispatched on murky missions behind enemy lines in Europe. Heaven knows what these involved. Certainly, he was with US troops when the Dachau death camp was liberated. And it was with this experience, encountering skeletal Holocaust survivors, that Elkins rediscovered his own Jewish roots.

In his book, Forged In Fury, published in 1971, Elkins wrote of a secret Jewish organisation, some 50-strong, called DIN, formed in Europe in 1945 to assassinate "the killers of Jews" - former Nazis, SS men, camp staff and others who had slipped away unpunished into civilian life. DIN was shortlived but deadly. Elkins changed names, places and dates to protect those of whom he wrote. One DIN member he describes, Arnie Berg, an American, bears a remarkable resemblance to the author himself.

A couple of years after the war, Elkins was introduced in New York to Teddy Kollek, later to be mayor of Jerusalem. Kollek was masterminding illegal shipments of arms to the Jewish Haganah in Palestine. With his OSS experience, Elkins was soon on board. When he found the FBI on his tail, he and his wife, Martha, decamped in a hurry to the new-born state of Israel. It was 1948.

After living for a year on a kibbutz, he took up documentary film-making, before getting into journalism, first with CBS and Newsweek, then, in 1965, with the BBC. In 1982, aged 65, his BBC days were over. He never regretted them.

Eight years later, he joined the Jerusalem Report, a new English-language magazine, as ombudsman and editor of its letters pages. As they themselves would tell you, he was "a walking history of modern Israel . . . our moral conscience and moral compass . . . a man who embodied the courtesy and integrity of a bygone age, and thereby challenged us to strive for those values". Michael Elkins was working with them full-time until his death.

He is survived by his son Jonathan, and his longtime companion Ruth Tzur.

Michael Elkins, journalist, born January 22 1917; died March 10 2001
