fields.headline: Appreciation: Sir Richard Foster
fields.trailText: In the modern world, museum directors are often characterised as being either barn-storming showmen or ivory tower scholars. Sir Richard Foster was neither.
fields.body:
In the modern world, museum directors are often characterised as being either barn-storming showmen or ivory tower scholars. Sir Richard Foster was neither.

He steered an independent course, combining a long-standing commitment to the traditional museum skills of caring for, researching and displaying collections for the benefit of the public with a belief that museums have to be effectively managed and responsible to their local communities. His courageous leadership of the fledgling National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside brought excellence, innovation and renewal to the city, and his wisdom and experience made him a person whose advice was sought by colleagues across the country and ministers in government.

Having moved to Merseyside as director of museums in 1978, the early 80s were, to say the least, a difficult period for a public servant in the middle of bitterly contested political battles within the Merseyside and Liverpool city councils. Foster displayed courage in defending the museum service, and maintained good relations with all parties.

When, in 1986, the first national museum with trustee status outside London, the National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside, was created, he was the natural choice as first director, but he took on an enormous challenge in drawing together a range of disparate museums, containing great collections but starved of funds - and with declining morale and audiences.

During the 80s, Foster had been a vigorous supporter of the plan to renovate Jesse Hartley's magnificent Albert Dock, which had remained derelict for decades. The success of that project, with the new Maritime Museum - as well as Tate Liverpool - at its heart, owed much to his determination and advocacy. At the Maritime Museum, the independence of his thinking was especially revealed by the controversial inclusion of a gallery devoted to the transatlantic slave trade.

He was later appointed a member of Unesco's scientific committee on slavery, and was one of the national museum directors who took special interest in the difficult issue of the return of human remains from British collections to their country of origin.

In the early 90s, Foster's vision determined the shape of the pioneering Conservation Centre, converting the former Midland goods depot, a magnificent warehouse, into a centre for the care of paintings and objects. He conceived the centre as not only a place where objects were conserved, but also where the public could watch the processes of care in open studios.

Not surprisingly, it won praise from every section of the professional and local community, but its genesis lay in Foster's firm belief that the mystique of museums should be swept away, and any isolation from their communities ended.

Later this year, in the brilliant climax of a series of developments, Foster would have completed the wholesale renovation of the Liverpool Museum and the Walker Art Gallery, in a £34m scheme which is one of the largest lottery-funded projects outside London. The number and scale of these projects during the last 10 years was astonishing.

At the time of his death, he was heavily involved both in the "Liverpool Vision" scheme for the renovation of the city centre and in the national bid for Liverpool to become the City of Culture in 2008. However, his experience was increasingly sought at national level. In 1993, he was appointed to the Museums and Galleries Commission, where he quickly became an authoritative influence, encouraging the creation of the scheme for designating regional collections of national importance.

In all his activities, Foster displayed the qualities and strengths that made him such an effective force in the museum world over more than 30 years. At meetings, he would take meticulous notes, deliberate and then sum up, taking the argument forward to a positive conclusion.

For Foster, the planning of a new building, the solution of an intractable problem, or having to deal with an awkward moral issue would serve as a challenge. He would tease out a solution, insisting on contributions from all as a way of engaging opposition - and, more often than not, leave people with a feeling that they had all contributed to a result built on the best of each individual idea.

His total lack of ego, generosity, gentle sense of humour, willingness to listen, and determination to find solutions made him an engaging colleague and an inspiring example for younger people. He carried his immense responsibilities lightly, but often found himself acting as the rock on which others would depend for solutions, advice or inspiration. It was a demanding life, and he was demanding on himself.

He will be missed in museums, and in the great city of Liverpool, which he served so well.

fields.headline: Ilse Singer
fields.trailText: Ilse Singer, who has died aged 89, was a committed activist for more than 60 years on behalf of the world's refugees
fields.body:
Ilse Singer, who has died aged 89, was a committed activist for more than 60 years on behalf of the world's refugees, working with the American Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef). Her life proved the old feminist adage that behind every great man - in this case, her husband, the economist Sir Hans Singer - stands a largely unrecognised, but equally remarkable, woman.

The daughter of well-to-do secular Jewish parents, Ilse was born in Hildesheim, Germany. She endured anti-semitism at her gentile school, a situation she was only liberated from by attendance at Bonn University in 1931, where she studied medicine and partied with an all-Jewish group of friends, including her husband-to-be.

Hitler's accession to power prevented her from finishing her degree, and, when Hans Singer was awarded a scholarship by King's College, Cambridge, on the initiative of John Maynard Keynes, the couple married and moved to England. Ilse's family later escaped to Argentina and Israel; Hans's father died in a Nazi prison.

During the war, Ilse worked for the resettlement of German refugees in Manchester, and brought up two children, coping with the death of a third and her husband's internment as an enemy alien in 1940. In 1947, she moved to New York, where Hans had been asked to work with the fledgling United Nations. Again, she steered her family through integration to another culture, challenging school authorities when they punished her child for refusing to pledge allegiance to the American flag.

Shortly afterwards, she was called into school again. Her son had suggested that the Rosenbergs, who were executed as Soviet spies, should be allowed to escape the death sentence. This time, Ilse reprimanded the school for checking up on parents through their children.

Her work was exacerbated when Hans was subject to political pressure during the McCarthyite era. But this did not prevent Ilse from quietly developing her own political work through a branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, testing racist landlords by organising black and white members of the group to pose as prospective tenants. With the help of her best friend, Gladys Schreiber, she also drafted speeches for a black activist in the American Labour party.

On the family's return to England in 1969, when Hans joined the Institute for Development Studies, at Sussex University, Ilse re-established her voluntary work selling Unicef cards, eventually clocking up 50 years of fundraising. But it was in 1978 that she came to the great shaping philosophy of her life - feminism.

It must have been an inspiring sight to see her arriving at the church hall where the early Brighton women's liberation group met. She was 67, by far the oldest member of the group - she said she had been invited to relieve her 48-year-old friend of the title. She lobbied for funds to start a women's refuge, picketed the Miss Brighton beauty contest and joined the Greenham Common protest.

Over the next 20 years, she became the much-loved friend of a wide circle of feminists and lesbians in East Sussex. Even in her 80s, she would don her duffle-coat to ramble the Seven Sisters with the Women's Walking Group.

When her husband was knighted in 1996, Ilse became Lady Singer. Her confident and faithful atheism was evident in her disinterest in all forms of posthumous glory, including a proposed biography, something she regarded as a misleading puff.

She is survived by Sir Hans and her son, Stephen.

Ilse Singer, fundraiser and feminist, born July 9 1911; died March 3 2001

webTitle: IMI takes £40m hit to cut jobs

fields.headline: IMI takes £40m hit to cut jobs
fields.trailText: IMI, the engineering group, yesterday announced plans to cut 1,200 jobs and sell off businesses to streamline operations and concentrate on higher value activities.
fields.body:
IMI, the engineering group, yesterday announced plans to cut 1,200 jobs and sell off businesses to streamline operations and concentrate on higher value activities.

The Birmingham-based company will take a £40m charge but will start to benefit from the restructuring within two years.

The new chief executive Martin Lamb said he was determined to create shareholder value at IMI whose stock, like that of other traditional engineering groups, has performed badly.

"My aim is to develop those businesses which offer the strongest prospects for growth. This will involve changes to the present composition of the group and in the short term some major operational restructuring," he said.

The bulk of the job losses will be in north America and continental Europe with only 200 planned for the Midlands. The company refused to say which plants would close.

The slowdown in the US economy is one of the pressure points for IMI which is a major producer of dispensers for the soft-drinks companies and fastfood restaurants.

But the deteriorating position over the Atlantic where IMI makes 25% of its sales is being offset by continued strength in European markets. This helped IMI yesterday to report annual pre-tax profits before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items of £143.6m for the 12 months to December 31 compared to £123.1m last time.

Sales rose from £1.5bn to £1.6bn and the dividend was raised from 15.1p to 15.5p.

Analysts said there was little organic growth in the company leaving the impetus on cost-cutting. IMI will try to achieve this by shifting some production to countries where wages are lower such as China and Mexico.

IMI shares ended the day down 4.75p at £261.25.

fields.headline: The lost leader
fields.standfirst: Simeon Solomon sought artistic fame but found public disgrace. Anthony Julius on the tragedy of the 19th-century Jewish painter
fields.trailText: Simeon Solomon sought artistic fame but found public disgrace. Anthony Julius on the tragedy of the 19th-century Jewish painter.
fields.body:
Simeon Solomon had a disastrous career: it was all early promise and calamitous conclusion, derailed midway by a criminal conviction, followed by the inevitable ostracism, penury, and premature death. Born into a wealthy, cultivated Jewish family, with older siblings both artists themselves, he astonished with his precocious draughtmanship. Solomon was taken up by the most advanced London artistic circles of the time, and he flourished. Flourished, that is, recklessly. He went too far, was more daring, less regarding of convention, more altogether provocative, than any of his contemporaries. Edward Burne-Jones said he was "the greatest artist of us all; we are mere schoolboys compared to (him)".

He drank, of course and was endlessly indiscreet, but it seemed containable until he was arrested for soliciting in a public lavatory. Fined but not imprisoned, he was disgraced even though no reference to the case ever appeared in any newspaper. His public career was over. Born in 1840, thrown out in 1873, dead in 1905. "We miss," remarked the Jewish Chronicle, "a competitor for artistic fame in Simeon Solomon, from causes which our readers will know only to lament." It was a catastrophe that prefigured Oscar Wilde's and it can overwhelm one's sense of the man's artworks. But he is more than his tragedy.

There is a drawing, executed in 1886, years after the private scandal of his importuning, which indicates something of what was lost by the disaster. It is of a Jew holding close to his chest the objects with which the harvest festival is celebrated. As a subject, it is unremarkable. By the late 19th century, works showing Jews at their devotions were circulating so widely, that they barely merited attention. These works introduced the customs of Jews to their Gentile neighbours in a manner both to reassure and entertain. The message they communicated was to the effect that the Jews are a solemn and devout people, and their practices are dignified and picturesque. They are, these works intimated, a pious and decorous people, in all these respects unthreatening.

Though many of Solomon's post-1873 works do seem underpowered, his turbaned Jew is not among them. Solomon takes a Jew at prayer as his starting point, but then does something quite remarkable with his subject. To appreciate it, we must first put to one side the tame exotica of dress, headgear and backdrop. We must also not trouble ourselves with the religious meaning of lulav and etrog . They merely provide the means by which the artist may realise his intention, which is the study of a man indifferent to his audience, essentially detached from everything that he wears or holds, rapt in contemplation. But contemplation of what? One cannot say. There is a hint of erotic self-absorption. There is also the implication of a certain reluctance on the part of the model to be portrayed thus. It is best understood, perhaps, as a study of the disengagement, not to say alienation, of a person from his ascribed role. There is a photograph of the artist himself, similarly turbaned, similarly tricked out in oriental finery, looking elsewhere than at the camera, that supports such a reading of the work. Taken in the late 1860s, it precedes by at least two decades the drawing and yet it offers a similar intimation of the appeal of costume to the artist: as the means by which a revelation of self may both be made and concealed.

One should resist the temptation to read the pictures either for their homoeroticism or their fuzzy religiosity. In an essay in the catalogue that accompanies the exhibition, Colin Cruise writes: "His paintings became emblematic of a kind of sexual desire, or being attracted to one's own sex." His work was accused of a "certain effeminacy". Likewise it is sometimes hard to spot any essential difference between praying Jews and entreating Copts. The picture Coptic Baptismal Procession (1865) bears more than a passing resemblance to the earlier drawing Procession with Scrolls of the Law (1862).

His early life, and the nature of his family affiliations, drew him to Biblical subjects. In his 20s he was drawn to more contemporary, and less entirely Jewish, devotional themes. His passage from subject to subject, the turning away from Jewish themes and the partial return to them, are the material of a certain kind of art history. Such investigations have their own limited value. But they do not get us especially close to Solomon. His true subject was the lonely, introspective male, one which his later circumstances both set him up to explore and denied him the means to realise.

 Anthony Julius is the author of Idolizing Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art (Thames & Hudson, £8.95). Simeon Solomon - Pre-Raphaelite Artist is at the Jewish Museum, London NW1 (020-7284 1997), until June 3.

fields.headline: 'We are not control freaks. We are freedom freaks'
fields.standfirst: Welcome to the Daft revolution . . . Daft Arts, Daft Life, Daft Music, Daft Trax. Ben Osborne on how two men in robot masks beat the music industry at its own game
fields.trailText: Welcome to the Daft revolution . . . Daft Arts, Daft Life, Daft Music, Daft Trax. Ben Osborne on how two men in robot masks beat the music industry at its own game.
fields.body:
It's been four years since Daft Punk took dance music by the tail and shoved it through a beat mangle. Their debut album, Homework, smashed house music's US-UK polarity and stamped the French tricolour on its forehead. This week they're back with Discovery, the most anticipated and talked-about dance album of the year. Mixmag, the UK's biggest-selling dance publication, has dubbed it "the greatest album ever"; DJ Roger Sanchez, one of the group's mentors, has declared the album "a lot happier than I expected".

"I don't know if I feel happier now," says Thomas Bangalter, one half of Daft Punk, "but I am happy. Homework was a happy thing, but there was also anger - a statement. Most of that anger has been proved right, so there's nothing wrong with being happy now."

Dance music, Bangalter continues, has won its battles: "Stylistically the revolution is over. Dance music has become mainstream. We fought for dance music on the first album because it was a minority and it's always better to fight for the minority: it's something you believe in, and it's about tolerance. Now it's important to push the limits.

"If we only do techno the way people want us to do techno then we'd be doing what the system wants us to do. What we have kept between Homework and Discovery is the home studio and the will to do anything. We want to destroy the limits between styles of music and show that it's possible to do funk and rock at the same time, or heavy metal and disco.

"It's still a battle because sometimes you realise people are more rigid than the system itself. You think that it's the structure that's hard to move, but when you move the structure you realise some people's minds are not ready to change."

Tall, with a mop of dark wavy hair, Bangalter has warm features and intelligent eyes that lock into you as he speaks. Guy-Manuel De Homem-Christo, the other half of Daft Punk, has already been worn down by the exhausting round of promotional interviews and voted with his feet.

Bangalter was born into music: his father, Daniel Vangarde, penned disco hits in the 1970s for the Gibson Brothers and Ottowan. This is where Bangalter's business acumen comes from. "He helped us to understand the way the record industry works," he says, "so we could make the choices we wanted to make. But I was not really in contact with him in my musical creativity."

Bangalter and De Homem-Christo met at school in 1987 and soon discovered a mutual love of records and movies from the 1960s and 1970s. Their first group, an indie affair called Darling, released a couple of tracks on the Duophonic label in 1993. Melody Maker condemned them as "a bunch of daft punks". The duo dropped the band, but kept the dismissive label and then discovered dance.

"Back in 1991 we were into the indie rock scene, but everybody was almost falling asleep," Bangalter says. "There was no energy in the audience. Then when we were about 17 we went to a rave and there was so much energy and open-mindedness that it blew our minds. We realised house music was something you could do in your bedroom. That was definitely new, because when you're in rock you have to go to a studio and you never get the time or result you want."

A year later they gave a tape to Stuart Macmillan, the head of Glasgow's Soma label, after meeting him at a rave. Macmillan released Daft Punk's first single, The New Wave, in 1994. It attracted enough interest for the Manchester-based magazine Jockey Slut to interview them and print a photograph - a now familiar image of two lanky, awkward teenagers. Their subsequent release for Soma, Da Funk, threw them into the limelight and led to their first proper photo shoot. It was to be their last. From then on, the duo would only appear hidden by masks.

"It's another way to work with your ego," Bangalter explains. "Some people want to get famous physically and have the ego to have their faces on the cover of a magazine. We had a bigger ego: we wanted to do things in a very unconventional way and to demonstrate our freedom. We also wanted to show that you don't have to be visible physically, so we replaced these [he points to his boyish, pin-up face] with other faces [of cows, pigs and currently robots]. We think these are more entertaining."

He has a point. Bangalter's final word on the masks is either entirely pretentious or the heart of the Daft Punk web: "We're into art, not information. To present our faces would just be information data and we like to work with artistic data. This way we can transform any promotional activity into creative activity."

When Da Funk became a dance anthem it was clear that the band had outgrown Soma. Before long a major deal with Virgin was secured. In February 1997 Da Funk was released commercially and jumped straight into the UK charts, supported by a video that featured a man in a dog costume. The band, it emerged, had made their masked anonymity a condition before signing with Virgin.

The 16-track album and stand-out singles Around the World and Revolution 909 that followed had been recorded in Bangalter's bedroom on low technology equipment. Its rebellion against polished production and anodyne commercial music sounded as raw as carpet burns.

Even though the pair were barely in their 20s, Daft Punk's business abilities were already apparent. Bangalter had set up the production company Daft Life, which enabled them to license all tracks to Virgin while maintaining control of their music. This has now evolved into a business empire: Daft Trax takes care of their music and management, Daft Music looks after their publishing in France, Daft Arts controls photography and logo copyright, and Daft Life looks after multimedia. "At least when you have your own production company you can decide what you want to do because you pay for it," Bangalter says. "That's the way we spend all our money: on videos, robots, the internet, plastic cards . . . "

They also started their own record labels - Bangalter rules Roulé and De Homem-Christo runs Crydamoure - enabling them to record outside of Daft Punk. This arrangement bore fruit in 1998 when Bangalter teamed up with Alan Braxe and Benjamin Diamond to release Stardust's Music Sounds Better With You, probably the most memorable dance record of the late 1990s.

And with the Daft Club the duo are taking on the internet. This online multimedia experience offers its own loyalty card (free with Discovery), exclusive online music and a range of downloadable Daft things. They've also launched the music industry's answer to MP3, the Sony/Dolby- developed ACC format.

In a sense Daft Punk are the ultimate in no-logo pop resistance, playing the game but manipulating its rules. "The Daft Club may be the only thing about this project that is entirely revolutionary," Bangalter claims. "It breaks the limits of the 70-minute CD format." At Daft Club, anyone who buys the CD will have access to additional music, not all of which has even been recorded yet. It gives people access to the middle of the creative process; it rewards people and breaks the old rules.

"We are not control freaks," says Bangalter before I've had a chance to ask the question. "We are freedom freaks because we want the liberty to do anything. Freedom is the control of your art and we live in a society where those who pay for art control it. This might be taken as a selfish attitude, but it's also honest. And it's about being able to have fun."

 Daft Punk's Discovery is out now on Virgin.

" They also started their own record labels - Bangalter rules Roulé and De Homem-Christo runs Crydamoure - enabling them to record outside of Daft Punk. This arrangement bore fruit in 1998 when Bangalter teamed up with Alan Braxe and Benjamin Diamond to release Stardust's Music Sounds Better With You, probably the most memorable dance record of the late 1990s. And with the Daft Club the duo are taking on the internet. This online multimedia experience offers its own loyalty card (free with Discovery), exclusive online music and a range of downloadable Daft things. They've also launched the music industry's answer to MP3, the Sony/Dolby- developed ACC format. In a sense Daft Punk are the ultimate in no-logo pop resistance, playing the game but manipulating its rules. "The Daft Club may be the only thing about this project that is entirely revolutionary," Bangalter claims. "It breaks the limits of the 70-minute CD format." At Daft Club, anyone who buys the CD will have access to additional music, not all of which has even been recorded yet. It gives people access to the middle of the creative process; it rewards people and breaks the old rules. "We are not control freaks," says Bangalter before I've had a chance to ask the question. "We are freedom freaks because we want the liberty to do anything. Freedom is the control of your art and we live in a society where those who pay for art control it. This might be taken as a selfish attitude, but it's also honest. And it's about being able to have fun."  Daft Punk's Discovery is out now on Virgin.

fields.headline: All eyes on Palm Beach as Florida returns to the polls
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: This time they were electing town councillors not the national president, but polling officials in Palm Beach county, Florida, were taking no chances yesterday.
fields.body:
This time they were electing town councillors not the national president, but polling officials in Palm Beach county, Florida, were taking no chances yesterday.

It was, after all, the first time some of Florida's voters had been to the polls since the disastrous November 7 election which held the United States and the world spellbound for 36 days.

Municipal elections in Palm Beach would normally have to work hard to draw the attention of even the local Palm Beach Post.

Yesterday, though, it was different, as reporters from CNN, National Public Radio and the New York Times hovered outside the polling stations just in case there was any repetition of last November's "butterfly ballot" debacle.

Returning to the public gaze for the first time since the traumatic November and December battles over hanging chads and dimpled ballots, the local election supervisor Theresa LePore, designer of the ballot paper that probably lost Al Gore the presidency, tried to act as though she had not a care in the world.

But a series of brightly coloured, prominently displayed notices headed "Attention Voters" gave the game away.

They featured a stylised kickboxer blasting his way through a ballot paper and exhorting voters to "Punch It Out!"

It is a fair bet that the only issue for the watching reporters was whether the celebrated elderly female Jewish voters of Palm Beach could finally master the ballot paper prepared for them by Ms LePore and successfully elect the candidate of their choice in yesterday's mayoral and council contests.

This time there were no interleaved names and punch holes of the kind that became famous on the butterfly ballot and left some November voters weeping and angry after they discovered that they had voted for the conservative Reform party candidate Pat Buchanan in mistake for for Mr Gore.

"These are not my elections. These are the city elections," Ms LePore told more than 100 election workers in a pep talk before the voting began.

But even she was philosophical. "I'm sure that if anything goes wrong, whether it's something I'm responsible for or not, it's going to come back on me," she said.

"I know we're going to be watched like a hawk."

Whether by coincidence or design, President George Bush's made his first visit to the sunshine state since the election controversy yesterday.

Touring the country to promote his plan to cut taxes by $1.3 trillion, Mr Bush kept well away from the traditionally Democrat-voting southern parts of the state, including Palm Beach county, and confined his visit to the heavily Republican Panama City.

"The president is looking forward," his spokeswoman said.

webTitle: Narrow escape as commuter trains collide

fields.headline: Narrow escape as commuter trains collide
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 rail passengers were yesterday forced off two packed commuter trains which clipped each other at the height of the London rush hour after a driver apparently passed through a red signal.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 rail passengers were yesterday forced off two packed commuter trains which clipped each other at the height of the London rush hour after a driver apparently passed through a red signal.

The health and safety executive launched an inquiry into the accident, which came less than two weeks after the Selby crash in which 10 people died.

One person suffered whip-lash injuries and eight others were treated for shock after the accident, which occurred outside Hither Green station near Lewisham, south-east London.

The accident involved two trains operated by Connex. One was travelling into London from Crayford, the other from Sevenoaks in Kent. The Crayford train had just left Hither Green when it clipped the back of the Sevenoaks train, which may have gone through a red signal.

Believing he had a clear track in front of him, the Crayford driver crossed the points outside Hither Green station and then saw the Sevenoaks train on the same line.

He applied the train's brakes, slowing the carriages before they "bumped" into the rear of the Sevenoaks train.

Karen O'Mahoney, an advertising executive, said that the eight carriage Crayford train came to a "screeching halt" just after Hither Green.

She added: "At first we thought it had come off the rails or there had been an incident up ahead. We didn't realise that we had actually hit something."

Part of the Crayford train was still in Hither Green at the time of the impact and passengers were able to get out on the platform. But it was three hours before passengers from the Sevenoaks train got off.

Olivier Brousse, Connex managing director, admitted that passengers would have been alarmed coming so soon after Selby. "It was a minor collision. You shouldn't jump on that and say that the network isn't safe. In terms of trends, the number of most serious signals passed at danger is declining within Connex."

Hither Green was the scene of one of Britain's worst rail disasters in 1967, when an express crashed near the station, killing 49 people and injuring 78.

webTitle: Six dead as US plane bombs wrong target

fields.headline: Six dead as US plane bombs wrong target
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Six people were killed and 10 wounded yesterday when a US Navy plane missed its target in a training exercise in Kuwait and dropped a bomb on parked cars near the Iraqi border, according to Pentagon officials.
fields.body:
Six people were killed and 10 wounded yesterday when a US Navy plane missed its target in a training exercise in Kuwait and dropped a bomb on parked cars near the Iraqi border, according to Pentagon officials.

At least four of the dead were Americans and one was a New Zealander. There were also five Americans and two Kuwaitis among the injured as a result of the the accident during a joint US-British-Kuwaiti exercise at the Udairi bombing range, about 30 miles from the desert border with Iraq.

The plane, a Navy F-18 "Hornet" was operating from the USS Harry Truman aircraft carrier patrolling the Gulf.

Early reports suggested that the pilot may have mistaken a group of parked vehicles for a target when it dropped a 500lb bomb on a group of military observers.

According to Kuwaiti officials, the vehicles had their lights on and were intended to guide the planes involved in a "close air support" exercise to wards their targets. US defence officials said it was too early yesterday to give the reasons for the accident.

Lieutenant Colonel Joe Lamarca, a spokesman for the US Central Command, said the accident occurred at around 4pm GMT.

"There were 16 confirmed casualties, which include dead and injured," he said, adding that the casualties were taken to a Kuwait military hospital.

Col Lamarca added that Kuwaiti, British and New Zealand forces were playing a support role in the exercise.

An MoD spokesman later confirmed that there were no British casualties. British soldiers had not been involved in that specific exercise and were nowhere near the area at the time of the accident, he said.

The accident comes at a time when the US Navy is struggling to recover from another lethal mishap, the deaths of nine Japanese, caused by a US submarine colliding with their fishing boat off the coast of Hawaii on February 9 during an emergency surfacing exercise.

The latest accident happened shortly after the 10th anniversary of the Gulf War and at a time when Arab sympathy for the plight of Iraq is at a height and when the US military presence in the region is increasingly unpopular.

President George Bush, speaking in Florida where he was promoting his tax proposals, called on an audience of supporters to hold a moment of silence for the dead, saying the accident was a reminder of "how dangerous service can be".

webTitle: Cult fear hits Bush plan to fund by faith

fields.headline: Cult fear hits Bush plan to fund by faith
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush's plan to channel US government aid to "faith-based" religious charities is being held back by the fear that it could end up funding controversial groups such as The Church of Scientology, Hare Krishna and the Unification Church - the Moonies..
fields.body:
George Bush's plan to channel US government aid to "faith-based" religious charities is being held back by the fear that it could end up funding controversial groups such as The Church of Scientology, Hare Krishna and the Unification Church - the Moonies..

The initiative, launched with great fanfare at a White House prayer breakfast in the president's second week in office, has stirred up a hornet's nest of accusations across the spectrum of religious groups and is being radically redrafted.

The decision to delay its introduction was taken at the end of last week after an unexpected war of words on the religious right threatened to derail the entire scheme.

"We're postponing," Don Eberly, deputy director of the White House office in charge of the faith-based programme, announced yesterday. "We're not ready."

The prospect of the billion-dollar initiative channelling large sums of public funds into the coffers of fringe groups is a very real one.

The groups have made it clear that they are anxious to get a slice of any government funding. For example, the Church of Scientology has said it will seek government aid for its drug rehabilitation and literacy programmes, which are based on the "dianetics" theories of the group's founder L Ron Hubbard.

The Hare Krishnas are gearing up to solicit federal funds for their prison release halfway houses and shelters for the homeless.

And the Rev Sun Myung Moon's church, now called the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification, is planning to ask for taxpayers' money to promote its sexual abstinence programmes in schools.

Conservative Christian bodies have expressed anxiety that Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam organisation, which runs several rehabilitation and education schemes for black American prisoners, might also try to become a beneficiary of Mr Bush's initiative. Mr Farrakhan has said he is not interested, however.

The furore raised by the plan - a central plank of the "compassionate conservative" platform on which Mr Bush campaigned for the presidency last year - has taken an entirely different turn from the one his advisers expected.

The administration prepared for an outcry from organisations and public figures who oppose any links between church and state.

What it did not expect was that most of the loudest criticism would come from the conservative Christian right, which was expected to be among the most vociferous supporters.

The critics include the veteran conservatives Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell, as well as Richard Land of the influential Southern Baptist Convention.

But perhaps the most remarkable opponent is Marvin Olasky, the guru of compassionate conservatism and a former Bush adviser whose ideas are at the root of the entire faith-based strategy.

In an article in the Wall Street Journal yesterday, Mr Robertson described the prospect that Scientologists might be beneficiaries of the scheme as "an intolerable situation".

Mr Falwell, in an interview last week, objected to Islamic groups having access to federal funds.

But the main complaint, which they share with Professor Olasky, is the White House declaration that religious groups which receive federal funds must not proselytise for converts. Such a condition would threaten "their very raison d' tre", Mr Robertson says.

Prof Olasky told a meeting last week: "I cannot give blanket support now because I am not willing to support discrimination in grant-making against evangelicals."

At the heart of the problem is the fact that the faith-based groups whose work he wishes to support are overwhelmingly evangelical, and see their welfare and religious roles as inseparable.

Mr Bush, on the other hand, wants to avoid being seen as the prisoner of the religious right. He said from the outset that he wished to fund the groups' welfare work but not their attempts at religious conversion. To Prof Olasky and Mr Robertson that decision negated the whole purpose of the programme.

In addition, many of the religious groups are worried about the consequences of such links with the federal government. "With the king's shillings come the king's shackles," Mr Land told an interviewer at the weekend.

The furore leaves the future of the planned White House bill on the faith-based initiative up in the air. The administration originally intended a bill to authorise federal funding of religious groups and to preserve the tax deductibility of donations to such groups.

"There is an innate mistrust of government among the religious right," said Robert Boston of Americans United for Separation of Church and State. "With government funding comes government regulations. Suddenly a lot of the groups are having second thoughts."

fields.headline: Chechen held for kidnapping British engineers
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Russia's arrest of a Chechen rebel leader suspected of kidnapping and beheading three British Telecom engineers in 1998 was hailed by British diplomats yesterday as the first breakthrough in the investigation of their deaths.
fields.body:
Russia's arrest of a Chechen rebel leader suspected of kidnapping and beheading three British Telecom engineers in 1998 was hailed by British diplomats yesterday as the first breakthrough in the investigation of their deaths.

Ruslan Akhmadov, 46, was being questioned last night in a detention centre in Dagestan, which borders Chechnya. He was arrested last week in Azerbaijan, travelling under false documents with a second Chechen rebel leader, Badrudin Murtazayev.

Mr Akhmadov has been charged with several kidnappings, the Interfax news agency said. Russian officials believe he helped carry out more than 30 abductions.

The Granger Telecom engineers Darren Hickey, 27, Peter Kennedy, 46, Rudolph Petschi, 42, and their New Zealand colleague Stanley Shaw, 58, were abducted from a house in the Chechen capital, Grozny, while installing a mobile telephone system in October 1998.

Their heads were found in a sack by the roadside at the beginning of December, after a rescue attempt went wrong. Their bodies were not found until Christmas Day.

Sergei Yastrzhembsky, President Vladmir Putin's spokesman, described the arrest as "a major coup".

"There has been a lot of criticism that rebel leaders are escaping. This time we have caught a really big fish," he said.

Russian officials are under pressure to broadcast even the arrests of minor rebels as cause for celebration, not least because the most powerful warlords remain at large.

Chechen experts in Moscow believe there are as many as eight Akhmadov brothers, all of whom are thought to have been involved in the lucrative kidnapping trade. Some are believed to have been killed, but the two most powerful, Uvais and Ramzan, are thought to be alive and at liberty.

The Akhmadovs are said to have handed the engineers over to another Chechen warlord, Arbi Barayev, shortly before their execution. Mr Barayev has also eluded capture.

British embassy sources were uncertain whether the Russian prosecutors would have enough evidence to prosecute Ruslan Akhmadov for the Granger kidnappings.

"It is the first time that one of the suspected ringleaders has been captured," a diplomat said.

A Foreign Office spokesman said: "We have always said that this has not been a forgotten case."

Major Vyacheslav Izmailov, a Russian military journalist who has helped in the release of several hostages, says the brothers were behind the abductions of the British aid workers Jon James and Camilla Carr, freed in September 1998 after a year in captivity.

Russian television reported yesterday that British officials would be invited to question Mr Akhmadov.

webTitle: Veteran killed woman in wartime flashback

fields.headline: Veteran killed woman in wartime flashback
fields.trailText: The loud explosions that woke George Daley from a deep sleep in his east London flat on the afternoon of November 5 last year were only fireworks being lit nearby. But for the 80-year-old veteran, who fought in north Africa, the sounds had terrifying connotations, plunging him into a wartime flashback so vivid he was convinced it was real.
fields.body:
The loud explosions that woke George Daley from a deep sleep in his east London flat on the afternoon of November 5 last year were only fireworks being lit nearby. But for the 80-year-old veteran, who fought in north Africa, the sounds had terrifying connotations, plunging him into a wartime flashback so vivid he was convinced it was real.

"I heard gunfire," he told police afterwards. "I thought I was back. I must have heard the noise outside and I must have picked up a knife and gone outside. I saw a dim figure in front of me and I was sure he was a German. I stabbed twice."

It was only when he fully awoke that he realised he had attacked his 85-year-old neighbour, Elizabeth Thompson, known as Betty, who was even more frail than him.

Yesterday at the Old Bailey, Mr Daley, who was using a walking frame and was not able to stand up in the dock, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

Describing what he called a "very sad series of events", prosecutor John Bevan QC said police had found the retired printer sitting in an armchair in the flat at Bakers Almshouses in Leyton where he had been staying with a female friend.

"I'm sorry. I done it," he told them. "I'm not going to deny it." Later he explained to detectives: "I thought I was back in the war. I done the murder. What else is there to say?"

The court heard how Mr Daley, who joined the army in 1940, fought as a private in the Royal Artillery in north Africa. He was "fairly forthright in his opinions about Germans," said Mr Bevan. Asked why he had stabbed her twice, Mr Daley had told police: "I don't know. Just what you always used to do, wasn't it? To make sure."

His victim was described as a "typical little old lady", stooped and with several fractures due to osteoporosis, "kind, sensitive and never having a cross word with anyone", who rarely left her flat.

Defence counsel John Burton QC called the widower a man "of blameless character, serving his country well with the quiet, unspoken heroism that occurred at that time".

Mr Daley had spent the five months after the attack in prison, a situation which Judge Neil Denison acknowledged was "undesirable". Yesterday he made an interim hospital order under Section 37 of the Mental Health Act, permitting the defendant to be detained in hospital pending the preparation of reports. Sentencing is due to take place on April 9.

"I'm sorry. I done it," he told them. "I'm not going to deny it." Later he explained to detectives: "I thought I was back in the war. I done the murder. What else is there to say?" The court heard how Mr Daley, who joined the army in 1940, fought as a private in the Royal Artillery in north Africa. He was "fairly forthright in his opinions about Germans," said Mr Bevan. Asked why he had stabbed her twice, Mr Daley had told police: "I don't know. Just what you always used to do, wasn't it? To make sure." His victim was described as a "typical little old lady", stooped and with several fractures due to osteoporosis, "kind, sensitive and never having a cross word with anyone", who rarely left her flat. Defence counsel John Burton QC called the widower a man "of blameless character, serving his country well with the quiet, unspoken heroism that occurred at that time". Mr Daley had spent the five months after the attack in prison, a situation which Judge Neil Denison acknowledged was "undesirable". Yesterday he made an interim hospital order under Section 37 of the Mental Health Act, permitting the defendant to be detained in hospital pending the preparation of reports. Sentencing is due to take place on April 9.

fields.headline: 'Evil' family killer granted appeal
fields.standfirst: Bamber relies on 'forensic issue' to overturn 1986 conviction
fields.trailText: The case of Jeremy Bamber, one of the most notorious killers of the last 20 years, is being referred to the court of appeal, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The case of Jeremy Bamber, one of the most notorious killers of the last 20 years, is being referred to the court of appeal, it emerged last night.

Bamber was convicted of shooting dead five members of his wealthy family, including six-year-old twins, at their Essex farmhouse in 1985.

The trial judge described Bamber as having a "warped, callous and evil mind" and characterised his conduct as "evil beyond belief". He became one of a handful of prisoners in Britain who have been told they will spend the rest of their lives behind bars.

However, there have long been doubts about the safety of his conviction. Experts from the criminal cases review commission, which investigates suspected miscarriages of justice, have been examining the case for several months and have now decided it should go to the appeal court.

Bamber was convicted of shooting his adoptive parents at their home in Tolleshunt D'Arcy, his sister, Sheila Caffell, and her twin sons. The prosecution alleged he murdered them to inherit a £500,000 family fortune.

But Bamber claimed Mrs Caffell, who had a history of mental illness, killed the family and turned the gun, a .22 semi-automatic rifle, on herself.

On a website set up on Bamber's behalf, he says the submission to the commission would focus on a "narrow forensic issue" but does not give details.

It is understood the appeal could centre on traces of blood found in a silencer believed to have been used in the killings. The prosecution suggested the blood was Mrs Caffell's and could not have entered the silencer had she killed herself.

It is believed that forensics experts consulted by those acting for Bamber may have cast doubt on this theory. The way the tests on the blood were carried out could have resulted in errors.

Bamber, 39, claims on the website: "I was wrongly convicted in 1986 of murdering five members of my family and I've been in jail for nearly 16 years. I have protested my innocence through all the usual channels and tried hard to find a successful path to the appeal courts."

He says the crucial forensic information has been disclosed only to his legal team but adds: "In time, I will publish this information but there are compelling reasons why I cannot do so now."

Bamber also appeals for anyone with any other information which could help his fight for freedom to come forward.

Bamber claims he has had 17 jail moves and 89 cell moves during his imprisonment. At present, he is in the high security Whitemoor prison, Cambridgeshire.

An earlier application for leave to appeal against his conviction was refused by the court of appeal in 1989.

Bamber then applied to the Home Office for a review of his conviction and his case was transferred to the criminal cases review commission after March 1997, when it assumed responsibility for the review of suspected miscarriages of justice.

In 1995 Bamber lost his high court attempt to challenge the home secretary's decision that he should remain behind bars for the rest of his life. The appeal was seen as a test case for 14 other convicted murderers.

Following Bamber's conviction, Essex police were criticised for the way the investigation was handled. Bamber's supporters believe vital evidence could have been destroyed.

fields.headline: New fathers sleep on ...
fields.trailText: A survey has revealed that just 17% of new fathers regularly get out of bed at night to help soothe their sleepless baby while one in five never gets up.
fields.body:
In an age when men are supposed to be more involved in helping to bring up children, a survey has revealed that just 17% of new fathers regularly get out of bed at night to help soothe their sleepless baby while one in five never gets up.

The stress of sleepless nights and the lack of help from slumbering partners has led eight out of 10 new mothers to say that having a baby has threatened to wreck their relationships.

The average mother gets four hours sleep a night during her baby's first four months, and after 18 months they are snatching five hours a night.

Women bearing the brunt of the sleepless nights causes resentment, rows and rifts among couples, the study of 2,000 new mothers by Mother and Baby magazine found.

More than two thirds of women admit resenting their partner for not getting up at night while eight out of 10 new mothers say their lack of sleep has put their relationship under "immense strain" and caused rows with their partners.

And 90% are left bad-tempered, tearful, forgetful and irritated with their baby. More than half are so tired that they feel in a "state of despair and desperation".

Just settling their baby to sleep at the beginning of the night takes 25 minutes. After that, mothers get up an average of three times a night to feed, change and comfort their child.

Older mothers suffer most, with those over 34 having less sleep and more problems than their younger counterparts.

Dani Zur, editor of Mother and Baby magazine, said: "The trend nowadays is to have children at a later age, and although there are many positive aspects, older mums don't have the same energy levels as those in their twenties.

"The fresh-faced image of famous older mums like Madonna and Cherie Blair doesn't usually show the entourage of helpers that follow them around."

 David Beckham is most men's idea of the perfect father, according to a survey out today. The Manchester United and England footballer, who has a two-year-old son, Brooklyn, topped the poll of perfect parents in a survey of first time dads. Oasis singer Liam Gallagher was named the worst role model for new fathers.

More than 400 men in Britain were questioned for the poll by the medical insurers Norwich Union Healthcare.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Greens join left list for Paris
fields.body:
Greens join left list for Paris

The Socialist candidate for mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delanoe, has reached agreement with the Greens for a common list of candidates for the second round of council elections on Sunday.

Mr Delanoe's leftwing coalition took almost 32% of the first round vote in Paris, but elsewhere several Socialist ministers fared badly in their mayoral campaigns. Jon Henley, Paris

Vote-rigging at Ugandan polls

Supporters of President Yoweri Museveni stuffed ballot boxes and sent away opposition agents during yesterday's presidential election, witnesses in Kambuga in western Uganda said.

Officials denied any wrongdoing in the election, in which Mr Museveni's main challenger is Kizza Besigye. AFP, Kambuga

Czech police in firing line

The Czech police are criticised in an Amnesty International report out today for using brutal tactics on globalisation protesters at the IMF and World Bank conference in Prague in September. Kate Connolly

fields.headline: Disasters unroll without a pattern
fields.standfirst:
Bush says the mishaps are Clinton's legacy but the evidence is not there
Special report: Iraq
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Yesterday's bombing accident in Kuwait is the latest in what appears to be a worsening series of US military mishaps which the new Bush administration has said are a legacy of declining readiness and morale left over from the Clinton years.
fields.body:
Yesterday's bombing accident in Kuwait is the latest in what appears to be a worsening series of US military mishaps which the new Bush administration has said are a legacy of declining readiness and morale left over from the Clinton years.

Over the course of last year's presidential campaign, George Bush portrayed the armed forces as being at the end of their tether, underpaid, overstretched and no longer able to fight two wars simultaneously - the Pentagon's benchmark of military strength.

However, a closer examination of recent accidents show no clear pattern. It was too early yesterday to judge whether the Navy F-18 Hornet which dropped a 500lb bomb on a group of military observers did so because of pilot error or a malfunction. A military inquiry was immediately launched.

The accident is unlikely to be the result of a lack of experience. Operation Southern Watch, in which US and British planes patrol the no-fly zones over southern Iraq, has been going on for almost a decade.

The al-Udairi range in northern Kuwait has been in use for almost as long.

The last major military accident, involving a collision in February between a US submarine, the USS Greeneville, and a Japanese fisheries training vessel, the Ehime Maru, in which nine people were killed, is still the subject of an inquiry.

It seems likely that the presence of 16 civilians on board played a role in the miscalculations of the crew, who were performing a rapid surfacing manoeuvre for the benefit of their visitors.

The presence of civilians on military operations like the Greeneville's is arguably a result of a squeeze on military funds, in which each armed service must compete for popular support. But arguably, that has always been true. The US navy may have simply gone too far on this occasion.

The other major accidents in recent years have involved the ill-fated and expensive MV-22 Osprey which, in a string of crashes, has cost the lives of more than 30 servicemen.

A government report published last week suggested that those crashes were a result of over-eagerness on the part of the different armed services to commission the helicopter-plane hybrid before it was fully tested, in order to secure a $40 billion share of the Pentagon budget for new projects.

In fact, far from being overstretched, some critics of the Pentagon believe it has become too complacent and set in its cold war ways to adjust to the requirements of a century in which the principal dangers are terrorists and "brush-fire" wars in which US soldiers have been called on to keep the peace.

Writing in the Los Angeles Times last week, Lawrence Korb, a senior Pentagon official in the Reagan years, argued that peacekeeping was not overstretching the US military. In fact, he said, such operations only took up 2% of the military budget.

"The military does not need to be rebuilt; it needs to be transformed," Mr Korb wrote. "In the 1990s, the Pentagon invested more than a trillion dollars in developing and procuring new weapons. But much of it was wasted on cold war relics - $200m fighter planes, $6bn aircraft carriers, $2bn submarines, $400m artillery pieces-that will be of little use in the conflicts of the 21st century."

A history of tragic military blunders

February 9 2001 A US navy submarine sank a Japanese fisheries training vessel by colliding with it, killing people on board. The USS Greeneville, a 109-metre attack submarine based at Pearl Harbour, which was carrying 16 civilians, hit the Japanese ship as it surfaced.

December 9 1999

A Sea Knight helicopter on a training flight crashed 15 miles off the Californian coast at San Diego, killing seven marines from Miramar naval air station.

April 10 1999 : Two marine jets dropped bombs on a lookout post at the Vieques training ground in Puerto Rico. One civilian was killed. Four others were injured, three of them civilians.

February 3 1998 Twenty people were killed when a marine corps EA-6B Prowler jet on a training mission cut ski lift cables at the Italian resort of Cavalese, sending a gondola full of skiers plunging into the valley.

October 2 1992 The USS Saratoga accidentally fired at a Turkish destroyer during a Nato training exercise in the Aegean Sea, killing five men and injuring 18 others.

July 31 1988 The cruiser Vincennes, stationed in the Gulf, shot down Iran Air Flight 655, killing all 290 people on board.The commander of the ship ordered a missile attack on the airbus after he was told that it was descending toward the cruiser at the speed of a fighter jet.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A man appeared in court yesterday charged with the murder of four-year-old Luke Gargan, of Saltcoats in Ayrshire, who disappeared from his home. John Gour-lay, 35, made no plea and was remanded in custody.
fields.body:
Man charged on boy's murder

A man appeared in court yesterday charged with the murder of four-year-old Luke Gargan, of Saltcoats in Ayrshire, who disappeared from his home. John Gour-lay, 35, made no plea and was remanded in custody.

PC alleges racial abuse

Police officers at Huyton station, Merseyside, taunted a black colleague, PC Dawn Devanna, 31, from Toxteth, and one of them subjected her to racially abusive calls, it was alleged at an employment tribunal yesterday. The tribunal continues.

British actors scoop awards

British actors excelled at the US Screen Actors Guild awards. Albert Finney won the best supporting actor award for his role in Erin Brockovich and Dame Judi Dench got best supporting actress for Chocolat.

Baby died after all-fruit diet

The parents of a nine-month- old girl who died of malnutrition after a fruitarian diet appeared at the Old Bailey charged with man-slaughter. Hasmik and Gar-abet Manuelyan, of Staines, Surrey, denied killing Areni.

Inflatable bra launched

More than 100,000 women have already ordered a bra with inflatable airbags, the Ultrabra Airotic, which can increase bust size by up to two cups, maker Gossard said, launching the bra yesterday.

fields.headline: Vicious circles
fields.standfirst: Rivers boiling with blood, deserts on fire, sinners tormented by grinning devils - Botticelli's hell is both horrible and hilarious, says Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Rivers boiling with blood, deserts on fire, sinners tormented by grinning devils - Botticelli's hell is both horrible and hilarious, says Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
This is hell. A narrowing funnel leading down to the centre of the earth. Sandro Botticelli's chart of hell is a little like a mushroom cloud or a child's spinning top. Look closely, and there are bodies on the terraces and narrow ledges, writhing like tiny maggots. It is the first thing you see as you walk into the Royal Academy's exhibition of his incomplete cycle of unfinished drawings illustrating Dante's Divine Comedy.

Botticelli's drawings were made some time between 1480 and 1495, over a century and a half after Dante Alighieri, a fellow Florentine, wrote the Divine Comedy. Terraced, pinnacled, travelling forever downward, the ledges, cities and basements of hell are furnished with sloughs, gorges and deserts; there are cities, rivers of boiling blood, lagoons of scalding pitch, burning deserts, thorny forests, ditches of shit and frozen subterranean lakes. Every kind of sin, and sinner, is catered for. Here, descending circle by circle, like tourists to Bedlam, came Dante and Virgil. Following them, at least through Dante's poem, came Botticelli.

For Botticelli, Dante's hell was in part his own Florence, in part the Biblical and Catholic worlds, a collision of religions and mythologies (here's Mohammed, disembowelled, here the giants of antiquity, enchained), in part the state of his own soul. Botticelli's version of the Inferno, and to a lesser extent his Purgatorio, is frequently as hilarious as it is horrible. It is impossible to look at certain of Botticelli's drawings - Inferno XIX, for example, with all those legs and feet on fire protruding from the wormholes that imprison sinners upside-down - without laughing. Hard not to smile, either, at the penitents in the Purgatorio, who crawl, as though between the frames of a strip cartoon, with boulders on their backs. Endless suffering and the variety of torments have become a running gag. Here come the snakes, the bat-winged grinning devils (who frequently smile back at us as we look at them), the guy with the scorpion's tail, the one with the comically engorged sausagey penis. The tormented - ravaged by beasts, or bursting in flames, or naked and frozen on an icy subterranean lake - provide a fabulous opportunity for Botticelli's wit, his empathy, the blackest of black humour. How many things can you do to a body, or a soul, before it breaks? Everything, the answer seems to be, again and again. The round of punishments and degradations eventually takes us to the Devil, a hairy, snaggletoothed, three-headed Satan at the earth's icy core. He is hard, nowadays, to take seriously; maybe that is his disguise.

While Satan and his devils are frequently mad cartoons, the suffering sinners are all too human. Dante and Virgil, on the other hand, are always the straight men, plainly drawn, with a kind of reserve. Beatrice, when she appears, is a stereotypical Botticelli beauty, all ringlets, long fingers, too much drapery. Sometimes, she gives her Dante a wry smile or a worried look, as she leads him from Purgatory to Paradise.

Ninety-two of Botticelli's original drawings remain; of his projected total - as far as we know - eight have been lost, two others disappeared in Berlin following the second world war, while others were never even begun. Of the vast majority that survive, few are finished, in the sense that Botticelli intended them. A few - such as the chart of hell - were worked over and painted up, rather badly, by studio assistants, while most remain as preparatory under-drawings. These were worked over, to varying degrees of completion, by the artist in pen and ink, using a silver point, which leaves a faint, indented, pencil-like mark, and a softer alloy nib. On the reverse sides of the sheets, Dante's text strikes through.

What one might call the nakedness, the incompleteness, of these drawings shouldn't deter us. In fact, they speak to us today all the more eloquently because of it. Fully worked-up illustrations - the one for Canto XVIII of the Inferno, for instance - are somehow removed from us by being filled-in with paint. The bare outlines and graphic shorthand of Botticelli's drawings leave more mental space for the imagination, and speak more directly. The language of drawing has not changed much, and Botticelli's drawing, at times cartoonish and caricatured, at other times painstaking, deli cate, even tentative, is consummate. In some works it is truly a shorthand, in which one is aware of the nib skittering across the smooth parchment, or of Botticelli recording things in a matter of seconds, creating cursive, repetitive rhythms, imagining faces amid writhing, rhythmic flames, figures running through a forest of living trees. The more you look, the more delirious it all gets, the more a mind and a temperament communicate themselves.

In the later, sparser and more restrained drawings of Dante's ascent through the circles of Paradise, guided by Beatrice, we see the two figures inside a bubble, a perfect compass-drawn circle. Except that part of the pleasure is seeing how imperfectly drawn the circles actually are, how the pen runs out of ink, or the nib slews away as the compass slips. The drawing, and the compositional organisation, is nevertheless marvellous. The idea is concrete, and needs no finish. Botticelli, like Dante, may have balked at the impossibility of depicting God and heaven. He turned, in part, to geometry, but towards the end left much unsaid, undrawn, blank. The bare, aged, yellowed parchment becomes a kind of immanence, a light-filled emptiness. In modern art, this has become a sign of the inexpressible, of spiritual presence.

The reproductions in the excellent catalogue - good though they are - are wholly inadequate, in the sense that one really needs to see the actual drawings, on the slightly translucent animal-skin parch ment. To draw and write on skin provides its own metaphor of the corporeal and the transcendent. The geography and architecture of Botticelli's universe - and Dante's - may seem medieval, part of a cosmology we can no longer believe in. Hell may be eternal, but a modern hell would be altogether different to the Florentine abyss. It would be just as much a product of our time as the hells of Dante, of Fra Filippo Lippi, of Leonardo and of Botticelli were of theirs. Yet popular culture still returns to medieval eschatology for its images: Hannibal Lector returns to Florence, in Thomas Harris's most recent Lector escapade, to the very palace where the conspirators against Botticelli's first mentor, Lorenzo de Medici, were hung. And Dante's journey - and Botticelli's - is still enormously affecting.

Both the poet and the artist make the imagery, and the concepts behind them, come alive for us through their respective languages. Thank heavens, I say, Botticelli's Divine Comedy was left unfinished: here is a plain voice, full of humour, imagination, liveliness, pictorial invention and doubt, speaking by and large an unchanged visual language. At times, Botticelli's drawings look forward to just about every 20th-century draughtsman you can think of: here is Henri Michaux on mescaline, in Botticelli's wood of thorns. Here's the Guardian's Steve Bell, in the If cartoon that is Inferno XIX. Here's Cy Twombly, leaving faint traces in Paradise.

It is possible, but unlikely, that Botticelli drew Dante entirely for his own pleasure; only a little less likely that they were meant as drawings for frescoes for Florence Cathedral. More likely, he made his drawings for a de luxe codex or collector's book, as an ambassadorial gift to a foreign dignitary, or to be installed in some private room dedicated to Dante, a kind of Borgesian chamber that it is pleasurable to imagine, but has never been found.

Whatever the reason for Botticelli's labours over Dante, it consumed him creatively and, according to Vasari "caused infinite disorder in his life". Botticelli's staging, his command of actions, emotions and bodies, either in relation to nature or to architecture, is always superb. I always like him best when he is marshalling groups of figures this way and that, choreographing events of enormous portent and stress. He's great, too, at the singular figure - a man sitting in a wilderness, a shade turning its head, a weeping woman. He is an orchestrator, not of anonymous human ciphers, but of individuals. Show me a video, point me at the movie, says the audience for contemporary art. Well, that is almost what Botticelli does here, in this great cycle of drawings, these incomparable works.

fields.bodyText: This is hell. A narrowing funnel leading down to the centre of the earth. Sandro Botticelli's chart of hell is a little like a mushroom cloud or a child's spinning top. Look closely, and there are bodies on the terraces and narrow ledges, writhing like tiny maggots. It is the first thing you see as you walk into the Royal Academy's exhibition of his incomplete cycle of unfinished drawings illustrating Dante's Divine Comedy. Botticelli's drawings were made some time between 1480 and 1495, over a century and a half after Dante Alighieri, a fellow Florentine, wrote the Divine Comedy. Terraced, pinnacled, travelling forever downward, the ledges, cities and basements of hell are furnished with sloughs, gorges and deserts; there are cities, rivers of boiling blood, lagoons of scalding pitch, burning deserts, thorny forests, ditches of shit and frozen subterranean lakes. Every kind of sin, and sinner, is catered for. Here, descending circle by circle, like tourists to Bedlam, came Dante and Virgil. Following them, at least through Dante's poem, came Botticelli. For Botticelli, Dante's hell was in part his own Florence, in part the Biblical and Catholic worlds, a collision of religions and mythologies (here's Mohammed, disembowelled, here the giants of antiquity, enchained), in part the state of his own soul. Botticelli's version of the Inferno, and to a lesser extent his Purgatorio, is frequently as hilarious as it is horrible. It is impossible to look at certain of Botticelli's drawings - Inferno XIX, for example, with all those legs and feet on fire protruding from the wormholes that imprison sinners upside-down - without laughing. Hard not to smile, either, at the penitents in the Purgatorio, who crawl, as though between the frames of a strip cartoon, with boulders on their backs. Endless suffering and the variety of torments have become a running gag. Here come the snakes, the bat-winged grinning devils (who frequently smile back at us as we look at them), the guy with the scorpion's tail, the one with the comically engorged sausagey penis. The tormented - ravaged by beasts, or bursting in flames, or naked and frozen on an icy subterranean lake - provide a fabulous opportunity for Botticelli's wit, his empathy, the blackest of black humour. How many things can you do to a body, or a soul, before it breaks? Everything, the answer seems to be, again and again. The round of punishments and degradations eventually takes us to the Devil, a hairy, snaggletoothed, three-headed Satan at the earth's icy core. He is hard, nowadays, to take seriously; maybe that is his disguise. While Satan and his devils are frequently mad cartoons, the suffering sinners are all too human. Dante and Virgil, on the other hand, are always the straight men, plainly drawn, with a kind of reserve. Beatrice, when she appears, is a stereotypical Botticelli beauty, all ringlets, long fingers, too much drapery. Sometimes, she gives her Dante a wry smile or a worried look, as she leads him from Purgatory to Paradise. Ninety-two of Botticelli's original drawings remain; of his projected total - as far as we know - eight have been lost, two others disappeared in Berlin following the second world war, while others were never even begun. Of the vast majority that survive, few are finished, in the sense that Botticelli intended them. A few - such as the chart of hell - were worked over and painted up, rather badly, by studio assistants, while most remain as preparatory under-drawings. These were worked over, to varying degrees of completion, by the artist in pen and ink, using a silver point, which leaves a faint, indented, pencil-like mark, and a softer alloy nib. On the reverse sides of the sheets, Dante's text strikes through. What one might call the nakedness, the incompleteness, of these drawings shouldn't deter us. In fact, they speak to us today all the more eloquently because of it. Fully worked-up illustrations - the one for Canto XVIII of the Inferno, for instance - are somehow removed from us by being filled-in with paint. The bare outlines and graphic shorthand of Botticelli's drawings leave more mental space for the imagination, and speak more directly. The language of drawing has not changed much, and Botticelli's drawing, at times cartoonish and caricatured, at other times painstaking, deli cate, even tentative, is consummate. In some works it is truly a shorthand, in which one is aware of the nib skittering across the smooth parchment, or of Botticelli recording things in a matter of seconds, creating cursive, repetitive rhythms, imagining faces amid writhing, rhythmic flames, figures running through a forest of living trees. The more you look, the more delirious it all gets, the more a mind and a temperament communicate themselves. In the later, sparser and more restrained drawings of Dante's ascent through the circles of Paradise, guided by Beatrice, we see the two figures inside a bubble, a perfect compass-drawn circle. Except that part of the pleasure is seeing how imperfectly drawn the circles actually are, how the pen runs out of ink, or the nib slews away as the compass slips. The drawing, and the compositional organisation, is nevertheless marvellous. The idea is concrete, and needs no finish. Botticelli, like Dante, may have balked at the impossibility of depicting God and heaven. He turned, in part, to geometry, but towards the end left much unsaid, undrawn, blank. The bare, aged, yellowed parchment becomes a kind of immanence, a light-filled emptiness. In modern art, this has become a sign of the inexpressible, of spiritual presence. The reproductions in the excellent catalogue - good though they are - are wholly inadequate, in the sense that one really needs to see the actual drawings, on the slightly translucent animal-skin parch ment. To draw and write on skin provides its own metaphor of the corporeal and the transcendent. The geography and architecture of Botticelli's universe - and Dante's - may seem medieval, part of a cosmology we can no longer believe in. Hell may be eternal, but a modern hell would be altogether different to the Florentine abyss. It would be just as much a product of our time as the hells of Dante, of Fra Filippo Lippi, of Leonardo and of Botticelli were of theirs. Yet popular culture still returns to medieval eschatology for its images: Hannibal Lector returns to Florence, in Thomas Harris's most recent Lector escapade, to the very palace where the conspirators against Botticelli's first mentor, Lorenzo de Medici, were hung. And Dante's journey - and Botticelli's - is still enormously affecting. Both the poet and the artist make the imagery, and the concepts behind them, come alive for us through their respective languages. Thank heavens, I say, Botticelli's Divine Comedy was left unfinished: here is a plain voice, full of humour, imagination, liveliness, pictorial invention and doubt, speaking by and large an unchanged visual language.
