fields.headline: The networker
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Timesheet | Pay check | On the radar | Debunker
fields.body:
Timesheet

The employment agency manager

Chrys Street, 36, is branch manager at Office Angels

6.00am: Alarm goes off. Makes a cup of tea, white, one sugar. Chris Tarrant on the radio.

7.00: Says hello to husband Steve as she walks out the door. Tube to Oxford Circus.

8.00: Opens up. Puts makeup on. Colleague makes her a cup of tea. "My smile in the morning is really important. I try to be bright and breezy.

"We're quite Essexy, though we've a couple of girls who are from south of the river, so we have a lot of banter. We say they're posh."

8.15: Makes list - "so I've got some structure" - in yellow notebook. "The last one was red. I start a new page every day."

8.30: "Perm" (permanent jobs) meeting. Goes through daily vacancies. "Just really quickly, I know you've a lot of people to see."

8.45: Makes telephone call. "Hi, is Helen there? It's Chrys from office Angels, Oxford Circus, just returning her call."

9.15: Telephone rings. "Hi Helen."

10.00: "Temps" (temporary jobs) meeting with Julie. "We discuss her goals, so I'm helping her structure her week. I make her pledge what she's got do. I think you need to be quite thick-skinned."

11.00: Colleague enters and wants to know whether it's safe to take another painkilller. "I'd wait another hour. There's some paracetamol in my drawer."

12.15pm: Organises speaker and invitations, with Suzanne, for a seminar to be held at the Ritz.

1.00: Sorts through marketing pack from head office.

2.00: Nips out of the office to grab a sandwich. "Lunch break is really non-existent. It's as and when."

2.15: Speaks to advertising team. Most advertising will appear in Miss London or Evening Standard. You've got to make the most of it. Time's too short.

3.00: Looks at photos of office trip to Paris with Julie. "Look how nice my hair was before it rained."

4.15: Debates how many coffee sachets to include in a mailshot. Decides on five. More calls.

5.45: Ticks goals off on her list.

6.00: Closes up. "Tonight I'm going for a curry with colleagues. We're often client entertaining in the evenings. It's a nice part of the job.

"But most evenings I'll go for the tube, suffer on the Central line for 45 minutes. I'll walk around the supermarket after work. You spend all day talking to clients, so it's nice to be alone in a supermarket where you don't know anyone.

"Then I'll cook dinner and catch up on Eastenders. I go to bingo once a week. When you're listening to the numbers you can't think of anything else."

Pay check

What you can do for £40,000

 Hearing aid audiologist, Surrey

 Managing editor, Which? magazine, London

 "Advanced skills" state-school teacher, national

 Policy expert, international childrens' charity, London

 Head of administration, university medical school, south-west England

 Senior divisional officer, fire service

On the radar

Dot.com slacker

In the 90s the word slacker referred to Gen Xers disillusioned with traditional career paths. Now the dot.com bubble has popped, the word has entered the lexicon of net whizzkids, who would once smugly have dismissed junior doctors as workshy loafers. It seems there are a lot of burnt-out bunnies who didn't have enough free time to spend the venture capitalists' money, but now have rather too much of it on their hands. Numerous ex-dot.com art directors are spending their gains and new-found free time on the slopes of Blueridge perfecting their 'boarding, or mastering the ancient game of Connect 4 in Thailand.

Debunker

Tripe with gravy

Bright eyes, healthy teeth and glossy coat. No longer only seen on best-in-show pooches, these attributes are now essential for any business (dober)man aspiring to a rosette.

At least, that would seem to be the message of a rash of publications extolling the virtues of eating your own dog food. It's tripe with marrow bone and gravy for dinner for those who have read Julie Bick's All I Really Need to Know In Business I Learned at Microsoft and Guy Kawasaki's Rules for Revolutions. Their mantra? Don't pant it, but howl at the moon: "Eat your own dog food."

Put through the debunker translator, this appears to refer to the practice of hiring a consultant to hold your nose while you swallow something that might otherwise offend your delicate business tastebuds. You pay them, they decide which part of your company is overdue to be downsized, that kind of thing.

But is this approach wise? "Eating dog food is not dangerous," a spokeswoman for the Pet Foods Manufacturing Association says, reassuringly. "It is just not suitable for human consumption as it is nutritionally formulated for dogs." In other words, it won't kill you, but it's not terribly good for the health. Which seems to relate rather neatly to the practice of paying a company to tell you which of your colleagues to sack.

fields.headline: K...
fields.standfirst:
Opéra Bastille, Paris
Rating:**
fields.trailText:
Opéra Bastille, Paris
Rating:**
fields.body:
There are great operas based on great literature, but not many. It is a risky business, taking a text that is powerfully self-sufficient in its own right and attempting to give it another life in a hybrid medium such as opera, but that has never inhibited composers from trying.

The latest to try his luck is 48-year-old Philippe Manoury. His second opera, K..., based upon Kafka's The Trial, was commissioned by the Paris Opera and received its first performance at the Bastille last week. It's easy to see why such a novel, with its pervasive air of menace and mystery, and dream-like connectivity, should appeal to a composer, who might imagine his music could expand upon some of the non sequiturs in the text and enhance its brooding atmosphere.

But at no point during the 12 scenes of this continuous, 100-minute piece does Manoury's score justifiy his choice of subject or create a world that is genuinely involving in a musical or a theatrical way. K... never takes off, never transcends its source. It doesn't tell us more about The Trial; on the contrary it diminishes the original, flattens out its ambiguities, turns its narrative into something that is ploddingly straightforward.

The libretto by Bernard Pantrat and the director André Engel was apparently shaped in French translation and then reworked in the original German, using Kafka's own words. Though some of the subsidiary figures are omitted, it simply unfolds the story from the hapless Josef K's first encounter with the investigators who are pursuing him for some never-revealed misdemeanour.

Manoury's vocal writing is functional rather than individual. There are a few soaring soprano moments for Leni, the solicitor's chamber maid who tries to help K, and a sharply drawn cameo for the painter Titorelli, whom K visits to find out more about the judge who is trying him, but most of the text, even for the hapless hero himself, is delivered in a neutral, semi-declamatory way.

The orchestra is left to provide the main interest and there at least Manoury's sharp ear for sonority and his expert use of electronics can come to the fore. Securely conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, the sounds in the pit are combined with pre-recorded material (realised using the technology at IRCAM), projected through 16 loudspeakers arrayed around the auditorium, and the layerings of instrumental and synthesised sounds and the correspondences between them are often beguiling. But their totality does nothing to enhance or to justify what is unfolding onstage.

Engel's production, with massive sets by Nicky Rieti, is lavish, yet apart from some strange departures from the libretto - the solicitor's office becomes a Turkish bath for instance - offers very little that is genuinely striking. K's scene with the painter goes best, partly because the part of Titorelli is sung by the great character tenor Kenneth Riegel, partly because Rieti's set is so elaborate. The German baritone Andreas Scheibner is impressively robust in the title role, and Susan Anthony makes what she can of the part of Leni. Like the audience, none of the rest of the cast has anything to get their teeth into.

Until March 27. Box office: 00331-36 69 78 68.

fields.headline: Lynne Arriale Trio
fields.standfirst:
Crucible Theatre Studio, Sheffield
Rating:***
fields.trailText:
Crucible Theatre Studio, Sheffield

Rating:***
fields.body:
A winner of the Great American Piano competition, Lynne Arriale is currently touring in support of a highly-praised live album. Her musical partners are fellow New Yorker Steve Davis on drums, and acclaimed British double bass player Malcolm Creese. The trio offer new compositions as well as a few old jazz and pop favourites, and the overall mood of the show is warm and congenial.

In Davis, Arriale has found a unique percussive performer. Using only a snare drum and two cymbals, he conjures an astonishing range of sounds, swishing his brushes in the air, then inverting them to drag their hooked metal ends across the surface of his cymbals. Undeterred by the absence of a bass drum, he simply smacks the floor with the heel of his shoe, and he occasionally leans over to play a paradiddle on a nearby chair. His colourfully unorthodox approach complements Creese's intelligent bass playing, and the two musicians lock together empathically, communicating with the tiniest of eyebrow twitches.

Arriale's own performance is technically impressive, her tone as sweetly meditative as Bill Evans at his most chilled out. However, there are rather a lot of very slow, drawn-out pieces on offer, some of which border on the soporific. James Taylor's Long Ago and Far Away is not so much dreamy as woozy, and even though everyone is clearly enjoying the creamy texture of the music, a contagious yawn spreads alarmingly throughout the audience.

If all significant jazz musicians have a story to tell, then Arriale's is a sepia-tinted fairy tale in which everyone always lives happily after. Her playing purrs with self-satisfaction, but it pushes at no boundaries, asks no questions, hints at no uncomfortable truths. Yet she receives a warm enough ovation and everyone seems happy to have escaped from reality for a couple of hours.

At Pizza Express, Maidstone (01622 683548), on March 19, then tours.

fields.headline: Prudential in £30bn merger
fields.trailText: Prudential yesterday unveiled the largest transatlantic financial services deal in history through its £30bn merger with American General of the United States.
fields.body:
Prudential yesterday unveiled the largest transatlantic financial services deal in history through its £30bn merger with American General of the United States.

The size of the transaction, which caught the City by surprise, led to a dramatic fall in the Pru's share price as investors tried to weigh up the implications of a deal which is being paid for by Pru's shareholders.

As a result of the acquisition, Prudential will be catapulted from 26th to sixth largest international insurance company in the world and the largest based in Britain. Provided its share price can regain its footing, the Pru will also become the 11th biggest company in the FTSE 100 index of the country's leading shares.

Jonathan Bloomer, chief executive of the Pru, described the transaction as a merger rather than a takeover. "Our two companies are a great fit. Not only will this give us a leading position in the US, it also gives us the scale and financial strength to allow for continued expansion and faster growth in the other regions of the world in which we operate," he said.

The transaction is part of Mr Bloomer's attempt to rid the company of its "man from the Pru" door-to-door salesman image and follows news last month of its planned 2,000 job cuts in Britain.

Mr Bloomer will remain as chief executive of the combined company, which will continue to be based in London but with a substantial business in the US, where the bulk of any redundancies are expected to be felt.

The transaction, which is being paid for entirely in shares, also lifts the lid on the dis crepancies between the pay levels of top executives in Britain and the United States.

Mr Bloomer, for instance, received £668,000 in 1999, the most up-to-date information available. Bob Devlin, the current chairman and chief executive of Texas-based American General, who will take over the operations of the Pru's existing business in the United States, earned almost $1m (£700,000) in basic salary last year and also received a $4m bonus. These sums exclude any shares or options awarded to the executives during that period.

The Pru insisted yesterday that it would not be altering its remuneration policy for its executives in Britain but would pay "appropriate rates" in the other parts of the world in which it operates.

fields.headline: Henze at 75
fields.standfirst:
South Bank Centre, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
South Bank Centre, London

Rating:****
fields.body:
Hans Werner Henze is one of the grandest old men of modern music. The South Bank Centre's Voices festival is a month-long celebration of the composer's 75th birthday year. The centrepiece of its first weekend - and the work that inspired the title - was the London Sinfonietta's performance of Henze's 22-song collection, Voices. Composed in 1973, and scored for mezzo- soprano, tenor and ensemble, this sets poems which express the horrors of oppression.

The diversity of Henze's sources - from Heine and Brecht to the Cuban poet Herberto Padilla - is matched by an enormous range of musical styles and techniques. Expertly crafted pastiches of Weill and Eisler appear alongside limpid evocations of Italian folksongs. Henze gives each song an individual soundworld, and there are startling solos for ocarinas and harmonicas, as well as electro-acoustic soundscapes. Soloists Fiona Kimm and Christopher Gillett ensured that each setting was a succinct, self-contained drama, while Oliver Knussen and the Sinfonietta players gave a kaleidoscopic continuity to the whole collection.

Whatever the emotive subject matter of Voices, Henze refuses to preach about doctrine. Even in the fourth number (based on Victor Hernandez Cruz's poem The Electric Cop), Henze's collage of presidential speeches, pop concerts, and shootings manages to be witty and acerbic rather than crassly anti-capitalist. In fact, Voices as a whole is both a compelling musical statement and a moving commentary on the darker sides of humanity. The Sinfonietta's performance allowed the work to speak with eloquence and imagination.

Henze's most recent collection of songs is also his most bewildering. His Richard Wagnersche Klavierlieder, written in 1999, is a set of 17 orchestrations of Wagner's early songs. The BBC Symphony Orchestra and Leonard Slatkin gave the work's UK premiere, with soloists Stella Doufexis and Thomas Mohr. The piece represents a rapprochement between Henze and the German romantic tradition that would have seemed impossible three decades ago.

But there are surprising connections between Wagner's music and Henze's present-day concerns. There is little sense of dissonance between the two composers in these orchestrations. Instead, Henze amplifies the vivid imagery of the originals: whether in the soldiers, rats and fleas in Wagner's settings of Goethe's Faust, or the love and lullabies of his French songs.

In his own work, Henze now seems to crave the immediacy of music such as Wagner's early romanticism. Tenor Mark Padmore and pianist Andrew West performed The Six Songs from the Arabian, which Henze composed for Ian Bostridge in 1998. The beauty of these settings of his own texts is overwhelming and intoxicating, with their luxurious depictions of storm-tossed ships, radiant sunrises and searing laments.

If the Wagnersche Klavierlieder and Voices demonstrate Henze's creativity in all its chameleon-like glory, The Six Songs apparently represent his real compositional voice. But the synthesis of romantic and modernist traditions in The Six Songs is as artificial as anything in the other works. And that is the fascination of Henze's music: there is no single approach which defines his work, and his musical personality remains as elusive as ever.

webTitle: Who said hard work never hurt anybody?

fields.headline: Who said hard work never hurt anybody?
fields.standfirst:
The Japanese courts have ruled you can die from overwork. So how long do you have to stay in the office before you keel over, ask Esther Addley and Laura Barton

Guardian Unlimited Work
Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The Japanese courts have ruled you can die from overwork. So how long do you have to stay in the office before you keel over, ask Esther Addley and Laura Barton.
fields.body:
Talk about a bad day at work. Nobuo Miuro was simply getting on with his job, when he keeled over and died. It had been a busy few weeks for the interiors fitter from Tokyo; he was struggling to get a new restaurant ready for its launch and had been putting in a fair bit of overtime. The day before he collapsed he had worked from 11am until 4.30am the next morning, but had managed to snatch a few hours' sleep before starting again. But when Miuro, 47, tried to pick up his hammer and nails again, he suddenly took ill. He died a week later. Last week a coroner returned a verdict of "karoshi": death by overwork.

In Japan at least, it seems, the old adage that no one ever died from working too hard has been proved comprehensively false. We know that the Japanese often show an unenviable dedication to the office - a typical office worker can leave home at 7am and return after 11pm, spending two hours commuting. But there is something rather more unsettling in the blithe recognition that working too hard - and nothing more - can be enough to kill you.

Karoshi is not a new concept in Japan, though assessments of quite how many salarymen keel over having shot a horrified glance at their diaries vary between a trickle and a torrent. In 1996 the Nagoya high court upheld a ruling that Yoshikazu Abo, a salesman for an electrical company in central Japan, had died from overwork 13 years earlier. In the 17 days before his death, Abo had been sent by his company on 20 sales missions around Japan; the last, to South Korea, was ruled to have killed him.

Hundreds of civil lawsuits are now being filed every year by the relatives of those believed or found by the coroner to have died from karoshi, seeking compensation for the deaths of their loved ones. But Japanese companies have until now managed to escape criminal charges. The expected prosecution of Junichi Ochiai, the president of the interiors fitting firm, over Miura's death will, if successful, be the first case of a company being held criminally responsible for the death of an employee. With some estimates for karoshi deaths running at 10,000 deaths a year, however, it is possible that a ruling could have a significant impact on Japan's notoriously draconian work ethic.

So much for Japanese employers, but what about those of us for whom Miura's 17-hour shift is a daunting, but not entirely unfamiliar, prospect? The British Medical Association estimates that junior doctors frequently work more than 100 hours a week - equivalent to 16 hours 40 minutes a day for six days out of seven. That's alarming enough for anyone about to go into hospital, without now expecting the chap in the white coat to drop dead as soon as he starts to yawn. So just how many hours' sleep do you have to miss before you risk dying?

The good news is that the bleary-eyed have no cause to fear their impending demise, according to professor Jim Horner, director of Loughborough University's sleep research laboratory. "Lack of sleep kills quite a few people at work because they fall asleep at the wheel and crash their lorry," he says, "but apart from that there is no evidence that someone can just spontaneously die from lack of sleep. In humans the effect of sleep loss is pretty uneventful.

"The studies that have been done show that where people have been deprived of sleep they get more and more sleepy, but from the neck down there is no evidence of anything going wrong, even in the immune system. There is no effect on any organ other than the brain."

The important factor, he notes, is whether the lack of sleep is caused or accompanied by a situation of high stress, the more likely reason for sudden, unexplained death being heart failure. However, according to Belinda Linden, a cardiac nurse at the British heart foundation, "there is very little evidence associating stress with coronary heart disease".

The illnesses that doctors can confidently relate to anxiety, such as gastric problems or eczema, are rarely life-threatening. And while the factors we know cause heart attacks - smoking, obesity, inactivity - are often found among those who spend long hours at their desks, they are certainly not unique to them.

Linden has never heard of someone spontaneously dropping dead because of stress. "Much more likely is a cumulative effect, or other lifestyle issues, or an underlying disorder. In that case, working sustained long hours might just tip the balance."

Which is comforting - up to a point. Because we British know ourselves to be the hardest workers in Europe, and while we may pity a Japanese workforce that allows itself to stay in the office until it expires, the facts show that we are not so very far behind them. The average Japanese employee works 2,000 hours per year, which sounds a lot until you realise that it works out at roughly an hour a week longer than we do.

Worry not, says Roger Mead, a stress management consultant who advises individuals on dealing with work-related anxiety and companies on the legal ramifications if they are not looking after their employees' emotional welfare. He acknowledges that the implications of a Japanese-style rash of karoshi cases in this country would be "enormous", but is confident that it is unlikely to happen. Work-related anxiety, he says, "depends on the way we look at things rather than the things themselves. The crucial difference is that in this country we don't have anything like the same working culture that there is in Japan. Obviously you can't work for ever, but if you get into a situation where you feel you can't cope, I believe in this country we do not have the general expectation that you will carry on working regardless."

Nonetheless, says Linden, it is important to carry out a careful assessment of whether your working environment, hours or, perhaps most crucially, attitude, is affecting you health. Recent studies have found that there appears to be an association between a feeling of powerlessness at work and an increased risk of heart disease.

While some of this may be explained by lifestyle factors - unhealthy coping mechanisms and a likelihood that workers isolated from decision-making are likely to be poorer - early results have shown that a feeling of powerlessness or stress in itself may irritate the coronary arteries, encouraging the development of the fatty deposits that lead to heart attacks. It is possible that Japan's less questioning work ethic may in itself explain its high incidence of karoshi.

Similarly, there is some evidence that frequent, temporary instances of high blood pressure, due to occasional stressful episodes, can encourage the blood pressure to rise permanently, which is known to contribute to heart attacks.

If the case of Nobuo Miura prompts a change in Japan's working culture, he will have died for more than the interior of a new Tokyo eatery. And even while the country attempts to sidestep economic crisis, there are signs that the tide may be turning. Some Japanese companies are introducing "no overtime" days, meaning that for one day a week you get to actually go home when you have done your contracted hours. Whether employees take any notice or not, it's a start. And it might even save a life or two.

fields.headline: Flamingos
fields.standfirst:
Bush, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Bush, London

Rating: **
fields.body:
Once upon a time curtains nightly rose on West End plays set in posh drawing rooms. You could expect some mild sexual skirmishing, regular trips to the drinks trolley and a comforting glow of audience recognition. Something similar happens in Jonathan Hall's Flamingos at the Bush; the key difference is that the action takes place, as it never would have done in the 1950s, in a gay B&B in Blackpool.

Hall's five characters are carefully chosen to embody different aspects of gay life. Cliff, the ageing establishment owner, pines nostalgically for the old days of sexual furtiveness and discretion. Among his weekend visitors, estate agent Mark selfishly exploits his quasi-open relationship with gentle geography teacher Phil. Gavin is a flighty Halifax civil servant who relishes his promiscuous freedom. And software expert Richard, apparently escaping for the first time from his long-term lover, shyly ventures into the clubs and acts as a catalyst among the boarding house regulars.

Undeniably, Hall's play is humane and well-observed. He creates one particularly good character in Phil, a self-confessed anorak who fusses over the weather reports, and accurately charts the inequality of supposedly open relationships in which one partner always has a much better time than the other. I just wish, both structurally and thematically, he took a few more risks. Like the Blackpool trams, his plot proceeds along predictable lines in which the outsider, Richard, stirs up unsuspected passions in his fellow guests. And far from showing, as his programme note suggests, the confusing number of lifestyle options available to gay men, Hall's play curiously replicates the dilemmas of the straight world: his characters agonise over the merits of freedom against attachment, the unfairness of marriage, the difficulty of choosing a holiday and rising house prices in the north of England.

Although cast in a traditional mould, the play is well performed under Mike Bradwell's direction. Mike Grady, who has the pouchy features and slight scruffiness of the middle-aged Auden, is outstanding as the dogged geography teacher and there is good, unshowy support from Ian Reddington as his errant partner and from Fred Pearson as the sedate, motherly hotelier. I don't doubt the accuracy of Hall's portrait but, like the small Blackpool hotel in which the action is mostly set, the play gives off an air of cosy familiarity.

Until April 14. Box office: 020-7610 4224.

fields.headline: Tim Richards/ Great Spirit
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room, London
Rating:***
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room, London

Rating:***
fields.body:
Longevity in jazz ensembles is rare. In a music for which spontaneous association of ideas and personalities is axiomatic, the notion of an unchanging band trucking up and down for years delivering its hits is just perverse. But though Spirit Level, the hard-boppish group founded in 1979 by pianist Tim Richards, observed an explicit tradition for 20 years, the personnel did pass through significant changes and the band's respect for a hard-swinging, blues-inflected jazz was always expressed through the work of good improvisers.

Great Spirit, the nine-piece version of Spirit Level, maintains those standards, and is augmented to include such powerful horn players as altoist Peter King, tenorist Ed Jones and trumpeter Dick Pearce. Half of Sunday's show was devoted to Richards' Suite for the Shed, a shrewd mix of the light, dancing energy of a Miles Davis group of the late 1950s, and the earthy heads-down drive of an Art Blakey band.

In the opening stages, Great Spirit ran through a repertoire embracing all those references but also some unusual angles on classic material. Thelonious Monk's rugged, train-rhythm swinger Epistrophy was a fine arrangement that emphasised that composer's characteristically sidelong approach to rhythm but also effectively bookended some powerful soloing .

Though they had opened inauspiciously, King soon accelerated a hard-bop groove with Latin peripherals. A hooting, exclamatory Blakeyesque theme followed, nodding to the Spirit Level repertoire of the 1980s. Drummer Seb Rochford remained in taut charge of a variety of rhythmic approaches, from straightahead time to the bleary, insinuating Crusaders-like electric funk that followed. Dick Pearce delivered a trumpet solo of punchy economy on the latter.

Not exactly a band at the cutting edge of contemporary music, maybe, but a respectful guardian of an indelibly attractive style.

fields.headline: Oriana
fields.standfirst:
Project Arts Centre, Dublin
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Project Arts Centre, Dublin
Rating:****
fields.body:
Will-o'-the-wisp French-style visual theatre has caught flame in Ireland in recent years. Notable companies include Blue Raincoats in Sligo, and now the Belfast company Kabosh, who bring this wordless, illusionist, beautifully tasteful little show.

On a dimly lit stage, four young movement-trained actors in shimmery autumnal pyjamas play jack-in-the-box through Gary McCann's geometric set, made up of slope-roofed De Chirico-style building blocks that double as Narnia wardrobes.

Time passes through a dreamy, evocative series of routines. There are breathtaking images of wonderstruck children, waking with a start or sinking back into sleep, clambering rooftops in their dreams or venturing out into a hostile city. Occasionally one breaks from the huddle to gaze romantically up, before joining the others in a mad sequence involving darkened trapdoors.

Much of it depends on visual tricks, some as old as the hills, but freshly deployed for the most part: torches shone at the audience, which then move high and far apart; the inevitable dance routine with a whirling umbrella; or the conceit of the guy suspended from a tiny helium balloon.

All is preserved in the atmosphere of John Dunne's rich score; some of it electronic minimalism; more of it acoustically arranged with soloists and musicians from the Irish Chamber Choir. There are warming progressions of piano chords, playful cabaret tropes, and a jagged, elegaic violin.

The company is impressive and assured, having arrived at such complex, ambitious physical performance and production values. But this tale - purportedly about a "golden" girl-child at a moment of choice between staying with the pack or going it alone - goes no further than wistfully peeping beneath the canopy of re-remembered childhood. Eventually director Karl Wallace, working with choreographer Rachel O'Riordan, seems to run out of trickster's steam.

The pleasures and mysteries of reading are constantly emphasised in Kabosh's new storybook world, with its very established visual aesthetic. But suggestive as it often is, the actors, despite their strong presence and solo routines, rarely inflate into recognisable characters or events.

Even so, the children in the audience - some sprawled on cast-iron cots, self-consciously inset into the front row - were absorbing it all curiously, even cackling at every odd piece of throwaway clowning.

fields.headline: Screams for the Hear'Say rollercoaster
fields.standfirst:
Astoria, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Not many bands can lay claim to the title "pop sensation" before they've even released a record. And, according to the rules of pop, a band formed by a man with a mullet and the woman responsible for Billie Piper should barely merit a footnote in the annals of music history. But when the five ordinary people brought together by the ITV reality show Popstars walked on stage for their first public live performance, the screams of the 2,000-strong crowd almost drowned out the singing - and sensation status was officially confirmed.

The audience at G.A.Y. - London's biggest gay night - is the music industry's pop barometer. If you can't get the crop-topped teenagers' hips swinging at 1am, then you've little chance of your record charting much higher than number 84. If tonight is anything to go by, anything less than number one this weekend will be a disappointment.

It's not that Hear'Say (as we must now learn to call them) are particularly sensational in their own right - their tracks are bog-standard pop fare and they don't particularly look like pop sensations. Instead, it's the whole deal. One was a cleaner who a few months ago could only dream of onstage adulation; another was a daffodil in a drag act. Now they're on everything from Richard and Judy to Ant and Dec: as exploitation goes, the Popstars phenomenon is about as cynical as it gets.

Happily, the G.A.Y. audience was up for all the exploitation on offer, and as the curtain went up to reveal the band in silhouette, they went wild. Despite a bungled start - the audience was to have been whipped into an even greater frenzy with a video compilation of memorable moments from the TV show - the troupers nervelessly launched straight into Pure and Simple, the first single. There were special screams for each of the performers as they stepped forward for the solo sections. For reasons that will be obvious to the careful reader of any tabloid, you might have expected this audience to go wild for Noel Sullivan (the cute one with the eyebrows). But in fact the loudest adulation was reserved for Kym Marsh, who is well on track to gay icon status - although the big-breasted single parent from Wigan is more Elsie Tanner than Kylie Minogue.

Three other album tracks - including the stonking second single Show Me the Way to Your Love - were performed just as slickly. It may be panto by Christmas for Noel, Danny, Kym, Suzanne and Myleene, but if G.A.Y. is anything to go by, pop superstardom is guaranteed for at least a week or two. And yes, Noel's mum cried.

webTitle: Bloomer makes his mark - but less pay

fields.headline: Bloomer makes his mark - but less pay
fields.trailText: Jonathan Bloomer was virtually unknown when he was elevated to the role of Prudential's chief executive a year ago.
fields.body:
Jonathan Bloomer was virtually unknown when he was elevated to the role of Prudential's chief executive a year ago.

The insurer's former finance director, 46-year-old Mr Bloomer had spent much of his working life at accountancy company Arthur Andersen specialising in insurance - despite his degree in physics - before joining the Pru in 1995.

In the shadow of his high profile predecessor, Sir Peter Davis - who has moved on to supermarket group J Sainsbury - Mr Bloomer tended to be branded as the analytical yet boring brain behind the robust front man. In the last year, however, Mr Bloomer has made his own mark on the insurance group once closely associated with the "man from the Pru".

That image has finally been laid to rest by Mr Bloomer, who is increasingly reducing the group's reliance on the highly competitive domestic market.

With him at the helm, the Pru has expanded in Asia through the acquisition of Orico Life of Japan, but he stepped back from the deal many City experts had expected him to snap at - Equitable Life, the troubled mutual insurance group eventually bought by Halifax.

The father of three, who lives on the more salubrious outskirts of Croydon, has also been paying a crucial role in the running of the country's railways. As a non-executive director of Railtrack, Mr Bloomer is said to have held an important role in shaking up the board of the troubled rail company.

When he is not engaged in the corporate world, Mr Bloomer is fanatical about sailing, rugby and music and owns his own dinghy.

However, while humorous and engaging in private, Mr Bloomer prefers to eschew a high public profile, keeping matters of business at the front of his life when in the public arena.

He will now need to use all his charm and the most persuasive arguments to win the support of the Pru's and American General's shareholders for what is the biggest transatlantic financial services deal in British corporate history.

The price for his "transforming" deal will require him to admit that Bob Delvin - head of American General who will now work for him - will have to be paid five times more than himself.

webTitle: Deal from the Pru alarms City

fields.headline: Deal from the Pru alarms City
fields.standfirst: Four million baby boomers are a sitting target. But is paying £18bn for American General the way to their premiums?
fields.trailText: Prudential's surprise £30bn merger with US rival American General, announced yesterday, could earn the 150-year-old insurer a position on the world stage and particularly America, a market British companies notoriously find difficult to crack.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Prudential's surprise £30bn merger with US rival American General, announced yesterday, could earn the 150-year-old insurer a position on the world stage and particularly America, a market British companies notoriously find difficult to crack.

The historic transaction, which involves Pru's shareholders paying some £18bn for American General, was greeted with concern in the City. Questions were asked about the price being paid, the structure of the transaction and the timing of the deal which will create the sixth largest international insurance group in the world.

Pru's shares fell by 14% to 772p, their lowest levels for two years, as the stock market arbitrageurs who often wade into major deals got to work on the discrepancies in the share prices between the Pru and American National.

Their manoeuvring, coupled with anxiety about the reaction of shareholders in America, combined to help reduce the size of the transaction by some £2bn as it was unveiled.

It was an inauspicious start - exacerbated by the fact that the overall stock market was at its weakest levels for two years - for a deal designed to transform the Pru, once and for all, from a domestic insurance company ranked 26th biggest in the world to a player on the global stage.

In one step thecompany, which already owns Jackson Life in the US, will have a greater foothold in a country where one inhabitant turns 50 every 7.5 seconds. These 4m "baby boomers" are a sitting audience for insurance companies, particularly ones eager to sell annuities for retirement.

The deal is one of the solutions found by Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of the Pru who will run the combined business, to expand the insurance company at a time when pressures are being exerted on profits at home - particularly by the government's introduction of low-cost pensions - and abroad.

Continuing pressure

It means that 65% of Pru's earnings will come from the US, with the rest coming from Asia, where it recently bought Orico Life of Japan, and Britain, where it also owns the M&G fund management group.

Mr Bloomer predicted yesterday that continuing pressure on their profit margins would cause further mergers between major insurance companies. "It's going to be uncomfortable if you're stuck in the middle ground," he said.

He was also at pains to insist he was not building up size for the sake of it. While analysts expressed some anxiety about the way the Pru was expanding in America when the economy was slowing, Mr Bloomer insisted the two companies were a "great fit".

This failed to calm a market that was still digesting last year's £258m bill at the Pru's US business Jackson Life. This came as a result of sweeping changes in the annuity market - an area where its new acquisition is a major player.

Earlier this year, American General itself warned that profits were likely to be lower when the US stock market was falling on concerns the economy had ground to a halt in recent months.

One investor who could see the long-term vision behind the transaction pointed out that by buying American General, the Pru was also able to put in a new management team for its entire US operation.

Bob Salzman, who has run Jackson Life since 1994, will leave the company once the deal is completed allowing Bob Devlin, the chairman and chief executive of American General, who was paid some $5m last year - some five times more than his new boss, Mr Bloomer - to take control of the new operation.

While British companies such as Marks & Spencer have had a patchy track record with attempts to expand in the US, the consensus yesterday appeared to be that Pru has the credentials for achieving success - in the long-term at least.

"Pru won't crash and burn in the US. It's got an existing business there and American General is a good company," said one leading insurance analyst. The Pru's expansion follows attempts by other European insurers to expand in the US, most recently Dutch insurer Aegon buying the marketing arm of JC Penney, a deal dwarfed by the Pru's move yesterday.

The deal is structured in such a way that the Pru's shareholders will end up owning 50.5% of the combined group - which will retain the Prudential name - and American General's the rest.

Pru's shareholders will have to pay 3.6 of their shares for each American General share, which prompted some of the complaints from its shareholders yesterday that the price tag was too high.

"The acquisition is good in the long-term but there appears to be a view that they've overpaid," said Tim Rees, director of investment strategy at fund management group Clerical Medical. This suggests that the size and transatlantic nature of the transaction is likely to result in a bumpy ride for Pru shareholders.

"For the next six months they've left their share price in the hands of arbitrageurs," an insurance analyst said.

This is because until the deal is completed, investors in London - where the main stock market listing is being retained - will be trying to gauge whether the US investors holding shares in American General decide to retain their shares in the Pru.

One factor in this decision is the restrictions on the types of shares investors can hold in the US. Pru's shares are denominated in sterling rather than dollars and while the insurer has a listing in New York - a move which first flagged its intention to expand in the US - City analysts say this does not solve all the technical difficulties which may be encountered by US investors.

Shares in American General, which is the second-largest publicly traded life insurer in the US, rose by more than 4% to more than $40 after the takeover was announced yesterday. Critics said this confirmed worries that the Pru was paying too much.

By merging with American General, Pru aims to make annual cost savings - usually market-speak for job cuts - of £85m a year. Most of this will be the result of combining American General with Jackson Life in the US. The head office will be in New York, eradicating the need for Jackson's headquarters in Michigan and American General's in Texas, although Mr Devlin refused to be specific about the impact on the workforce yesterday.

Mr Devlin was more anxious to point out the opportunities for growth. The American retirement market enjoyed strong growth during the last five years of the millennium when a combination of an ageing baby boomer population and a soaring stock market encouraged more people to save. Variable annuities rose 23% a year between 1995 and 2000 for the industry as a whole. American General beat the industry average with an average growth of 35%.

Along with Mr Bloomer, Mr Devlin will spend the next three weeks attempting to charm his shareholders into accepting the deal which could take at least six months to complete.

In that time, if there is a temptation to speculate about spoiling counter-bids, perhaps from the likes of Allianz of Germany or Axa of France, it may be quashed by some of the small print in the complicated deal. Following the standard procedures with US deals, American General will pay £408m to the Pru if the deal fails to happen while Pru faces a £236m bill if its shareholders get cold feet.
